PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1965 Code, as supplemented through November 25, 2002, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the village board. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1965 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of James S. Vaught, Supervising Editor, and Connie Timmons, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Russ Wajda, Village Administrator, Mr. John T. Flood, Jr., Assistant Village Administrator, Mr. Patrick Deady, Village Attorney, Mr. Patrick F. O'Sullivan, Village Clerk, and Ms. Sue Voelker, deputy clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the village's affairs.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE NO. 05-09 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the Village of Hillside, Illinois; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be It Ordained by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Hillside, Cook County, Illinois: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, Village of Hillside, Illinois," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 102, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before 6-2-2003, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. Notwithstanding section 2 hereof, the following sections of the "The Municipal Code of Hillside of 1965", as supplemented through November 25, 2002 shall remain in full force and are hereby saved from repeal, pending their inclusion in the revised "Code of Ordinances, Village of Hillside, Illinois": Sec. 18.751 subsections (84) through (92), each inclusive; and Sec. 20.307; but repeal Sec. 12.101(a) through 12.211(a) appearing at the end of Section 90-13. Adoption of Illinois Vehicle Code provisions; and amend Sec. 15-114, 625 ILCS 5/15-114 (Unlawful pushing of disabled vehicle). 
    Section 4. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 5. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $750.00. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the President and Board of Trustees may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 6. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the President and Board of Trustees to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 7. Ordinances adopted after 6-2-2003 that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 8. This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication, in pamphlet form, as provided by law. 
Passed: This 27th day of June, 2005. 
Approved: This 27th day of June, 2005. 
/s/ Joseph T. Tamburino 
      Village President   Attest: 
/s/ Patrick F. O'Sullivan 
      Village Clerk

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, Village of Hillside, Illinois," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1965, § 26.101) 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
(a)  In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the village board. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
    Board or village board. The words "board" or "village board" shall mean the board of trustees of the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Code. The term "Code" or "this Code" shall mean the Code of Ordinances, Village of Hillside, Illinois, including any additions or amendments to such Code by ordinances adopted subsequent to the last ordinance included in the Code prior to its adoption. Reference to a section of this Code shall be understood also to refer to and include the penalty section relating thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided. In case of amendment of any section of this Code containing the provisions for which a penalty is provided in another section, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the amended section or the amending section, whether re-enacted in the amendatory ordinance or not, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day is Saturday or Sunday or is a holiday as defined or fixed in any statute now or hereafter in force in this state, and then it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or a Saturday or Sunday, then such succeeding day shall also be excluded. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.11. 
    Corporate limits or village limits. The term "corporate limits" or "village limits" shall mean the legal boundaries of the Village of Hillside. 
    County or the county. The term "county" or "the county" shall mean Cook County in the State of Illinois. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    Fire. The word "fire" shall include, but is not limited to, the consumption of mass under conditions of high heat and low oxygen. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender may be applied to females. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.04. 
    ILCS. The letters "ILCS" shall mean the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as now or hereafter amended. 
    In the village or within the village. The words "in the village" or "within the village" shall mean and include all territory over which the village now has or shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other regulatory powers. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or persons. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.09. 
    Misdemeanor. The word "misdemeanor" shall mean any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/2-11. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.10. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Nuisance. The word "nuisance" shall mean any condition which: 
(1)  Endangers the health and welfare of another person within the village; or 
(2)  Creates a detrimental effect on the property of another person in the village; or 
(3)  Unreasonably interferes with the enjoyment of life, health, safety, peace, comfort or property of another person in the village. 
    Nuisance, dangerous condition or fire hazard (or "dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance"). The phrase "dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance" means any premises in the village which is so occupied, so operated or so situated as to endanger persons or property, or cause an odor nuisance, in the village, by reason of any of the following conditions: 
(1)  Faulty construction, age, or lack of proper repair; 
(2)  The presence of combustible or explosive material or inflammable conditions; 
(3)  The presence of any other condition or any other cause that has made the building or other structure especially liable to fire; 
(4)  The presence of any other condition or any other cause that has made the building or other structure especially liable to cause injury or damage to persons or property in the village by collapsing or otherwise; or 
(5)  The premises, or any building or other structure thereon, are on fire, including a subsurface fire. 
    Nuisance, odor (or "odor nuisance"). The phrase "odor nuisance" means a type of nuisance specifically prohibited by section 42-15 of the Code. 
    Nuisance, solid waste (or "solid waste nuisance"). The phrase "solid waste nuisance" means a type of nuisance specifically prohibited by section 42-16 of the Code. 
    Number. Words importing the singular number may extend and be applied to several persons or things and words importing the plural may include the singular. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.03. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be deemed to include an affirmation, and the word "sworn" shall be construed to include the word "affirmed." 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.12. 
    Occupant or tenant. The word "occupant" or "tenant," applied to a building or land, shall mean any person who holds a written or an oral lease of or who actually occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Offense. The word "offense" shall mean any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this Code. 
    Officers, departments, etc. Officers, departments, boards, commissions, committees and employees referred to in this Code shall mean officers, departments, boards, commissions, committees and employees of the village, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    Operator. The word "operator" means the person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession, or who exercises control over premises upon which an operation, business or profession is being conducted, including by way of example, but not limitation, a tenant, licensee or occupant of premises. 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," when applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant by the entirety, tenant in partnership, or joint tenant of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person," as well as all words referring to or importing persons, may extend and be applied to bodies politic and corporate as well as individuals. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.05. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall mean and include every species of property, except real property as defined by this section. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Premises. In addition to its common and ordinary meaning, the word "premises" includes real property and a building or structure. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments and shall embrace all chattels real. 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The term "state" or "the state" shall mean the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
    Structure. The word "structure" shall have the meaning given that term in PM-202.0 of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, 1996 edition [1], as previously adopted by the Village of Hillside, and shall include by way of example and not limitation an excavation, quarry, landfill or a landfill in a quarry. 
    Tenant. The word "tenant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words in the present tense include the future. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.02. 
    Village. The word "village" shall mean the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Village president or president. The words "village president" or "president" shall mean the president of the village. The president of the village may also be referred to as "mayor" or "president" of the village. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide president may also be referred to as "mayor," 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2.1. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" may include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such person, or if he is unable to write, by his proper mark. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year unless otherwise expressed. 
(b)  All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the village board may be fully carried out. 
(c)  In the interpretation and application of any provisions of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(Code 1965, §§ 26.102, 26.105(a), 26.106, 26.201, 26.202; Ord. No. 08-09, § I, 3-24-2008)

Editor's note- Section 202 of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code defgines a "Structure as [t]hat which is built or constructed..." 

Sec. 1-3. - Acceptance of Code in courts and tribunals of state. 
    This Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect, except the excluded ordinances referred to in section 1-16. 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections and other headings. 
    The catchlines of the several sections and subsections of this Code, and the headings of chapters, articles, divisions and subdivisions, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section, subsection, chapter, article, division or subdivision, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, subsections, chapters, articles, divisions or subdivisions, nor as any part of the section, subsection, chapter, article, division or subdivision, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, subsections, chapters, articles, divisions or subdivisions, including the catchlines or other headings, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. In the case of repealed chapters, sections or subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or as omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code of ordinances by the village board. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section _______ of the Code of Ordinances, Village of Hillside, Illinois, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(c)  If a new section not then existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Code of Ordinances, Village of Hillside, Illinois is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered _______, which section (or article or chapter) reads as follows:...." The provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions of this Code desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(e)  Two official copies of this Code shall be maintained so that all amendments thereto and all general ordinances thereafter passed may be posted and inserted in their proper places within the Code. One of the copies shall be maintained by the village clerk and the other by the village attorney. In case of any doubt as to whether a new ordinance is a general ordinance, the village clerk shall be guided by the advice of the village attorney. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided. 
Sec. 1-7. - Jurisdiction. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, this Code applies to acts performed within the corporate limits of the village. Provisions of this Code also apply to acts performed outside the corporate limits and up to the limits prescribed by law where the law confers power on the village to regulate such particular acts outside the corporate limits. 
Sec. 1-8. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this Code be declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining words, phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the village board without the incorporation in this Code of any such invalid or unconstitutional word, phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
Sec. 1-9. - Unauthorized alteration or tampering with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portions of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented thereby. 
Sec. 1-10. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations; judicial enforcement of Code upon conviction. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the village any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be a misdemeanor and punished by a fine not exceeding $750.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Whenever in this Code a minimum but not maximum fine or penalty is imposed, the court may in its discretion fine the offender any sum exceeding the minimum fine or penalty but not exceeding $750.00. 
(Code 1965, § 26.104) 
State Law reference- Authority to provide that ordinance violations constitute misdemeanors and to provide for penalties, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 1-2-1.1. 
Sec. 1-11. - Responsibility for acts. 
    Every person concerned in the commission of an act prohibited by this Code, whether he directly commits the act, or prosecutes, counsels, aids or abets in its commission, may be prosecuted and on conviction is punishable as if he had directly committed such act. 
Sec. 1-12. - Officers and employees not liable to fine for failure to perform duties. 
    No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty provided in this Code for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the village board to impose such a fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. 
(Code 1965, § 26.105(b)) 
Sec. 1-13. - Acts punishable under different sections. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense, provided that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. 
Sec. 1-14. - References and notes. 
    State law references, editor's notes and history notes are by way of explanation only and shall not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
Sec. 1-15. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by village personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the village board. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive parts of permanent and general ordinances passed by the village board during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate units, such as chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections. 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other units of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other units to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other unit numbers. 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code). 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections or the alphabetical arrangement of new chapters inserted into the Code. In no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-16. - Ordinances not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  The repeal provided for in the ordinance adopting this Code shall not affect any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated by any provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect. 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the village, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the village or any evidence of the village's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the village. 
(3)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance of the village. 
(4)  Any ordinance establishing, dedicating, accepting the dedication of, naming, grading, improving, altering, locating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street, alley, sidewalk, public way, public park or public grounds in the village. 
(5)  Any appropriation ordinance. 
(6)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes or special assessments, or authorizing tax fund transfers, not inconsistent with this Code. 
(7)  Any ordinance rezoning specific property or any amendment thereto. 
(8)  Any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the village. 
(9)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the village. 
(11)  Any ordinance establishing the boundaries of any wards in the village, or extending or contracting the boundaries of the village. 
(12)  Any ordinance respecting the conveyance or acceptance of real property or easements in real property. 
(13)  Any ordinance prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any village officers or employees, not inconsistent herewith. 
(14)  Any ordinance adopted by reference by any provision of this Code or any amendments to such ordinances. 
(15)  Any ordinance establishing fire lanes on private property. 
(16)  Any temporary or special ordinance not in conflict with the provisions of this Code. 
(17)  Any ordinance establishing the prevailing wage rates for public works of the village. 
(b)  The provisions of this Code, so far as they are the same in substance as those of heretofore existing ordinances, are continuations of such ordinances and not new enactments. 
(Code 1965, §§ 26.401-26.403) 
Sec. 1-17. - Records of amendments. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the village clerk to keep at least one copy of this Code which he shall mark in the following manner: Whenever any ordinance which amends or makes an addition to the Code is passed and approved he shall note on the margin of the section or sections amended that such amendment has been made, with a reference in the amendment, hereinafter described where the amendment may be found, and in the case of an addition, he shall mark in the appropriate place a notation that such addition has been made, with a similar reference to the aforementioned amendment book. 
(b)  The village clerk shall also keep a separate book containing every amendment or addition passed to this Code, with a reference on each copy of such amendment or addition as to the place in the record of ordinances where the original ordinance may be found. 
(c)  The above-mentioned records shall be kept in addition to the record of ordinances which the clerk is required to keep by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 26.203) 
Sec. 1-18. - Publication of Code. 
    This Code shall be printed and published in book form. 
(Code 1965, § 26.301) 
Sec. 1-19. - Distribution of copies of Code. 
    All of the printed copies of this Code belonging to the village shall be deposited with the clerk. He shall deliver one copy thereof to the president and each member of the board of trustees, and copies to such other persons as the president and board of trustees may direct. 
(Code 1965, § 26.302) 
Sec. 1-20. - Presentation of copies of Code. 
    The president and board of trustees shall have the power to extend or reciprocate courtesies of other municipalities by presenting them with a copy of this Code, bound at the expense of the village, as to them seem suitable, and they shall also have the power to present two copies of this Code to the Illinois Municipal League. 
(Code 1965, § 26.303) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Corporate seal. 
    The corporate seal of the village shall be as follows: a circular disc, with the words, "Village of Hillside, Cook County, Ill." on the perimeter and the words "Village Seal" enclosed therein. 
(Code 1965, § 8.701) 
Sec. 2-2. - Datum. 
    The datum for the establishment of grades in the village is hereby established as a horizontal plane, 64.44 feet below the square cut chiseled in the north end of the top step at the front entrance to the village hall building, 30 North Wolf Road, Hillside, Cook County, Illinois. The village datum shall be the base line from which all grades and elevations for all public works or public improvements of the village shall refer or be deduced. 
(Code 1965, § 8.702) 
Sec. 2-3. - Elections. 
    Elections for municipal offices shall be held as provided by statute, and at the time prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 8.705) 
Sec. 2-4. - Surety bonds. 
(a)  Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is required, as a prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of any special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in this state as a surety company in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance. 
(b)  Whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the village against loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or sureties or for any other reason, the village may order a new surety or sureties to be secured for such bond. If such new surety or sureties are not procured within ten days from the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond, or his assignee, the board shall declare the bond to be void, and there upon such principal or assignee, shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as condition of which the bond was required. 
(Code 1965, § 8.706) 
Secs. 2-5-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-31. - Election; term and commencement of office. 
    Each member of the board of trustees shall be elected for a term of four years, which term shall commence with his inauguration as the last order of business at the last regular meeting of the president and board of trustees in the month of April following his election to office. The board on which each of its six members serve shall be the legislative department of the village government, and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 2.101) 
State Law reference- Election of officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15.5; terms, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-5. 
Sec. 2-32. - Oath. 
    The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 2.102) 
State Law reference- Oath, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25. 
Sec. 2-33. - Compensation. 
(a)  Each trustee shall receive annual compensation of $2,400.00, payable in equal monthly installments on the last payday of each month during their respective terms of office. 
(b)  No other compensation shall be allowed any trustee. 
(Code 1965, § 2.102.1) 
Sec. 2-34. - Meetings. 
(a)  The regular meetings of the president and board of trustees shall be held on the fourth Monday of each calendar month at 8:00 p.m. or as soon thereafter on those days as the meetings shall be convened. Regular board-of-the-whole meetings of the president and board of trustees shall be held on the second Monday of each calendar month at 8:00 p.m. or as soon thereafter on those days as the meetings shall be convened. No definitive action on any measure requiring board action shall be taken at the board-of-the-whole meetings. 
(b)  The meeting place of the said board shall be at the village hall, unless otherwise ordered by the board. 
(c)  Special meetings may be called by the village president or any three trustees upon at least 48 hours' advance notice to the president and all trustees; provided, however, that actual attendance at a special meeting by the president or any trustee shall be deemed a waiver by the person of such notice. 
(Code 1965, § 2.103) 
State Law reference- Special meeting notices, 5 ILCS 120/2.02(a). 
Sec. 2-35. - Presiding officer. 
    The village president shall be the presiding officer of all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees and at all times when the board meets as a committee of the whole. 
(Code 1965, § 2.104) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30. 
Sec. 2-36. - Deciding vote. 
    The village president shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution, or motion except: 
(1)  Where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie. 
(2)  Where one-half of the trustees have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution, or motion even though there is no tie vote. In both instances specified, the village president shall vote. 
(3)  Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is required by this Code or an ordinance to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. 
Nothing in this section shall deprive a president pro-tem from voting in his capacity as trustee, but he shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as president pro-tem. 
(Code 1965, § 2.105) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-30. 
Sec. 2-37. - Approval of ordinances, resolutions and motions by president; veto; reconsideration and passing over veto. 
(a)  All resolutions and motions (1) which create any liability against the village, or (2) which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, or (3) to sell any village property, and all ordinances passed by the village board shall be deposited with the village clerk. If the village president approves of them, he shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves, he shall return to the village board, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the village board occurring not less than five days after their passage. The village president may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any ordinance, resolution, or motion making an appropriation, and if so, the remainder shall be effective. However, the village president may disapprove entirely of an ordinance, resolution, or motion making an appropriation. If the village president fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution with his written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. 
(b)  Every resolution and motion specified in subsection (a) of this section, and every ordinance, which is returned to the board of trustees by the village president shall be reconsidered by the board of trustees. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of all the trustees elected to the village board shall agree to pass an ordinance, resolution or motion, notwithstanding the president's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the president's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded in the journal. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.106, 2.107) 
Secs. 2-38-2-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRESIDENT 

Sec. 2-61. - Election; term and commencement of office. 
    The village president shall be elected for a term of four years, which term shall commence with his inauguration as the last order of business at the last regular meeting of the president and board of trustees in the month of April following his election to that office. He shall be the president of the board of trustees as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 1.001) 
Sec. 2-62. - Duties. 
    He shall be the chief executive officer of the village, and he shall perform all duties that may be required of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have supervision over all executive officers of the village, and over all of the employees of the village. He shall have the power and the authority to inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or employee at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1965, § 1.002) 
Sec. 2-63. - Designation of duties. 
    Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of any appointed officer of the village, this shall be settled by the president; and he shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform that duty. 
(Code 1965, § 1.003) 
Sec. 2-64. - Bond, oath and salary. 
(a)  Before entering upon the duties of his office, the president shall give a bond, with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, in the sum of $3,000.00, and he shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute. For the purpose of this section, IRMA (Intergovernmental Risk Management Agency), unless the board of trustees shall direct otherwise, will be deemed to be an acceptable surety. 
(b)  The president shall receive annual compensation of $5,000.00, payable in equal monthly installments on the last payday of each month during his term of office. 
(Code 1965, § 1.004) 
Sec. 2-65. - President pro-tem. 
    During the temporary absence or disability of the village president, the board of trustees shall elect one of its members to act as president pro-tem, who during the absence or disability of the president shall perform the duties pertaining to the office. 
(Code 1965, § 1.005) 
Sec. 2-66. - Title. 
(a)  The term "village president" as used in any ordinance, resolution, motion or other action of the corporate authorities shall be construed as meaning the mayor; and the term "mayor" wherever used shall be construed to mean the village president. 
(b)  The title "mayor" as used in the minutes of the meetings of the corporate authorities or any other official document shall be construed as meaning "village president." 
(Code 1965, § 1.006) 
Secs. 2-67-2-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RULES OF ORDER 

Sec. 2-91. - Order of business. 
    The order of business of the board of trustees of the village shall be as follows: 
(1)  Roll call; 
(2)  Town hall meeting; 
(3)  Approval or correction of minutes of preceding regular meeting; 
(4)  Communications; 
(5)  Reports of committees; 
(6)  Report of officers; 
(7)  Old business; 
(8)  New business; 
(9)  President's report; 
(10)  Announcements; 
(11)  Adjournment. 
(Code 1965, § 2.201) 
Sec. 2-92. - Rescinded actions. 
    No vote or action of the board of trustees shall be rescinded at any special meeting of the board of trustees unless there be present at such special meeting as many members of the board of trustees as were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 2.202) 
Sec. 2-93. - Resolutions. 
    Any resolutions submitted to the board of trustees shall be reduced to writing before being voted on, upon request of any two members of the board. 
(Code 1965, § 2.203) 
Sec. 2-94. - Town hall meeting. 
    At each regular meeting of the board of trustees, immediately following roll call, the president, or in his absence the chairperson of the meeting, shall announce to those assembled that a "town hall meeting" is being convened to give each of them an opportunity to address the board on any matter appearing on the meeting agenda or on any other matter which the president or chairperson may deem to be of public interest. Any person desiring to address the board shall stand to be recognized and shall give his name and home address and the subject matter of the remarks he intends to present. The president or chairperson shall then determine whether the matter appears on the meeting agenda or whether, if not on the agenda, the matter is of public interest. The person so recognized shall then proceed to address the board subject to any time limitation the president or chairperson may impose. When all persons desiring to address the board have been heard, the president or chairperson shall entertain a motion to close the town hall portion of the meeting and to proceed to the next order of business. 
(Code 1965, § 2.204) 
Sec. 2-95. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at any time by the consent of a majority of the members present at any meeting. 
(Code 1965, § 2.205) 
Sec. 2-96. - Use of Robert's Rules of Order. 
    Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the deliberations of the board of trustees except when in conflict with any of the foregoing rules. 
(Code 1965, § 2.206) 
Sec. 2-97. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the trustees, or three trustees and the village president shall constitute a quorum to do business. 
(Code 1965, § 2.207) 
Sec. 2-98. - Committees. 
(a)  The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees: 
(1)  Finance, licensing and ordinance review committee; 
(2)  Public works, inspection services, economic development, environmental committee; 
(3)  Public safety committee; 
(4)  Planning, zoning and legislative committee; 
(5)  Community affairs committee; 
(6)  Human relations, intergovernmental relations committee. 
(b)  Special committees shall be created from time to time as directed by the board of trustees. 
(c)  All standing and special committees shall consist of three members each, including the chairperson, who shall be the trustee first named for the committee, unless the board shall direct otherwise. All committee members shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees by simple majority vote of its members then holding office. 
(Code 1965, § 2.208) 
Secs. 2-99-2-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-121. - Effect of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply alike to all officers and employees of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office or position or the time of the appointment of the officer or employee. 
(Code 1965, § 8.101) 
Sec. 2-122. - Appointments. 
    All officers other than elective officers and police officers and firefighters under the jurisdiction of the fire and police commissioners shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees as is provided by statute; provided that all employees shall, in the absence of any provisions to the contrary be appointed or selected by the village president. All original appointments of officers and employees shall be for a probationary period of one year from date of appointment, unless as to a particular appointee the probationary period or any portion thereof shall be waived by the president and board of trustees, or as to a police officer or firefighter, by the board of fire and police commissioners. If a leave of absence is granted during a probationary period, the period shall be extended by the number of days equal to the period of the leave of absence. Continuance in service shall be dependent upon the conduct of the appointee and his fitness for the performance of the duties to which he is assigned. Unless the appointee shall have been summarily dismissed in the interim, at the end of the probation, he shall either be dismissed or, in the case of the probationary police officer or firefighter, shall be given a permanent appointment subject to discharge by the board of fire and police commissioners, or in case of an employee or officer, other than a police officer or firefighter, shall be appointed for a fixed period of time, or in the absence of such appointment, shall be deemed to have been appointed to serve "at will," subject to dismissal at any time with or without cause. 
(Code 1965, § 8.102) 
State Law reference- Authority of president and board to appoint officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5. 
Sec. 2-123. - Term of office; vacancies. 
    Every appointive officer of the village shall hold office until May 1 following his appointment or until his successor is appointed and qualified, unless it is otherwise provided by ordinance. In case of a vacancy in any such place, it shall be filled in the same manner in which appointments or selections are made, in the absence of provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1965, § 8.103) 
Sec. 2-124. - Disposition of monies received. 
    Every officer of the village shall turn over all money received by him in his official capacity, to the treasurer, upon receipt, with a statement showing the source from which the same was received. 
(Code 1965, § 8.104) 
Sec. 2-125. - Oath. 
    Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon his duties, take the oath prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 8.105) 
State Law reference- Oath of office, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25. 
Sec. 2-126. - Salaries. 
    All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salary as may from time to time be provided by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1965, § 8.106) 
Sec. 2-127. - Conflict of interest. 
    In the absence of the express prior approval by the president and board of trustees, no appointed, nongoverning official or employee of the village shall: 
(1)  Engage in any conduct which serves the personal interest of such official or employee to the prejudice of the public interest of the village; 
(2)  Take any action which tends reasonably to arouse the suspicion that his social or business relations or friendships influence his public performance; 
(3)  Give grounds for reasonable suspicion that he is using the power or prestige of his office to persuade or influence others to patronize or contribute to the success of any business; 
(4)  Accept compensation of any kind, whether in the form of loans, gifts, gratuities or otherwise, for services performed or withheld in the conduct of his public performance; or 
(5)  Enter into any relationship, contractual or otherwise, with any individuals or organizations, which will interfere, or reasonably appear to interfere, with the proper performance of his public duties, or which would give rise to divided loyalties, or the appearance thereof, toward individuals or organizations on the one hand and the public on the other. 
(Code 1965, § 8.106.1) 
Sec. 2-128. - Assignment of duties. 
    The village president shall have the power to assign to any appointive officer any duty which is not assigned by ordinance to some other specific officer, and shall determine disputes or questions relating to the respective powers or duties of officers. 
(Code 1965, § 8.107) 
Sec. 2-129. - Inspection of records. 
    All records kept by any officer of the village shall be open to inspection by the president, or any member of the board of trustees at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 8.108) 
Sec. 2-130. - Bond. 
    Every officer or employee shall, if required by the president and board of trustees, upon entering upon the duties of his office, give a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be determined by the said president and board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office or position. 
(Code 1965, § 8.109) 
Sec. 2-131. - Arrests. 
    The village president and members of the board of trustees, after receiving a certificate attesting to the successful completion of a training course administered by the state law enforcement training standards board, as well as every member of the police department, are hereby declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of the peace by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 8.110) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-25. 
Sec. 2-132. - Delivery of records to successor upon termination of office. 
    Every officer and employee of the village, upon the expiration of his term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books and records which may be the property of the village, and if no successor has been appointed within one week after the termination of office such property shall be delivered to the village clerk or village treasurer. 
(Code 1965, § 8.111) 
Sec. 2-133. - Impersonation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate without lawful authority any village officer or employee. Any person violating this section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1965, § 8.112) 
Sec. 2-134. - Interference with officers. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the village while engaged in the duties of his office or employment. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1965, § 8.113) 
Sec. 2-135. - Inspections by officers and employees. 
(a)  Any officer or employee of the village who is authorized to enforce ordinances may make such inspections as may be necessary to investigate a nuisance or enforce such ordinances; provided however, that he may not make any such inspection in any case in which he has an interest, pecuniary or otherwise, in the outcome of the inspection. 
(b)  Whenever such officer or employee shall have reason to believe that conditions exist on or in any premises in the village causing any nuisance, he shall ask permission of the occupant of such premises, or the owner, operator or custodian thereof, if the premises, to inspect the same. If permission is so granted, he shall promptly make the inspection. If permission is denied, he shall promptly refer the matter to the village attorney for such action as may be deemed appropriate. 
(c)  Any officer or employee of the village authorized to make inspections and conduct investigations under subsections (a) and (b) of section 2-135 may request the current or former owner or operator of the premises which is the subject of the investigation or inspection to furnish, on reasonable notice, information or documents relating to existence of a nuisance condition, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The identification, nature, and quantity of materials which have been or are generated, treated, stored, or disposed of at the premises; and 
(2)  Conditions on the premises or the nature or extent of a release or threatened release of a regulated substance at or from the premises. 
(d)  Failure to furnish information or documents requested pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2-135 shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 8.114; Ord. No. 08-09, § I, 3-24-2008) 
Sec. 2-136. - Participation in Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund. 
(a)  The village does hereby elect to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, effective January 1, 1971. 
(b)  The village clerk is hereby directed to promptly file a certified copy of this section with the board of trustees of the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund. 
(Code 1965, § 8.115) 
Sec. 2-137. - Employee vacations. 
(a)  Calculation of vacation time; use and accrual. 
(1)  All full-time village employees will be entitled to a paid vacation. Vacation earned in any given year will be calculated and allocated on January 1 of the following year and then taken during that following calendar year between January 1 and December 31. No unused vacation time for any employee may be accrued from one year to the next but will be deemed forfeited as of December 31. 
(2)  Vacation time allocated on January 1 shall be calculated according to the following schedule: 
YEARS OF SERVICE TO BE COMPLETED IN THE CALENDAR YEAR 
BEGINNING JANUARY 1 
Vacation in Working Days Years of Service Firefighters All Other 
Employees 1 5 10 2 5 11 3 5 12 4 8 13 5 8 14 6 8 15 7 8 16 8 9 17 9 9 18 10 9 19 11 or more but less than 20 10 20 20 or more (no maximum) 12 25  
(3)  New employees, during their first calendar year of employment, shall be entitled to take vacation days according to the following schedule, with the approval of their department head: 
Vacation in Working Days Hired on or after But before Firefighters All Other Employees January 1 April 1 2 5 April 1 July 1 1 3 July 1 October 1 0 1  
(b)  Payment to retiring employee for unused time. Upon retirement, there shall be paid to the retiring employee, in addition to any other sums due him, an amount to be computed at the retiring employee's then per diem base salary rate for each unused vacation day and for each earned but unallocated vacation day which shall be determined by multiplying a fraction, where the number of full months the retiring employee is employed in his final calendar year is the numerator and where "12" is the denominator, by the number of annual vacation days to which the retiring employee would be entitled, based on his years of service at retirement and the first schedule contained in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Scheduling generally. The scheduling of vacations within each department will be done by the person in charge of the department after full consideration of the seniority status of each employee and their individual choices of vacation period; provided, however, that no more than two calendar weeks of vacation shall be scheduled between April 1 and October 1 for any one employee until two calendar weeks of vacation shall have been scheduled for all other employees of the particular department, whereupon, based on seniority status and individual choices, the remaining vacation time of each employee will be scheduled by the person in charge of the department. 
(d)  Police department scheduling. The scheduling of vacations for all employees of the police department will be exempt from the scheduling requirements set forth in subsection (c) of this section. In lieu thereof, the following requirements will be applicable to police department employees: 
(1)  Vacation periods for employees assigned to the detective division will be scheduled by joint determination of the chief of police and the person in charge of the detective division, who may allow such employees split-vacation periods. 
(2)  The vacation periods for all employees of the police department other than employees assigned to the detective division will be scheduled by the chief of police or by a lieutenant authorized by the chief of police to determine vacation schedules. Such scheduling will be done after full consideration of each such employee's seniority status, rank and individual choice of vacation period; provided, however, that each vacation period shall commence and terminate wholly within a given 28-day scheduled work period, and further, that unless otherwise approved by the chief of police, any such employee's first 15 eligible vacation days must be scheduled in a single vacation period, and any remaining eligible vacation days, not included in the initial vacation period, must be scheduled in one additional period and then only after all initial vacation periods have been scheduled. 
(3)  The chief of police may establish any other regulations governing the scheduling of vacation periods for employees of the police department not in conflict with this section. 
(Code 1965, § 8.116) 
Sec. 2-138. - Employee absences. 
(a)  Sick leave. 
(1)  Sick leave, with full pay, will be granted to all permanent full-time employees at the rate of one day for each full month of service, except for the rate of one day for each two full months of service applicable to firefighters assigned to 24-hour shifts. Sick leave may be accumulated up to a maximum of 60 days, except for a maximum of 30 days applicable to firefighters assigned to 24-hour shifts. Sick leave will continue to accrue during any period in which the employee is on approved sick leave status. Sick leave shall not be considered as a privilege which an employee may use at his discretion, but shall be allowed, subject to all other provisions of this section, only in case of actual sickness of an employee which prevents his performance of duties, or because of illness in his immediate family as hereinafter provided, or to take physical examinations or other sickness prevention measures prescribed by a practicing physician. Sick leave which would otherwise accrue during each calendar year, commencing on January 1 following the first anniversary of employment, may be drawn in advance during said calendar year; provided, however, that in the event the employment is terminated during said calendar year, the gross salary for any sick leave days so drawn in advance which would otherwise have accrued following termination shall be deducted from said employee's final compensation. In addition to the foregoing any permanent full-time employee, who shall have accumulated the maximum number of sick leave days, shall in lieu of additional sick leave days be entitled to accumulate bonus leave days at the same rate of accrual as provided hereinabove for sick leave, to a maximum of 12 such bonus leave days in any given calendar year except as to firefighters who are assigned to 24-hour shifts and who shall be entitled to a maximum accrual of six such bonus leave days in any given calendar year. If an employee has accumulated bonus leave days in a calendar year and subsequently must be out on sick leave during that same year, he must first use accumulated bonus leave days as sick days and not until such bonus leave days are exhausted shall the employee begin to use regular sick days. If, on December 31, an employee has accumulated accrued bonus leave days, then those days may be used as days off, not necessarily related to illness, during the following calendar year, subject to scheduling at the request of the employee and with the discretionary approval of the person in charge of the particular employee's department, not later than February 15 of such following year. Any such bonus leave days not so scheduled to be used during such following year may not be thereafter carried forward but instead the employee shall be paid, not later than March 15 of such following year, an amount equal to the employees then per diem base salary rate for each such unscheduled bonus leave day. Upon retirement, the employee will receive compensation at 100 percent for all his accumulated sick days, if he has accrued 54 or more sick days. If he has accrued less than 54 sick days, he will receive compensation for the accrued sick days equal to 50 percent of the full amount of each sick day. Firefighter/paramedics who are assigned to 24-hour shifts will receive compensation at 100 percent for all his accumulated sick days, if he has accrued 27 or more sick days. If he has accrued less then 27 sick days, he will receive compensation for the accrued sick days equal to 50 percent of the full amount of each sick day. 
(2)  To receive compensation while absent on sick leave, the employee shall notify his department head, and/or supervisor in charge, at least one-half hour prior to the time set for his regular scheduled working hours. An employee absent for at least three full consecutive working days shall present to his department head, prior to his return to duty, a medical certificate from his attending physician and, if required by the village board, from a practicing physician or clinic designated by and at the expense of the village board. The employee may be removed from the payroll if the absence for sickness continues beyond the number of sick leave days accumulated by such employee. In the case of very serious or prolonged illness, an employee, with the approval of his department head and the village board of trustees, may, however, use all accumulated vacation time in addition to his accumulated sick leave before he shall be removed from the village payroll. 
(3)  As a condition of the granting of sick leave benefits, the village board or the respective department head may require an employee to file, from time to time, a certificate of health examination and a report from a practicing physician or clinic designated by the village board. The village board or the respective department head may require the employee to conform to any medical advice contained in such report as a condition of continuing employment with the village. 
(4)  If in the judgment of the village board an employee is unfit to perform his duties because of his physical condition, the village board may require the employee to take sick leave sufficient to improve his condition to a point where he would again be capable of performing his duties. 
(5)  An employee on sick leave, who is absent from his home at the time of a visit from his department head, a person designated by his department head to make such visit, or by a member of the village board, will have all sick leave benefits for the particular illness cancelled and the time lost will not be restored to the accumulated sick leave credit of the employee, unless at the time of the visit the employee is confined to a hospital, is receiving medical attention or is absent for other reasons acceptable to the village board. An offense of this type will be sufficient cause for dismissal. 
(6)  The department head will maintain a record of all credits and debits to the sick leave account of each employee in his department. These sick leave accounts are to be available for inspection by the employee and a monthly report shall be filed with the payroll clerk and village board. 
(7)  Any total temporary disability benefit checks received by the employee from the village's workmen's compensation insurance carrier for any number of working days which exceed the employee's accumulated sick leave time shall be endorsed over to the village or, in the alternative, the village shall deduct the aggregate amount of such benefit checks for the excess period from the salary otherwise due the employee. Any such benefit checks received by the employee, whether or not in excess of the accumulated sick leave time, may be retained by the employee for any period during which the employee is not receiving regular salary or sick leave pay from the village. 
(8)  Notwithstanding any provision in this section to the contrary, whenever any full-time police officer or firefighter shall suffer any injury in the line of duty which causes him to be unable to perform his duties, he shall continue to be paid by the village for not longer than one year in relation to the same injury on the same basis as he was paid before the injury, with no deduction from his sick leave credits, compensatory time for overtime accumulations or vacations, or service credits in the police officers' or firefighters' pension funds during the time he is unable to perform his duties due to the result of the injury. At any time during the period for which such compensation shall continue to accrue, the village board may order, at its expense, a physical or medical examination of the injured person to determine the degree of disability. The village board shall make the determination as to whether the injured person is unable to perform his duties, taking into consideration all medical and physical examination reports, including workmen's compensation documentation, available to the village board. During this period of disability, the injured person shall not be employed in any other manner with or without monetary compensation. If such person is so employed contrary to this prohibition, he shall thereby forfeit the continuing compensation provided by this section. Any disabled person receiving such continuing compensation shall not be entitled to any benefits for which he would otherwise qualify because of his disability under the provisions of the Illinois Pension Code approved March 18, 1963, as amended before or hereafter. 
(9)  Notwithstanding any provision in this section other than subsection (a)(8) to the contrary, sick leave compensation will not be paid to any employee for any absence from duty on any day immediately before or after such employee's regular, personal or vacation day off; however, such exclusion shall not apply to any full-time firefighter on any day immediately before or after his regular day off. 
(b)  Funeral leave. In the event of death in the immediate family (defined as the employee's legal spouse, children, parents, parents of spouse, brother, sister, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, grandparents and grandchildren), an employee shall be granted up to three consecutive workdays as funeral leave if the employee attends the funeral. In the event of death of an employee's brother-in-law, sister-in-law, or legal spouse's grandparents or grandchildren, an employee shall be granted up to one workday as funeral leave if the employee attends the funeral. An employee if requested may be required to provide satisfactory evidence of the death of a member of the immediate family. 
(c)  Family medical leave. An employee shall be covered by the Family Medical Lave Act of 1993 and therefore, shall be eligible, in accordance with the Act and the regulations thereunder, for up to 12 weeks of leave per year for the birth, adoption or foster care of a child, or a serious injury or illness of the employee or the employee's immediate family. An employee utilizing such leave must provide such notice as is required by the Act. Employees shall suffer no loss of benefits while on such leave and the employee may use any accrued paid time off option in any order, including sick time. However, when choosing to utilize FMLA for immediate family, the employee must exhaust time due, then vacation, then personal days and finally sick time. 
(Code 1965, § 8.117; Ord. No. 04-05, § 1, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 2-139. - Health care plan for certain employees of police and fire departments who opt to take early retirement. 
(a)  Definitions: For the purpose of this section wherever the following terms appear, they shall be defined as or construed to mean: 
    Board: The words "board" or "the board" mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Employee benefit committee: Hereafter known as (EBC) consist of the fire chief, police chief, public safety committee chairman, village treasurer, and the village administrator with a chairman being appointed from among the committee members by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
    Gender: The masculine gender whenever used in this ordinance includes the female gender unless manifestly inconsistent with the context. 
    Participant: "Participant" means a person who is a recipient, either directly or as beneficiary of a pension, disability pension benefit or retirement annuity from the following funds: policemen's pension or firemen's pension. Further, the individual must have been a full-time policeman or firefighter of the village immediately prior to the effective date of this section. 
    Permanent or full-time employees: Permanent or full-time employees shall be those employees who are employed on a minimum 40 hours per week schedule as per their respective departments, and are entitled to all benefits. 
(b)  Eligibility: To be eligible for this health care plan hereinafter described, a person: 
(1)  Must be a participant as defined in subsection (a). 
(2)  Must have held either the office or position or have attained the rank of any of the positions within the respective department as set forth below, and who is a full-time employee of the village. 
a.  Police chief. 
b.  Fire chief. 
c.  Fire captains. 
d.  Fire lieutenants. 
e.  Police lieutenants (Includes exempt ranks). 
f.  Police sergeants. 
g.  Patrolmen. 
h.  Firefighters. 
(3)  Must have at least 20 years of creditable service. 
(4)  Must have a total of 70 points, consisting of the employee's age plus total years in a position or positions described in subsection (b)(2). 
(5)  If a potential participant is 50 years of age or older, has accumulated 20 years of creditable service and is eligible for early retirement within the time period described in subsection (c) and does not avail himself of this plan, he will not be eligible for any similar plans in the future. 
(c)  Time period: If a potential participant elects to participate, he will have up to three months from the effective date of this section to exercise the option to retire. If retirement is so elected within the period, a $10,000.00 longevity increase will be included in the pensioner's present salary. Said increase will be included in the last four paychecks, in an amount of 1/12 of the longevity increase. 
(d)  Notification: To be eligible for participation in this plan, each potential participant as set forth in subsection (b) must notify the village, in writing within a minimum of 60 days prior to the expiration of the option period set forth in subsection (c), of his intention to retire. 
(e)  Insurance benefit: 
(1)  If notification is given within the requisite time period, the total of 70 points and the 20 years of creditable service has been accumulated, the village will pay 100 percent of the employee's hospitalization insurance premium at the level provided at separation of service. 
(2)  The employee is eligible to remain on the village hospitalization program until: 
a.  If the employee is able to secure future employment, and insurance is available, the employee must accept that coverage and leave the village plan. 
b.  When the employee becomes entitled to Medicare benefits, the employee will accept Medicare and leave the village plan. 
(f)  Evaluation of plan: 
(1)  The board and the EBC shall evaluate this plan at least annually for the purpose of keeping it current with the needs of the employees and pensioners so covered and to evaluate the availability of funds from the village budget to cover the cost thereof. Consideration shall be given to, but not limited to, the following factors: 
a.  Increased rates and costs. 
b.  Funding/experience factors. 
c.  Contract for the applicable health care policy. 
(2)  Based upon said evaluation, the board of trustees may amend, alter, or revoke this plan at any time and no employee shall be deemed to have a continued right to coverage; provided, however, that said health care coverage may not be terminated by the board as to those pensioners who are then currently covered unless coverage is terminated for all employees. 
(Code 1965, § 8.119; Ord. No. 05-21, §§ 1-6, 7-25-2005) 
Sec. 2-139.5. - Disability hospitalization insurance plan to benefit certain full-time employees. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section wherever the following terms appear, they shall be defined as or construed to mean: 
    Board: The words "board" or "the board" mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Disability hospitalization insurance: Is the health insurance coverage the Village provides to its employees during their employment with the village. 
    Employee: A person who is a permanent or full-time employee [of the] village immediately prior to the effective date of this section. 
    Employee benefit committee: Hereafter known as ("EBC") consists of the fire chief, police chief, finance committee chairman, village treasurer, and the village administrator with a chairman being appointed from among the committee members be the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
    Gender: The masculine gender whenever used in this section includes the female gender unless manifestly inconsistent with the context. 
    Permanent or full-time employees: Permanent or full-time employees shall be those employees who are employed on a minimum 40-hour per week schedule as per their respective departments, and are entitled to all benefits. 
(b)  Eligibility. To be eligible for this disability hospitalization insurance hereinafter described, a person: 
(1)  Must be an employee as defined in subsection (a) of this section. 
(2)  Must be disabled due to an on-the-job injury. 
(3)  Must be unable to continue work in the position held with the village at the time of the injury.
