(4)  Must be/have been enrolled in [the] village offered health plan or HMO at the time of the on-the-job injury causing the disability. 
(c)  Ineligibility. A person will no longer be eligible for this disability hospitalization insurance should a person: 
(1)  Secure future employment, and health insurance is available, the disabled employee must accept the coverage and leave the village plan. 
(2)  Become entitled to Medicare benefits, the disabled employee must accept Medicare benefits and leave the village plan. 
(3)  Receive health insurance coverage through a spouse or some other source, the disabled employee must accept that coverage and leave the village plan. 
(d)  Health insurance benefit. Subject the conditions set forth in subsection (b) of this section and subsection (c) above, the village will pay 100 percent of the employee's hospitalization insurance premium(s); and the village will provide continuing coverage to the disabled employee's family for up to one year or until a settlement of any worker's compensation claim is reached, whichever is sooner. 
(e)  Evaluation of plan. The board and the EBC shall evaluate this plan at least annually for the purpose of keeping it current with the needs of the employees and pensioners so covered and to evaluate the availability of funds from the village budget to cover the cost thereof. Consideration shall be given to, but not limited to, the following factors: 
(1)  Increased rates and costs. 
(2)  Funding/experience factors. 
(3)  Contract for the applicable health care benefit. 
Based upon said evaluation, the board of trustees of the village may amend, alter, or revoke this plan at any time and no employee shall be deemed to have a continued right to coverage; provided, however, that said disability hospitalization coverage may not be terminated by the board as to those disabled employees who are then currently covered unless coverage is terminated for all employees. 
(Ord. No. 12-10, §§ 1-5, 8-27-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-10, §§ 1-5, adopted Aug. 27, 2012, enacted provisions which did not specify manner of inclusion. To facilitate indexing, said provisions have been included herein as § 2-139.5. 
Sec. 2-140. - Education pay. 
    An employee of the village who has received an associate degree in a field of study related to his particular job duties in a college approved by the village president and board of trustees shall receive, in addition to normal base pay, $1,500.00 per year; and if he obtains a bachelor's degree in a field of study related in his particular job duties, he shall receive, in addition to normal base pay, an additional $1,500.00 per year for a total of $3,000.00 per year. 
(Code 1965, § 8.120) 
Sec. 2-141. - Tuition reimbursement. 
    The employer shall reimburse employees the cost of tuition for courses for degrees related to their job duties if the employee has received written permission in advance of the start of the course from the village president and board of trustees to take the course, which shall not be unreasonably denied or withheld, and the employee has obtained a grade "C" or above, or the equivalent, for classes, courses or degrees. 
(Code 1965, § 8.121) 
Sec. 2-142. - Health care plan to benefit certain full-time employees who opt to take early retirement. 
(a)  Definitions: For the purpose of this section wherever the following terms appear, they shall be defined as or construed to mean: 
    Board: The words "board" or "the board" mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Employee benefit committee: Hereafter known as (EBC) consist of the fire chief, police chief, public safety committee chairman, village treasurer, and the village administrator with a chairman being appointed from among the committee members by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
    Gender: The masculine gender whenever used in this section includes the female gender unless manifestly inconsistent with the context. 
    Participant: Means a person who is a recipient, either directly or as beneficiary of a pension, disability pension benefit or retirement annuity from the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF). Further, the individual must have been a full-time employee of the Village of Hillside immediately prior to the effective date of this section. 
    Permanent or full-time employees: Permanent or full-time employees shall be those employees who are employed on a minimum 40-hour per week schedule as per their respective departments, and are entitled to all benefits. 
(b)  Eligibility: To be eligible for this health care plan hereinafter described, a person: 
(1)  Must be a participant as defined in subsection (a). 
(2)  Must have at least 20 years of creditable service. 
(3)  Must have a total of 70 points, consisting of the employee's age plus total years in a position or positions described in subsection (b)(2) [eligible positions with the village]. 
(4)  Must attain a minimum of 50 years of age or older within the time frame of this section. 
(5)  If a potential participant is 50 years of age or older and has accumulated 20 years of creditable service and is eligible for early retirement and does not avail himself of this plan, he will not be eligible for any similar plans in the future. 
(c)  Time period: If a potential participant elects to participate, he will have up to one year from the effective date of this section to exercise the option to retire. If retirement is so elected within the period, a 125 percent longevity increase will be included in the pensioner's last three months salary. 
(d)  Notification: To be eligible for participation in this plan, each potential participant as set forth in subsection (b) must notify the village, in writing within a minimum of 90 days prior to the expiration of the option period set forth in subsection (c), of his intention to retire. 
(e)  Insurance benefit: If notification is given within the requisite time period, the employee is as least 50 years of age, the total of 70 points and the 20 years of creditable service has been accumulated, the village will pay 100 percent of the employee's hospitalization insurance premium at the level provided at separation of service. 
(f)  Evaluation of plan: 
(1)  The board and the EBC shall evaluate this plan at least annually for the purpose of keeping it current with the needs of the employees and pensioners so covered and to evaluate the availability of funds from the village budget to cover the cost thereof. Consideration shall be given to, but not limited to, the following factors: 
a.  Increased rates and costs. 
b.  Funding/experience factors. 
c.  Contract for the applicable health care policy. 
(2)  Based upon said evaluation, the board of trustees may amend, alter, or revoke this plan at any time and no employee shall be deemed to have a continued right to coverage; provided, however, that said health care coverage may not be terminated by the board as to those pensioners who are then currently covered unless coverage is terminated for all employees. 
(Ord. No. 05-24, §§ 1-6, 8-22-2005) 
Sec. 2-143. - Health care plan to benefit certain full-time employees of the police and fire departments who opt to take early retirement. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section wherever the following terms appear, they shall be defined as or construed to mean: 
(1)  Definition of permanent or full-time employees: Permanent or full-time employees shall be those employees who are employed on a minimum 40-hour per week schedule as per their respective departments, and are entitled to all benefits. 
(2)  board: The words "board" or "the board" mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
(3)  Employee benefit committee: Hereafter known as (EBC) consist of the fire chief, police chief, public safety committee chairman, village treasurer, and the village administrator with a chairman being appointed from among the committee members by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(4)  Participant: Means a person who is a recipient, either directly or as beneficiary of a pension, disability pension benefit or retirement annuity from the following funds: Policemen's Pension or Firemen's Pension. Further, the individual must have been a full-time policeman or firefighter of the Village of Hillside immediately prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(5)  Gender: The masculine gender whenever used in this ordinance includes the female gender unless manifestly inconsistent with the context. 
(b)  Eligibility: To be eligible for this health care plan hereinafter described, a person: 
(1)  Must be a participant as defined in subsection (a) of this section. 
(2)  Must have held either the office or position or have attained the rank of any of the positions within the respective department as set forth below, and who is a full-time employee of the Village of Hillside. 
a.  Police chief. 
b.  Fire chief. 
c.  Fire captains. 
d.  Police lieutenants (Includes exempt ranks). 
(3)  Must have at least 20 years of creditable service. 
(4)  Must have a total of 70 points, consisting of the employee's age plus total years in a position or positions described in subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(5)  If a potential participant is 50 years of age or older, has accumulated 20 years of creditable service and is eligible for early retirement within the time period described in subection (c) of this section and does not avail himself of this plan, he will not be eligible for any similar plans in the future. 
(c)  Time period: For a potential participant to participate in the health care plan hereinafter described, he must retire on December 1, 2009. 
(d)  Notification: To be eligible to participate in this plan, each potential participant as set forth in subsection (b) must notify the village, in writing within a minimum of 60 days prior to the option date set forth in subsection (c) of this section of his intention to retire. 
(e)  Insurance benefit: 
(1)  If notification is given within the requisite time period, and the total of 70 points and the 20 years of creditable service has been accumulated by the participant, the village will pay 100 percent of the employee's hospitalization insurance premium at the level provided at separation of service. 
(2)  The employee is eligible to remain on the village hospitalization program until one of the following occurs: 
a.  The employee secures future employment where hospitalization insurance is available. The employee must accept the coverage of his future employer and leave the village plan. 
b.  The employee becomes entitled to Medicare benefits. The employee must accept Medicare and leave the village plan. 
(f)  Evaluation of plan: 
(1)  The board and the EBC shall evaluate this plan at least annually for the purpose of keeping it current with the needs of the employees and pensioners so covered and to evaluate the availability of funds from the village budget to cover the cost thereof. Consideration shall be given to, but not limited to, the following factors: 
a.  Increased rates and costs. 
b.  Funding/experience factors. 
c.  Contract for the applicable health care policy. 
(2)  Based upon said evaluation, the board of trustees of the village may amend, alter, or revoke this plan at any time and no employee shall be deemed to have a continued right to coverage; provided, however, that said health care coverage may not be terminated by the board as to those pensioners who are then currently covered unless coverage is terminated for all employees. 
(g)  Future eligibility: If an employee is eligible to retire under this plan and does not take it, the employee will not be eligible to accept and future incentive plans that may become available in the future. 
(Ord. No. 09-21, §§ 1-7, 9-28-2009) 
Sec. 2-144. - Longevity pay increase for certain full-time employees. 
(a)  Definitions: That for the purpose of this section wherever the following terms appear, they shall be defined as or construed to mean: 
(1)  Definition of permanent or full-time employees: Permanent or full-time employees shall be those employees who are employed on a minimum 40 hour per week schedule as per their respective departments, and are entitled to all benefits. 
(2)  Gender: The masculine gender whenever used in this ordinance includes the female gender unless manifestly inconsistent with the context. 
(b)  Eligibility: To be eligible for this longevity pay increase hereinafter described, a person: 
(1)  Must be a permanent or full-time employee as defined in subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(2)  Must have held either the office or position or have attained the rank of any of the positions within the respective department as set forth below, and who is a full-time employee of the village. 
a.  Police chief. 
b.  Fire chief. 
c.  Fire captains. 
d.  Police sergeants. 
(3)  Must have at least 20 years of creditable service as a permanent or full-time employee with the Village of Hillside. 
(4)  Must have a total of 70 points, consisting of the employee's age plus the total years in a position or positions described in subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(c)  Longevity pay increase: On the date an employee becomes eligible, that employee will receive a one-time longevity pay increase in salary in the amount of $5,000.00, which increase will be included as part of the employee's salary for the next 12 months. Said increase shall be paid in a lump sum in the pay period immediately following the date the employee achieves eligibility as set forth in subsection (2) of this section. After 12 months, the employee's salary will revert to his salary prior to the longevity pay increase. 
(d)  Evaluation of plan: The board shall evaluate this longevity pay increase at least annually for the purpose of keeping it current with the needs of the employees so covered and to evaluate the availability of funds from the village budget to cover the cost thereof. Based upon said evaluation, the board of trustees of the village may amend, alter, or revoke this longevity pay increase at any time and no employee shall be deemed to have a continued right to longevity pay increase; provided, however, that said longevity pay increase may not be terminated by the board as to those employees who will become eligible to receive the longevity pay increase in the current fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 09-22, §§ 1-4, 9-28-2009; Ord. No. 16-01, § 1, 1-25-2016) 
Sec. 2-145. - Extended health care plan for full-time department heads. 
(a)  Definitions. That for the purpose of this section wherever the following terms appear, they shall be defined as or construed to mean: 
    Creditable service . Creditable service shall mean continuing employment by the village for no less than 20 years without deduction for time taken under the Family Medical Leave Act or vacation. 
    Department head . Department head shall mean and include the following village employees: the village administrator; the village treasurer/assistant village administrator/director of community development; police chief; fire chief; and, director of public works and building services. 
    Full-time employees . Full-time employees are those employees who are employed on an average of 40 hours per week and eligible for benefits awarded to such employment status by the village. 
    Medical insurance benefit . The medical insurance benefit shall mean the medical insurance plan for the eligible retired department heads and the dependents of such department heads as provided by the village, from time to time, for its full-time employees. 
(b)  Upon retirement from employment with the village, department heads shall be eligible to participate in the village's medical insurance benefit upon completion of 20 years of continuous credible service to the village and attaining the minimum age of 55 years until the first to occur: 
(1)  The department head secures employment after retirement from the village and such employment position offers any medical insurance plan whether or not such plan is equal to or lesser than the medical insurance benefit offered by the village; or, 
(2)  The department head is eligible for Medicare benefit, whether or not said department head accepts such coverage under Medicare. 
(c)  If a department head declines the medical insurance benefit at the date of retirement or at any time thereafter and notifies the village that participation in the medical insurance benefit is no longer desired, the department head shall not be eligible for any future medical insurance benefit offered by the village. 
(Ord. No. 17-13, §§ 1-3, 11-20-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-13, §§ 1-3, adopted Nov. 20, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion, hence, codification as § 2-145 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-146-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-161. - Creation of office. 
    There is hereby created the office of village administrator, an executive office of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1001) 
Sec. 2-162. - Appointment; removal; designation of acting administrator. 
    The village administrator shall be appointed by the president, by and with the consent of the board of trustees, for an indefinite term, and he shall be the direct representative of the corporate authorities in the transaction of all village business and in all matters concerning he citizens of the village. He shall be the chief administrative officer of the village, serving under the president and the board of trustees. In the event of the absence or disability of the village administrator, the president, by and with the consent of the board of trustees, may designate a qualified administrative officer or employee of the village to perform the duties of village administrator during such absence or disability. The president, by and with the consent of the board of trustees, may at any time remove the village administrator from office. In each instance wherein consent of the board of trustees is required under this section, a simple majority vote of those members of the board of trustees then holding office shall be sufficient. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1002) 
Sec. 2-163. - Supervision and coordination of departments. 
    It shall be the duty and responsibility of the village administrator to supervise and coordinate the work of all departments of the village and to report directly to the president and board of trustees who, whenever possible and practical, shall deal with departmental services through the village administrator. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1003) 
Sec. 2-164. - Hiring, suspension and discharge of employees. 
    The village administrator shall have the responsibility for the hiring, suspension and discharge of all village employees, except those under the jurisdiction of the board of fire and police commissioners or other "tenure of office" laws, and except those who, on May 1, 1985, were holding appointments as department heads, the authority over whose suspension or discharge shall be exercised exclusively by the president and board of trustees. However, the village administrator shall not hire or discharge an employee without the consent of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1004) 
Sec. 2-165. - Appointment recommendations of nonelected officers. 
    The village administrator may recommend the appointment of all nonelected officers of the village, such as the treasurer engineer, fire chief, police chief, prosecutor and attorney, as well as all commission members and village inspectors, but the final authority to make such appointments shall reside in the president, by and with the consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1005) 
Sec. 2-166. - Authority regarding expenditures of funds. 
    The village administrator shall supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment, not to exceed $1,000.00 for any single purchase or contract. The village administrator may delegate this authority as he deems appropriate. The village administrator may approve any purchase of materials, supplies and equipment over $1,000.00 but less than $4,000.00 with the prior approval of the appropriate committees of the board of trustees. All other contracts shall be let only by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1006) 
Sec. 2-167. - Powers and duties generally. 
    As the direct representative of the corporate authorities of the village, the village administrator shall have the power to direct or to stop any local improvements or public work in the village if, in his sole discretion, such direction is required to safeguard the public interest or if the work is being carried out in an improper manner. The village administrator shall receive all complaints, suggestions, requests, applications and petitions and other correspondence or communications directed to the corporate authorities, and whenever possible, shall take action promptly to adjust or resolve those matters which do not require official action of the corporate authorities. He shall cause all laws and ordinances applicable within the village to be enforced. He shall have and exercise the power, authority and duties of any department head during the time when the position or office of such department head shall be vacant or no person shall have been appointed thereto. The village administrator shall be responsible for the preparation of the annual appropriation ordinance and tax levy ordinance and shall submit them to the president and board of trustees sufficiently in advance of the necessary enactment date of permit full examination and discussion by the president and board of trustees prior to their adoption. He shall perform the duties of the zoning administrator as specified in the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980, as amended, and shall supervise the actions of all village inspectors. Finally, the village administrator shall attend all meetings of the board of trustees, unless excused therefrom, and shall also attend, when appropriate, other meetings outside the village as the village's representative. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1007) 
Sec. 2-168. - Compensation. 
    The village administrator shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be fixed by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1008) 
Sec. 2-169. - Bond. 
    Before taking office, the village administrator shall furnish a fidelity bond in the amount of $10,000.00 at the expense of the village and conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, with and insurance company, as surety satisfactory to the president and board of trustees and licensed to do business in the state. Such bond shall be filed with the village clerk after being approved by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1009) 
Secs. 2-170-2-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-191. - Creation of office; appointment; bond. 
    There is hereby created the office of village attorney, an executive office of the village. The attorney shall be appointed by the president, with the consent of the board of trustees. The bond of the village attorney shall be fixed by the board at the time of his appointment. 
(Code 1965, § 4.101) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to appoint attorney, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5(a)(5). 
Sec. 2-192. - Special counsel. 
    The president with the consent of the board of trustees may from time to time retain an attorney to represent or advise the village on legal matters if no village attorney has been appointed; and he may likewise retain special counsel to advise or represent the village on special matters or to assist the village attorney. 
(Code 1965, § 4.102) 
Sec. 2-193. - Drafting of ordinances and other documents. 
    The attorney shall, on direction of the president or board of trustees, draft or supervise the drafting of all ordinances and resolutions to be acted on, and all contracts or other documents in which the village is interested. 
(Code 1965, § 4.103) 
Sec. 2-194. - Prosecution or defense of suits and actions. 
    The attorney shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer of the village on behalf of the village or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.104) 
Sec. 2-195. - Legal advice. 
    The attorney shall be the legal advisor of the village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting it, whenever requested to do so by any village official. Upon request by the president of the village board, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing. 
(Code 1965, § 4.105) 
Sec. 2-196. - Attendance at meetings. 
    The attorney shall attend all meetings of the village board and all meetings of the board of local improvements. 
(Code 1965, § 4.106) 
Sec. 2-197. - Compensation. 
    The attorney shall receive such compensation as may be decided from time to time by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.107) 
State Law reference- Compensation of officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-5. 
Sec. 2-198. - Special assessment and condemnation proceedings. 
    The attorney shall carry through, to completion, all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings, for which he shall receive additional compensation based upon the fair and reasonable value of his services. 
(Code 1965, § 4-108) 
Secs. 2-199-2-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROSECUTOR 

Sec. 2-221. - Creation of office; appointment; bond. 
    There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor. The prosecutor shall be appointed by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The bond of the prosecutor shall be fixed by the board at the time of his appointment. 
(Code 1965, § 4.901) 
Sec. 2-222. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the prosecutor to render advice to any member of the police department or to any village official who so requests, concerning any violation of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/1-1, or any violation, punishable by fine or imprisonment, of the provisions of the ordinances of the village. He shall assist the members of the police department, when they so request, in the preparation of written criminal or quasi-criminal complaints or arrest citations. Further, he shall prepare for, institute and complete the prosecution before the proper court of any violations of the provisions of the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.902) 
Sec. 2-223. - Compensation. 
    The prosecutor shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be fixed by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.903) 
Secs. 2-224-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CLERK-COLLECTOR[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, adopted April 26, 2004, repealed former div. 5, §§ 2-241-2-53, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former div. 5 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 3.001-3.014. 

Sec. 2-241. - Election; term and commencement of office. 
    The village clerk-collector shall be elected for a term of four years, which term shall commence with his inauguration as the last order of business at the last regular meeting of the president and board of trustees in the month of April following his election to that office. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-242. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon his duties of office, the village clerk-collector shall execute a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-243. - Signatures. 
    The village clerk-collector shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require this formality. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-244. - Money collected. 
    The clerk-collector shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the village to the village treasurer promptly upon receipt of the same, and with such money he shall give a statement as to the source thereof. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-245. - Accounts. 
    The clerk-collector shall keep accounts showing all money received by him and the source and disposition thereof, and such other accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-246. - Issuance of licenses and permits, and record keeping. 
    The clerk-collector shall issue and keep a register of all licenses and permits, collect and receive all fees therefore, and furnish applicable forms, where no provisions to the contrary is made by statute or ordinance. The clerk-collector shall also keep a record of all inauguration, appointment and employment dates of all elected and appointed officers and of all employees of the village, and such other records as may be required by statute or ordinance to be kept by the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-247. - Seal. 
    The clerk-collector shall be the custodian of the village seal, and shall affix its impression on documents whenever this is required. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-248. - Documents. 
    The clerk-collector shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the village which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-249. - Indices. 
    The clerk-collector shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. 
Sec. 2-250. - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties herein provided, the clerk-collector shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
Sec. 2-251. - Vacancies. 
    In case the office of village clerk-collector shall become vacant for any reason, the president and board of trustees shall appoint a successor as provided by statute. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-252. - Deputy clerk. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk. The village clerk is authorized to appoint a deputy clerk who shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the clerk, and affix the seal of the village thereto whenever required. 
(b)  When signing any documents the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the village clerk-collector followed by the work "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the word "deputy clerk". 
(c)  The powers and duties herein described shall be exercised by such deputy clerk only in the absence of the village clerk-collector from his office in the village hall, and only when either written document has been given by the village clerk-collector to exercise such power, or the village board has determined by resolution that the village clerk-collector is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. 
(d)  Such deputy clerk shall have the authority and power herein described, and such further power and authority as may be provided by statute. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-253. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-254. - Compensation of clerk-collector. 
    The village clerk-collector shall receive annual compensation of $12,000.00, payable in equal monthly installments of the last payday of each month during the term of his office. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 4-26-2004) 
Secs. 2-255-2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER 

Sec. 2-271. - Creation of office. 
    There is hereby created the office of code enforcement officer, an executive office of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1101) 
Sec. 2-272. - Appointment. 
    The code enforcement officer shall be appointed, and may thereafter be removed, by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. A simple majority vote of those trustees then holding office shall be sufficient to constitute consent of the board. In the event of the code enforcement officer's absence or disability; the director of public works or his/her designee may perform the duties of the code enforcement officer during such absence or disability. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1102; Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-273. - Duties. 
    The duties of the code enforcement officer shall consist of ensuring compliance with and enforcement of all ordinances provisions relating to property maintenance or zoning of business, commercial, industrial and residential properties in the village. The code enforcement officer shall inspect properties as frequently as necessary to insure compliance with the village ordinances. The code enforcement officer shall perform the following duties as may be required: 
(1)  Zoning regulations. Rendering assistance to the zoning administrator, under his direction, in investigating complaints, inspecting proposed and existing land uses, abating nonconforming uses and processing enforcement files for prosecution, involving alleged or actual violations of the provisions of the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980, as amended. 
(2)  Licenses. Inspecting those business premises, coin-operated services, vending and amusement machines and devices, taxicabs, elevators and escalators, solicitors, canvassers and peddlers, which are required by ordinance to be licensed, for the purpose of ascertaining that the decal, plate or badge, evidencing that current licenses or permits have been issued, is being conspicuously displayed on the property or person of the licensee or permittee as required by this Code. 
(3)  Animals. Investigating complaints concerning dogs and vicious animals of any kind which may be running at large within the village, and causing such dogs and other animals to be impounded in those instances whereby the owners cannot be located or the owners are unable or unwilling to exercise adequate control of the animals to ensure the safety of the community. 
(4)  Additional duties. Performing such other services relative to code enforcement as are delegated to him from time to time by the director of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1103; Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-274. - Citations; penalties for violations. 
    If the code enforcement officer, upon inspection and investigation, shall determine that an individual, firm or corporation has violated or is in violation of any Village Code provision pertaining to the duties of the code enforcement officer as set forth in this article, the code enforcement officer shall be empowered to serve such person, firm or corporation with a written citation specifying the date, time, location, nature of the violation and applicable code provision. The citation shall be for an amount not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00; a separate offense shall be deemed committed each date on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1104; Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Sec. 2-275. - Limitation on authority. 
    None of the areas of authority delegated to the code enforcement officer as set forth in this article shall be deemed to rescind or supersede the existing authority of any other elected or appointed officer, or employee, of the village. Rather, it is intent of this article that the duties of the code enforcement officer shall augment the area of responsibility of various inspectors and officers, to assist them in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1105) 
Sec. 2-276. - Compensation. 
    The code enforcement officer shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be fixed by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.1106; Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 1-26-2004) 
Secs. 2-277-2-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - TREASURER 

Sec. 2-291. - Creation of office; appointment; term. 
    There is hereby created the office of village treasurer, who shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees as provided by statute. He shall serve for one year. 
(Code 1965, § 4.801) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to appoint treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5(a)(1). 
Sec. 2-292. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village treasurer shall give a bond to the village in the sum of $350,000.00 or in such sum as may be required by statute from time to time, whichever sum is greater. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties as the village treasurer, and shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act of the village treasurer. 
(Code 1965, § 4.802) 
State Law reference- Bond of treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 
Sec. 2-293. - Duties generally. 
    The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the village whether directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the president and clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 4.803) 
Sec. 2-294. - Deposit of funds. 
    The treasurer shall deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as provided by law; and he shall keep the deposit of the village money separate and distinct from his own money, and shall not make private or personal use of any village money. 
(Code 1965, § 4.804) 
Sec. 2-295. - Records. 
    The treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him, showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid, and he shall keep records at all times showing the financial status of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.805) 
Sec. 2-296. - Accounts. 
    The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance, and he shall keep them in the manner required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.806) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-40(a). 
Sec. 2-297. - Special assessment funds. 
    All money received on a special assessment shall be held by the municipal treasurer as a special fund to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and the money shall be used for no other purpose, except to reimburse the village for money expended for the improvement. 
(Code 1965, § 4.807) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-85. 
Sec. 2-298. - Warrants. 
    All warrants drawn upon the treasurer must be signed by the president and countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular fund or appropriation to which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom payable. 
(Code 1965, § 4.808) 
Sec. 2-299. - Designation of depositories; deposit and withdrawal of funds. 
(a)  The Bank of New York Trust Company, N.A., Chicago, Illinois; BMO Harris Bank, N.A., Chicago, Illinois; Charles Schwab & Co., Inc. Chicago, Illinois; Huntington National Bank, Westchester, Illinois; Inland Bank, Hillside, Illinois; Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith Incorporated, Chicago, Illinois; Republic Bank, Berkeley, Illinois; U.S. Bank, Elmhurst, Illinois; Wachovia Bank, N.A., Chicago, Illinois; and the Illinois Funds established under Section 17 of the State Treasurer's Act (ISILCS 505/17) shall be and the same are hereby approved and designated as banks or depositories for the funds and monies of the village. 
(b)  The village treasurer and all other village officials in custody or control of village funds or monies shall deposit such funds and monies only in one or more of the depositories designated in subsection (a) of this section or as otherwise specifically designated by the board of trustees from time to time. 
(c)  All checks or drafts drawn against village funds and monies on deposit in one or more of the depositories designated in subsection (a) of this section shall be hand-signed by at least two of the following village officers: the president, treasurer, clerk, village administrator or manager or administrative services; provided, however, that any check drawn in an amount not to exceed $1,500.00 may be issued with facsimile signatures of the president and clerk in lieu of the hand signatures otherwise required in this subsection. 
(Code 1965, § 4.808.1; Ord. No. 05-04, § 1, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 06-38, § 1, 12-18-2006; Ord. No. 10-13, § 1, 5-24-2010;Ord. No. 14-16, § 1, 11-10-2014; Ord. No. 18-01, § 1, 1-22-2018) 
Sec. 2-300. - Compensation. 
    The treasurer shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be fixed by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.809) 
Secs. 2-301-2-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 

Sec. 2-321. - Creation of office. 
    There is hereby created the office of superintendent of public works, an executive office of the village. The said superintendent shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.701) 
Sec. 2-322. - Duties regarding streets. 
    The superintendent of public works shall have charge of the construction and care of all public streets, alleys, and driveways in the village, and with the cleaning of the same. He shall see to it that all gutters and drains therein function properly and that the same are kept free from defects. 
(Code 1965, § 4.702) 
Sec. 2-323. - Duties regarding lighting system. 
    The superintendent of public works shall supervise the lighting of the public streets and alleys, and shall keep the lighting system in efficient operation and good repair. 
(Code 1965, § 4.703) 
Sec. 2-324. - Duties regarding water distribution system. 
    The superintendent of public works shall have charge of the operation and maintenance of the municipal water distribution system. 
(Code 1965, § 4.704) 
Sec. 2-325. - Duties regarding sewers. 
    In the absence of provisions to the contrary, the superintendent of public works shall have charge of the construction and maintenance of all public sanitary and storm water sewers in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.705) 
Sec. 2-326. - Supervision of employees. 
    All officers or employees assigned to the department of public works shall perform their duties subject to the orders and under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 4.706) 
Sec. 2-327. - Custody of village property. 
    The superintendent of public works shall be the custodian of all property of the village which is not assigned to the care or custody of any other officer. 
(Code 1965, § 4.707) 
Secs. 2-328-2-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-381-2-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS 

Sec. 2-401. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners consisting of three members whose term of office shall be three years, and until their respective successors shall be appointed and qualified as provided by 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1. Such members shall be appointed by the village president, with the consent of the board of trustees. Of the three members of the board, one shall be a member of the employee class, one shall be from the employing class, and the third shall be a representative citizen not identified with either the employee or employing class, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.501) 
Sec. 2-402. - Qualifications of members; oath; bond; removal of members. 
    The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall possess the qualifications required of other officers of the village, shall take oath or affirmation of office, and shall give bond in the same manner as other appointive officers of the village. They shall be subject to removal from office as other officers. 
(Code 1965, § 7.502) 
Sec. 2-403. - Appointment of officers and members of fire and police departments. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the fire and police departments of the village, except the chief of police and the chief of the fire department; provided that all appointments to each department other than that of the lowest rank shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment shall be made, except in the respective appointments of the chief of police and the chief of the fire department, who shall be appointed by the president, with the consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 7.503) 
Sec. 2-404. - Powers. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall make such rules and make such appointments and removals and shall have such other and further powers as are provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.504) 
Sec. 2-405. - Hiring criteria regarding appointment of firefighter/paramedics; award of preference points for applicants to police and fire department. 
(a)  The board of fire and police commissioners is authorized to enact and follow certain procedures, through the board's rules and regulations, which will permit applicants for positions of full-time employment as a firefighter/paramedic with the village fire department who are currently certified, at the time of appointment as paramedics, to be preferred over non-certified applicants, and revise the manner by which preference points are awarded to candidates for the police and fire department. 
(b)  The board of fire and police commissioners, pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-8 and 5/10-2.1-9(a) and (b) (the Board of Fire and Police Commissioner's Act), shall give preference points for military service (veteran's points) only provided the applicant timely claims such veteran's preference points and provides proof of satisfactory service by the submission of the applicant's Form DD 214. 
(c)  The board of fire and police commissioners, within its rules, may provide the applicants for the position of firefighter/paramedic who, at the time of application are currently certified, according to the laws of the state, as paramedics, upon timely claim and proof of certification, be awarded ten preference points to be added to their final score. 
(d)  The board of fire and police commissioners may, at its discretion, choose to appoint applicants who are currently certified, by the state, as paramedics to a position of firefighter/paramedic ahead of non-certified applicants. 
(Code 1965, § 7.504.1) 
Sec. 2-406. - Secretary. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held, and shall perform such other duties as the board shall prescribe. 
(Code 1965, § 7.505) 
Sec. 2-407. - Hearings. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall hold hearings on any charges brought against any police officer, except the chief of police, and any full time firefighter, except the chief of the fire department, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.506) 
Sec. 2-408. - Additional duties. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall perform any additional duties required by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.507) 
Sec. 2-409. - Compensation of members. 
    Each member of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be paid the sum $15.00 for each meeting or hearing session convened or reconvened on different dates in accordance with this division; provided, however, no such member shall be so paid unless he is actually in attendance at the particular session, it being the intention of this section that no person shall be compensated for any session during which that person was absent from the entire session, whether or not such absence was excused or unavoidable. Immediately following each such session, the secretary thereof shall verify in writing the names of persons entitled hereunder to be paid, and shall transmit such verification promptly thereafter to the village clerk for processing of payment. 
(Code 1965, § 7.508) 
Secs. 2-410-2-430. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - YOUTH COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-431. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a youth commission which shall consist of seven members to be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of a majority of the board of trustees. A majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of all business. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1101) 
Sec. 2-432. - Term of members; vacancies. 
    The term of office of each of the members of the youth commission shall be three years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified, except as hereinafter provided. Any vacancy on the commission shall be filled by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, except that no such appointment shall be made by the village president within 30 days before the expiration of the president's term of office. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1102) 
Sec. 2-433. - Powers and duties. 
    The youth commission shall have the duties and may exercise the powers set forth hereinafter as follows: 
(1)  To cooperate with the village president, the board of trustees and other village departments, agencies and officials in carrying out a comprehensive program of youth welfare and youth activities. 
(2)  To invite, enlist and encourage the cooperation of and join with other public and voluntary agencies engaged or interested in providing recreational services and facilities to the youth who are residents of the village. 
(3)  To cooperate with local, state and federal agencies in a concerted effort to minimize juvenile delinquency and to urge parental and community responsibility for the actions of our youth. 
(4)  To conduct hearings, carry on research, or otherwise obtain factual data, issue such publications and make such administrative and legislative recommendations as in its judgment will effectuate the policy of the commission. 
(5)  To render an annual report of its activities to the village president and the board of trustees not later than July 1 of each year, commencing July 1, 1970. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1105) 
Sec. 2-434. - Cooperation by other departments and agencies. 
    The cooperation of all village departments and agencies shall be extended to the members of the youth commission upon request of the commission. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1106) 
Secs. 2-435-2-480. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE 

Sec. 2-481. - Appropriation ordinance. 
(a)  During the first quarter of each fiscal year, as required by statute, the president and board of trustees shall enact an appropriation ordinance in which shall be itemized all anticipated expenditures to be met during the coming year, other than those payable from bond issues. 
(b)  This article shall be published as required by law within ten days after its enactment. 
(Code 1965, § 8.201) 
Sec. 2-482. - Tax levy ordinance. 
(a)  Not sooner than ten days after the publication of the appropriation ordinance a tax levy ordinance shall be enacted, as required by law, levying such taxes as may be needed to meet the anticipated expenses of the coming year, together with such taxes as may be required to meet outstanding bond issues, or for purposes payable from special taxes properly authorized. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for the 1995 tax year (tax payable in 1996) and in the tax years thereafter, the increase in the amount levied by the village and extended upon all taxable real property located within the village (exclusive of the amount levied and extended against new improvements or additions to existing improvements which increased the assessed value of those properties during the levy year, and except as to any levy for debt service on bonds issued by the village prior to March 1, 1995) shall be limited to 105 percent of the previous year's tax extension or the increase in the Consumer Price Index, whichever is less. The "Consumer Price Index" herein referred to is the Index for All Urban Consumers for items published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor, and the percentage increase, if any, shall be based on the tax extension for the calendar year preceding the levy year, and the additional amount levied during the levy year. 
(b)  A certified copy of the tax levy ordinance shall be filed with the county clerk not later than the last Tuesday in December. Such ordinance shall show the total appropriated for each item and the amount of tax levied therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 8.202) 
Sec. 2-483. - Indebtedness. 
    No indebtedness shall be incurred, excepting such indebtedness as may be payable solely from the proceeds of a duly authorized bond issue or from a designated specified source, unless there is a prior appropriation out of which such indebtedness could be paid, as provided by statute. Provided that during the first quarter of any fiscal year, before the enactment of the current appropriation ordinance, the village may operate under the appropriation ordinance of the preceding year. 
(Code 1965, § 8.203) 
Sec. 2-484. - Contracts. 
    The village president, or any other person designated by the village board, may sign on behalf of the village any contract authorized by the president and board of trustees. No contract may be entered into without the authority of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 8.204) 
Sec. 2-485. - Approval of bills. 
    All bills payable by the village, other than for the payment of salaries established by the president and board of trustees, shall be submitted to the village board for approval before payment. 
(Code 1965, § 8.205) 
Sec. 2-486. - Payments by treasurer; warrants. 
    The treasurer shall pay out money in payment of all bills, or for salaries, or for any other purpose other than the retirement of principal or interest on bonds or tax anticipation warrants, only upon warrant signed by the president and the clerk as provided by statute. Such warrants shall designate the items to be paid and the funds from which they are to be paid. 
(Code 1965, § 8.206) 
Sec. 2-487. - Audits. 
    As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal year, and no later than six months thereafter, there shall be an audit of all accounts of the village made by a competent person authorized to act as an auditor under the laws of the state, to be designated by the president and board of trustees. Copies of such audit report shall be filed with the village clerk and with the director of the state department of revenue and in such other places as may be required by law. 
(Code 1965, § 8.207) 
Sec. 2-488. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year for the village shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of each year. 
(Code 1965, § 8.703) 
Sec. 2-489. - Debt policies. 
(a)  This policy establishes guidelines for use of debt financing that will allow the village to minimize financing costs and retain or improve its bond rating from Moody's Investors Services (or an equivalent rating from a similar firm). 
(b)  Conditions under which the village may consider use of debt financing. The village may consider the use of debt financing when all of the following conditions apply: 
(1)  For one-time capital improvement projects and unusual equipment purchases; 
(2)  When the project's useful life, or the projected service life of the equipment, will exceed the term of financing; and 
(3)  Then the Village has identified revenues sufficient to service the debt, either from existing revenues or increased taxes or fees. 
The village will not use debt for any recurring purpose such as current operating and infrastructure maintenance expenditures, nor will the village use short-term debt, unless under exigent circumstances. 
(c)  The village will use the following criteria to evaluate pay-as-you-go financing versus debt financing in funding capital improvements: 
(1)  Factors that favor pay-as-you-go financing. 
a.  Current revenues and/or adequate fund balances are available to finance the project. 
b.  Project phasing could allow the village to finance the project over time without debt. 
c.  Additional debt would adversely affect the village credit rating. 
d.  Market conditions are unstable or the project presents marketing difficulties. 
(2)  Factors that favor debt financing. 
a.  Revenues available for debt service are sufficient and reliable. 
b.  Issuance of debt will not jeopardize the village's credit rating. 
c.  Market conditions present favorable interest rates and good demand for municipal financing. 
d.  A project is mandated by state or federal requirements and current revenues and fund balances are insufficient to pay project costs. 
e.  A project is immediately required to meet or relieve infrastructure capacity needs, and current revenues and fund balances are not sufficient to finance the project 
f.  The life of the project or asset financed is ten years or longer. 
(Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 3-26-2007) 
Sec. 2-490. - Debt issuance guidelines. 
(a)  Considerations in issuing general obligation (G.O.) or revenue bonds. When the village has the option of using G.O. or revenue bonds, the village will consider the benefits of reduced debt expense and flexibility achievable through G.O. debt versus reserving the village's G.O. debt capacity by issuing revenue debt. The village may use General Obligation bonds in lieu of revenue bonds if debt expense can be significantly reduced (as compared to financing with revenue debt) and if a special or enterprise fund revenue is sufficient and reliable to fund debt service costs. In such cases, the village board of trustees will adopt ordinances abating the debt tax levies and direct staff to pay debt service costs with alternative revenues. 
(b)  Credit enhancements. The village will seek credit enhancements such as letters of credit or insurance when necessary for marketing purposes or to make the financing most cost-effective. 
(c)  Debt structure guidelines. 
(1)  In general, the village will maintain a debt structure under which 50 percent of the outstanding principal will be repaid within ten years. 
(2)  The term of financing (final bond maturity) will not exceed the expected useful life of the project or equipment financed with the debt. 
(3)  If the village plans to pay debt service expenses from a specific revenue source, the village will use conservative assumptions in its revenue projections. 
(d)  Professional services. To provide assistance in debt issuance, the village will select a financial advisor and/or investment banker and bond counsel on a competitive basis; these advisors will be retained for several years to provide continuity and allow them to develop an understanding of the village's needs. 
(e)  Competitive versus negotiated debt issuance. The village will generally conduct financing on a competitive basis; however, negotiated financing may be used where market volatility or the use of an unusual or complex financing or security structure causes a concern with regard to marketability. 
(f)  Inter-fund loans. The village may use inter-fund loans (in lieu or borrowing from private parties) to minimize the expense and administrative effort associated with external borrowing. Inter-fund loans are typically made for relatively short periods of time (under five years) and relatively low amounts (under $3,000, 000.00). Inter-fund loans will be considered to finance high priority needs on a case-by-case basis, only when other planned expenditures in the fund making the loan would not be affected. 
(g)  Maintenance of specific credit ratings. 
(1)  The village will seek to maintain or improve its current bond rating and will specifically discuss with the village board of trustees any proposal which might cause that rating to be lowered. 
(2)  An analysis will be prepared by village staff for each proposed financing; such analysis will assess the impact of debt issuance on current and future operating and capital budgets and address the reliability of revenues to support debt service payments. 
(Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 3-26-2007) 
Sec. 2-491. - Debt capacity guidelines or general obligation debt. 
(a)  Direct debt. To maintain its sound fiscal condition and debt rating, the village will limit the amount of debt it will issue and its annual debt service expenses in accordance with state statute. 
(b)  Computation of legal debt margin. 
(1)  Statutory debt limitation is 8.625% of the village's assessed valuation. 
(2)  The legal debt margin (debt that the village may issue) is the statutory debt limit less all present applicable debt. 
(c)  Overlapping debt. The village will monitor levels of overlapping debt and communicate debt plans with public entities that may issue overlapping debt. The village will take into account overlapping debt in considering both the amount of debt that the Village will issue, and the timing or village bond issues. 
(Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 3-26-2007) 
Sec. 2-492. - Debt administration. 
(a)  Financial disclosure. The village will follow a policy of full disclosure on every financial report and bond prospectus (Official Statement), voluntarily following disclosure guidelines provided by the Government Finance Officers Association unless the cost of compliance with the higher standard is unreasonable. 
(b)  Monitoring outstanding debt. 
(1)  The village will monitor all forms of debt annually and include an analysis in the village's financial plan; concerns and recommended remedies will be reported to the village board of trustees as necessary. 
(2)  The village will monitor bond covenants and federal regulations concerning debt, and adhere to those covenants and regulations at all times. 
(3)  Investment of bond proceeds. The village will invest bonds proceeds in accordance with the village's adopted investment policy and federal arbitrage regulations. 
(Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 3-26-2007) 
Sec. 2-493. - Responsible bidding for contracts. 
(a)  The recitals of the ordinance from which this ordinance derives are hereby adopted as findings of fact as if said recitals were fully set forth in this section. 
(b)  Financial responsibility is an important factor in determining the "lowest responsible bidder," and the village, through its contracting authority, shall require an entity that bids on a public contract produce satisfactory evidence of the following: 
(1)  That the business entity is properly registered and authorized to conduct the type of work to be performed, including evidence that demonstrates that the entity possesses or complies with requirements of the Internal Revenue Service (evidence of federal employer tax identification number - EIN), Illinois Departments of Revenue and/or Registration, and Illinois Department of Employment Security registration requirements, as well as complying with the general business license requirements of the village prior to the award and during the term of the contract; 
(2)  That the business entity is in compliance with all federal, state and village equal employment opportunity requirements; 
(3)  That the business entity has evidence of all specified insurance coverages; 
(4)  That the business entity complies with all provisions of the Illinois Prevailing Wage Act, including evidence that the business entity provides or participates in a medical hospitalization program for its employees, has a pension or retirement benefit program for its employees, with the premium or cost or contribution rate, as well as benefit configuration for each of the respective aforementioned programs, being no less than required under the Illinois Prevailing Wage Act; 
(5)  That the business entity has an apprenticeship and training program approved and registered with the U.S. Department of Labor's Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training; 
(6)  That the business entity complies with any other additional requirements the village may find beneficial. 
(c)  The contracting authority, in order to make its determination as to whether the bidding entity is a "responsible bidder," shall confirm and substantiate that the contract awardee can be reasonably be expected to complete and perform under the contract specifications, and the contracting authority may require the successful bidder to post a bid, performance, wage/fringe benefit and/or material bond(s). The contracting authority shall also determine if the successful bidder can reasonably be expected to complete the project within the time constraints as delineated in the request for bids and/or proposals. The contracting authority shall also determine if the bidding entity maintains a satisfactory level of past performance and integrity as well as possesses the financial, supervisory, personnel, material, equipment, and other resources and expertise to satisfactorily meet its contractual responsibilities and obligations. 
(d)  Social responsibility is a concern in awarding public contracts, and the contracting authority may factor in its determination of whether a bidder is "responsible" such factors as bidder's record of conformity with environmental, labor, and health and safety laws including compliance with the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor's Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Furthermore, the bidder shall be required to provide a certificate of insurance, designating the village as an additional insured under all pertinent policies, specifying all required coverages, including general liability, workers' compensation, completed operations, automobile, hazardous occupation, product liability, and professional liability at such limits as the contracting authority deems appropriate to protect the interests of the village. 
(Ord. No. 07-05, §§ 1-4, 2-26-2007) 
Cross reference- Statement to contracting parties regarding village policy with respect to human rights and discrimination. 
Secs. 2-494-2-530. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADJUDICATION OF MUNICIPAL CODE VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 2-531. - Adoption of state law; applicability. 
    The village hereby adopts 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq. in its current form and as it may be amended from time to time for adjudication of municipal code violations to the extent permitted by the Illinois Constitution. As used in this article, a "system of administrative adjudication" means the adjudication of any violation of any village municipal ordinance, except: 
(1)  Proceedings not within the statutory or the home rule authority of the municipalities (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.); 
(2)  Any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles and except for any reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/6-204; and 
(3)  Any offense for building code violations as provided by previous municipal ordinances adopted in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., to be determined on a case by case basis by the village. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1101) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-2. 
Sec. 2-532. - Procedures not exclusive. 
    The adoption by the village of a system of administrative adjudication does not preclude the village from using other methods to enforce municipal ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1102) 
Sec. 2-533. - Code hearing unit; hearing officers. 
(a)  Code hearing unit established; jurisdiction. There is hereby established a code hearing unit in the village municipal government. The code hearing unit shall have jurisdiction to adjudicate any violation of any village municipal ordinances hereinafter referred to from time to time as "code violations" except for: 
(1)  Proceedings not within the statutory or the home rule authority of municipalities (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.); 
(2)  Any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles and except for any reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/6-204; and 
(3)  Any offense for building code violations as provided by previous municipal ordinances adopted in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., to be determined on a case by case basis by the village. 
(b)  Powers and duties of hearing officers. Adjudicatory hearings shall be presided over by hearing officers. The powers and duties of a hearing officer shall include: 
(1)  Hearing testimony and accepting evidence that is relevant to the existence of the code violation; 
(2)  Issuing subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant testimony at the hearing, upon the request of the parties or their representatives; 
(3)  Preserving and authenticating the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
(4)  Issuing a determination, based on the evidence presented at the hearing, of whether a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall include a written finding of fact, decision, and order including the fine, penalty, or action with which the defendant must comply; and 
(5)  Imposing penalties consistent with applicable code provisions and assessing costs upon finding a party, liable for the charged violation, except, however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to: (i) impose a penalty of incarceration, or (ii) impose a fine in excess of $50,000.00, or at the option of the village, such other amount not to exceed the maximum amount established by the mandatory arbitration system as prescribed by the Rules of the Illinois Supreme Court from time to time for the judicial circuit in which the village is located. The maximum monetary fine under this subsection (b)(5) shall be exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure compliance with the village's ordinances and shall not be applicable to cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the village. 
(c)  Training of hearing officers. Prior to conducting administrative adjudication proceedings, administrative hearing officers shall have successfully completed a formal training program which includes the following: 
(1)  Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings which they will conduct; 
(2)  Orientation to each subject area of the code violations that they will adjudicate; 
(3)  Observation of administrative hearings; and 
(4)  Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence and issuing final orders. 
In addition, every administrative hearing officer must be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state for at least three years. 
(d)  Initiation of proceedings. A proceeding before a code hearing unit shall be instituted upon the filing of a written pleading by an authorized official of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1103) 
Sec. 2-534. - Administrative hearing proceedings. 
(a)  Parties to administrative adjudication shall be afforded due process of law, including notice and opportunity for hearing. Parties shall be served with process in a manner reasonably calculated to give them actual notice, including, as appropriate, personal service of process upon a party or its employees or agents; service by mail at a party's address; or notice that is posted upon the property where the code violation is found when the party is the owner or manager of the property. 
(b)  Parties shall be given notice of an adjudicatory hearing which includes the type and nature of the code violation to the adjudicated, the date and location of the adjudicatory hearing, the legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held, and the penalties for failure to appear at the hearing. 
(c)  Parties shall be provided with an opportunity for a hearing during which they may be represented by counsel, present witnesses, and cross-examine opposing witnesses. Parties may request the hearing officer to issue subpoenas to direct the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and the production of relevant documents. Hearings shall be scheduled with reasonable promptness, provided that for hearings scheduled in all non-emergency situations, if requested by the defendant, the defendant shall have at least 15 days after service of process to prepare for a hearing. For purposes of this subsection (c), "non-emergency situation" means any situation that does not reasonably constitute a threat to the public interest, safety, or welfare. If service is provided by mail, the 15-day period shall begin to run on the day that the notice is deposited in the mail. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1104) 
Sec. 2-535. - Evidence. 
    The formal and technical rules of evidence do not apply in an adjudicatory hearing permitted under this article. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1105) 
Sec. 2-536. - Judicial review. 
    Any final decision by a code hearing unit that a code violation does or does not exist shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1106) 
Sec. 2-537. - Enforcement of judgement. 
(a)  Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the Illinois Administrative Review Law are a debt due and owing the village and may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final determination of a code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the findings, decision, and order of the hearing officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment ordering a defendant to correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by a municipality to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney's fees, court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer, shall be a debt due and owing the village and may be collected in accordance with applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a hearing officer pursuant to this subsection (c), the village shall provide notice to the defendant that states that the defendant shall appear at a hearing before the administrative hearing officer to determine whether the defendant has failed to comply with the judgment. The notice shall set the date for such a hearing, which shall not be less than seven days from the date that notice is served. If notice is served by mail, the seven-day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was deposited in the mail. 
(Code 1965, § 8.1107) 
Secs. 2-538-2-560. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SMOKING IN MUNICIPAL FACILITIES 

Sec. 2-561. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Municipal facility means any enclosed building or structure that is owned or leased and operated by the village, which includes, but is not limited to, the village hall, the fire station, the public works garage, the water tank storage area, and the community center. 
    Smoking means the lighting and holding, carrying or possessing of, or emitting or exhaling the smoke from, a tobacco filled pipe, cigar or cigarette of any kind. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1501) 
Sec. 2-562. - Smoking prohibited; exceptions; posting of signs. 
(a)  Smoking is prohibited in any municipal facility except in areas specifically designated as "smoking area" by a sign or signs posted and prominently displayed in conspicuous locations within such areas. "No smoking" signs shall be posted and prominently displayed on an inside wall or freestanding sign post near each entrance door to a municipal facility. Such signs shall also bear the international symbol for "smoking area" or "no smoking," as the case may be. 
(b)  Smoking is also prohibited in all municipal vehicles concurrently shared by the driver and one or more passengers, unless all such persons identify themselves as smokers. 
(c)  Designation of smoking areas in all municipal facilities and the posting of signs as required in subsection (a) of this section shall be the personal responsibility of the village administrator. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1502) 
Sec. 2-563. - Smoking prohibitions under other laws. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise prohibited by law or governmental regulation. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1503) 
Sec. 2-564. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1504) 
Secs. 2-255-2-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ETHICS 

Sec. 2-571. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms shall be given these definitions: 
    Campaign for elective office means any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination election, or appointment of any individual to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/1-3). 
    Collective bargaining has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
    Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this article, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence.
