    Every licensee shall cause his license or licenses to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1965, § 14.021) 
Sec. 6-55. - Suspension or revocation. 
    The village president may suspend for not more than 30 days (235 ILCS 5/4-4) or revoke for cause any liquor dealer's license for any violation of any provision pertaining to the sale of alcoholic liquor, as provided and in the manner provided in 235 ILCS 5/7-5. 
(Code 1965, § 14.027) 
Chapter 7 - INDOOR SMOKING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions of Ord. No. 07-36, adopted Dec. 17, 2007, superseding the provisions of uncodified Ord. No. 07-03, adopted Jan. 22, 2007, which also pertained to indoor smoking and added provisions to this Code designated as §§ 7-1-7-5. 
The provisions of this chapter frequently refer to sections of "this Act." The references to "this Act" may refer to the Smoke Free Illinois Act, 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq. The editor has added material in brackets to help clarify the references used in this chapter. 
Cross reference- Smoking in municipal facilities, § 2-561 et seq; tobacco possession and consumption by minors, § 58-111 et seq. 

Sec. 7-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be cited as the "Smoke Free Hillside Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-2. - Definitions. 
    Bar means an establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than ten percent of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the premises. "Bar" includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges, adult entertainment facilities, and cabarets. 
    Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages or profits or a person who volunteers his or her services for a non-profit entity. 
    Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, or corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust, or non-profit entity, that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or partially enclosed with (i) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways, or (ii) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that extend from the floor to the ceiling, including, without limitation, lobbies and corridors. 
    Enclosed or partially enclosed sports arena means any sports pavilion, stadium, gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink, bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or other events. 
    Gaming equipment or supplies means gaming equipment/supplies as defined in the Illinois Gaming Board Rules of the Illinois Administrative Code. 
    Gaming facility means an establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of accruing business revenue. 
    Healthcare facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare facilities. 
    Place of employment means any area under the control of a public or private employer that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during the course of employment, including, but not limited to entrances and exits to places of employment, including a minimum distance, as set forth in Section 70 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/70], of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference and classrooms; break rooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home-based business, unless used to provide licensed child care, foster care, adult care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a "place of employment". 
    Private club means a not-for-profit association that (1) has been in active and continuous existence for at least three years prior to the effective date of this amendatory Act of the 95th General Assembly [410 ILCS 82-1 et seq.], whether incorporated or not, (2) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, (3) is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and (4) only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. For purposes of this definition, "private club" means an organization that is managed by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting, has established bylaws, a constitution, or both to govern its activities, and has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. 501. 
    Private residence means the part of a structure used as a dwelling, including, without limitation: a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast or other similar public accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be considered a private residence. 
    Public place means that portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to the public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or in part by private persons or entities, the State of Illinois, or any other public entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission, including a minimum distance, as set forth in Section 70 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/70], of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. A "public place" does not include a private residence unless the private residence is used to provide licensed child care, foster care, or other similar social service care on the premises. A "public place" includes, but is not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls, public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums, enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools, exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming facilities, all government owned vehicles and facilities, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by the State or State subcontract, healthcare facilities or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service establishments, financial institutions, educational facilities, ticket areas, public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars, taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than 75 percent of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel, resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodation that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences. 
    Restaurant means (i) an eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, and (ii) a kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. 
    Restaurant includes a bar area within the restaurant. 
    Retail tobacco store means a retail establishment that derives more than 80 percent of its gross revenue from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, and other smoking devices for burning tobacco and related smoking accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. "Retail tobacco store" does not include a tobacco department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any establishment with any type of liquor, food, or restaurant license. 
    Smoke or smoking means the carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling, or exhaling of any kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, or any other lighted smoking equipment. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-3. - Smoking in public places, places of employment, and governmental vehicles prohibited. 
    No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment or within 15 feet of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the state or a political subdivision of the state. Smoking is prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by Section 35 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/35]. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-4. - Posting of signs; removal of ashtrays. 
(a)  "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol, consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it, shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this Act by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that place. 
(b)  Each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this Act shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this Act by the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-5. - Smoking prohibited in student dormitories. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, smoking is prohibited in any portion of the living quarters, including, but not limited to, sleeping rooms, dining areas, restrooms, laundry areas, lobbies, and hallways, of a building used in whole or in part as a student dormitory that is owned and operated or otherwise utilized by a public or private institution of higher education. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-6. - Designation of other nonsmoking areas. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, any employer, owner, occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public place or place of employment may designate a non-enclosed area of a public place or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in subsections (a) and (b) of Section 20 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/20, and section 7-4 of this chapter]. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-7. - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, smoking is allowed in the following areas: 
(1)  Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a child care, adult day care, or healthcare facility or any other home-based business open to the public. 
(2)  Retail tobacco stores as defined in Section 10 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/10 and section 7-2 of this chapter] in operation prior to the effective date of this amendatory Act of the 95th General Assembly. The retail tobacco store shall annually file with the Illinois Department of Public Health by January 31 an affidavit stating the percentage of its gross income during the prior calendar year that was derived from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, or other smoking devices for smoking tobacco and related smoking accessories. Any retail tobacco store that begins operation after the effective date of this amendatory Act may only qualify for an exemption if located in a freestanding structure occupied solely by the business and smoke from the business does not migrate into an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. 
(3)  Private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes and long-term care facilities that are occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers and have requested in writing to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the nursing home. 
(4)  Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than 25 percent of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to permanently add additional nonsmoking rooms. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-8. - Enforcement; complaints. 
(a)  Any person may report a violation of this chapter to any person who owns, operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment through oral or written complaint to any employee, agent or representative of the public place or place of employment. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a complaint, the person who owns, operates or otherwise controls the public place or place of employment shall immediately request that the person or persons committing the smoking violation cease smoking and/or leave the establishment. 
(c)  Any person may register a complaint with the Hillside Police Department for a violation of this Act by any person or entity who violates sections 7-3 or 7-8(b) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-9. - Violations. 
(a)  A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who violates Section 15 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/15 and section 7-3 of this chapter] shall be fined pursuant to this section. Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation. 
(b)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under Section 15 of this Act [410 ILCS 82/15 and section 7-3 of this chapter] shall be fined in an amount that is not less than $100.00 and not more than $250.00. 
(c)  A person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment that violates section 7-8 of this Chapter shall be fined (i) not less than $250.00 for the first violation, (ii) not less than $500.00 for the second violation within one year after the first violation, and (iii) not less than $2,500.00 for each additional violation within one year after the first violation. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-10. - Injunctions. 
    The Village of Hillside or any individual personally affected by repeated violations may institute, in a circuit court, an action to enjoin violations of this Act. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-11. - Discrimination prohibited. 
    No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the exercise of any rights afforded by this Act. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-12. - Section 70 [410 ILCS 82/70]. Entrances, exits, windows, and ventilation intakes. 
    Smoking is prohibited within a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this Act so as to ensure that tobacco smoke does not enter the area through entrances, exits, open windows, or other means. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-13. - Rules. 
    The Village of Hillside Police Department shall adopt rules necessary for the administration of this Act. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-14. - Severability. 
    If any provision, clause or paragraph of this Act shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such validity shall not affect the other provisions of this Act. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 7-15. - Construction with other ordinances. 
    This chapter does not modify, change or repeal Chapter 58, Article II, Division III regarding tobacco possession and consumption by minors. 
(Ord. No. 07-36, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Applicability of chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the village whether specifically licensed under another article in this chapter or not. 
(Code 1965, § 11.101) 
Sec. 10-2. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the public and for which admission is charged without having first secured a license therefor; provided that the provisions of this section shall not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed under any other ordinance of the village. 
(b)  Application; fee. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of the ordinances relating to such application. The fees for such licenses shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.102) 
Sec. 10-3. - Street shows. 
    No carnival, exhibition, show or other amusement shall be conducted on any public street or sidewalk, or in any public place, unless a permit therefor shall have been issued by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 11.103) 
Sec. 10-4. - Pool rooms. 
(a)  License required. No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain or conduct for profit within the village any public place for the purpose of providing a table or implements for the playing of billiards or pool without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  Application for license; fee. Application for a poolroom shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of chapter 22, article II. The annual fee for any such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(c)  Minors. Persons under the age of 17 years shall not, under any circumstances, frequent, loiter or remain at any time in any room licensed hereunder; and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor of any room so licensed to allow or permit any such persons to frequent, loiter or remain within the room in violation of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 11.104) 
Sec. 10-5. - Order; crowding. 
(a)  The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly and quiet at all times and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to permit such a crowd to witness any amusement, show or theatrical as to create a dangerous condition because of fire and other risks. 
(Code 1965, § 11.105) 
Sec. 10-6. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire marshal to see that every exhibition, amusement, show, theatrical or other public performance is inspected by a member of the police and fire departments, to insure conformity with the provisions concerning such amusements. 
(Code 1965, § 11.106) 
Sec. 10-7. - Obscene shows prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to present, exhibit, conduct or take part in any obscene, as such term is defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), show, theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of amusement or show. 
(Code 1965, § 11.107) 
Sec. 10-8. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.113) 
Secs. 10-9-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOWLING ALLEYS 

Sec. 10-31. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate, maintain or conduct for profit within the village any bowling alley, pin or ball alley without first having obtained a license therefor, as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 11.301) 
Sec. 10-32. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for any such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.302) 
Sec. 10-33. - Hours of operation. 
    No person shall keep open, operate or play upon any bowling alley, ball or pin alley, licensed hereunder, except during the times as may be established by ordinance from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.303) 
Sec. 10-34. - Minors. 
    Minors under the age of 18 years shall under no circumstances frequent, loiter, go to or remain in any hall licensed hereunder at any time, unless it be upon some errand and sent by the directions and with the consent and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the lawful custody of said minor; and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor of any hall so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter or remain within the hall in violation of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 11.304) 
Sec. 10-35. - Noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation keeping or conducting any such place to permit the patrons of the same to make loud and boisterous noises so as to disturb the peace in the vicinity. It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause any such noise in a bowling alley, ball or pin alley; or to congregate on the sidewalk or street in front of any such premises in such manner or in numbers as to obstruct foot or vehicle traffic along the street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 11.305) 
Sec. 10-36. - Game rooms. 
    Bowling alleys may provide a separate game room with up to 12 coin operated amusement devices, provided that these devices are in compliance with Chapter 10, Article X of the Hillside Municipal Code. The proprietor of the establishment will ensure that the room has adequate security and supervision at all times. Loitering will not be permitted at any time. 
(Ord. No. 10-20, § 1, 9-27-2010) 
Sec. 10-37. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.306; Ord. No. 10-20, § 1, 9-27-2010) 
Note- Formerly numbered as § 10-36. 
Secs. 10-38-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIRCUSES 

Sec. 10-61. - License required. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall conduct or operate a circus in the village without first having obtained a license as is provided in this article. 
(b)  Applications for such licenses shall be made to the clerk and shall specify the place in or on which the circus is to be conducted. 
(Code 1965, § 11.401) 
Sec. 10-62. - License fee. 
    The fee for such licenses shall be as established by the village board from time to time, and no license shall be issued without payment of this fee. 
(Code 1965, § 11.402) 
Sec. 10-63. - License fee for side shows and concessions. 
    The license fee for each side show and concession operated in connection with a circus shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.403) 
Sec. 10-64. - Compliance with applicable regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this article to obey the provisions of the article and all other ordinance provisions relating to circuses or the premises occupied. 
(Code 1965, § 11.404) 
Sec. 10-65. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire marshal to see that inspections as provided for in article I of this chapter shall be made of all circuses and circus performances and of the premises used. 
(Code 1965, § 11.405) 
Sec. 10-66. - Theft. 
    A person commits theft, which is hereby prohibited, when he knowingly: 
(1)  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; 
(2)  Obtains by deception control over property of the owner; 
(3)  Obtains by threat control over property of the owner; 
(4)  Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have been stolen or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him to believe that the property was stolen; or 
(5)  Obtains or exerts control over property in the custody of any law enforcement agency which is explicitly represented to him by any law enforcement officer or any individual acting in behalf of a law enforcement agency as being stolen; 
and intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property; knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or uses, conceals, or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit. 
(Code 1965, § 11.406) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/16-1. 
Sec. 10-67. - Parades. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct any parade connected with a circus on any public street, alley or other public way or place in the village unless a permit therefor is first obtained from the board of trustees. Such permit shall specify the route to be followed, and shall be accompanied by a bond in the sum of $10,000.00 conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss, damage or liability incurred or caused by the conduct of such exhibition or such parade. 
(Code 1965, § 11.407) 
Sec. 10-68. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.408) 
Secs. 10-69-10-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS 

Sec. 10-91. - License required; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion pictures or theatricals for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or charitable organization, without having first secured a license therefor as is herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 11.501) 
Sec. 10-92. - Application for license. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the general provisions relating to such applications and shall state in addition to the other information required the place of the intended performances and the seating capacity thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 11.502) 
Sec. 10-93. - Annual license fee. 
    Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures or theatricals naming a specific place or building where the performances are to be presented may present therein any number of performances, including theatricals, during the year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional fee under this article. The annual license fee shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.503) 
Sec. 10-94. - Premises not having annual license. 
    For motion pictures and theatricals which are to be presented in premises which are not covered by such annual license fee, the fee to be paid shall be as established by the village board from time to time. No such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented in or on any premises or building which does not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances for the construction and maintenance of buildings for this purpose. 
(Code 1965, § 11.504) 
Sec. 10-95. - Obscene motion pictures prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any person to offer or present any motion picture which is obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b). 
(Code 1965, § 11.505) 
Sec. 10-96. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.510) 
Secs. 10-97-10-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC DANCES 

Sec. 10-121. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the village without first having obtained a license therefor as is herein required. 
(Code 1965, § 11.601) 
Sec. 10-122. - Application for license. 
(a)  Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of the ordinances relating to licenses, and shall specify the location of the proposed dances and the person or organization sponsoring the same. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral character nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented by a person of good moral character. 
(Code 1965, § 11.602) 
Sec. 10-123. - Investigation. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant and report the results of such investigation to the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 11.603) 
Sec. 10-124. - License fee. 
    The fees for such public dances shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.604) 
Sec. 10-125. - Obscene or indecent conduct prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to indulge in or to permit any obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), conduct or any conduct constituting public indecency, as defined under 720 ILCS 5/11-9, at any public dance. 
(Code 1965, § 11.606) 
Sec. 10-126. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.607) 
Secs. 10-127-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RENTAL KART TRACKS 

Sec. 10-151. - Permit and license required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain, in the village, any rental kart track for amusement, without first having obtained a permit and license. 
(Code 1965, § 11.701) 
Sec. 10-152. - Application for permit and license. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring to construct, maintain or lease a rental kart track for amusement shall make application for a permit and license to the village clerk, in which application shall be set forth the full name and address of the applicant and the number of karts. 
(Code 1965, § 11.702) 
Sec. 10-153. - License fee. 
    The license fee shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.704) 
Sec. 10-154. - Track surface. 
    The track surface shall be asphalt or concrete. 
(Code 1965, § 11.705) 
Sec. 10-155. - Track length. 
    The track length shall be a minimum of 1/25 mile and a maximum of one-quarter mile. 
(Code 1965, § 11.706) 
Sec. 10-156. - Track width. 
    The width of the track shall be a minimum of 16 feet and a maximum of 34 feet. 
(Code 1965, § 11.707) 
Sec. 10-157. - Starting and stopping area. 
    There shall be an additional ten feet of width available on the main straight-away for the purpose of starting and stopping riders. 
(Code 1965, § 11.708) 
Sec. 10-158. - Safety apron. 
    A minimum of 20 feet must be maintained around the tracks on all sides. 
(Code 1965, § 11.709) 
Sec. 10-159. - Fencing generally. 
    The entire outside of the safety apron, around the track proper, must be fenced with a four-foot-high fence, with posts ten feet apart. Posts must be on the outside of the fence and protected with bales of hay. 
(Code 1965, § 11.710) 
Sec. 10-160. - Type of fence. 
    The fencing required by section 10-159 shall be of galvanized welded type fence 16-gauge two-inch by 2 5/8 -inch mesh, or chain link fence nine-gauge two-inch mesh, or 16-gauge wire four-inch opening, or a solid wood fence. 
(Code 1965, § 11.711) 
Sec. 10-161. - Spectator area. 
    Each rental kart track shall be provided with a safe area for spectators and parking, which must be separated from the track. 
(Code 1965, § 11.712) 
Sec. 10-162. - Lighting. 
    General and track lighting should be adequate and so designed for good visibility on the part of drivers as well as spectators. A minimum candle power of ten footcandles is required. Location should be such that glare in the driver's eyes is reduced to a minimum. The base of the poles shall be on the outside of the fence. 
(Code 1965, § 11.713) 
Sec. 10-163. - Speed. 
    The maximum speed shall be 15 miles per hour. 
(Code 1965, § 11.714) 
Sec. 10-164. - Kart specifications. 
    Each kart rented at a rental kart track must meet the following specifications and requirements: 
(1)  Wheel base: Maximum 50 inches, minimum 40 inches as measured from the axle centers. Kart maximum overall length 72 inches. 
(2)  Tread width: Minimum of two-thirds the measurement of the wheelbase. 
(3)  Height: Maximum of 24 inches measured at center of seat back. 
(4)  Tire size: Maximum 12.5 inches, minimum nine inches, of a type incorporating a pneumatic tire. 
(5)  Wheels: To incorporate bearings of ground ball, or roller type only. 
(6)  Axle ends: Must be cottered, keyed or safety wired. 
(7)  Frame: Must be all metal. There may be a safety shell located above the wheel centers, constructed of a plastic, or metal material. 
(8)  Firewall and floor plan: Metal firewall between driver and engine. No void is allowable in either the floor plan or firewall. 
(9)  Steering: Must be direct and of a suitable design for maximum safety. Linkage bolts and nuts must be cottered, keyed or safety wired. All rod ends must be universal type swivel joints. 
(10)  Engines: All engines must be mounted behind the driver and must have mufflers on. Exhaust systems must be such that exhaust gases are carried away from the driver. 
(11)  Gear box: No type of gear box will be permitted. 
(12)  Brakes: All karts must have pedal operated brakes, working in such manner as to brake both rear wheels equally and adequately. 
(13)  Clutches: It is mandatory that all karts be equipped with clutches. 
(14)  Throttle: Must be equipped with a foot operated throttle with self-returning spring. 
(15)  Ignition: Off and on ignition switch within easy reach of the driver and in front of the firewall is mandatory. All engines must have a protective covering on the end of spark plug. 
(16)  Driver's compartment: All karts must be equipped with side rails, being a maximum of four inches above the seat. 
(17)  Fuel tanks: Fuel tanks must be mounted in back of the driver. 
(18)  Rear and front bumpers: Rear and front bumpers are mandatory and must be so constructed that they will not become easily hooked with another kart. 
(19)  Roll bars and safety seat belts: Not permitted. 
(Code 1965, § 11.715) 
Sec. 10-165. - Number of karts on track. 
    The maximum number of karts permitted on a track at one time is as follows, based on length of the track: 
(1)  One-twenty-fifth mile to one-half mile: Maximum six karts. 
(2)  One-tenth mile to one-eighth mile: Maximum ten karts. 
(3)  One-eighth mile to one-fourth mile: Maximum 12 karts. 
(Code 1965, § 11.716) 
Sec. 10-166. - Competitions. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall use any such track for competition. 
(Code 1965, § 11.717) 
Sec. 10-167. - Insurance. 
    Any firm, person or corporation making application for a permit and license for the construction and operation of a rental kart track must furnish the village with a certificate or memorandum of liability insurance. 
(Code 1965, § 11.718) 
Sec. 10-168. - Limit on number of tracks. 
    Rental kart tracks shall be limited to one within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 11.720) 
Sec. 10-169. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.719) 
Secs. 10-170-10-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AUTOMATIC MUSICAL DEVICES 

Sec. 10-191. - Definition. 
    As use in this article, the term "automatic musical device" means any phonograph, piano player, music box, "juke box" or other instrument or device capable of producing or reproducing any vocal or instrumental sounds, other than a motion picture sound machine, which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a coin or token. 
(Code 1965, § 11.801) 
Sec. 10-192. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall keep or permit to be kept, for gain or profit from operation within the village, any automatic musical instrument without first having obtained a license as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 11.802) 
Sec. 10-193. - Application for license. 
    An application for said license shall be made to the clerk, in conformity with chapter 22, article II, except as otherwise herein provided. In addition, the applicant shall set forth the description of the automatic musical instrument or instruments intended to be kept for use on his premises. 
(Code 1965, § 11.803) 
Sec. 10-194. - License fee; term of license. 
    The annual fee for such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.804) 
Sec. 10-195. - Transfer of license. 
    No license issued to any person, firm or corporation shall be transferable. 
(Code 1965, § 11.805) 
Sec. 10-196. - Prohibited acts. 
    No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of any automatic musical instrument at any place or in any manner which will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed premises. No obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), selections shall be played on any such instrument. 
(Code 1965, § 11.806) 
Sec. 10-197. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or permit the operation of any coin-operated music device licensed hereunder other than during the hours open for business. 
(Code 1965, § 11.808) 
Sec. 10-198. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.807) 
Secs. 10-199-10-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - GOLF DRIVING RANGES 

Sec. 10-221. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain within the village any golf driving ranges without having first obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of chapter 22, article II. 
(Code 1965, § 11.901) 
Sec. 10-222. - License fee. 
    The license fee for any self drivisn range shall be $250.00 per year. 
(Code 1965, § 11.902; Ord. No. 07-29, § 1, 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 10-223. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.904) 
Secs. 10-224-10-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PROMOTIONAL AMUSEMENT RIDES 

Sec. 10-251. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "promotional amusement ride" means any animal, vehicle or device used or designed to carry or transport persons with or without charge in an entertaining manner for the purpose of creating or renewing interest in a sponsoring business enterprise. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1001) 
Sec. 10-252. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain within the village any promotional amusement ride without having first obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of chapter 22, article II. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1002) 
Sec. 10-253. - License fee. 
    The fee for such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1003) 
Sec. 10-254. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1004) 
Secs. 10-255-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES 

Sec. 10-281. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-operated amusement device means any fortune-telling machines, palm reading machines, and machines or devices for games of skill and science which return the player thereof no money or property or right to receive money or property, and which are governed or controlled by the insertion of a coin, token currency or similar object. 
    Simulated video gaming device means video poker machines, video slot machines, video bingo machines, and other devices which involve any game or amusement based upon poker, blackjack, dog racing, or horse racing, craps, or any card or dice game, or similar amusement machines or devices operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, currency or similar object. 
    Video gaming terminal shall be defined as that term is defined under Section 5 of the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/5, as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1101; Ord. No. 12-06, § 2, 5-21-2012) 
Sec. 10-282. - License; prohibited devices. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall locate or maintain or operate within the village any coin-operated amusement device for use by the public without first having obtained a local coin-operated amusement device license therefor, as herein provided. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall locate or maintain within the village any video gaming terminal without first having obtained a State location license in accordance with the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., and a local video gaming location license, as herein provided. The loss or suspension of a State location license shall automatically result in the same status for the local video gaming license issued hereunder, without refund of any license fee. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation shall be issued a local video gaming location license on or after April 8, 2013 without first having obtained a local liquor license of one of the following classes: 
(1)  Class A-1 license, as defined under section 6-46(1) of Chapter 6, Article II of this Code; 
(2)  Class A-3 license, as defined under section 6-46(4) of Chapter 6, Article II of this Code; 
(3)  Class A-4 license, as defined under section 6-46(5) of Chapter 6, Article II of this Code; or 
(4)  Class C license, as defined under Section 6-46(10) of Chapter 6, Article II of this Code. 
The loss or suspension of a local liquor license shall automatically result in the same status for the local video gaming license issued hereunder, without refund of any license fee. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1102; Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 5-21-2012; Ord. No. 13-08, § 2, 4-22-2013) 
Sec. 10-283. - Application for license. 
    An application for a local coin-operated amusement device license or a local video gaming location license shall be made to the village clerk in conformity with chapter 22, article II of this Code, except as otherwise provided herein. In addition, the application shall set forth the location and character of the building or place where such coin-operated amusement devices or video gaming terminals are to be located, maintained or operated, the number and type of such devices or terminals to be so located, and the main or principal occupation or business being conducted or to be conducted by the applicant upon the same premises where wherein such devices or terminals are to be located, maintained or operated. Further, an application for a local video gaming location license shall include a copy of the corresponding state location license. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1103; Ord. No. 12-06, § 4, 5-21-2012) 
Sec. 10-284. - Limitation of number of devices. 
    Except as provided in section 10-36 of this chapter, no more than six coin-operated amusement devices may be located, maintained or operated in or upon any single business establishment, and no such device or devices shall be located, maintained or operated unless the location, maintenance or operation thereof is secondary or incidental to the main or principal occupation or business being conducted or to be conducted by the applicant in or upon said establishment. 
    The location, maintenance, and operation of all video gaming terminals shall be subject to and in accordance with the regulations, requirements, and restrictions set forth in the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1104; Ord. No. 10-22, § 1, 9-27-2010; Ord. No. 12-06, § 4, 5-21-2012) 
Sec. 10-285. - License fee; posting of decals. 
(a)  The annual fee for a local coin-operated amusement device license shall be as established by the village board from time to time, and a separate decal or sticker, to be issued by the village clerk, shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each coin-operated amusement device when in use. 
(b)  The annual fee for a local video gaming location license shall be $1,000.00. A separate decal or sticker, to be issued by the village clerk, shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each video gaming terminal when in use. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1105; Ord. No. 12-06, § 5, 5-21-2012) 
Sec. 10-286. - Transfer of license. 
    No license issued to any person, firm or corporation under this article shall be transferable. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1106) 
Sec. 10-287. - Disturbing the peace; creation of nuisance. 
    No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of a coin-operated amusement device or video gaming terminal at any place or in any manner which will disturb the peace of persons otherwise properly within or without the licensed premises, or shall permit the operation thereof to amount to a nuisance in fact. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1107; Ord. No. 12-06, § 6, 5-21-2012) 
Sec. 10-288. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 11.1108) 
Secs. 10-289-10-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - GOLF COURSES 

Sec. 10-326. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain within the Village, any golf course without having first obtained a license therefore. Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of chapter 22, article II. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 1, 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 10-327. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for such license shall be $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 1, 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 10-328. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during, on or which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 1, 9-24-2007) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Cruelty. 
(a)  General prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously inflict unnecessary or needless cruelty, torture, or abuse upon or cruelly beat, strike or abuse any animal, or by an act, omission or neglect cause or inflict any unnecessary or unjustifiable pain, suffering, injury or death to any animal, whether such animal belongs to such person or to another, except that reasonable force may be employed to drive away vicious or trespassing animals. Any unwanted animals should be delivered to the licensed veterinarian. 
(b)  Care of animals; carrying animal on vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any animal to fail, refuse, or neglect to provide such animal with food, potable water, shade or shelter; to cruelly or unnecessarily expose any such animal in hot, stormy, cold or inclement weather; or to carry any such animal in or upon any vehicle in a cruel or inhumane manner. 
(c)  Definitions . For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Shade means protection from the direct rays of the sun during the months of June through September. 
    Shelter , as it applies to dogs, means a moisture-proof structure of suitable size to accommodate the dog and allow retention of body heat, made of durable material with a solid floor raised at least two inches from the ground and with the entrance covered by a flexible, windproof material. Such structure shall be provided with a sufficient quantity of suitable bedding 
(Code 1965, § 19.101) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to prohibit cruelty to animals, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-6. 
Sec. 14-2. - Dangerous or vicious animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous animal or any vicious animal of any kind to run at large within the village. Exhibitions or parades of animals which are ferae naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit from the chief of police. 
(Code 1965, § 19.102) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to prohibit the running at large of animals, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-9. 
Sec. 14-3. - Noisy animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. 
(Code 1965, § 19.103) 
Sec. 14-4. - Keeping certain animals prohibited; maximum number of dogs and cats. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep any cattle, horses, swine, sheep, goats, poultry, pigeons or bees in the village. Further, it shall be unlawful to keep more than three dogs and/or three cats in or about any residential house or separate duplex or apartment unit in the village, except that in addition and regardless of number, any puppies or kittens produced by a female dog or cat kept on any such premises may also be kept on such premises until said puppies or kittens are three months old. 
(Code 1965, § 19.104; Ord. No. 05-22, § 1, 8-22-2005) 
Sec. 14-5. - Removal of excrement. 
    No person shall appear with a pet animal upon the public ways or within public places or upon the property of another in the absence of the owner's consent, without some means for the removal of excrement, nor shall any such person fail to remove any excrement deposited thereon by such pet. This section shall not apply to a blind person while walking his guide dog. 
(Code 1965, § 19.104.1) 
Sec. 14-6. - Killing dangerous animals. 
    The members of the police department or any other person in the village are authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind when necessary for the protection of any person or property. 
(Code 1965, § 19.105) 
Sec. 14-7. - Diseased animals. 
(a)  No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious disease or an infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large, or to be exposed in any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected; nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof, except under the supervision of the health officer. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the health officer to secure such disposition of any diseased animal and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication and spread of contagion or infection, except in cases where the state veterinarian is empowered to act. 
(Code 1965, § 19.106) 
Sec. 14-8. - Small animal farms. 
(a)  Permit. It shall be unlawful to conduct, operate or maintain in the village any small animal farm, or place where animals that are ferae naturae, not domestic, are kept or raised, without having first secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made in compliance with the provisions of chapter 22, article II, and the annual fee therefor shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(b)  Cleanliness; fencing. Any premises so used shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, with adequate fences to restrain such animals within the place and to prevent children from coming into contact with any such animal. All such places shall be cleaned at least twice a week and so much oftener as may be necessary to prevent the accumulation of refuse, decaying matter or any other offensive substance thereon; and such places shall be kept from rodents. 
(Code 1965, § 19.107) 
Sec. 14-9. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 19.108) 
Secs. 14-10-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS AND CATS 

Sec. 14-31. - Registration required. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, keeping or harboring any dog or cat in the village to register the same with the village clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 19.201) 
Sec. 14-32. - Registration procedures; tags. 
(a)  Annual free registration of dogs and cats shall commence May 1 and terminate April 30 of the following year. 
(b)  The person registering a dog or cat shall receive a license tag, containing such lettering as may be directed by the village administrator. 
(c)  Every dog and/or cat kept in the village shall be equipped with a collar, and a tag fastened to such collar at all times when such dog and/or cat is on any public street, alley or other public place. Any dog or cat which does not have such tag while in or upon any public street shall be deemed to be a stray and shall be impounded. 
(d)  The village clerk shall keep a dog and cat register book, in which shall be listed the owners of all such dogs and cats in the village, with a description of said animal. 
(Code 1965, § 19.203) 
Sec. 14-33. - Muzzles. 
    Whenever the village president shall, by proclamation, declare that danger from rabies is great, it shall be unlawful to permit any dog or cat to go upon any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place unless such dog or cat is securely muzzled. 
(Code 1965, § 19.204) 
Sec. 14-34. - Dog and cat bites. 
    Whenever any dog or cat bites a person, the owner of said dog or cat shall immediately notify the police department, which shall order the dog or cat held on the owner's premises or shall have it impounded for a period of two weeks. The dog or cat shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of the two-week period. If, at the end of two weeks, a veterinarian is convinced that the dog or cat is then free from rabies, the dog or cat shall be released from quarantine or from the pound, as the case may be. If the dog or cat dies in the meantime, its head shall be sent to the state department of health for examination for rabies. 
(Code 1965, § 19.205) 
Sec. 14-35. - Running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to permit any dog or cat to run at large in the village at any time. Dogs and cats which are on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place without being held securely on a leash shall be deemed running at large. 
(b)  Dogs and cats which are running at large shall be taken upon and impounded by the police department. 
(Code 1965, § 19.206) 
Sec. 14-36. - Dogs and cats menacing persons on adjacent property. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit an unattended dog or cat, when tethered in an unenclosed yard, to be able to come within five feet of the yard lot lines, thereby placing persons lawfully upon adjacent streets, alleys or property in fear of their personal safety by reason of the menacing manner of the dog or cat, whether or not the danger was real or merely perceived. 
(Code 1965, § 19.206.1) 
Sec. 14-37. - Payment of impoundment fees. 
    Any person seeking to redeem any impounded dog or cat shall pay any and all fees incurred for caring for the dog or cat for each day during which said dog or cat has been held in the pound. 
(Code 1965, § 19.207) 
Sec. 14-38. - Care of impounded animals; disposition of unredeemed animals. 
    Dogs or cats which are kept in the village's designated impoundment facility shall be humanely treated and fed. Such pound shall be in the charge of the chief of police, who shall be responsible for the care and custody of the same. Unredeemed dogs and/or cats shall be disposed of as provided by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 19.208) 
Sec. 14-39. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1965, § 19.209) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to construct, alter or repair any building or structure in the village without complying with all construction regulations set forth in this Code or adopted by reference herein. 
(Code 1965, § 21.101) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to adopt building code, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-2. 
Sec. 18-2. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 21.102) 
Secs. 18-3-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 18-31-18-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING INSPECTOR 

Sec. 18-51. - Creation of office; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the position of building inspector, who shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.201) 
Sec. 18-52. - Duties; compensation. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector to see to the compliance with and enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to buildings or zoning in the village and to inspect all buildings or structures being constructed, repaired or altered or which may appear to be substandard, as frequently as may be necessary to insure compliance with the village ordinances. The building inspector shall receive such compensation as may be decided from time to time by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.202) 
Sec. 18-53. - Building inspector to act as plumbing inspector. 
    The building inspector shall act as ex officio plumbing inspector and shall have the powers and perform all the duties connected with that office. 
(Code 1965, § 4.203) 
Sec. 18-54. - Building inspector to act as electrical inspector. 
    The building inspector shall act as ex officio electrical inspector and shall have the powers and perform all the duties connected with that office. 
(Code 1965, § 4.204) 
Sec. 18-55. - Stop orders. 
    The building inspector shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction, alteration or repair of buildings in the village when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any ordinance relating thereto or in violation of the zoning ordinance. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written permission of the building inspector; provided, however, that if the stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour. Such stop order may be served by any police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 4.205) 
Sec. 18-56. - Citations. 
    If the building inspector, upon inspection or investigation, shall determine that an individual, firm or corporation has violated or is in violation of any provision of this Code relating to the construction, alteration, repair, maintenance or condition of any building or structure located within the limits of the village, the building inspector shall be empowered to serve such person, firm or corporation with a written citation specifying the date, time, location, nature of the violation and applicable Code provision. 
(Code 1965, § 4.205.1) 
Sec. 18-57. - Entry powers. 
    The building inspector shall have the power to make or cause to be made an entry into any building or premises where work of altering, repairing or constructing of any building or structure is going on for the purpose of making inspections at any reasonable hour. 
(Code 1965, § 4.206) 
Sec. 18-58. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall continue to work in violation of a stop order of the building inspector shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each day on which any work in violation of such stop order is done. 
(Code 1965, § 4.207) 
Secs. 18-59-18-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR 

Sec. 18-81. - Creation of office; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the position of electrical inspector, who shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.301) 
Sec. 18-82. - Powers. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the electrical equipment therein; and he shall have the authority to enforce all the ordinance provisions relating to the electrical wiring and equipment. He shall have the power to cause the current in any wire or conduit to be turned off whenever this is necessary in an emergency for the protection of life and property. 
(Code 1965, § 4.302) 
Sec. 18-83. - Duties; compensation. 
    The electrical inspector shall make all inspections necessary to determine that the installation and condition of electrical apparatus and wiring installed within the village fully complies with the ordinances of the village, and no electric wiring shall be covered until it has been inspected and approved. The electrical inspector shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be fixed by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.303) 
Sec. 18-84. - Certificate of approval. 
    The electrical inspector shall give a certificate of approval to the owner or person in charge of premises which he has inspected where he finds that the electrical apparatus and wiring therein fully comply with the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 4.304) 
Sec. 18-85. - Stop orders. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction or alteration or repair of buildings in the village when such work is being done in violation of any provisions of any ordinances relating thereto, or in violation of the zoning ordinance. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except upon the written permission of the inspector; provided, however, that if the stop order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour. Such written stop order may be served by any police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 4.305) 
Sec. 18-86. - Citations. 
    If the electrical inspector, upon inspection or investigation, shall determine that an individual, firm or corporation has violated or is in violation of any provision of this Code relating to the installation, repair, maintenance or condition of any electrical wiring or equipment in or about any building or structure located within the limits of the village, the electrical inspector shall be empowered to serve such person, firm or corporation with a written citation specifying the date, time, location, nature of the violation and applicable Code provision. The citation shall also contain instructions for the manner of paying such penalty to the office of the village collector. 
(Code 1965, § 4.305.1) 
Sec. 18-87. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall continue work in violation of a stop order of the electrical inspector shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which any work in violation of such order is done. 
(Code 1965, § 4.306) 
Secs. 18-88-18-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLUMBING INSPECTOR 

Sec. 18-111. - Creation of office; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the position of plumbing inspector, who shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 4.401) 
Sec. 18-112. - Powers. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection or test of the plumbing equipment therein; and he shall have the authority to enforce all the ordinance provisions relating to plumbing. 
(Code 1965, § 4.402) 
Sec. 18-113. - Duties; compensation. 
    The plumbing inspector shall make inspections necessary to determine that the installation and condition of plumbing apparatus and sewer and water lines installed within the village fully complies with the ordinances of the village, and no pipe or water mains shall be covered until they have been inspected and approved. The plumbing inspector shall receive such compensation as may from time to time be fixed by the village board. 
(Code 1965, § 4.403) 
Sec. 18-114. - Stop orders. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction or alteration or repair of buildings in the village when such work is being done in violation of any provisions of any ordinances relating thereto, or in violation of the zoning ordinance. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order, except upon the written permission of the inspector; provided, however, that if the stop work order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order within an hour. Such written stop order may be served by any police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 4.404) 
Sec. 18-115. - Citations. 
    If the plumbing inspector, upon inspection or investigation, shall determine that an individual, firm or corporation has violated or is in violation of any provision of this Code relating to the installation, repair, maintenance or condition of any plumbing lines or equipment in or about any building or structure located within the limits of the village, the plumbing inspector shall be empowered to serve such person, firm or corporation with a written citation specifying the date, time, location, nature of the violation and applicable Code provision. The citation shall also contain instructions for the manner of paying such penalty to the office of the village collector. 
(Code 1965, § 4.404.1) 
Sec. 18-116. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall continue work in violation of a stop order of the plumbing inspector shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which any work in violation of such order is done. 
(Code 1965, § 4.405) 
Secs. 18-117-18-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CERTIFICATES OF COMPLIANCE AND TEMPORARY OCCUPANCY PERMITS 

Sec. 18-141. - Applicability. 
    This division shall apply to all improved single-family residential properties located within the corporate boundaries of the village hereinafter described. 
(Code 1965, § 21.801; Ord. No. 04-17A, § 1, 10-25-2004) 
Sec. 18-142. - Exemptions. 
    This division shall not apply to transfers of title by tax deeds or sheriff's deeds, or other transfers made pursuant to orders issued by county, state or federal courts. 
(Code 1965, § 21.802; Ord. No. 04-17A, § 1, 10-25-2004) 
Sec. 18-143. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Codes. The term "codes" shall be limited to those definitions set forth in section 18-144. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation or trustee. 
    Real property means all improved real estate located within the corporate boundaries of the village. 
    Transfer. Transfer of real property means any conveyance whether by deed, articles of agreement for deed, or assignment of the beneficial interest under a land trust pursuant to a contract of sale for good and valuable consideration other than nominal consideration. 
    Village administrator means the duly appointed village administrator of the Village of Hillside or his duly appointed agents or assistants. 
(Code 1965, § 21.803) 
Sec. 18-144. - Applicable codes. 
    Codes as defined in section 18-143 shall include: 
(1)  Electrical requirements. (as noted in the Chicago Electrical Code): 
a.  Three prong receptacles in all outlets including garage. 
b.  GFI (Ground Fault Interrupters) protection on all outlets within six feet of water and any outside receptacles including garage. 
c.  100 amp. service. (Note: Any 100 amp. service upgrade must be done by a licensed electrical contractor with a Village of Hillside electrical permit). 
d.  Smoke detectors on each level (including basement) and one within 15 feet of each sleeping area. 
(2)  Property maintenance conditions. (as noted in the International Property Maintenance Code): 
a.  Peeling paint. 
b.  Condition of gutters and downspouts. 
c.  Broken/cracked windows. 
d.  Rotted/missing wood. 
e.  Garbage or debris accumulated or scattered on property. 
f.  Condition of fencing. 
g.  Tuckpointing. 
h.  Condition of driveway (stone or gravel driveways are prohibited). 
(3)  Sewer conditions. (as noted by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago). 
a.  Gutters and downspouts. 
b.  Sump pump. 
c.  Floor drains. 
(Code 1965, art. VIII, schedule A; Ord. No. 04-06, § 1, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 18-145. - Duty of persons transferring property to have property inspected; issuance of certificate of compliance. 
(a)  Any person entering into a contract for the sale or rental of real estate within the corporate boundaries of the village shall be required to apply to the village administrator for an inspection of the real estate being sold or rented. Upon receipt of the said application for said inspection and payment of the inspection fee, as hereinafter provided, the village administrator shall cause such property to be inspected. In the event the property inspected is found to be in compliance with the building code and zoning code of the village as provided for in section 18-144, the village administrator shall then immediately cause a certificate to be issued stating that the said property is in compliance with said codes. If violations of said codes are found to exist, the village administrator shall, as soon as practicable, but in no event later than 30 days following such inspection, provide the applicant with a detailed report of the violations to be corrected. The person in title, beneficiary of the land trust, purchaser or renter of the subject real property shall then be given a reasonable time in which to correct such violations. In the event the purchaser or renter of such real property is to undertake the required corrections, he shall first file a statement with the village administrator, duly sworn before a notary public, that he is aware of said violations and is willing to take title or leasehold subject to same, and make the necessary corrections. In the event the required corrections are not made within the time specified by the village administrator, he may cause suit to be commenced against the person in title and all other parties in interest in the appropriate court for the purpose of enforcing full compliance with the applicable codes. If violations are disclosed which, in the opinion of the village administrator, render the subject real property unsafe for habitation, the village administrator may order that the said real property shall not be occupied until all corrections necessary to render the subject property habitable are made. Upon correction of all violations specified by the village administrator, he shall then issue the required certificate of compliance. 
(b)  The issuance of this certificate shall in no way be construed to be a guarantee by the village that the structure is free from any defects, whether latent or patent. Also, this certificate provides no guarantee that future violations cannot or will not occur at the inspected site. 
(Code 1965, § 21.804; Ord. No. 09-12, § 2, 5-19-2009) 
Sec. 18-146. - Application form for certificate of compliance. 
    The village administrator shall supply application forms that specify the address of the real property being transferred, and the improvement or improvements located thereon. Said application shall also set forth the fee as required by this division. 
(Code 1965, § 21.805) 
Sec. 18-147. - Time for filing application for certificate of compliance. 
    The application for inspection as provided for herein shall be filed no less than 30 days prior to the proposed transfer of the real property. 
(Code 1965, § 21.806) 
Sec. 18-148. - Transfer of certificate of compliance. 
    The certificate of compliance referred to herein shall be transferable upon subsequent transfers of title of the same property made within six months after the date of issuance, provided that each subsequent purchaser shall execute a supplementary application to be made a part of the original application. Further, a statement duly executed and sworn before a notary public shall be filed by the party in title, or beneficiary of a title holding land trust, stating that no structural or mechanical system changes have been made to the property since the last inspection was completed. Transfers of the same real property made after six months from the date of issuance of the original certificate of compliance shall be subject to reinspection and payment of fees in accordance with the provisions of this division as if no previous inspection had been made. 
(Code 1965, § 21.807) 
Sec. 18-149. - Records of certificates of compliance; temporary occupancy permits. 
    A record of all certificates shall be kept on file in the office of the village clerk and copies shall be furnished on request to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building affected. Pending the satisfactory completion of all work necessary to bring the building into compliance, a temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued. Such temporary certificate shall not be construed as in any way altering the respective rights, duties or obligations of the owners or of the village relating to the use or occupancy of the premises or any other matter covered by this division, and such temporary certificate shall not be issued except under such restrictions and provisions as will adequately insure the safety of the occupants. No temporary certificate shall be issued if, prior to the completion of necessary corrections, the building does not comply with the building code or this division to such a degree as to render it unsafe for the occupancy proposed. A fee for each temporary occupancy permit shall be the same as charged for a certificate of compliance. 
(Code 1965, § 21.808) 
Sec. 18-150. - Fee. 
    For residential property, the combined fee for said inspection, permit and/or certificate shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 21.809) 
Sec. 18-151. - Penalties; additional remedies. 
(a)  Any person who wilfully violates the provisions of this division shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. Violation of any of the terms of this division shall be deemed a continuing violation, subject to the penalties provided for herein. 
(b)  In addition to the foregoing penalties, the village may also maintain a civil action against the violator to compel compliance with the codes of the village and statutes of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 21.810) 
Sec. 18-152. - Savings clause. 
    This division shall not affect suits pending or rights existing at the time this division takes effect, but such suits and rights shall continue in force to the same extent and with like effect as if this division had not been enacted. This division shall not be construed or held to avoid or impair any cause of action now existing under any ordinance of the village, or amendments thereto, but such actions shall be continued in full force and effect. 
(Code 1965, § 21.811) 
Secs. 18-153-18-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 18-201. - BOCA National Building Code adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing the construction, alteration or repair of any building in the village, the regulations contained in that certain code known as the BOCA National Building Code recommended by the Building Officials Conference of America, Inc., being particularly the 1999 edition as modified by subsequent triennial supplements issued by said corporation up to the date of adoption of this Code of Ordinances. Not less than three copies of said code have been and now are filed in the office of the village clerk. The provisions thereof, as amended, pertaining to the construction, alteration or repair of the above described residential buildings, are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and shall be controlling within the limits of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 21.501) 
Sec. 18-202. - Termination of permit upon abandonment of work. 
    Any permit issued shall become invalid if the authorized work is suspended or abandoned for a period of three months after the time of commencing the work.
