Nothing in the BOCA National Building Code shall require changes in the plans, construction or designated use of a building for which a lawful permit has been heretofore issued or otherwise lawfully authorized, and the construction of which shall have been actively prosecuted within three months after the effective date of the issuance of the permit or of the lawful authorization of such work; and the entire building shall be completed as authorized within nine months after the date of such issuance or authorization unless the permit or authority is extended for one or more successive terms not to exceed three months each, provided each such extension has the prior written approval of the majority of the members of the building committee of the board of trustees. This section supersedes sections 112.2 and 112.3 of the 1999 BOCA National Building Code, which sections are deemed to be deleted therefrom insofar as said 1999 National Building Code has been otherwise adopted by reference as a part of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 21.501.2) 
Sec. 18-203. - Permit fees. 
(a)  The fee for each building permit shall be as established from time to time by the village board. 
(b)  A surcharge, equal to 50 percent of the applicable permit fees, shall be included in the aggregate permit fee computation if construction is started prior to the approval of the issuance of the permit. This section supersedes sections 117.3, 117.4 and 117.5 of the BOCA National Building Code, which sections are deemed to be deleted therefrom insofar as said building code has been otherwise adopted by reference as a part of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 21.501.3) 
Sec. 18-204. - Fire resistance. 
    The provisions of this section shall apply only to all multi-family structures which contain three or more living units, or to any other structures designed to be used or being used for any business, commercial or industrial purpose. 
(1)  All interior load bearing walls, tenant separation walls or party walls shall be constructed of masonry or concrete. 
(2)  All floors shall be constructed of precast or poured concrete. 
(3)  All exterior wall construction shall be of masonry. 
(4)  All of the foregoing structural elements, together with all roof areas, shall have a minimum two-hour fire resistance rating. 
(5)  All non-structural elements and interior walls shall be constructed of non-combustible materials. 
(6)  A minimum 5/8 -inch wallboard shall be installed in all areas of construction. 
(7)  A smoke partition wall at a minimum shall separate tenant spaces. 
(Code 1965, § 21.501.4; Ord. No. 06-01, 1-23-2006) 
Sec. 18-205. - Screening of roof-mounted mechanical equipment. 
    All heating, air conditioning, ventilating, or other mechanical equipment mounted on the roof of any structure located in a B-1 general business district, a B-2 planned shopping center district, an M-1 office and restricted industrial district, an M-2 industrial district or an M-3 limited industrial district, as those districts are defined in the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980, shall be enclosed, or otherwise totally screened for the entire height of the equipment, in such a manner as to mask such equipment from public view. 
(Code 1965, § 21.501.5) 
Sec. 18-206. - Demolition, wrecking and moving. 
    The requirements of this section shall apply to demolition, wrecking or moving of structures. The owner of a building or structure and/or his agent, upon meeting all village requirements and issuance of permits, is required to remove, in addition to the building or structure, all of the foundation, foundation attachments and old pavement in their entirety. All materials and debris shall be properly disposed of by a licensed village refuse carrier. An adequate amount of village approved backfill shall be provided, compressed to a degree of 95 percent proctor, leveled to grade and seeded with not less than six inches of topsoil. All common areas, including but not limited to streets, sidewalks and alleys, shall be returned to a condition satisfactory to the village, exclusive to ordinary wear and tear. 
(Code 1965, § 21.501.6) 
Sec. 18-207. - Grading and altering of the grade of property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to add or deposit dirt, clay or any other material on any real estate parcel within the village which would result in the alteration of the topography of the site to a degree where adjacent properties will be adversely effected or potentially adversely effected from water run-off, drainage matters or otherwise. 
(b)  A person desiring to place dirt, clay or other material on a parcel of real estate within the village which may potentially change the topography of said parcel shall first secure a permit from the village allowing for the deposit of landfill of any nature. 
There shall be a non-refundable fee for the permit payable at the time of application as fixed by the village board from time to time. 
(c)  Said person must present to the village a topography rendering or sketch depicting the existing contours of the entire site to be affected and all adjoining parcel within 100 feet thereof and the proposed contours resulting from the addition of any landfill. The rendering or sketch shall be done at a scale which is easily legible and shall include property lines, structures, drive-ways, sidewalks, easements and similar items, including dimensions of each. The proposed rendering or sketch view must indicate the point at which storm water run-off will exist on the site and evidencing that there will be no effect on adjacent properties. 
(d)  Said person shall post with the office of the village clerk a $150.00 cash bond to guaranty and assure compliance with the terms and conditions stated herein. Upon completion of the material deposits and alterations, presuming that said person has otherwise complied with all terms and conditions hereof and has not caused an adverse effect to adjacent properties, said bond shall be refunded by the village clerk. 
The rendering of sketch shall include the name and address of the property owner, the address of the property being altered by the addition of landfill and the addresses of adjacent properties in 100 feet in each direction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 05-23, § 1, 8-22-05) 
Sec. 18-208. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 21.502; Ord. No. 05-23, § 1, 8-22-2005) 
Editor's note- Formerly numbered as § 18-207. 
Secs. 18-209-18-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-231. - Chicago electrical code adopted. 
    The Chicago electrical code, formulated by the electrical commission of the City of Chicago, the adoption of which, together with all amendments thereto as of the date of adoption of this Code of Ordinances, has been duly recommended by the village electrical commission, is hereby adopted by reference, pursuant to authority of 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4, of which Chicago electrical code not less than three copies have been and now are filed in the office of the village clerk, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out in length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling henceforth within the limits of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 21.201) 
Sec. 18-232. - Installation of electrical system on test basis. 
    Notwithstanding any provision set forth or incorporated by reference in this article to the contrary, the president and board of trustees may authorize the electrical inspector, from time to time, to grant a permit to install an electrical system in any building located within the village, which system may vary from those systems specifically permitted by this article, subject to the following pre-conditions: 
(1)  Authorization may be granted only in those instances wherein the village electrical commission shall have certified the use of the system on a test basis during a period not to exceed 24 consecutive months unless otherwise extended by the commission. 
(2)  The permit shall provide that, during the test period, the electrical inspector will be notified by the building owner or occupants of any operational problems which might develop in the system and of any changes or alterations which, for any reason, are to be made in the original design of the system exclusive of relocation of outlets to accommodate any change in location of work areas. 
(3)  The permit shall further provide that, during the test period or any extended period during which the system remains in place, the electrical inspector will be allowed continual access during normal business hours to the interior of the building for the purpose of enabling the inspector to make periodic inspections of the system to ascertain its safe condition and operation. 
(4)  At any time during the test period, the commission may (and at the conclusion of the test period shall) conduct a public hearing for the purpose of determining the results of the test and the proper course of action to be taken by the commission and the village to insure the safety of building occupants and members of the surrounding community. 
(5)  If, as a result of such hearing, the commission shall make findings of fact and shall conclude that the system meets all minimum standards of safety as may be recommended from time to time by the commission and made a part of this article by amendment, then this article may be further amended to provide for the installation or retention within the village of the same or any like system which has specifications at least equal to those of the test system. However, in the alternative, the commission may certify an extension of the test period if the test results are deemed inconclusive by the commission, or may recommend to the president and board of trustees the immediate removal of the test system if the commission finds that it has failed to meet all such minimum standards of safety. 
(Code 1965, § 21.201.1) 
Sec. 18-233. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 21.202) 
Secs. 18-234-18-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION 

Sec. 18-261. - Established; composition; term of members. 
    There is hereby created an electrical commission consisting of six members appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The chief electrical inspector shall be a member and ex officio chairperson of such commission. Of the other five members, one shall be a registered professional engineer, one shall be an electrical contractor, one shall be a journeyman electrician, one shall be a representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the fire underwriters (or, if no such representative resides in the village, then the chief of the fire department), and one shall be a representative of an electricity supply company. Such members shall be appointed for one year and shall serve until their successors have been appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1965, § 7.401) 
Sec. 18-262. - Recommendations. 
    Such electrical commission shall recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment in the village designed to meet the necessities and conditions in the village, and shall recommend reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits and fees to be paid; however, such standards and specifications, rules and regulations, and fees shall not be effective until adopted by ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 7.402) 
Secs. 18-263-18-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 26, 2015, repealed the former art. V, §§ 18-291-18-308, and enacted a new art. V as set out herein. The former art. V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1965, §§ 21.301-21.311 and Ord. No. 06-05, § 1, adopted Feb. 27, 2006. 

Sec. 18-291. - Plumbing provisions and the Illinois Plumbing Code adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of prescribing the establishment of a minimum code of standards for fixtures, material, design installation methods and use of plumbing systems in the village, pursuant to authority set forth under Section 1-2-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4, the Illinois Plumbing Code, Ill. Admin. Code tit. 77 § 890.110 et seq. 
(b)  Three copies of the Illinois Plumbing Code, which set out the Code in full, have been and now are filed in the office of the village clerk, and the sections therein are hereby adopted and incorporated fully as if set out at length herein and shall be controlling within the limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-292. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The administrative authority under this article shall be the village building inspector, and he or she shall enforce the provisions of this article and all other ordinances pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-293. - Minimum requirements. 
    The provisions of this article shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the community. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-294. - Certificate of compliance. 
(a)  No parcel of property which is improved with a building or structure having a sanitary sewer connection, direct or indirect, to the sanitary sewer system operated and maintained by the village shall be sold unless and until a certificate of compliance shall have been issued by the village. The certificate will evidence that the stormwater discharge from sump pumps, downspouts and roof drains is in compliance with this article or, in the alternative, that adequate financial arrangements have been made to guarantee performance of all necessary correction work in accordance with the provisions of subsection (c)(3) of this section. 
(b)  Each owner of any parcel of property subject to the provisions of this section shall notify in writing the village building inspector, directly or through the owner's agent or broker, of the impending sale of such parcel within five business days after a contract of sale shall have been executed by the seller and purchaser. Prior to closing of the sales transaction, it shall be the owner's obligation to make application for such certificate of compliance to the village building inspector on such form as he or she may prescribe. The filing of such application within the five business day period will also satisfy the owner's obligation to notify the village building inspector of the impending sale as otherwise required under this subsection. 
(c)  No certificate of compliance shall be issued unless and until the following standards have been met: 
(1)  The building or structure subject to the provisions of this section shall have been inspected under the supervision of the village building inspector for compliance with all requirements under this article pertaining to stormwater discharge from sump pumps, downspouts and roof drains. 
(2)  A written report of the inspection shall have been prepared and a copy thereof furnished to the property owner, directly or through the owner's agent or broker. 
(3)  If the inspection report indicates a lack of compliance with any requirement under this article pertaining to stormwater discharge from sump pumps, downspouts and roof drains, then the owner shall have arranged for the correction work to be completed before the closing of the sales transaction. If the owner is unable to complete the work before the closing date, then a cost estimate of the work necessary to bring the building or structure into compliance shall have been prepared by a licensed plumber or sewer contractor in the form of an offer to perform the necessary work for a specified price. In that event, the owner must either deposit with a broker, attorney, bank, savings and loan association or trust company mutually acceptable to the seller and purchaser, as escrowee, a sum equal to the cost estimate, a true copy of which estimate and escrow agreement shall be filed with the village building inspector. In lieu of the escrow deposit, the owner may furnish a performance bond issued by a surety company licensed to do business in the state, naming the purchaser of the property as obligee in an amount equal to the cost estimate. The escrow agreement or the performance bond, as the case may be, shall require that the correction work be completed within 90 days from the date of issuance of the certificate of compliance. Failure to timely complete the correction work will be deemed a default of the escrow agreement or the performance bond and the certificate of compliance will become null and void, whereupon the purchaser of the property will become responsible for the completion of the correction work. 
(4)  There shall be on file with the village building inspector a written verification by the village clerk's office that a water meter reading has been made to determine the volume of water furnished to the parcel of property to be sold from the date of the prior reading through the date preceding the date of issuance of the certificate of compliance and that the water account as of that last meter reading date has been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-295. - Nuisances; periodic outside inspections. 
(a)  Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the president, or members of the board of trustees, or department of health, or building inspector, or plumbing inspector, or complaint shall be made by the owner or occupant, that the plumbing or drainage in any building has become a nuisance, or is contrary to the provisions and requirements of this article, or is of faulty construction and liable to breed disease or endanger the health of the occupants, then the village building inspector shall examine the plumbing or drainage in any such building. 
(b)  Further, the village will make periodic outside inspections of all properties within the village, with specific attention to downspouts, roof drains and other visible or outside connections, and, if requested by the occupant of the property, the village will enter into the buildings located thereon to make or assist in making additional inspections of the premises to ascertain if such illegal connections to the sanitary sewer are present, in addition to such visual inspections of the municipal sewer system as it deems necessary in order to locate such illegal connections and sources of extraneous flow into the sanitary sewers as may exist. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-296. - Issuance of notice of violation. 
    The owner, agent or occupant shall be notified by the village building inspector of the existence of the nuisance or other violations of this article as set out in section 18-295 and such changes which are necessary, if any, to be made, and such changes shall be made within the time fixed in such notification. Upon refusal or neglect to obey such orders, legal proceedings shall be instituted to have such changes made and such nuisance abated. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-297. - Service of notice of violation. 
    Notice of any violation of this article shall be delivered to the person responsible for the same (if such person resides within the village) by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by the police department. If such person resides outside of the village, such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-298. - Right of entry of enforcement officers. 
(a)  For the purposes of enforcing the requirements of this article and other laws and regulations relating to plumbing and house drainage, the village building inspector, or anyone authorized by him, shall be permitted to enter any house or building, ground or premises in the village during reasonable hours to examine the plumbing, drainage, ventilation or any nuisance that might affect the public health. 
(b)  No person shall hinder or obstruct or in any manner interfere with the village building inspector or his authorized representative in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-299. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the village building inspector shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a license or permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the village building inspector to the president and board of trustees within 30 days from the date of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-300. - Fees. 
    Whenever any person, firm or corporation proposes to install, alter or repair any plumbing lines, connections or fixtures in, on or about any building, structure or improvement located on land within the village, the following minimum fees and charges shall be paid to the collector of the village: 
(1)  Plumbing line and fixture fee . Whenever it is proposed to install, alter or repair any plumbing lines or fixtures in, on or about any building, structure or improvement located on land within the village, there shall be a charge as established by the village board from time to time plus an inspection fee as established by the village board from time to time. If, after the initial inspection, additional inspections are required by reason of the failure to pass inspection, an additional charge as established by the village board from time to time shall be made for each additional inspection trip to the site. 
(2)  Sewer connections . 
a.  Wherever it is necessary to make a connection with the sanitary or storm system of the village, whether or not a building permit is otherwise required, there shall be a charge as established by the village board from time to time. The charges shall apply for every connection with the system of any building, structure or improvement located on land within the village. 
b.  In addition to the connection charge, an inspection charge shall be made for the inspection of any sewer line which is being installed, altered or repaired, as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Sec. 18-301. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-26-2015) 
Secs. 18-302-18-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 18-331. - BOCA National Property Maintenance Code adopted. 
    For the purpose of prescribing minimum acceptable standards to govern the maintenance of, and minimum requirements for hazard abatement in, existing buildings, structures, premises and facilities located within the village, that certain code known as the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, 1996 edition, recommended by the Building Officials and Code Administrators (BOCA) International, Inc., except as to those provisions thereof which are modified by additions, deletions or substitutions thereto, all as may be provided under this article, is adopted as the property maintenance code of the village. Said BOCA code, of which not less than three copies have been and now are on file in the office of the village clerk, is incorporated into this Code of Ordinances as fully as if set out at length herein, except as so modified, and shall be controlling within the limits of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 21.701) 
Sec. 18-332. - Modifications to BOCA National Property Maintenance Code. 
    The provisions of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, 1996 edition, are modified only in the following respects: 
    PM-101.1 shall read: 
Title: These regulations shall be known as the Existing Structures Code of the Village of Hillside hereinafter referred to as "this code" or as the existing structures code. 
    PM-101.8 is added to read as follows: 
Other regulations: The provisions of this code shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other ordinances or regulations which prescribe standards other than are provided herein. To the extent that any provision of this code is in conflict with a correlative provision of the building, electrical, plumbing, elevator, fire prevention and zoning codes of the Village of Hillside, the provision of those codes and not this code shall apply. 
    PM-105.1 shall read: 
General: The code official shall enforce all the provisions of this code relative to the maintenance of buildings, structures, premises and facilities, except as may otherwise be specifically provided for by other regulations. 
    PM-105.2 shall read: 
Notices and orders: The code official shall issue all necessary notices and orders to abate illegal or unsafe conditions to insure compliance with the requirements of this code for the safety, health and general welfare of the public. 
    PM-105.3 shall read: 
Right of entry: In order to safeguard the safety, health and welfare of the public, the code officials are authorized, with the prior permission of the owner or tenant, to enter any building, structure, premises or facility for the purpose of making inspections and performing duties under this code; provided, however, no such prior permission shall be required to enter and inspect the area thereof which is, at the time of the inspection, open to members of the general public. 
    PM-105.5 shall read: 
Identification: The code officials authorized to enforce this code shall disclose proper credentials of their respective offices for the purpose of inspecting any and all buildings and premises in the performance of their respective duties under this code. 
    PM-105.7 (Rule making authority) is deleted in its entirety. 
    PM-105.12 is added to read as follows: 
Annual report: At least annually, the code officials shall submit to the village administrator of the Village of Hillside a written statement of operations in the form and content as the administrator shall prescribe. 
    PM-106.2 shall read: 
Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this code shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of the Hillside Code of Ordinances at the discretion of the court. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served, in accordance with the terms and provisions hereof, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
PM-202.0 shall remain unchanged except for the following definitions which shall be deleted in their entirety, namely, "Rooming house" and "Rooming unit," and except for the following definitions, which shall read as indicated, except that the definition of "Renovation" is added: 
Dwellings: 
One-family dwelling: A building containing one dwelling unit occupied by a single family. 
Two-family dwellings: A building containing two dwelling units occupied by not more than a single family in each unit. 
Boarding house, lodging house and tourist house: A building arranged or used for lodging of persons with or without meals, for compensation. 
Family: An individual maintaining a household; or two or more persons each related to the other by blood, adoption or marriage, who are living together and maintaining a common household; or in the alternative, a "family" is a group of not more than three persons, who need not be related by blood, adoption or marriage, living together in a single dwelling and maintaining a common household. In any event, the limitations imposed in this definition shall be exclusive of any servants residing in the dwelling. 
Occupant: Any person living or sleeping in a dwelling unit or having actual possession of said dwelling or rooming unit. 
Renovation: A building and its facilities made to conform to present day minimum standards of health, sanitation, fire and life safety. 
    PM-306.3.2 shall read: 
Containers: The operator of every establishment producing garbage, vegetable wastes, or other putrescible materials shall provide, and at all times cause to be used, leakproof approved containers, provided with close fitting covers for the storage of such materials until removed from the premises for disposal. Containers shall not be stored in front of any property, premises or structure. 
    PM-303.4 shall read: 
Noxious weeds: All areas shall be kept free from weeds or plant growth which are noxious as defined in 505 ILCS 100/2. 
    PM-303.8 shall read: 
Residential areas: No vehicle located in a residential district shall be at any time in a state of major disassembly, disrepair nor shall it be in the process of being stripped or dismantled. 
    PM-304.18 (Guards for basement windows) is deleted in its entirety. 
    PM-305.3 shall read: 
Interior surfaces: Floors, walls (including windows and doors), ceilings, and other interior surfaces should be maintained in good, clean, and sanitary condition. Peeling paint, cracked or loose plaster, decayed wood, and other defective surface conditions should be eliminated. 
    PM-602.2 shall read: 
Residential buildings: Every dwelling unit and guest room shall be provided with heating facilities capable of maintaining a room temperature of 68 degrees F (18.33 degrees C) at point three feet (0.91 m) above the floor and three feet (0.91 m) from an exterior wall in all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms. 
    PM-702.3 is revised by revising the second sentence to read as follows: 
Every dwelling unit or hotel/motel room shall have access directly to the outside or to a public corridor. 
    PM-306.4 is hereby and shall read: 
Receptacle required: It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of any house, building, flat or apartment located within the village where people reside, board or lodge, or where animal or vegetable matter is prepared or served, to maintain in good order and repair, at all times, one or more cans or containers designed as receptacles for discarded garbage, bottles, cans and similar refuse. 
    PM-306.5 is hereby added to read: 
Receptacles in street right-of-way: No garbage or refuse of any kind shall be deposited on the paved portion of any street right-of-way, nor shall such garbage or refuse be deposited on any parkway except within cans or containers designed as receptacles thereof and in such a manner as would reasonably assure that the garbage and refuse would not be blown about or scattered by the wind, animals or vandals. No cans, sealed trash bags or other trash containers shall be placed on any parkway prior to 4:00 p.m. of the day before the scheduled pick-up day for that particular area, and they shall be removed before midnight of the actual pick-up day. 
    PM-306.3 shall read: 
Disposal of garbage: Every occupant of a structure or part thereof shall dispose of garbage in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in garbage disposal facilities, or if such facilities are not available, by securely wrapping such garbage and placing it in tight garbage storage containers as required by this code, or by such other disposal method as may be required by applicable laws or ordinances. Any can in which garbage is disposed shall be watertight and shall be fitted with a close cover. All cans and garbage and refuse shall have a capacity of not more than 32 gallons and shall be provided with suitable handles. 
    PM-306.6 is hereby added to read: 
Accumulation: It shall be unlawful and is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person, firm or corporation to accumulate or permit the accumulation, on any open lots, or other premises, under their control, of any lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stone, scrap metal, motor vehicle bodies or parts or similar articles that cause a blight on the environment. Any such articles that are germane to the operation of a business must be placed on open racks that are elevated not less than 18 inches above the ground evenly piled or stacked or stored in a manner that would prevent rodent harborage. 
    PM-307.2 shall read: 
Owner: The owner of any structure shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rats or other pests within the structure or on the premises prior to renting, leasing or selling the structure. 
(Code 1965, § 21.702) 
Secs. 18-333-18-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-361. - Numbering system. 
    All lots, buildings and structures in the village shall be numbered in accordance with the following plan: Harrison Street shall be the base for north and south numbers. There shall be no East and West designation; numbers shall start at Mannheim Road and continue west through the village. There shall be one number for each 25 feet of frontage, but so far as practicable the numbers at each street intersection shall begin with 100 or a multiple thereof; odd numbers shall be on the south and east sides of the streets. 
(Code 1965, § 8.401) 
Sec. 18-362. - Map. 
    The clerk shall keep a map showing the proper street number of every lot in the village, which shall be open to inspection by anyone interested. 
(Code 1965, § 8.402) 
Sec. 18-363. - Posting of numbers. 
(a)  Residential buildings. It shall be the duty of owners and occupants of every single family and multifamily residence in the village to have placed thereon, in a place visible from the street, figures at least four inches high, showing the number of the residence. Numbers, instead of letters spelling the address, shall be used. These numbers shall be in contrast to the background and visible from the street. 
(b)  Other buildings. Buildings other than those described in subsection (a) of this section shall have a minimum of four-inch numbers. The code official shall determine the size. The numbers shall be attached to the building. Where signs are present near driveways leading to buildings, numbers indicating the address shall also be on the sign. 
(c)  Buildings located off street. Buildings located off the street and not easily seen from the street shall have a sign that indicates the name and address of the business or occupancy. The zoning administrator shall approve such signs. 
(d)  Buildings served by alley. Buildings that are served by an alley shall have proper address numbers on the rear of the building. These numbers can be four inches high and attached to a contrasting background. 
(e)  Violations; penalty. Any person, firm or corporation failing to so number any occupancy owned or occupied after receiving notice to do so from the clerk shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 8.403) 
Secs. 18-364-18-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ELEVATOR SAFETY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-32, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2007, amended former art. VIII, §§ 18-391-18-394, in it entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VIII pertained to the same subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965. 

Sec. 18-391. - Boca National Building Code for elevators adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing the design, construction, installation, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration and repair of elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, moving walks and special hoisting and conveying equipment in and about any buildings or structures within the village, the regulations contained in that certain code known as the BOCA National Building Code, 1999 edition, chapter 30, Elevators and Conveying Systems, as modified by the subsequent annual supplements issued by said code's publisher, Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc. Not less than three copies of said code have been and now are filed in the office of the village clerk. The provisions thereof are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and shall be controlling within the limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 07-32, § 1, 12-17-2007) 
Sec. 18-391.1. - Additional standards. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of prescribing additional standards governing the design, construction, installation, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration and repair of elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, moving walks and special hoisting and conveying equipment in and about any buildings or structures within the village; 
(1)  American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME): 
a.  Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators (ASME A17.1-2005), A17.1(a)-2005, and A17.1(s)-2005; 
b.  Guide to Inspection of Elevators, Escalators, and Moving Walks (ASME 17.2-2004); 
c.  Safety Code for Existing Elevators and Escalators (ASME A17.3-2005); 
d.  Safety Standard for Platform Lifts and Stairway Chairlifts (ASME A18.1-2005); and 
e.  Standard for Qualification of Elevator Inspectors (ASME QEI-1-2004). 
(2)  American National Standards: 
a.  Safety Requirements for Personal Hoists and Employee Elevators (ANSI A10.4-2004). 
(3)  American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE): 
a.  Automated People Mover Standards (ASCE 21-2000). 
(Ord. No. 07-32, § 1, 12-17-2007) 
Sec. 18-392. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector, or the elevator inspector if the latter position is filled by appointment of the village president with the consent of the members of the board of trustees, to inspect or cause to be inspected any elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator, or moving walk in and about any building or structure within the village prior to the commencement of the use thereof and annually or semiannually thereafter, the number and interval between inspections to be determined by the inspector. If any such elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or moving walk is found to be in violation of the regulations referred to in section 18-391, he shall report this fact in writing to the owner or occupant of the building in or about which such device is located and require that all repairs or alterations deemed necessary by the inspector be made within a specified time. After said time limit, such device shall not be used and a sign so advising the public shall be affixed thereto by the inspector, until the necessary repairs or alterations have been made and a reinspection has been requested by the owner or occupant and made by the inspector, who shall verify such repairs or alterations. 
(Ord. No. 07-32, § 1, 12-17-2007) 
Sec. 18-393. - Fees. 
    The initial inspection fee for new installations shall be as established by the village board from time to time. Fees for subsequent semi-annual or any required follow-up inspections shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 07-32, § 1, 12-17-2007) 
Sec. 18-394. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 07-32, § 1, 12-17-2007) 
Secs. 18-395-18-420. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SWIMMING POOLS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, adopted Aug. 27, 2007, amended former art. IX, §§ 18-421-18-436 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. IX pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965. 

Sec. 18-421. - Permit. 
    No person shall construct or cause to be constructed a private outdoor swimming pool with capacity of 2,500 gallons or more without first obtaining a permit from the building inspector. An application for a permit to construct and the plans and specifications and pertinent explanatory data shall be submitted to the building inspector for his approval, and no part of the work shall be commenced until the building inspector has granted such approval by a written permit to construct and has further evidenced his approval by a suitable endorsement upon such plans and specifications. The building inspector shall review such plans and specifications to determine whether they comply with the provisions of this article and with reasonable standards of swimming pool construction for the protection of the public safety, health and morals as prescribed in rules and regulations promulgated by the building inspector pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-422. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, a private outdoor swimming pool is a man-made rigid or semi-rigid receptacle for water having a depth at any point greater that 24 inches and a length or width at any point, or diameter, greater than 12 feet, used or intended to be used for swimming, wading or bathing and constructed, installed or maintained in or above the ground, and which is used exclusively by the owner or occupant of the property on which it is located, the owner's family and guests. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-423. - Enclosures. 
    Every owner, purchaser under contract, lessee, tenant or licensee of land within the village upon which is situated a private outdoor swimming pool shall at all times maintain, on the lot or premises upon which such private swimming pool is located, a fence or other structure completely surrounding such pool, not less that five feet in height, with no gaps or apertures, other that doors or gates, with any dimensions greater that two inches. All gates or doors opening through such fence or enclosure shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices places at the top or such gates or doors and made inaccessible to small children. Such devices shall be so designed as to be capable of keeping such doors or gates securely locked at all times when not in use by the owner or occupant of the property on which it is located, the owner's family and guests; provided, however, that the door of any dwelling forming a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped. The building inspector may make modifications in individual cases, upon a showing of good cause, with respect to the height, nature or location of the fence, wall, gates or latches, or the necessity therefore, provided the protection as sought hereunder is not reduced thereby. The building inspector may permit other protective devices or structures to be used so long as the degree of protection afforded by the substitute devices or structures is not less than the protection afforded by the wall, fence, gate and latch described herein. The building inspector shall allow a reasonable period within which to comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-424. - Walks. 
    A walk area not less than four feet wide shall be installed entirely around an in-ground pool. The walk shall be of impervious materials and shall have a definite pitch away from the pool or at least one-half inch to foot. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-425. - Water supply; filtering system; discharge of water. 
    Every person in possession of land on which a private outdoor swimming pool is located shall have such pool conform to the following regulations: 
(1)  The water supply shall be from a connection to a public water supply and shall consist of a permanent rigid system of piping having an air-gap delivery connection located not less than six inches vertically above the flood rim of the pool, or through a spigot protected with a backflow prevention device (#9). 
(2)  No private outdoor swimming pool in excess of 2,500 gallons capacity shall be installed or used without a recirculating and filtering system having a minimum hourly capacity equal to the pool volume divided by ten. Sufficient filter area shall be proved to filter the entire pool volume in 18 hours at a rate not exceeding three gallons per square foot of filter area per minute. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-426. - Electrical requirements. 
(a)  No current-carrying electrical conductors including telephone and cable, shall cross private residential swimming pools, either overhead or underground or within ten feet of such pools, as required by Commonwealth Edison. 
(b)  All metal fences, enclosures or railings or lighting fixtures near or adjacent to private residential swimming pools, which might become electrically alive as a result of contact with broken conductors or from any other cause, shall be effectively grounded. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-427. - Sanitation. 
    Every private outdoor swimming pool shall be so designed and constructed as to facilitate cleaning and shall be maintained and operated in such a manner as to be clean and sanitary at all times. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-428. - Interference with enjoyment of property rights. 
    No private outdoor swimming pool shall be located, designed, operated or maintained as to interfere unduly with the enjoyment of their property rights by owners of property adjoining the private swimming pool or located in the neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-429. - Shielding of lights. 
    Lights used to illuminate any private outdoor swimming pool shall be so arranged and shaded as to reflect light away from adjoining premises. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-430. - Noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued at any private outdoor swimming pool any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others. In the operation of a private outdoor swimming pool, the use or permitting the use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, stereo or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing of the person or persons who are in the private outdoor swimming pool premises shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-431. - Hours of use; skilled swimmer to be present during use. 
    No private outdoor swimming pool shall be used between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., nor shall a private outdoor swimming pool be used at any time when a skilled swimmer is not present. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-432. - Commercial activities; signs. 
    The carrying on of any commercial undertakings at a private swimming pool entailing sales of food, drinks, novelties or other merchandise in a manner unreasonably disturbing neighboring property owners and inhabitants in the enjoyment of their property shall be prohibited. Swimming pool signs and placards shall be of such type and so affixed as not to prejudice or unreasonably disturb the enjoyment of neighboring property owners of their property. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-433. - Compliance with state regulations. 
    In the construction, operation and maintenance of any private outdoor swimming pool, state laws and the rules, regulations and requirements of the state department of health shall be observed. In the event of any conflict between the provisions of this article and any provision of state law or requirement, rule or regulation of the state department of public health, the provision imposing the higher standard or the more stringent requirement shall be controlling. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-434. - Permit fees. 
    The fee for a permit to construct, install or re-install a private outdoor swimming pool shall be as established by the Village Board from time to time. The fee to construct any additions, improvements, or alterations or for the remodeling of any existing private swimming pool shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-435. - Enforcement; inspections. 
    The code enforcement officer/building inspector is hereby charged with the duty of enforcing this article. For this purpose, the inspectors are hereby authorized to enter any premises in the village to inspect any private outdoor swimming pool at any reasonable hour. The village inspectors are hereby authorized to enter upon any premises, private or public, to take such samples of water from such pools at such times as he may deem necessary and to require the owner to comply with rules and regulations pertaining to private outdoor swimming pools promulgated by the village inspector in accordance with this article. In the event of the failure of compliance after due notice with the rules and regulations and requirements of the building inspector or the requirements of this article, the village inspectors shall have the power to abate or cause a suspension of the use of such private outdoor swimming pool until such time as the same is, in the opinion of the village inspector, no longer a menace or a hazard to health, safety or morals. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Sec. 18-436. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 07-25, § 1, 8-22-07) 
Secs. 18-437-18-460. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PUBLIC BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-461. - Responsibility for compliance. 
    The owner, agent, occupant or person charged with the custody of any public building, auditorium, hotel, theater, lodge hall, or church, and in the case of schools the president of the board of education or the person in charge thereof and owning the same, shall be held liable for the equipment and maintenance of such apparatus as is required in this article for the maintenance and safety of all exits, doors, windows or passageways. 
(Code 1965, § 24.901) 
Sec. 18-462. - Enforcement; inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire chief or his assistants to inspect all apparatus to be installed, and its location, and to make or cause to be made periodic inspections concerning the operation and accessibility of regular and emergency exits in all such public places, unless and until the building is equipped with an adequate sprinkler system or is connected with a public fire alarm system. 
(Code 1965, § 24.902) 
Sec. 18-463. - Removal of fire detection, fire alarm or fire protection apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove from its proper place any device, equipment or system used to detect a fire, activate an alarm, or suppress or control a fire, or any combination thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 24.905) 
Sec. 18-464. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.908) 
Secs. 18-465-18-490. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PUBLIC GATHERINGS 

Sec. 18-491. - Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of any kind in the village in any premises other than a building constructed in full compliance with the ordinances and laws pertaining thereto for auditorium, theater or lodge room purposes, excepting in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1001) 
Sec. 18-492. - Inspection of premises; roof materials. 
    No such gathering or entertainment shall be held or presented in any premises other than a building as described in section 18-491 unless such premises have been examined by the fire marshal or building inspector not more than three days before the date of such gathering and found to be free from any fire hazard and found to be suitable for the purpose. No structure enclosed by a roof shall be used for such purpose unless the same is constructed of non-flammable materials. Provided that tents or structures covered by canvas or similar materials may be so used if such canvas or other material has been properly treated so as to be rendered fire resistive. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1002) 
Sec. 18-493. - Seats. 
(a)  Any stands or rows of seats used in such premises shall be so constructed as to be safe for the use designed, and shall be sufficiently strong to carry the same weight and stress as is required for the construction of the auditorium floors of theater buildings, not less than 100 pounds per square foot. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to admit to any such premises a number of persons to exceed the actual number of seats maintained for their accommodation. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1004) 
Sec. 18-494. - Notification of proposed gathering; conditions of permit. 
    It shall be the duty of any person or persons conducting, calling for or managing any gathering in any premises other than a theater, lodge room or auditorium building constructed as provided in section 18-491, to notify the clerk of the date of such intended performance at least ten days before the meeting is to take place; upon such notice the fire marshal or the building inspector shall inspect the premises to determine whether or not they comply with the provisions hereof. Any permit issued for any such gathering shall be subject to the condition that this article be fully complied with, whether or not such condition is embodied in the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1006) 
Sec. 18-495. - Hours of use of property owned or controlled by village. 
    Unless otherwise authorized by the board of trustees in connection with seasonal recreational activities or with special functions for which public gathering permits shall be issued, it shall be unlawful for any person, between dusk to dawn, to be upon any outdoor portion of the Hillside Commons park property or upon any other village-owned or village-controlled outdoor area devoted to recreational use. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1006.1) 
Sec. 18-496. - Standards of conduct for persons using Hillside Commons park property. 
    No person, while upon the Hillside Commons park property, shall: 
(1)  Operate or park a motor vehicle in other than an established or designated area in accordance with posted directions or personal instructions of any village police officer, officer or attendant who may be present; 
(2)  Saw, cut, carve or otherwise damage or remove any trees or plant or flower therefrom, or dig within or otherwise disturb grassy areas, or in any other way injure or impair the attractiveness or usefulness of any area thereof; 
(3)  Dump, deposit or leave any bottles, cans, boxes, paper, rubbish, garbage or other trash upon any area thereof, except in proper receptacles where provided; 
(4)  Bring upon or drink, within any portion thereof, any alcoholic beverages at any time, except under the authority of a permit issued pursuant to section 18-497; 
(5)  Build or attempt to build an open fire, or drop, throw or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, or other flammable material upon any area thereof; 
(6)  Expose or offer for sale or hire any personal property or service, or erect or cause to be erected any sign, regardless of message thereon, upon any areas thereof, except with the specific prior approval of the president and board of trustees; 
(7)  Enter upon any area thereof which is posted as "closed to the public"; 
(8)  Speak or shout in a threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent manner or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of public peace; 
(9)  Disturb or interfere unreasonably with any members or guests of groups or organizations occupying or participating in any activity upon any area thereof under the authority of a permit issued pursuant to section 18-497; 
(10)  Fail or refuse to produce and exhibit to any village police officer, officer or attendant, a permit claimed by said person to have been issued and held by him pursuant to 18-497; 
(11)  Fail or refuse to comply with any order by any village police officer, officer or attendant to remove himself and his property from the park property when charged with any violation of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1006.2) 
Sec. 18-497. - Issuance and use of outdoor public gathering permits for Hillside Commons. 
(a)  Required; application; conditions. A permit must be obtained by any group of 25 or more persons as a precondition to gathering as a group upon the village commons, subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Application. Written application for such permit shall be submitted to the village clerk on forms provided for that purpose at least 14 days prior to the proposed date of such gathering. 
(2)  Eligibility. Permits will be issued only to groups of persons or organizations whose purpose would qualify for incorporation under the Illinois General Not For Profit Corporation Act of 1986, 805 ILCS 105/101.01 et seq., and which is located in Hillside or more than half of whose participants or members are Hillside residents. 
(3)  Deposit. A deposit of $100.00 must be submitted with the application and will be refunded to the depositor upon presentation of the deposit receipt within 30 days after the gathering date, provided that the park property, upon inspection by the department of public works promptly following the conclusion of the gathering, is found to be in good order. A reasonable charge for cleanup, repair or replacement may be deducted from the deposit and retained by the village to cover the cost thereof. 
(4)  Serving of beer. The permit may authorize serving, without sale, of beer to members or guests of the permittee for consumption on the park property, provided a certificate of fully prepaid liquor liability insurance, naming the village as an additional party insured, shall be filed with the village clerk at least seven days before the proposed gathering date. 
(5)  Sanitation facilities. Sanitation facilities must be provided by the permittee during the entire period of the actual gathering, provided such gathering is reasonably expected to exceed two hours. 
(6)  Limitation on number. Only one permit per calendar year shall be issued to any one organization unless otherwise authorized by the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  Notice of denial; appeals. Within seven days after receipt of an application for permit, the village clerk shall notify an applicant in writing if the permit is to be denied, citing the reasons for such denial. The applicant shall then have a right to appeal the denial by notice in writing to the village clerk within seven days after said notice of denial. Both such notices shall be deemed to have been timely made if personally served or if mailed by certified mail, postage prepaid, to the village hall or to the address of the applicant appearing on the application. The appeal shall be considered by the president and board of trustees upon careful review of the application under the standards set forth in subsection (a) of this section and the president and board of trustees shall sustain or overrule the village clerk's denial not later than the next regularly scheduled meeting of the president and board of trustees, which decision shall be final. 
(c)  Compliance with ordinances. A permittee shall be bound by all applicable ordinances of the village as though the same were fully inserted in the permit. 
(d)  Liability for damage. The permittee shall be liable for any loss or damage to property or injury to persons by reason of any negligent act of the permittee, its members or guests committed upon the park property. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1006.3) 
Sec. 18-498. - Alcoholic beverages, dogs and cats prohibited on ball field area. 
    With regard to the vacant ball field area lying east of the St. Domitilla Church and School property and north of Washington Street, which area is under lease by the Catholic Bishop of Chicago to the village, no person shall at any time bring upon or drink within any portion thereof any alcoholic beverage nor allow any dog, other than a dog accompanying a blind, hearing impaired or physically handicapped person or a person who is subject to epilepsy or other seizure disorders which dog serves as a guide, leader, seizure-alert, or seizure-response dog for such person or when a trainer of a guide, leader, seizure-alert, or seizure-response dog is accompanied by a guide, leader, seizure-alert, or seizure-response dog or a dog that is being trained to be a guide, leader, seizure-alert, or seizure-response dog, or cat over which such person has custody or control to enter upon or remain within any portion thereof under any circumstances. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1006.4) 
State Law reference- Guide Dog Access Act, 720 ILCS 630/1 et seq. 
Sec. 18-499. - Entry upon Hillside Retention Reservoir property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the president and board of trustees, to enter upon the land commonly referred to as the Hillside Retention Reservoir, being approximately seven acres of land located in the Hillside Congress Executive Park Subdivision north of Roosevelt Road and west of Orchard Street in the village; provided, however, that this prohibition shall not be applicable during those hours when members of the public are authorized by written notice posted on the reservoir fence gates to enter upon the land for recreational or other public purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1006.5) 
Sec. 18-500. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1007) 
Sec. 18-501. - Facility use agreements for use of the community center. 
(a)  Required; application; conditions . A facility use agreement must be entered into between the village and any group or organization as a precondition to the use of community center. Written application for a facility use agreement shall be submitted to the village clerk on forms provided for that purpose at least 21 days prior to the proposed date of use. The facility use agreement shall be subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Eligible user . The village will only enter into a facility rental agreement with an eligible user. 
(2)  Eligible use . The village will only enter into a facility use agreement with an eligible user who is not using the community center for religious services or for political activities. 
(3)  Entrance fees . No entrance fee of any kind may be charged by the eligible user in connection with the use of the community center. The eligible user is prohibited from accepting donations, money or any other thing of value in connection with the use of the community center. 
(4)  Hours of use . All activities conducted at the community center shall be conducted between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(5)  Premise limitations . Alcohol, smoking and the use of helium balloons are prohibited in or on the community center premises. The eligible user shall not place or allow the placement of any wall decorations on the community center, and the use of smoke machines, fog machines, and bubble machines is prohibited in or on the community center premises. 
(6)  Cleanup and restoration . Eligible user is responsible for: (a) set up and take down of all equipment used ; (b) removal of all of the eligible user's and its guests' trash from the community center premises; and (c) cleanup and restoration of the community center to the same condition that the community center was in immediately prior to the eligible user's rental period. 
(7)  Capacity . The maximum capacity of the community center is 100 people. 
(8)  Insurance . The eligible user shall provide proof of comprehensive general liability insurance in which the village is named as an additional insured with combined single limit coverage of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and $2,000,000.00 in the aggregate. 
(9)  Deposit . The applicant must submit a deposit of $100.00, payable to the village, with the application. If the application is denied, the deposit will be returned to the applicant upon presentation of the deposit receipt. If the application is granted, the deposit will be refunded to the renter upon presentation of the deposit receipt within 30 days after the expiration or termination of the facility use agreement, provided that the village's property, upon inspection by the village department of public works, is found to be in good condition and order. A reasonable charge for cleanup, repair or replacement may be deducted from the deposit and retained by the village to cover the cost of such cleanup, repair or replacement. 
(10)  Liability for damage . The eligible user shall be liable for any loss or damage to property or injury to persons by reason of any negligent act of the renter, its members or guests. The facility use agreement shall require the renter to indemnify the village and its officers, agents and employees from any such loss or damage. The security deposit required pursuant to section 18-501(a)(9) shall in no way limit the eligible user's potential liability arising under this section 18-501(a)(10). 
(b)  Compliance with ordinances . An eligible user shall be bound by all applicable ordinances of the village as though the same were fully inserted in the facility use agreement. 
(c)  Availability . Use of the community center is contingent upon the availability of space within the community center. The village's right to use the community center for village functions and village sponsored functions takes priority over all other requests for use. 
(d)  Notice of denial; appeals . Within seven days after receipt of an application for a facility use agreement, the village clerk shall notify the applicant in writing if the application is to be granted or denied. If the application is to be granted, the village clerk will issue a facility use agreement to the applicant for execution. 
If the application is to be denied, the village clerk will issue a written notice of denial citing the reasons for such denial. The applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial by submitting a written notice of appeal to the village clerk. The notice of appeal shall be submitted within seven days from the date of issuance of the notice of denial. 
The appeal shall be considered by the president and board of trustees upon careful review of the application under the standards set forth in subsection (a) of this section. The president and board of trustees shall sustain or overrule the village clerk's denial not later than the next regularly scheduled meeting of the president and board of trustees. The decision of the president and board of trustees shall be final. 
All notices required under this subsection shall be personally delivered or mailed by certified mail, postage prepaid. All notices to the village shall be delivered or mailed to the village clerk. All notices to the applicant shall be delivered or mailed to the address of the applicant appearing on the application. All notices shall be deemed to have been timely made if personally delivered or mailed within the timeframe and in accordance with the requirements specified in this subsection. 
(e)  Definitions . For purposes of this section, the following terms shall be given these definitions: 
    Applicant means a person that submits an application for a facility use agreement on behalf of an eligible user pursuant to this section. 
    Community center means the village community center located at 1 North Linder Avenue, Hillside, Illinois. 
    Eligible user includes groups of persons or organizations whose purpose would qualify for incorporation under the Illinois General Not for Profit Corporation Act of 1986, 805 ILCS 105/101.01 et seq., and which is located in Hillside or more than half of whose participants or members are Hillside residents. 
(Ord. No. 17-07, § 2, 7-24-2017) 
Secs. 18-502-18-520. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - CONTRACTORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 18-521-18-540. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HEATING, AIR CONDITIONING AND REFRIGERATION CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 18-541. - Definition. 
(a)  The term "heating, air conditioning, and refrigeration contractor," as used in this division, means: 
(1)  Any person engaged in the business of installing, altering or servicing heating, air conditioning or refrigerating systems; 
(2)  Any private or municipally owned public utility if such public utility installs heating, air conditioning or refrigerating systems. 
(b)  The term "heating, air conditioning and refrigeration contractor" does not include: 
(1)  Any private or municipally owned public utility, fuel supplier or dealer that supplies fuel and services or repairs heating or air conditioning appliances or equipment in connection with or as a part of their business of supplying the fuel used in such appliances or equipment; 
(2)  Any liquefied petroleum gas dealer subject to "An Act to regulate the storage, transportation, sale and use of liquefied petroleum gases," approved July 11, 1955, 430 ILCS 5/0.01 et seq., as now or hereafter amended, and the rules and regulations of the department of state police promulgated pursuant to such statute; or 
(3)  Any electrical contractor registered or licensed as such under the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-32-1, or any other statute. 
    (Code 1965, § 16.560) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-32-1(3)A.(a), (b). 
Sec. 18-542. - License required. 
    No contractor as defined in section 18-541 shall engage in the business of such contractor in the village without having first secured a license therefor; provided, however, that any such contractor, if properly licensed under the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-32-1(2), in the municipality of his principal place of business in this state, need not be so licensed in this village to engage in said business. 
(Code 1965, § 16.561) 
Sec. 18-543. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for such a license shall be as established by the village board from time to time; provided, however, that if the annual fee for an initial license is submitted after the contractor commences doing business in the village, or if the annual fee for a renewal license is submitted after May 1 of any given year, a late charge as established by the village board from time to time shall be added to and payable with the license fee otherwise required to be paid as provided in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 16.562) 
Sec. 18-544. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.563) 
Secs. 18-545-18-570. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 18-571. - Definition; license required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to engage in business in the village as a building contractor without first having obtained a license therefor as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  The term "building contractor" shall mean and include anyone engaged in the business of cement or concrete contracting, either flat, form or wall works as a masonry contractor; or as an electrical contractor; or as a roofing contractor; or as a mechanical contractor; or as a carpenter contractor; or as a general building contractor; and any person engaged in the construction, alteration or repair of buildings or other structures, or sidewalk or street pavements. 
(c)  Engaging in the construction, repair or alteration of any building, structure, or street or sidewalk pavement in the village for which a permit is required under the ordinances of the village shall be construed as doing business as a contractor in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1501) 
Sec. 18-572. - License fee; bond; insurance. 
(a)  The annual license fee for engaging in the business of a concrete or cement contractor, masonry contractor, electrical contractor, roofing contractor, mechanical contractor, carpenter contractor, catchbasin-sewer cleaner contractor and general contractor shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(b)  In addition to said license fee, all building contractors, before engaging in business, shall furnish to the village: 
(1)  A license and permit bond in the penal sum of $10,000.00, which shall save and hold harmless the village from any loss, costs and damages, expenses or liability of any kind resulting from the issuance of said license or permit. 
(2)  A certificate of insurance listing the village as an additional insured. 
Both the license and permit bond and the certificate of insurance shall remain in full force and effect for the duration of work performed by the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1502) 
Sec. 18-573. - Late charge. 
    If the annual fee for an initial license is submitted after the contractor commences doing business in the village, or if the annual fee for a renewal license is submitted after May 1 of any given year, a late charge as established by the village board from time to time shall be added to and payable with the license fee otherwise required to be paid as provided in section 18-572. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1502.1) 
Sec. 18-574. - Sub-contractors. 
    Any person doing business as a sub-contractor shall be construed as engaged in the business of a building contractor for which a license is required by this division. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1503) 
Sec. 18-575. - Hours of operation. 
    Contractors are permitted to perform work in residential or business districts only from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1504.1) 
Sec. 18-576. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1505) 
Secs. 18-577-18-579. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - CONDOMINIUM CONVERSION 

Sec. 18-580. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this Section. 
    Agent means any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture, corporation or any other entity or combination of entities, who represents or acts for or on behalf of a developer in selling or offering to sell any condominium unit. 
    Bedrooms shall be defined by the inclusion of enclosed closet space and a door that separates the sleeping quarters from other interior space. 
    Board of managers means the entity formed in compliance with all regulations of the Illinois Condominium Property Act as the acting body of the property. 
    Building means all structures, attached or unattached, containing one or more units. 
    Common elements means all portions of the property except the units, including limited common elements unless otherwise specified. 
    Common expenses means the proposed or actual expenses affecting the property, including reserves, if any, lawfully assessed by the board of managers of the unit owner's association. 
    Condominium instruments means all documents and authorized amendments thereto recorded pursuant to the provisions of the Act, including the declaration, bylaws and plat. 
    Conversion condominium means a property that contains structures, excepting those newly constructed and intended for condominium ownership, which are, or have previously been, wholly or partially occupied before recording of condominium instruments by persons other than those who have contracted for the purchase of condominiums. 
    Declaration means the instrument by which the property is submitted to the provisions of this Act, as hereinafter provided, and such declaration as from time to time amended. 
    Dens shall be differentiated from bedrooms by the fact that there are no closets. 
    Developer means any person who submits property legally or equitably owned in fee simple by the developer, or leased to the developer to the provisions of this Act, or any person who offers units legally or equitably owned in fee simple by the developer, or leased to the developer, for sale in the ordinary course of such person's business, including any successor or successors to such developers' entire interest in the property other than the purchaser of an individual unit. 
    Dwelling unit or unit means a part of the property designed and intended for any type of independent use. This shall be inclusive of all bedrooms, bathrooms, kitchens and the like that are inhabited and owned independently from the rest of the property. 
    General common elements means except as otherwise provided in the plat of condominium subdivision, all portions of the property with the exception of the individual condominium unit. 
    Limited common elements means those common elements to be reserved for the use of a certain number of condominium units, such as special corridors, stairways, elevators, parking and other items common to a particular floor, and the like. 
    Parcel means the lot or lots, tract or tracts of land, described in the declaration, submitted to the provisions of this Act. 
    Person means a natural individual, corporation, partnership, trustee or other legal entity capable of holding title to real property. 
    Plat means a plat or plats of survey of the parcel and of all units in the property submitted to the provisions of this Act, which may consist of a three-dimensional horizontal and vertical delineation of all such units. 
    Property means all the land, property and space comprising the parcel, all improvements and structures erected, constructed or contained therein or thereon, including the building and all easements, rights and appurtenances belonging thereto, and all fixtures and equipment intended for the mutual use, benefit or enjoyment of the unit owners, submitted to the provisions of this Act. 
    Purchaser means any person or persons other than the Developer who purchase a unit in a bona fide transaction for value. 
    Unit owner means the person or persons whose estates or interests, individually or collectively, aggregate fee simple absolute ownership of a unit.
