    Unit owners' association or "Association" means the association of all the unit owners, acting pursuant to bylaws through its duly elected board of managers. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-581. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish procedures and standards for the conversion of existing multiple-family rental housing to condominiums. These procedures and standards have been enacted to assure that purchasers of converted housing have been properly informed as to the physical condition of the structure that is offered for purchase and to ensure that converted housing achieves a high standard of appearance, quality, and safety, and is in good condition without hidden needs for maintenance and repair. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-582. - Criteria for condominium conversion. 
    Each condominium conversion shall be reviewed upon its merits and the ability to achieve the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-583. - Required submittals. 
(a)  The developer shall submit information documenting that the project as a whole will be in good repair on the interior and the exterior when offered for sale. As part of the material necessary for the village to determine this to be the case, the reports and/or information required by this section shall be submitted. The developer shall pay the cost of all reports. The reports shall include information on what improvements, if any, shall be accomplished by the developer and at what point in the conversion proceedings such improvements shall be completed. The village board shall consider all improvements cited in the reports, whether required or voluntary, conditions of approval. 
The developer shall be responsible for submitting the following documents for consideration of the conversion of multiple-family rental housing to condominiums: 
(1)  Schedule of proposed improvements which shall be made to the project prior to their sale; such list shall not prohibit the facility owner from making additional improvements; 
(2)  Submittal of a Plat of survey of the project including the location and sizes of structures, parking layout and access areas. 
(3)  Submittal of a of the proposed subdivision plats of survey (referred to as a final map) for the complex distinctively outlining areas that will be privately owned by unit owners and those areas of the facility that are common elements and regulated by the board of managers of the unit owner's association. 
(4)  Submittal of landscape plan. 
(b)  Physical elements report. A report on the physical elements of all structures and facilities shall be submitted, containing the following: 
(1)  A report by an Illinois-licensed architect and structural engineer, when required, detailing the structural condition, useful life, and any apparent deferred maintenance of all elements of the property, including, but not limited to, foundations, electricity, plumbing, utilities, walls, ceilings, windows, frames, recreational facilities, sound transmissions of each building, mechanical equipment, parking facilities, and drainage facilities. Such report also shall describe the condition of refuse disposal facilities; swimming pools, saunas, and fountains; stone and brickwork; fireplaces; and exterior lighting. 
(2)  A report by a licensed mechanical contractor detailing the age, condition, expected size, and the cost of replacement for each appliance and mechanical equipment for heating and cooling. The report shall identify any defective or unsafe appliances and set forth the proposed corrective measures to be employed. 
(3)  A report by an Illinois-licensed structural termite and pest control specialist certifying whether or not all attached or detached structures are free of infestation and structural damage caused by pests and dry rot. The report shall describe what procedures would be necessary to eliminate infestation or damage, if present. 
(4)  A report by an Illinois-licensed roofing contractor verifying the condition of the roofs of all structures and an estimate of the remaining physical life of the roofs and the cost of replacement. 
(5)  A declaration of the covenants, conditions, restrictions, and rules and regulations which would be applied on behalf of any and all owners of condominium units within the project. The declaration shall include, but not be limited to: the conveyance of units; the assignment of parking and storage areas; and an agreement for common area maintenance, together with an estimate of any initial assessment fees anticipated for such maintenance, and an indication of appropriate responsibilities for the maintenance of all utility lines and services for each unit. 
(6)  The proposed price of each of the units; 
(7)  The proposed homeowners' association budget, detailed to include fixed costs, operating costs, reserves, administration, and contingencies. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-584. - Compliance with village codes. 
(a)  All units, as well as the common ownership facilities, shall be brought into compliance with all applicable state and local zoning, building, housing, mechanical, and fire codes adopted for use by the village. 
(b)  All main buildings, structures, fences, patio enclosures, carports, parking garages, swimming pools, outdoor recreational facilities, accessory buildings, sidewalks, driveways, parking lots, landscaped areas, and additional elements as required shall be refurbished and restored as necessary to achieve a high standard of appearance, quality, and safety. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-585. - Minimum unit size. 
(a)  Each dwelling unit size shall have a minimum floor space of 1,100 square feet.
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-586. - Private open space and balconies. 
(a)  Each condominium dwelling unit shall have a minimum private open space. For units at ground level, open space each unit shall be provided not less than 150 square feet with a minimum dimension of ten feet. For units designed above the ground units, one or two balconies, with a combined minimum area of 60 square feet, shall be provided. Installation of balconies shall be integrated into to the existing building design so there shall be no discernable difference in construction or materials. 
(b)  Subterranean condominium dwelling units shall be except from this requirement. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-587. - Lighting. 
    All garages, parking lots, walkways, and driveways shall be sufficiently lighted during the hours of darkness. Fixtures for all lights shall be of the types that are protected from breakage. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-588. - Trash collection areas. 
(a)  Trash collection areas shall be provided; such collection areas shall be situated to eliminate, insofar as possible, noise and visual intrusion on adjacent property as well as to eliminate fire hazards to adjacent structures. 
(b)  Trash collection areas that are located outside the facility shall be screened from view by construction of a masonry enclosure that reflects the characteristics of the surrounding properties. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-589. - Security devices. 
    Each main entry way utilized for ingress or egress of owners or deliveries shall be monitored by an adequate security device to ascertain individuals accessing the facility. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-590. - Utilities. 
(a)  All utilities shall be underground. 
(b)  Electricity and natural gas that is controlled by and consumed within the individual condominium unit shall be separately metered. 
(c)  All meters, utility service connections and major roof chimneys, pipes or structures shall be integrated with the design of the building and screened architecturally and/or by landscaping and as required by the village. 
(d)  All fixtures shall be furnished with separate shut off valves both the hot and cold water supply so that the each fixture can be isolated. 
(e)  Each condominium unit shall be furnished with it own independent furnace, condenser for air conditioning, washer, dryer and hot water heater that service only that unit. 
(f)  Clothes washers, dishwashers, hot water heaters and any other appliances likely to be a potential source of water leakage or flooding shall be installed with built-in drip pans and appropriate drains. 
(g)  Each condominium unit shall have its own circuit breaker panel for all electrical circuits and outlets that serve the unit. Such panel shall be accessible without leaving the unit. 
(h)  All water supply lines within the project shall be isolated from wood, metal and other framing with pipe isolators specifically manufactured for that purpose and approved by the village. All vertical drainage lines within the project shall be isolated from touching wood, metal and other framing and all drainage pipes shall be surrounded by approved insulation. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-591. - Sound insulation. 
    Wall and floor/ceiling assemblies separating units from each other or from public or quasi-public spaces, such as interior corridors, laundry rooms, recreation rooms, parking spaces, etc., shall provide airborne sound insulation, impact sound insulation, and isolation of vibration and sources of structure-borne noise (including shock mounting of mechanical equipment). 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-592. - Fire protection. 
(a)  Sprinkler and other systems. A sprinkler system, fire alarm, and other fire protection devices shall be installed in all condominium facilities. 
(b)  Smoke detectors. Every condominium dwelling unit shall be provided with an AC- powered smoke detector. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-593. - Parking requirements. 
(a)  The property shall conform to all applicable parking requirements of the Village of Hillside 1980 Zoning Ordinance as amended. 
(b)  The village will require a submittal of a current plat of survey depicting the striping detail of the parking facilities. The submittal shall include the dimensions of all parking spaces and drive aisles. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-594. - Inspections. 
(a)  All existing multiple-family rental housing converting to condominiums shall be inspected for needed repairs to bring the project into compliance with the current codes of the village. The cost of such inspection shall be borne by the individuals seeking the conversion. 
(b)  All existing multiple-family rental housing converting to condominiums shall perform tests and attain certification on existing all existing fire protection equipment. All tests shall be scheduled and witnessed by the Hillside Fire Department. The fire department shall conduct inspections to the project facility to determine the sufficiency of fire protection systems serving such project and report on any deficiencies and indicate which deficiencies are required to be corrected. 
(c)  All existing multiple-family rental housing converting to condominiums shall be inspected by the Village to ascertain conformance of the project with zoning ordinance requirements applicable to the project. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Sec. 18-595. - Other requirements. 
    Correction of deficiencies: 
(1)  Corrections required in the building inspection report shall be made by the property owner at the property owner's expense. 
(2)  The property owner shall correct any deficiencies in the fire protection system, required by law. (Require fire test and certification) 
(3)  The property owner shall repair or replace any damaged or infested areas in need of repair or replacement as shown in the structural pest control report, which shall be prepared by a licensed structural pest control operator and dated and filed at least thirty days prior to the submittal of the final map. 
(4)  The property owner shall bring into conformity any zoning ordinance violations. 
(5)  Final inspection report. A final inspection report shall be made by the village prior to consideration of occupancy, indicating the compliance with all requirements imposed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 06-04, 4-24-2006) 
Secs. 18-596-18-599. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - VACANT BUILDING REGISTRATION PROGRAM 

Sec. 18-600. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Vacant means a building which is lacking habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises or at which substantially all lawful business operations or residential occupancy has ceased. A residential property shall not be deemed vacant if it has been used as a residence by a person entitled to possession for a period of at least three months within the previous nine months and a person entitled to possession intends to resume residing at the property; further, a multi-family residential property containing five or more dwelling units shall be considered vacant when substantially all of the dwelling units are unoccupied. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 2, 5-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-601. - Liability. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article or of the rules and regulations hereunder shall be fined not less than $200.00 and not more than $1,000.00 for each offense. Every day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 2, 5-18-2009) 
Sec. 18-602. - Owner required to act. 
(a)  Notification of village. 
(1)  The owner of any building that has become vacant shall within 30 days after the building becomes vacant, or within 30 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives, whichever is later, file a registration statement for each such building with the village administrator on forms provided by the village administrator for such purposes. The registration shall remain valid for one year from the date of registration. The owner shall be required to annually renew the registration as long as the building remains vacant and shall pay an annual registration fee of $100.00 for each registered building, provided, however, that charitable, religious, educational or benevolent associations and all governmental agencies shall be exempt from the payment of the annual registration fee. The owner shall notify the village administrator, within 20 days, of any change in the registration information by filing an amended registration statement on a form provided by the village administrator for such purposes. The registration statement shall be deemed prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the village against the owner or owners of the building. Registration of a building in accordance with this section shall be deemed to satisfy the registration and notification requirements set forth in this Code. 
(2)  In addition to other information required by the village administrator, the registration statement shall include the name, street address and telephone number of a natural person 21 years of age or older, designated by the owner or owners as the authorized agent for receiving notices of code violations and for receiving process, in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding, on behalf of such owner or owners in connection with the enforcement of this Code. This person must maintain an office in Cook County, Illinois, or must actually reside within Cook County, Illinois. An owner who is a natural person and who meets the requirements of this subsection as to location of residence or office may designate himself as agent. By designating an authorized agent under the provisions of this subsection the owner is consenting to receive any and all notices of code violations concerning the registered building and all process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding brought to enforce code provisions concerning the registered building by service of the notice or process on the authorized agent. Any owner who fails to register a vacant building under the provisions of this subsection shall further be deemed to consent to receive, by posting at the building, any and all notices of code violations and all process in an administrative proceeding brought to enforce code provisions concerning the building. 
(b)  Responsibilities of owner or manager. 
(1)  The owner of any building that has become vacant, and any person maintaining, operating or collecting rent for any building that has become vacant shall, within 30 days perform the following: 
(i)  Enclose and secure the building so that all the building's doors, and other openings, are closed and secured, using secure doors, windows without broken or cracked panes, or boarded with plywood installed and secured in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated by the village administrator. At least one building entrance shall be accessible from the exterior and secured with a a door that is locked to allow access only to authorized persons; 
(ii)  Post a sign affixed to the building indicating the name, address and telephone number of the owner and the owner's authorized agent for the purpose of service of process. The sign shall be of a size and placed in such a location so as to be legible from the nearest public street or sidewalk, whichever is nearer; and 
(iii)  Maintain the building in a secure and closed condition and maintain the sign until the building is again occupied or until repair or completion of the building has been undertaken; 
(iv)  Maintain the property, including but not limited to: 
a.  Maintain all grass and weeds on the property in accordance with village ordinances; 
b.  Clear or remove snow from the walkway leading to the main entry door and any public sidewalk adjoining the property; 
c.  Abate the accumulation of debris, trash, and litter the does not constitute personal property on any exterior portions of the property; 
d.  Reasonably maintain all fences and gates; 
e.  Winterize the building, which shall mean cleaning all toilets and completely draining all plumbing and heating systems; and 
f.  Keeping the exterior and interior of the property free of vermin and rodents. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 2, 5-18-2009; Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 18-603. - Rules and regulations to be promulgated. 
    The village administrator may issue rules and regulations for the administration of this section. These rules may designate board-up materials and methods which must be used when securing a building so that the boarding is reasonably incapable of being removed by trespassers or others acting without the building owner's consent. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this section or any rules and regulations issued hereunder shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 for each offense. Every day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Fines assessed under this section shall be recoverable from the owner and shall be a lien on the property. 
(Ord. No. 09-13, § 2, 5-18-2009; Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 18-604. - Vacant buildings-Mortgagee required to act-Enforcement authority. 
(a)  The mortgagee of any residential building that has become vacant, and which is not registered pursuant to this section of section 18-602 of this Code, shall, within the later of 30 days after the building becomes vacant and unregistered or 60 days after a default, file a registration statement with the village administrator on forms provided by the village administrator for such purposes and pay a registration fee of $200.00. The registration shall remain valid for six months from the date of registration. The mortgagee shall be required to renew the registration every six months as long as the building remains vacant and the mortgagee maintains a lien against the property. There will be no fee for such renewal. The mortgagee shall notify the village administrator within 20 days of any change in the registration information by filing an amended registration statement on a form provided by the village administrator for such purposes. The registration statement shall be deemed prima facie proof of the statements contained therein in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the village against the mortgagee with respect to the registered property. 
(b)  In addition to the other information required by the village administrator, the registration statement shall include the name, street address, and telephone number of a of a natural person, 21 years of age or older, or business entity registered with the Illinois Secretary of State designated by the mortgagee as an authorized agent for receiving notices of code violations and for receiving process in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding on behalf of such mortgagee in connection with enforcement of this or any other code section. This person or business entity must maintain an office in Cook County, Illinois, or must actually reside in Cook County, Illinois. 
By designating an authorized agent under the provisions of this section, a mortgagee consents to receive any and all notices of violations of the Municipal Code concerning the registered property in any court proceeding or administrative enforcement proceeding with respect to the registered property by service of the notice on the registered agent. 
Any mortgagee who has designated an authorized agent under the provisions of this section shall be deemed to consent to the continuation of the agent's designation for the purposes of this section until the mortgagee notifies the village administrator of a change in authorized agent or until the mortgagee files a new registration statement. The village shall notify the registered agent of all violations and enforcement proceedings. 
(c)  The mortgagee of any residential property that has become vacant shall maintain the property as required by section 18-602 of this Code. 
(d)  For purposes of this section, the following terms shall be defined as set forth below: 
(1)  Default shall mean, with respect to a residential building containing four for fewer dwelling units, when the mortgagor is 60 days past due on the mortgagor's obligation to make a scheduled payment under a mortgage or a mortgage note. With respect to all other residential buildings, "default" shall mean when the mortgagor is 90 days past due on the mortgagor's obligation to make a scheduled payment under a mortgage or a mortgage note. 
(2)  Mortgage shall mean any consensual lien created by a written instrument which grants or retains an interest in real estate to secure a debt or other obligation. The term includes, without limitation: 
a.  Mortgages securing reverse mortgage loans; 
b.  Revolving credit loans; 
c.  Every deed conveying real estate, although an absolute conveyance in its terms, which shall have been intended only as a security in the nature of a mortgage; and 
d.  Equitable mortgages. 
(3)  Mortgagee shall mean: 
a.  The holder of an indebtedness or obligee of a non-monetary obligation secured by a mortgage or any person designated or authorized to act on behalf of such holder; 
b.  Any person claiming through a mortgagee as successor; and 
c.  Any person identified as such in a recorded document which has not been released, assigned, or superseded of record. 
(4)  Mortgagor shall mean: 
a.  The person whose interest in the real estate is the subject of the mortgage; and 
b.  Any person claiming through a mortgagor as successor. Where a mortgage is executed by a trustee of a land trust, the mortgagor is the trustee and not the beneficiary or beneficiaries. 
(5)  Vacant shall mean any real estate improved with a complete structure containing one or more dwelling units or an incomplete structure if the real estate is zoned for residential development, where the structure is empty or otherwise uninhabited by persons and the structure or lot is in need of maintenance, repair or securing, and with respect to which one or more of the following conditions exist: 
(i)  All lawful business or construction operations have ceased for six months; 
(ii)  It has been declared unfit for occupancy and ordered to remain vacant and unoccupied under an order issued by either the building inspector, the board of health, the chief of the fire department, or the chief of police pursuant to the Village Code or by an order issued by court of competent jurisdiction; 
(iii)  No construction or legal repairs have commenced for six months; 
(iv)  The doors or windows are smashed through, broken, unhinged, removed or continuously unlocked; 
(v)  Law enforcement officials have received at least one report of trespassers or vandalism or other illegal acts being committed at the property in the last six months; and 
(vi)  Gas, electrical or water services to the entire premises have been terminated. 
A property shall not be considered vacant if: 
a.  There is an unoccupied building which is undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation that is proceeding diligently to completion, and the building is in compliance with all applicable ordinances, codes, regulations and legislation; 
b.  There is a building occupied on a seasonal basis, but otherwise secure; 
c.  There is a secure building on which there are bona fide rental or sale signs; 
d.  There is a building that is secure, but is the subject of a probate action, action to quiet title, or other ownership dispute; or 
e.  There is otherwise a building that is secure and in substantial compliance with all applicable ordinances. 
(e)  If a building is registered under subsection (a) of this section, only the registered mortgagee shall be liable under this section during the registration period. Nothing in this section shall bar the concurrent enforcement of any provision of this Code against the owner or owners of a property. 
(f)  To the extent permitted by law, a mortgagee's acts or omissions required by this section shall not subject the mortgagee to civil or criminal liability unless the act or omission constitutes gross negligence or willful, wanton, or intentional misconduct. This provision shall not waive the requirement to obtain permits or licenses for performing certain work required under this section, as otherwise required by this Code, or the penalties provided for failure to do so. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 18-605. - Mortgagee to inspect real estate. 
(a)  For purposes of this section the terms "default," "mortgage," "mortgagee," "mortgagor," and "vacant" shall be defined as provided in section 19-604. 
(b)  Beginning 45 days after a default, a mortgagee shall determine, on a monthly basis, if the building on the real estate subject to its mortgage is vacant. Such determination may be made by communication with the mortgagor, a visual inspection of the real estate, or other means reasonably calculated to determine if the building is vacant. 
(c)  This section shall not require a mortgagee to perform any action which it is barred from doing by an automatic stay pursuant to a bankruptcy proceeding. 
(d)  To the extent permitted by law, a mortgagee's acts or omissions required by this section shall not subject the mortgagee to civil or criminal liability unless the act or omission constitutes gross negligence or willful, wanton, or intentional misconduct. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 3-24-2014) 
Sec. 18-606. - Termination. 
(a)  For purposes of this section the terms "mortgage," "mortgagee," and "vacant" shall be defined as provided in section 18-604. 
(b)  Upon the occurrence of any of the following, the requirements of sections 18-604 and 18-605 shall terminate with respect to a mortgagee: 
(1)  Recorded assignment of the mortgagee's mortgage; 
(2)  Recorded satisfaction or release of the mortgagee's mortgage; 
(c)  Upon the occurrence of any of the following, the requirements of sections 18-604 and 18-605 shall terminate with respect to a building: 
(1)  Recorded conveyance of title to the underlying real estate, pursuant to foreclosure proceedings or otherwise; 
(2)  The building ceases to be vacant; or 
(3)  The building is demolished with all permits required by this Code. 
(d)  Within 20 days of termination pursuant to this section, a mortgagee shall notify the building inspector on a form provided by the inspection services department for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 3-24-2014) 
Secs. 18-607-18-630. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - SYSTEMATIC INSPECTION OF RENTAL HOUSING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-08, adopted April 26, 2010, amended the Code by adding provisions numbered as Art. XIV, §§ 18-600-18-616. In order to avoid conflicts in the numbering of provisions the editor has renumbered the provisions enacted by Ord. No. 10-08 as herein set out. 

Sec. 18-631. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish a systematic inspection for rental housing in the village for the purposes of protecting occupants from substandard housing, maintaining neighborhood stability, providing for an environmentally desirable community for all residents and promoting the condition and property values of residential neighborhoods within the village. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-632. - Other ordinances. 
    This article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, statutes, laws, orders, rules or regulations that prescribe standards for the subject matter of this article. In the event of a conflict between the provisions of this article and any other ordinance, code, statute, law, order, rule or regulation, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-633. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Applicable law(s): Includes, but is not limited to, the village's codes, ordinances and other county, state or federal laws or regulations, relating to the health or safety of the village's residents or the public. 
    Code official: Building inspector, code enforcement officer, fire marshal or such other person designated by the village president, the village administrator or the assistant village administrator. 
    Dwelling: A building or portion thereof (excluding hotels or motels, house trailers and recreational vehicles) containing as one of its uses one or more rooms for sleeping and habitation purposes and having its own kitchen and sanitation facilities, all arranged for occupancy by one or more persons. 
    Owner: Shall mean any person owning a rental dwelling as showed on the last equalized roll for village taxes or his/her designee. 
    Rental dwelling: means a dwelling occupied by or intended for occupancy by someone other than the owner. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-634. - Notice to village of rental dwelling. 
    The owner or person in charge of a rental dwelling shall provide the village administrator or assistant village administrator or their designee with written notice that a dwelling is being leased or rented. Such notice shall be given within 30 days of the effective date of this article. For any dwelling that is intended to become a rental dwelling after the effective date of this article, the owner or person in charge of the rental dwelling shall provide the same written notice prior to allowing the occupancy of the rental dwelling by a lessee or tenant. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-635. - Inspection of rental dwellings. 
(a)  Inspection. Any rental dwelling that is leased or rented shall be subject to inspection by a code official on an annual basis, upon a request of a tenant or owner or for cause, for the purpose of determining that the rental dwelling is in compliance with all applicable laws. 
(b)  Notice of inspection. The code official shall give a minimum of 30 days advance written notice of the inspection to the Owner or at least one of the occupants of the rental dwelling. Notice shall be given to the Owner by either mailing notice to the address of the person or entity to whom real estate tax bills are mailed or by hand delivery to the owner. Notice shall be given to the occupant(s) by mailing the notice to the address of the rental dwelling to be inspected or by hand delivery of the notice to an occupant who is 18 years of age or older or by posting the notice on the front door of the rental dwelling. 
(c)  Consent to inspection. If owners or non-owner occupants do not consent to the code official's entry for inspection pursuant to this article, the code official may not otherwise attempt to gain entry except with an administrative search warrant issued from a competent authority in accordance with the applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-636. - Immediate health and safety threats. 
    Nothing in this article shall limit the village's ability to inspect properties without notice and issue citations for property-related conditions that may constitute an immediate health or safety threat. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-637. - Frequency of inspections. 
(a)  Inspection based on cause. Nothing in this article shall preclude the inspection of a rental dwelling when the code official has notice or a reasonable suspicion that the rental dwelling has one or more violations of any applicable law. 
(b)  Reinspections. The code official shall be authorized to conduct reinspections of rental dwellings following an initial inspection if the code official has found violations of any applicable law and has given the owner or occupant notice of the violations with a directive to correct those violations within a specific time period. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-638. - Certificate of compliance. 
(a)  Issuance of certificate. After the code official has determined that a rental dwelling is in compliance with all applicable laws, the code official shall issue a certificate of compliance to the owner or person in charge of a rental dwelling. The certificate of compliance shall be valid for a period of one (1) year or until another inspection is required. A copy of the certificate of compliance shall be maintained by the village clerk. 
(b)  Certificate required. Subject to the provisions of subsection (c), no owner or person in charge of a rental dwelling may permit the occupancy of the rental dwelling by any lessee or tenant without having a valid certificate of compliance for the rental dwelling. 
(c)  Interim occupancy. During the first year of the effective date of this article, any owner or person in charge of a rental dwelling may continue to permit the occupancy of the rental dwelling by the lessee or tenant until the code official has conducted an inspection of the rental dwelling, provided that the owner or person in charge of the rental dwelling gives notice to the village of the rental dwelling in accordance with section 18-634 herein. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-639. - Correction of violations. 
    The owner or person in charge of a rental dwelling shall correct violations of any applicable law within the time allowed by the code official. If the violations do not pose an immediate threat to life safety, the owner or person in charge of the rental dwelling will then be permitted to allow the interim occupancy of the rental dwelling during the time specified for corrective action. If the owner or person in charge of the rental dwelling fails to bring the rental dwelling into compliance within the applicable time period, the code official shall be authorized to order the vacation of the rental dwelling and to seek the revocation or suspension of any previously issued certificate of compliance still in effect. When the code official finds violations that threaten the life safety of the occupants of the rental dwelling or the occupants of nearby dwellings, the code official may order the immediate evacuation of the rental dwelling in accordance with applicable law. The code official's decision shall be subject to the proceedings set forth in Chapter 2, Article VI of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-640. - Notice of violations. 
    If the inspection of the rental dwelling unit discloses noncompliance with the applicable law, the code official shall issue a notice of violation which shall set forth the following: 
(1)  The street address or appropriate description of the rental dwelling; 
(2)  The date of the inspection; 
(3)  The identity of the inspector; 
(4)  A list of the deficiencies and/or violations of the applicable law; 
(5)  The number of days in which the owner and/or occupant is to cure the violation(s); 
(6)  Notice that if the conditions are not repaired or the rental dwelling is not otherwise brought into compliance with the provisions of this article within the time specified, owner or occupant of the rental dwelling may be prosecuted and/or the rental dwelling may be placarded as unfit for human occupancy, in which event the occupants shall promptly vacate the rental dwelling and/or the village may elect to cure the violations in which event the rental dwelling may be subject to a lien for the costs incurred by the village. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-641. - Failure to cure the violations. 
(a)  If the person so served with the notice of violation does not cure the violations within the time specified in the notice, an officer or employee of the village may proceed to cure the violation, keeping an account of the expense thereof, and such expense shall be charged to and paid by such owner or occupant. 
(b)  Costs and charges incurred by the village for curing the violations shall be a debt to the village jointly and severally owed by the rental dwelling owner and occupant. Such costs and charges shall be a lien on the real property upon which the rental dwelling is located. Whenever a bill for such charges remains unpaid for 30 days after it has been rendered, the clerk shall file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the real property, the expenses and costs incurred, the date of the cure activity and a notice that the village claims a lien for certain amounts. Notice of such lien shall be sent by certified mail to the taxpayer of record for the preceding year. Provided, however, that failure of the clerk to record such lien claim or to mail such notice, or the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for such charges as provided herein. 
(c)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid cure charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges after deducting costs, as is the case with the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be in equity in the name of the village. 
(d)  The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the village in any court having jurisdiction over such matter, against any property for which such bill has remained unpaid 30 days after it has been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-642. - Suspension or revocation or refusal to renew certificate. 
    The suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of any certificate of compliance shall not release or discharge the certificate holder from the payment of any fees due under this article, nor shall the certificate holder be released from prosecution for violating this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-643. - Fees. 
    The initial inspection fee for rental dwellings shall be as established by the village board from time to time. Fees for subsequent inspections or any required follow-up inspections shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-644. - No warranty of habitability. 
    The issuance of a certificate of compliance shall not be construed as a warranty of habitability of the rental dwelling or any guarantee to the certificate holder or any occupant of the rental dwelling that the rental dwelling is free from all violations of all applicable laws. Nothing in this article shall be construed as creating a duty or obligation of the village or its code official or agents and employees to any individual certificate holder or occupant of or visitor to a rental dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-645. - Certificate of compliance not transferable. 
    A certificate of compliance shall be personal to the owner or person in charge of a rental dwelling and is not transferable to a subsequent purchaser. When a sale of a rental dwelling is subject to contract and the purchaser will use the dwelling as rental housing, the purchaser shall be required to obtain a new certificate of compliance from the village prior to allowing the occupancy of a rental dwelling by a lessee or tenant. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-646. - Penalties. 
(a)  Failure to pay an inspection fee will result in a certificate of compliance not being issued. 
(b)  Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-10 of the Code. 
(c)  Any person violating any provision of section 18-634 though and including section 18-645 shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $75.00, and each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Sec. 18-647. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance from which this article derives shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 4-26-2010) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Distinction between wholesaler and retailer. 
    In all cases where the words "wholesaler" or "wholesale dealer" are used in this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, they shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer who sells in smaller quantities direct to the consumer. 
(Code 1965, § 26.103) 
Secs. 22-2-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND PERMITS GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-31. - Applications. 
    Applications for all licenses and permits required by ordinances shall be made in writing to the village clerk in the absence of provisions to the contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the village officials in the issuing of the permit or license applied for. 
(Code 1965, § 10.001) 
Sec. 22-32. - Person subject to license requirement. 
    Whenever in this Code a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment or for doing business or engaging in any activity or occupation, any person, firm or corporation shall be subject to the requirement if, by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he holds himself forth as being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such business or occupation in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 10.002) 
Sec. 22-33. - Forms. 
    Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept on file by the village clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 10.003) 
Sec. 22-34. - Signatures. 
    Each license or permit issued shall bear the signature of the president and clerk in the absence of any provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1965, § 10.004) 
Sec. 22-35. - Investigations. 
    Upon the receipt of any application for a license or permit where the ordinances of the village necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such permit or license, the village clerk shall refer such application to the proper officer for making such investigation within 48 hours of the time of such receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making the investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten days after receiving the application or a copy thereof. The health officer shall make or cause to be made any investigation in regard to such licenses in connection with the care of and handling of food and the prevention of nuisances and the spread of disease, for the protection of health; and the building inspector shall make or cause to be made any such inspections relative to the construction of buildings or other structures. All other investigations, except where otherwise provided, shall be made by the chief of police or some other officer designated by the president. 
(Code 1965, § 10.005) 
Sec. 22-36. - Fees. 
    In the absence of provisions to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to the village clerk. When an applicant has not engaged in the business until after the expiration of part of the current license year, the license fee shall be prorated by quarters and the fee paid for such quarter or fraction thereof during which the business has been or will be pursued. Except as otherwise provided all license fees shall become a part of the corporate fund. 
(Code 1965, § 10.006) 
Sec. 22-37. - Expiration of licenses. 
(a)  All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal year of the village where no provision to the contrary is made. 
(b)  The village clerk shall mail to all licensees of the village a statement at the time of the expiration of the license held by the licensee, three weeks prior to the date of such expiration. Provided that failure to send out such notice, or the failure of the licensee to receive it, shall not excuse a licensee from a failure to secure a new license or a renewal thereof, nor shall it be a defense in action for operation without a license. 
(Code 1965, § 10.007) 
Sec. 22-38. - Building and premises. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances of the village. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning ordinance of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 10.008) 
Sec. 22-39. - Change of location. 
    The location of any licensed business or occupation or of any permitted act may be changed, provided ten days' notice thereof is given to the village clerk, in the absence of any provision to the contrary, provided that the building, zoning and frontage consent requirements of the ordinances are complied with. 
(Code 1965, § 10.009) 
Sec. 22-40. - Inspections. 
(a)  Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by ordinance, or are reasonably necessary thereto to secure compliance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b)  Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee of the village whose business is governed by the provision to give any authorized officer or employee of the village requesting the same, sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such analysis upon request. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the president and board of trustees may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the village who refuses to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection or take an adequate sample of said commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection, provided that no license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises in the name of the village, stating that such inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to make the inspection or to obtain the sample. 
(Code 1965, § 10.010) 
Sec. 22-41. - Nuisances. 
    No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to a nuisance in fact. 
(Code 1965, § 10.011) 
Sec. 22-42. - Revocation. 
    Any license or permit for a limited time may be revoked by the president and board of trustees during the life of such license or permit for the violation by the licensee or permittee of any ordinance provision relating to the license or permit, the subject of the license or permit, or the premises occupied; such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. 
(Code 1965, § 10.012) 
Sec. 22-43. - Posting of license. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the village to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such business at all times. 
(Code 1965, § 10.013) 
Sec. 22-44. - Vehicle tags. 
    Whenever the number of vehicles used is a basis of a license fee, the village clerk shall furnish each licensee with a tag or sticker for each vehicle covered by the license and such tag or sticker shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each such vehicle while it is in use. 
(Code 1965, § 10.014) 
Sec. 22-45. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 10.015) 
Secs. 22-46-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MERCHANTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-71-22-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AUTOMOBILE SERVICE STATIONS 

Sec. 22-91. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the village without having first obtained a license therefore. The annual license fees are as follows: 
Storage tanks: 
500 gallons or less ..... $75.00 
Over 500 gallons, but not exceeding 1,000 gallons ..... 100.00 
For each additional 1,000 gallons or fraction thereof ..... 25.00 
(b)  No such license shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be used fully comply with the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 15.101; Ord. No. 07-30, § 1, 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 22-92. - Definition; applicability. 
(a)  An automatic service station is any place of business where gasoline, or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines, are sold or offered for sale at retail, and dispensed into fuel tanks of such motor vehicles. 
(b)  This definition shall include also a private storage and dispensing of such products for the same purpose as those served by a service station, whether the storage is maintained for the use or benefit of the owner, lessee, agents or employees of either, or of any others. 
(c)  The requirements covering service stations shall also govern underground storage maintained at general storage plants and places other than service stations, so far as applicable. 
(Code 1965, § 15.102) 
Sec. 22-93. - Non-business service stations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use of automobiles for the owner, lessee, employees or agents of such person, firm or corporation shall comply with all of the provisions of this division other than the requirement for the payment of a fee. 
(Code 1965, § 15.103) 
Sec. 22-94. - Dispensing fuel into receptacles other than fuel tanks. 
    No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion system of such vehicles; provided, however, that individual sales up to five gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with the Gasoline Receptacle Labeling Act, 430 ILCS 20/0.01 et seq., such individual sales to be limited to five gallons to any one person. 
(Code 1965, § 15.104) 
Sec. 22-95. - Toilet and lavatory facilities. 
(a)  Each filling station shall be equipped with toilet and lavatory facilities, which shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(b)  Each lavatory shall be provided with hot and cold running water, soap and individual or roller type towels of either paper or cloth. 
(c)  No permit for a new filling station shall be issued unless the plans show provisions for separate toilet and lavatory facilities for men and for women. 
(Code 1965, § 15.122) 
Sec. 22-96. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.124) 
Secs. 22-97-22-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BANKERS AND MONEY CHANGERS 

Sec. 22-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Banker means any commercial bank or savings and loan association. 
    Money changer means any person, firm or corporation, other than bankers, engaged as a dealer in money or exchange. 
(Code 1965, § 16.160) 
Sec. 22-122. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in business as a banker or money changer in the village without first having secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 16.161) 
Sec. 22-123. - Application for license. 
    Application for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16.162) 
Sec. 22-124. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee to engage in business as a banker is as established by the village board from time to time. The annual license fee to engage in business as a money changer is as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.163) 
Sec. 22-125. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.164) 
Secs. 22-126-22-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BARBERSHOPS, BEAUTY SHOPS, SALONS AND SPAS 

Sec. 22-151. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in business as a barbershop, beauty shop, salon and/or spa in the village without first having secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 15.150) 
Sec. 22-152. - Application for license. 
    Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15.151) 
Sec. 22-153. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for doing business as a barbershop, beauty shop, salon and/or spa shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.152) 
Sec. 22-154. - Hours of operation. 
    No barbershop, beauty shop, salon and/or spa shall be operated and open to the public any day of the week before 7:30 a.m. and after 10:00 p.m. 
(Code 1965, § 15.153) 
Sec. 22-155. - Visibility into interior. 
    No barbershop, beauty shop, salon and/or spa operating within a building intended for business or commercial use shall contain any screen, blind, curtain, partition, window covering, or visual obstruction of any kind which could restrict or prevent clear visibility into the interior of such premises from an adjacent street or sidewalk through the building's exterior doors and windows. 
(Code 1965, § 15.154) 
Sec. 22-156. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.156) 
Secs. 22-157-22-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO DEALERS 

Sec. 22-181. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale at retail of cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form or in any number without having obtained first a license therefor. Applications for such license shall be made to the clerk; and no such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character, or to any corporation that is not represented in the village by a person of good character. 
(Code 1965, § 15.201) 
Sec. 22-182. - Vending machines. 
    Any person, firm or corporation selling or permitting the sale of cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form from any vending machine shall first secure a permit required in section 22-181 and comply with all the requirements of this division and article IV of this chapter relating to vending machines. The annual fee for such licenses shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.202) 
Sec. 22-183. - License fee for over-the-counter sales. 
    The annual license fee for over-the-counter cigarette and tobacco sales at retail shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.203) 
Sec. 22-184. - Sanitation. 
    Premises and buildings used for the sale of cigarettes, cigars and tobacco shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition; the health officer shall investigate such places sufficiently often to insure compliance with the provisions of this section. Provided further that any dealer licensed hereunder shall give samples of cigarettes to the health officer when requested, for analysis. 
(Code 1965, § 15.204) 
Sec. 22-185. - Self-service sales prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, or display tobacco products for sale at any location where the consumer can acquire those products through self-service. All tobacco products will be displayed from behind a sales/service counter so that no consumer can access tobacco products without assistance by an employee of the licensee. This restriction shall not apply to customer self-service as described in section 22-182 (Vending machines). 
(Code 1965, § 15.204.1) 
Sec. 22-186. - Sales to minors; sales by minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell or give cigarettes, cigars or tobacco to any male or female child under 18 years of age except upon the written order or an adult known to the dealer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to engage, employ or permit any person under 18 years of age to sell tobacco products in any licensed premises. 
(Code 1965, § 15.205) 
Sec. 22-187. - Posting of warning to minors. 
(a)  Every retailer of tobacco products shall place and maintain, in legible condition, at each point of sale of tobacco products to consumers, including the front of each vending machine, a sign stating: 
Warning 
It is a Violation of the Law For Cigarettes Or Other Tobacco Products To Be Sold To Any Person Under The Age of 18. 
(b)  The sign shall not be less than eight inches by 11 inches in size, except for a sign placed on the front of a vending machine. The sign for a vending machine shall not be less than four inches by four inches in size. The text of such printed card shall be in red letters on a white background, said letters to be at least one inch high. 
(Code 1965, § 15.205.1) 
Sec. 22-188. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.206) 
Secs. 22-189-22-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - COAL AND LUMBER YARDS AND STOREHOUSES 

Sec. 22-211. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall do business as a coal or lumber dealer maintaining a coal or lumber yard or storehouse in the village without first securing a license therefor as is herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 15.301) 
Sec. 22-212. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for either a coal of lumber dealer maintaining a coal or lumber yard or storehouse in the village shall be $750.00 per year. 
(Code 1965, § 15.302; Ord. No. 07-28, § 1, 9-24-2007) 
Sec. 22-213. - Piling coal or lumber. 
    It shall be unlawful to pile any coal or lumber in such a way that it can fall down on adjoining property or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place. 
(Code 1965, § 15.303) 
Sec. 22-214. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be ) subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.305) 
Secs. 22-215-22-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - DAY NURSERIES 

Sec. 22-231. - Definition. 
    The term "day nursery," as used in this division, is hereby construed to mean any specially equipped room or quarters where parents or guardians for a money consideration may temporarily leave their children or minor wards during the daytime with trained attendants while the parents or guardians are otherwise occupied. 
(Code 1965, § 16.260) 
Sec. 22-232. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate a day nursery in the village without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 12.261) 
Sec. 22-233. - Application for license. 
    Application for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16.262) 
Sec. 22-234. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for such a license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.263) 
Sec. 22-235. - Sanitation; inspections; revocation of license. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensee at all times to keep the licensed premises in a safe, clean and sanitary condition. The health officer shall make periodic inspections of all premises licensed hereunder to determine that they are being kept in a safe, clean and sanitary condition. If the health officer deems it necessary, he shall recommend the revocation of such license to the president and board of trustees. Whenever it shall appear to their satisfaction that the licensee or its agents or employees have violated any provisions of the ordinances of this village or the laws of the state relating to day nurseries or the moral turpitude of the licensee, its agents or employees has been clearly evidenced, the president and board of trustees shall promptly cause such license to be revoked. 
(Code 1965, § 16.265) 
Sec. 22-236. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.266) 
Secs. 22-237-22-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - DRY CLEANERS AND LAUNDRIES 

Sec. 22-251. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dry cleaner means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of cleaning or pressing wearing apparel or household linens, curtains or draperies by means of the use of solvents or non-water-based cleaners, on premises located within the village. 
    Laundry means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of washing, drying, starching or ironing wearing apparel or household linens, towels or other washable fabrics by means of the use of water and soaps or detergents on premises located within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 16.360) 
Sec. 22-252. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of a dry cleaner or laundry in the village without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 16.361) 
Sec. 22-253. - Application for license. 
    Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16.362) 
Sec. 22-254. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for such a license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.363) 
Sec. 22-255. - Sanitation; inspections; revocation of license. 
    The health officer shall make periodic inspections of all establishments licensed hereunder to determine that the premises and the persons employed thereon are being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. If the health officer deems it necessary, he shall recommend the revocation of such license to the president and board of trustees. Whenever it shall appear to their satisfaction that the licensee or its agents or employees have violated any provision of the ordinances of this village or the laws of the state relating to dry cleaners and laundries, the president and board of trustees shall promptly cause such license to be revoked. 
(Code 1965, § 16.364) 
Sec. 22-256. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.

Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of servicing, repairing or refilling fire extinguishers shall be construed to be a dealer hereunder.
