DIVISION 10. - FLORISTS 

Sec. 22-291. - License required; definition. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in business as a florist in the village without first having secured a license therefor. Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of selling flowers, shrubs or ornamental plants from a store, nursery or garden supply center, at retail or wholesale, in the village shall be construed to be a florist. 
(Code 1965, § 15.401) 
Sec. 22-292. - Application for license. 
    Applications for such licenses to do business as a florist shall be made in writing to the clerk, and must state thereon the nature of the business and the proposed location. 
(Code 1965, § 15.402) 
Sec. 22-293. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for doing business as a florist shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.403) 
Sec. 22-294. - Dead or dying vegetation causing noxious odors. 
    No owner or operator of a florist shop shall permit any dead or dying vegetation to remain in or upon the premises so as to cause noxious or disagreeable odors. 
(Code 1965, § 15.404) 
Sec. 22-295. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.405) 
Secs. 22-296-22-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - ITINERANT MERCHANTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of village to license, tax, regulate itinerant merchants, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

Sec. 22-311. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to do business in the village as an itinerant merchant without having first secured a license as provided herein. In the event that two or more itinerant merchants shall do business as participants in a multi-booth itinerant merchant show held at a single location in the village on the same date or dates, only one license need be secured by the sponsoring organization. For the purpose of this division, any merchant engaging or intending to engage in business as a merchant in the village for a period of time not exceeding 100 days shall be considered as an itinerant merchant; provided, however, that a peddler, for whom a business license is required under division 15 of this article, shall not be considered an itinerant merchant. 
(Code 1965, § 15.501) 
Sec. 22-312. - Application for license. 
    Every application for such license shall set forth the commodities to be sold, the state sales tax identifying number, and the place intended to be occupied or used for the business. 
(Code 1965, § 15.502) 
Sec. 22-313. - License fee. 
    The license fee for an itinerant merchant shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.503) 
Sec. 22-314. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.504) 
Secs. 22-315-22-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - KENNELS AND ANIMAL HOSPITALS 

Sec. 22-331. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of operating a dog kennel or animal hospital in the village without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 16.590) 
Sec. 22-332. - Application for license. 
    Application for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16.591) 
Sec. 22-333. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee to operate a dog kennel or animal hospital in the village shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.592) 
Sec. 22-334. - Sanitation; inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensee at all times to keep the licensed premises in a clean and sanitary condition. The health officer shall make periodic inspections of all establishments licensed hereunder to determine whether the sanitary regulations of this division are being observed. 
(Code 1965, § 16.593) 
Sec. 22-335. - Revocation of license. 
    The health officer may recommend, at any time, the revocation of any license issued under the terms of this division, and the president and board of trustees shall revoke such license whenever it appears to their satisfaction that the licensee has violated the provisions of any ordinance of the village or any law of the state relating to kennels and animal hospitals. 
(Code 1965, § 16.594) 
Sec. 22-336. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.595) 
Secs. 22-337-22-350. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - MOTELS AND AUTO COURTS 

Sec. 22-351. - License required; definition. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any motel or auto court in the village without having first obtained a license therefor or without complying with all of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  The term "motel or auto court" as used in this division shall be construed to mean any parking lot or garage for the accommodation of motor vehicles where transient sleeping accommodations of five or more units are afforded or provided on the same premises for the public or for the occupants of such automobiles. Provided that a hotel which furnishes parking space or has a garage in connection with the hotel shall not be construed as an auto court. 
(Code 1965, § 16.601) 
Sec. 22-352. - Application for license; submission of plans. 
    Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain any motel or auto court shall file an application with the clerk, and shall state thereon the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the owner or manager thereof, the location of the auto court, and the maximum number of persons and vehicles to be accommodated. This application shall be accompanied by plans of the toilet, bath and wash basin facilities, slop sinks, water faucets, sewer connections, driveways and other improvements. 
(Code 1965, § 16.602) 
Sec. 22-353. - Registration of guests. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the manager of any motel or auto court to maintain a register of all guests who occupy, at any time, a room or rooms on the premises which afford sleeping accommodations. Such register must bear the name and residence or business address of each guest; provided, however, that when any such room or rooms are occupied by two or more persons of the same family, the register need only bear the name and address of one adult member of such family but must indicate the number of persons who will occupy such room or rooms. The register must also bear the initials or signature of the registration clerk or other representative of the motel or auto court who shall be designated by the manager to accept and process such registrations, such initials or signature to be evidence of verification of identification of the guest by such clerk or other representative. The nature of the source of identification shall be a copy of a valid driver's license or some other form of valid state identification that contains a photograph of the guest or guests registering. Said copies shall be maintained by the motel or auto court for at least one year from the date of registration. 
    The register shall immediately be made available to all village law enforcement officers, when requested, in the normal scope of their duties for the purpose of conducting a criminal investigation. 
(Code 1965, § 16.602.1; Ord. No. 04-01, § 1, 1-26-2004; Ord. No. 13-04, § 1, 2-25-2013) 
Sec. 22-354. - Furnishing false identification. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who registers to occupy a sleeping room or rooms in any motel or auto court located within the village to furnish false identification. 
(Code 1965, § 16.602.2) 
Sec. 22-355. - License fee; term of license. 
    The annual license fee for any such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time, and the license year shall be the same as that provided for general business licenses in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 16.604) 
Sec. 22-356. - Sanitary facilities. 
    No such premises shall be operated as an auto court unless they are equipped with adequate toilet and other sanitary facilities to serve the total number of persons accommodated therein. All such sanitary facilities shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewer system of the village if the premises are located on a street served by such sewer. 
(Code 1965, § 16.605) 
Sec. 22-357. - Permitting violation of law; cleanliness; inspections; prohibited rentals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any ordinance or law on or in any auto court. Such premises must be kept clean and sanitary at all times and all waste material must be removed therefrom at least once every 24 hours. The building inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected each auto court to see to the compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any auto court or any portion thereof for immoral purpose. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to permit the renting of rooms on an hourly basis. 
(Code 1965, § 16.606) 
Sec. 22-358. - Lights. 
    Any area or premises of an auto court open to use by the public or by all persons staying in or being accommodated in the court shall be kept adequately lighted at night time; provided that such lights must be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any adjacent premises. 
(Code 1965, § 16.607) 
Sec. 22-359. - Trailers. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of an auto court for the accommodation of a trailer. 
(Code 1965, § 16.608) 
Sec. 22-360. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.609) 
Secs. 22-361-22-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - PAINT DEALERS AND DISTRIBUTORS 

Sec. 22-381. - Definition. 
    The term "paint dealer or distributor," as used in this division, is hereby construed to mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in the sale or distribution of any paints, dry colors, wallpaper, varnishes, calcimine, white or red lead, raw or boiled linseed oil, turpentine, benzine, naphtha or painter's tools, supplies and equipment from a location within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 15.760) 
Sec. 22-382. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in business as a paint dealer at retail or distributor at wholesale in the village without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 15.761) 
Sec. 22-383. - Application for license. 
    Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15.762) 
Sec. 22-384. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for doing business as a paint dealer and/or distributor shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.763) 
Secs. 22-385-22-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - PEDDLERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of village to license, tax, regulate peddlers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

Sec. 22-401. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in the business of hawker or peddler of any merchandise, article or thing without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 15.801) 
Sec. 22-402. - Application for license. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk and shall state thereon the number of vehicles, if any, intended to be operated, the kind of merchandise to be peddled, and the permanent address of the peddler. 
(Code 1965, § 15.802) 
Sec. 22-403. - License fee. 
    The fee for such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.803) 
Sec. 22-404. - Fraud. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensed peddler or hawker to commit any fraud, or to cheat or misrepresent, whether through himself or through an employee, while acting as a peddler in the village, or barter, sell or peddle, any goods or merchandise or wares other than those specified in his application for a license. Any peddler or hawker committing such act shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 22-405. 
(Code 1965, § 15.804) 
Sec. 22-405. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.805) 
Secs. 22-406-22-420. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 16. - SELF-SERVICE COIN-OPERATED DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 22-421. - Compliance with ordinances. 
    Dry cleaning establishments commonly known as self-service coin-operated dry cleaning establishments shall comply with all the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1301) 
Sec. 22-422. - Attendant required. 
    There shall be present in every self-service coin-operated establishment of this type an attendant during all operational hours of the establishment. The attendant shall not permit any person under the age of 15 years to operate any such machine. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1302) 
Sec. 22-423. - Qualifications of attendant. 
(a)  No person shall act as an attendant in any such dry cleaning establishment unless he shall be the holder of a current certificate of fitness, issued by the fire chief and the health officer. Before the issuance of any such certificate, the fire chief and the health officer shall examine the applicant as to his qualifications to fill such position. To receive a certificate of fitness the applicant must: 
(1)  Be a lawful resident of the United States; 
(2)  Be at least 18 years of age; 
(3)  Be able to understand and speak the English language; 
(4)  Be of good moral character; 
(5)  Be familiar with the provisions of the law and the regulations governing dry cleaning, particularly those relating to the service to be performed by the applicant; and 
(6)  Be familiar with the risks incident to the service to be performed by him, and capable of taking on necessary precautions. 
(b)  The annual fee for the issuance or renewal of any such certificate shall be as established by the village board from time to time and shall be paid to the village collector. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1303) 
Sec. 22-424. - Approval of plans. 
    Any person establishing a dry cleaning establishment of the coin-operated self-service type shall be required to submit to the board of trustees for their approval a complete set of plans and specifications of the building in which any such dry cleaning establishment is to be located and also a complete diagram of the floor plan of each room to be occupied by such dry cleaning establishment, correctly showing the arrangement or setting of all machinery and equipment to be installed therein. Each such plan shall be explicit and complete. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1304) 
Sec. 22-425. - Hours of operation. 
    No coin-operated self-service dry-cleaning establishment shall be operated between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1305) 
Sec. 22-426. - License required; license fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate or maintain a coin-operated dry cleaning establishment in the village without first securing a license therefor. The annual license fee for such a license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1306) 
Sec. 22-427. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1307) 
Secs. 22-428-22-440. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 17. - SELF-SERVICE COIN-OPERATED LAUNDRY ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 22-441. - Compliance with ordinances. 
    Laundry establishments commonly known as self-service coin-operated laundry establishments shall comply with all the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1401) 
Sec. 22-442. - Attendant required. 
    There shall be present in every self-service coin-operated establishment of this type an attendant during all operational hours of the establishment. The attendant shall not permit any person under the age of 15 years to operate any such machine. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1402) 
Sec. 22-443. - Qualifications of attendant. 
(a)  No person shall act as an attendant in any such laundry establishment unless he shall be the holder of a certificate of fitness issued by the fire chief and the health officer. Before the issuance of any such certificate, the fire chief and the health officer shall examine the applicant as to his qualifications to fill such position. To receive a certificate of fitness the applicant must: 
(1)  Be 18 years of age, of temperate habits and of good moral character; 
(2)  Be able to speak and understand the English language; 
(3)  Produce evidence of his employment or occupation and residence for the previous two years; 
(4)  Be familiar with the operation of the machines in the establishment; and 
(5)  Be familiar with risks incident to the operation of the machines and capable of taking the necessary precautions. 
(b)  The annual fee for the issuance or renewal of any such certificate shall be as established by the village board from time to time and shall be paid to the village collector. 
(c)  Where a self-service coin-operated dry cleaning establishment and a self-service coin-operated laundry establishment are operated on the same premises, only one attendant, who is the holder of a certificate of fitness issued pursuant to this division or division 16 of this article, shall be required. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1403) 
Sec. 22-444. - Approval of plans. 
    Any person establishing a laundry of the coin-operated self-service type shall be required to submit to the board of trustees for their approval a complete set of plans and specifications of the building in which such establishment is to be located and also a complete diagram of the floor plan of each room to be occupied by such establishment, showing the arrangement or setting of all machinery and equipment to be installed therein. Each such plan shall be explicit and complete. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1404) 
Sec. 22-445. - Hours of operation. 
    No coin-operated self-service laundry now or hereafter established shall be operated between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1405) 
Sec. 22-446. - License fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate or maintain a coin-operated laundry establishment in the village without first securing a license therefor. The annual license fee for such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1406) 
Sec. 22-447. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1407) 
Secs. 22-448-22-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 18. - STORAGE FACILITIES 

Sec. 22-461. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Individual storage space, within the self-service storage facility, means any space rented or leased by a person for the purpose of storing personal property. 
    Occupant means a person, his sublessee, successor or assigns entitled to the use of the storage space at a self-service storage facility under a rental agreement to the exclusion of others. 
    Owner means the owner, operator, lessor or sublessor of a self-service storage facility, his agent, or any other person authorized by him to manage the facility, or to receive rent from an occupant under a rental agreement. 
    Person means any individual, copartnership, firm, association, joint stock company, corporation, or any combination of individuals of whatever form or character. 
    Personal property means movable property not affixed to land and includes, but is not limited to, goods, merchandise, household items, tools, machinery and equipment. 
    Rental agreement means any agreement or lease, written or oral, that establishes or modifies the terms, conditions, rules or any other provisions concerning the use and occupancy of a self-service storage facility. 
    Self-service storage facility means any real property designed and used for the purpose of renting or leasing individual storage space to occupants who are to have access to such for the purpose of storing and removing personal property. A self-service storage facility, as defined in this section, is not a warehouse for the purpose of article 7 of the Uniform Commercial Code, 810 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq. In the event an owner issues any warehouse receipt, bill of lading, or other document of title for the personal property stored, the provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code, 810 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq., do not apply. 
(Code 1965, § 16.901) 
Sec. 22-462. - User fee imposed. 
    There is imposed hereby and shall accrue and shall be collected a user fee as herein provided upon the rental or leasing of any individual storage space in the village at the rate of three percent of the gross rental or leasing charge. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the user fee imposed by this section shall be borne by the occupant of any such individual storage space. The user fee shall be in addition to any and all other taxes. It shall be the duty of every owner of every self-service storage facility to collect the user fee from the occupant and pay over to the village treasurer of the village the user fee under the rules and regulations prescribed by the president and board of trustees and as otherwise provided by this division. 
(Code 1965, § 16.902) 
Sec. 22-463. - Payment of user fee; penalty for nonpayment. 
(a)  Every owner within the village shall file with the village treasurer a sworn user fee return on a monthly basis, due not later than the 15th day of the month following the preceding month for which the return is being made, showing user fee receipts received with respect to storage space rented or leased during the preceding monthly period and upon forms prescribed by the village treasurer. At the time of filing the return, the owner shall pay to the village treasurer of the village all user fees due for the period to which the return applies. 
(b)  If for any reason any user fee is not paid when due, a penalty at the rate of two percent per month on the amount of user fee which remains unpaid shall be added and collected. Whenever any person shall fail to pay any amounts as herein provided, upon request of the village treasurer, the village attorney shall bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of user fees on behalf of the village in any court of competent jurisdiction, with costs of such enforcement to be borne by the owner. 
(Code 1965, § 16.903) 
Sec. 22-464. - Records. 
    Every owner in the village shall keep books and records reflecting the price, rents or charges made or changed and occupancies assessed under this division. The village president and/or the village treasurer or their designee shall, at all reasonable times, have full access to the books and records. 
(Code 1965, § 16.904) 
Sec. 22-465. - Suspension or revocation of licenses. 
    After a hearing held by the village president, in the event the village president shall find that any owner has willfully avoided payment of the user fee imposed by this division, the village president may suspend or revoke all village licenses held by such owner. The owner shall have an opportunity to be heard, and such hearing shall be held not less than five days after notice of the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall be addressed to the owner at his last known place of business. The suspension or revocation of any license shall not release or discharge the owner from civil liability for the payment of the user fees nor for prosecution of such offense. 
(Code 1965, § 16.905) 
Sec. 22-466. - Disposition of proceeds of user fee and fines. 
    All proceeds which result from the imposition of fees levied and fines imposed pursuant to this division shall be paid into the treasury of the village to be used for general municipal expenditures. 
(Code 1965, § 16.906) 
Sec. 22-467. - Penalty. 
(a)  It is a misdemeanor for any person to violate any of the provisions of this division unless such violation is by this division or other law of the state declared to be a felony. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation convicted of a misdemeanor for a violation of any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.907) 
Secs. 22-468-22-470. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 19. - MOTOR FREIGHT TERMINALS[3] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 22-471. - Definitions.

(Ord. No. 06-43, § 1, 12-18-2006) 
Sec. 22-472. - Compliance with ordinances.

ARTICLE IV. - VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 22-521. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain in the village any automatic vending machine for the sale of any or all products or merchandise, excluding milk, the sale of which is regulated under chapter 42, article III, including but not limited to candy, nuts, soft drinks, popcorn, cigarettes, cigars or gum, without first having obtained a license for each of such automatic vending machines as provided in this article. Such license shall be renewed annually. 
(Code 1965, § 13.101) 
Sec. 22-522. - Application for license. 
    Any person desiring to sell candy, nuts, soft drinks, popcorn, cigarettes or gum by means of automatic vending machines shall make application for a license for that purpose to the village clerk, in which application shall be set forth the full name of the applicant and the number of machines for which the applicant desires licenses. 
(Code 1965, § 13.102) 
Sec. 22-523. - License fee; tags. 
(a)  The person in possession of any such machine shall pay a fee as established by the village board from time to time. 
(b)  The village clerk shall issue a decalcomania, tag, or sticker for each such machine to be so operated by the applicant in the village. The person in possession of each such machine shall be responsible to make certain that such decalcomania, tag or sticker is affixed to the front of the machine or to the front of a stand or bracket supporting such machine so that it can be readily viewed by the public and the village officials. 
(Code 1965, § 13.103) 
Sec. 22-524. - Inspections; analysis of food and drink. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the health officer and he is hereby authorized and empowered to inspect and examine all food or drink being offered for sale by means of the automatic vending machine for the purpose of ascertaining whether the laws of the state and of the village in relation to sales from the vending machines are complied with, and that the food and drink so offered for sale have been kept fresh, clean and wholesome; and it shall be the duty of all persons operating the vending machine, upon the demand of the health officer, to furnish to him for his inspection samples of all such food and drink, which samples may be analyzed by or under the direction of the health officer, and a record of such analysis shall be made and kept in his office for the inspection of the public. 
(b)  The health officer shall also inspect all locations where the machines are placed in order to ascertain that the candy, nuts, soft drinks, popcorn and gum shall be free of contamination and in a wholesome condition; and all machines shall be kept within the enclosure of a substantial building, and the owners of the machines shall, on the request of the health officer, furnish keys for the machines so that the contents of same may be inspected in company with a representative that the owner of the machine may designate. 
(Code 1965, § 13.104) 
Sec. 22-525. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 13.105) 
Secs. 22-526-22-550. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ASPHALT PLANTS 

Sec. 22-551. - License required; license fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to maintain or operate any asphalt manufacturing plant, or any asphalt refining or treatment plant in the village without having first secured a license therefor. The annual fee for such licenses shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.101) 
Sec. 22-552. - Application for license. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk in compliance with the general ordinances of the village relative to license applications. 
(Code 1965, § 16.102) 
Sec. 22-553. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any such plant during the nighttime; and it shall be unlawful to operate any such plant at any time between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of any day, or at any time on Sunday. 
(Code 1965, § 16.103) 
Sec. 22-554. - Requirements. 
    No such plant shall be operated unless it is equipped with adequate devices in good working order to prevent the escape of dense smoke, noxious fumes, soot or dust. 
(Code 1965, § 16.104) 
Sec. 22-555. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.105) 
Secs. 22-556-22-570. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DRUG, CHEMICAL AND PAINT FACTORIES 

Sec. 22-571. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a drug, chemical or paint factory as defined in this article without having first secured a license therefor as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 16.301) 
Sec. 22-572. - Definition. 
    The term "drug, chemical or paint factory" as used in this article shall be construed to mean and include any premises or establishment where soda, soda ash, sal soda, bicarbonate of soda, caustic soda, alcohol, ether, essential oils, carbonic acid gas, chlorine, aniline, perfumes, coal tar chemicals, inks, dyes, bluing, boiler compounds, disinfectants, cleaning compounds, explosives, photographic chemicals, glycerine, proprietary or patent medicines, paints, linseed oil, shellac, varnish, enamels, or other chemicals, drugs or preparations containing any of the foregoing, are made, mixed, compounded, purified or prepared for sale or for commercial or industrial use. 
(Code 1965, § 16.302) 
Sec. 22-573. - Application for license. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the ordinance provisions relating thereto, and each such application shall state whether or not a certificate of occupancy has been issued covering the premises and use contemplated. 
(Code 1965, § 16.303) 
Sec. 22-574. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for the operation of a drug, chemical or paint factory shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.304) 
Sec. 22-575. - Sanitation and cleanliness; removal of fumes, odors and dust. 
    All such premises shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be thoroughly cleaned of all dirt, refuse and debris at least once every 24 hours. Each building, or part thereof, used for such purposes shall be adequately equipped with devices to remove and eliminate all fumes, odors and dust. Adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities for employees shall be provided. 
(Code 1965, § 16.305) 
Sec. 22-576. - Inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this article and the provisions of all ordinances relating to fire and health hazards applicable to such premises. 
(Code 1965, § 16.306) 
Sec. 22-577. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.307) 
Secs. 22-578-22-610. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FACTORIES, TANNERIES, PACKING HOUSES, BLACKSMITH OR MACHINE SHOPS, FOUNDRIES AND PUBLIC WAREHOUSES 

Sec. 22-611. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain any public warehouse, factory for the manufacture of tallow candles, soap or fertilizer, tannery or packing house, or blacksmith or machine shop within the village without first having secured a license therefor as is hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1965, § 16.401) 
Sec. 22-612. - Application for license. 
    Application for such license shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16.402) 
Sec. 22-613. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for such licenses shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.403) 
Sec. 22-614. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-10 of this Code, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.405) 
Secs. 22-615-22-630. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 22-631. - Definition. 
    The term "parking lot" as used in this article shall be construed to mean and include any place maintained for the outdoor parking of cars, excepting on a street, alley or other public place, where such parking is permitted upon the payment of compensation or is made available to patrons or customers of any places of business. 
(Code 1965, § 16.701) 
Sec. 22-632. - Permit. 
(a)  Required; application. It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot without first having obtained a permit therefor. Applications for such permit shall be made in writing to the clerk and shall contain all necessary information to insure compliance with the provisions of this article, including a description of the location, size, number of cars to be accommodated, and a statement of any various services other than parking, or of any commodities for sale, offered to patrons of the parking lot. 
(b)  Fee. The annual fee for such licenses shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.702) 
Sec. 22-633. - Maximum number of cars; marking of spaces; entrances and exits. 
    Not more than one car for each 200 square feet of area shall be accepted for parking in any such place. Each parking lot shall be marked so as to show the parking place allotted for each car, and shall have sufficient entrances and exits to permit the entrance and egress of cars without obstruction to traffic. 
(Code 1965, § 16.703) 
Sec. 22-634. - Fire protection. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any parking lot unless there are available on the premises adequate fire extinguishers and personnel competent to use them. There shall be maintained on each parking lot at least one hand chemical fire extinguisher having a capacity of one quart of liquid or 21/2 pounds of carbon dioxide for each ten cars for which accommodations are offered, which extinguishers shall always be maintained in good order and in accessible places. Provided, however, that where accommodations are provided for more than 100 cars, there shall be maintained in addition to the hand extinguishers required at least one portable chemical fire extinguisher having a capacity of 21/2 gallons of liquid or 15 pounds of carbon dioxide. 
(Code 1965, § 16.704) 
Sec. 22-635. - Driveways. 
    It shall be the duty of the operator of each parking lot to maintain the sidewalk and parkway over which such driveway passes in good condition. No driveway fee need be paid by the holders of a parking lot license. 
(Code 1965, § 16.705) 
Sec. 22-636. - Posting of rates; attendant; refuse containers. 
(a)  At the entrance of each parking lot there shall be posted, in words and figures large enough to be read by prospective patrons, a statement of the rates to be charged and of the closing hours. There shall be at least one attendant on the premises at all times during which the parking lot is open for business. 
(b)  If a parking lot is maintained in connection with a licensed establishment serving food for consumption on the premises, and food or drinks are served to the occupants of cars, sufficient adequate containers must be maintained for all trash and refuse, and the premises must be kept thoroughly clean by the proprietor. 
(Code 1965, § 16.707) 
Sec. 22-637. - Surface. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot unless the surface thereof is covered with concrete, asphalt, macadam or similar paving; and such parking lot shall at all times be kept clean and free from dust or refuse. 
(Code 1965, § 16.709) 
Sec. 22-638. - Condition of vehicles; prohibited uses. 
    It shall be unlawful to park or store, in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in a condition ready for use, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such lot. It shall be unlawful to use any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the primary purpose of displaying the same for sale, or to use any parking lot or portion thereof as an automobile repair shop. 
(Code 1965, § 16.711) 
Sec. 22-639. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.712) 
Secs. 22-640-22-660. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PUBLIC GARAGES 

Sec. 22-661. - License required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain a public garage in the village without having first obtained a license therefor as is provided in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 16.801) 
Sec. 22-662. - Application for license; license fee. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk in writing, and shall state the location of the garage and the number of cars which can be accommodated therein. The annual fee for such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. No fee for maintaining a driveway to a garage licensed hereunder shall be required. 
(Code 1965, § 16.802) 
Sec. 22-663. - Smoking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or light a cigarette, pipe or cigar in any public garage. 
(Code 1965, § 16.803) 
Sec. 22-664. - Premises; building. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building, or in any building or structure used for school, church or theater purposes, or in any building which does not conform to the requirements of the building ordinances. The premises of every garage must be kept clean and free from flammable waste. 
(Code 1965, § 16.804) 
Sec. 22-665. - Changing vehicle identification marks or license tags. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change the identification marks on the engine of any car or automobile in any public garage. It shall be unlawful to change the license tags on such cars, excepting to accord with the register of motor vehicles kept by the secretary of state of Illinois. 
(Code 1965, § 16.805) 
Sec. 22-666. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made such inspections of public garages as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. Any police officer may be permitted at any reasonable time to view any car stored or kept in any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal any motor car or motor vehicle from inspection. 
(Code 1965, § 16.807) 
Sec. 22-667. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.808) 
Secs. 22-668-22-690. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SOLICITORS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 28, 2013, and Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, adopted March 25, 2013, amended former Art. X, §§ 22-691-22-702, in its entirety which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 16.1101-16.1112. 

Sec. 22-691. - Definition. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, the terms "soliciting" or "solicitation" shall be defined and shall include any one or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders, either for immediate or future deliver, for the purchase of goods, wares merchandise, magazines, foodstuffs, or services of any kind or description, for any kind of consideration; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any kind, type or character; 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers, or any other type of publication; 
(4)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of any type, kind, or character or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable, religious, civic, local fire or police auxiliary, school, scouting, or other not-for-profit association, organization, or corporation; or 
(5)  Going upon any premises and ringing the doorbell upon or near any door, knocking upon any door, or creating any sound in a manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of engaging in any activities described in this section. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, the terms "soliciting" or "solicitation" shall not include the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to conduct any of the activities enumerated in section 22-691(a) of this chapter when undertaken by any person pursuant to a previous appointment or invitation of the party being contacted; or 
(2)  Seeking to obtain signatures to petitions on political or public policy questions or matters. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-692. - Uninvited soliciting prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in solicitation upon any premises or in any dwelling house, apartment, or other residence located within in The village after having been asked by the owner or occupant thereof to leave such premises or residence, nor shall any person engage in solicitation upon an premises or in any dwelling, house, apartment, or other residence located thereon if such premises or dwelling building is posted against solicitation by means of a notice prominently displayed, upon which is printed the legend: 
"NO SOLICITORS" or "NO SOLICITORS INVITED" or "NO TRESPASSING" 
which notice is posted or exhibited at or near the main entrance to the premises or on or near the main door to any dwelling or residence thereon or any point of approach of entry thereto. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-693. - Time limit on solicitation and excepted activities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any of the solicitation activities defined in subsection 22-691(a) of this chapter or in any of the excepted activities listed in subsection Section 22-691(B) of this chapter at any time prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 8:00 p.m., local time, Monday through Friday, or prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 1:00 p.m., local time, Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or a state or national holiday. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013; Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 22-694. - Registration required. 
(a)  Every solicitor, except as indicated in section 22-691(b) of this chapter, prior to engaging in such activity, shall register with the village clerk and furnish in writing on an application form prescribed by the village clerk the following: 
(1)  The name, current address and telephone number of the solicitor; also the business address and telephone number if other than the residence address; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the person, firm, corporation, association, or organization by whom the solicitor is employed or with whom is associated; 
(3)  The nature of the commodities, articles, or services the solicitor is selling or offering for sale, or the charitable purpose for which goods or funds are to be solicited; 
(4)  An estimate of the time period in which solicitation activities will be pursued; 
(5)  List of other municipalities or cities where the solicitor has solicited in the past three years; 
(6)  A description of the methods of solicitation to be used; 
(7)  List of any criminal convictions of the solicitor; and 
(8)  Submission of a waiver for a name check only criminal background check. 
(b)  Registration forms may be completed in person or submitted via U.S. mail. 
(c)  A person, firm, corporation, association, or organization is limited to eight solicitors representing the person, firm, corporation, association, or organization at any time. 
(d)  Any application form containing false or untruthful information will be denied. 
(e)  The village clerk shall approve or deny an application for registration no more than three business days after receipt of a properly completed application form. Solicitors must carry the approved registration document on his or her person at all times while soliciting in the Village, and shall present proof of registration upon request. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-695. - Waiver of registration requirements. 
    The registration requirements set forth in section 22-694 of this chapter are hereby waived for groups that are community based youth groups or school sponsored student groups, provided the leader, sponsor, or organizer of such youth or student groups maintains a roster listing the names of all current members. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-696. - Registration fees. 
    Any person, firm, corporation, association, or organization eligible to conduct solicitation activities within the corporate limits of the Village of Hillside shall be required to pay a registration fee of $100.00 for each 12-month period, which includes the cost of the requestor's background check. Each subsequent solicitor associated with or employed by the person, firm, corporation, association, or organization, subject to the limitation of eight total solicitors, will be charged a background check fee of $25.00. Each solicitor will also be required to deposit a fee of $25.00, which is refundable upon the return of the undamaged solicitor badge. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013; Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 22-697. - Contents of registration; transfer of registration. 
    Approved registration(s) issued by the village clerk shall bear the name and address of the person, firm, corporation, association, or organization by and for which the solicitation is to be made, the date the registration was approved, and the dates in which the solicitation will be conducted. The registration approved by the village clerk shall be nontransferable. No permit may grant to solicit for a period of longer than 21 days, although the permitted solicitor may deliver any goods or merchandise following the 21 days which were ordered within the permit time period. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013; Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 3-25-2013) 
Sec. 22-698. - Right of occupants of residences regarding invitation of solicitors. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the village that the occupants of the residences in the village shall make the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective residences. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-699. - Duties of solicitors. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any residence in the village to first determine if there is a notice provided for in section 22-692 and to be governed by the statement contained in the notice. If the notice states "No Solicitors," or "No Solicitors Invited," or "No Trespassing" then the solicitor shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(b)  Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(c)  At the request of the occupant of the residence, the solicitor shall give to the resident a written receipt signed by the solicitor showing the name of the organization to which the registration was issued, the name of the solicitor and the amount of merchandise received. 
(d)  No solicitor shall use any tactics based on force, threat of force, or intimidation or psychological pressure to knowingly misrepresent themselves or his/her product to any Village official, or potential or actual contributor; or to make or cause to be made any contract, order form or instrument of indebtedness without full knowledge of the contributor. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-700. - Suspension or revocation of registration. 
    In the event that the village clerk shall determine that an solicitor holding a solicitor's registration has violated any of the provisions of this article, the village clerk may file written allegations with the village administrative hearing officer and, concurrently, suspend the solicitor's registration pending a hearing before the village administrative hearing officer, who, upon being notified in writing of the charges, may hold a hearing within five days from the service of notice. Written notice of the time and place of the hearing, and a copy of the allegation filed, shall be served upon the solicitor personally or by certified letter mailed to the solicitor's address listed on the registration application form. Failure to appear at said hearing will constitute a default and may result in a finding that the suspension was for good cause shown, that the suspension may be extended for a total suspension of 30 days, or that the registration may be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Sec. 22-701. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § 1, 1-28-2013) 
Secs. 22-702-22-720. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - SPRAYING PAINT 

Sec. 22-721. - Buildings to be fireproof. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct the business of painting any objects by spraying paint, lacquer or similar material, or to perform such acts in connection with any business, in any building which is not fireproof as prescribed in the ordinances relating to buildings. 
(Code 1965, § 24.701) 
Sec. 22-722. - General regulations. 
    In conducting such spraying operations all requirements of the standards of the National Board of Underwriters as printed in their Bulletin NBFU No. 35 shall be complied with. 
(Code 1965, § 24.702) 
Sec. 22-723. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.703) 
Secs. 22-724-22-740. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SIGNS 

Sec. 22-741. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Billboard means any signboard or similar structure used for the display of advertisements or notices. 
    Directional retail sign means: 
(1)  A sign containing directional information about retail establishments within the Village of Hillside necessary to regulate and control the flow of vehicular traffic; 
(2)  A sign setting forth the names of multiple retail establishments operating on a shared site of twenty (20) acres or more; and 
(3)  A sign located on property other than the shared site of the retail establishments. 
    Electrical sign means any sign containing electrical wiring which is attached or intended to be attached to an electrical energy source. 
    Electronic message center means any sign which uses changing lights to form a sign message or messages wherein the sequence of messages and the rate of change is electronically programmed and may be modified by electronic controls. 
    Flashing lights means lights which intermittently cut on or off, or change in intensity. 
    Ground sign means a sign which is erected on or supported by a freestanding frame which rests on the ground and is not attached to any building. 
    Illuminated sign means any sign which emanates light by means of exposed tubing or lamps on its surface, or by means of lamps located inside a housing with a translucent surface or any sign which reflects light from a source intentionally directed upon it. 
    Poster means a bill or placard, made of paper, placed in a public location, used to inform or advertise. 
    Roof sign means a sign erected upon, against or directly above a roof. 
    Sign means any identification, description, illustration or device illuminated or nonilluminated which is visible from any public place or is located on private property and exposed to the public and which directs attention to a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation, including any permanently installed or situated merchandise; or any emblem, painting, banner, pennant or placard (or temporary sign) designed to advertise, identify or convey information, with the exception of window displays and national flags. For the purpose of removal, signs shall also include all sign structures. 
    Size of a sign means the size, expressed in square feet, determined by multiplying the length by the width of the sign, not including posts, poles, columns, or brackets used to support the sign. 
    Temporary sign means any sign which is portable or which is not permanently affixed to the ground. 
    Zoning districts. Districts designated as R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, B-1, B-2, M-1, M-2, or M-3 are defined as provided in the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1401; Ord. No. 07-24, § 2, 07-24, § 2, 8-27-2007) 
Sec. 22-742. - Exempt signs. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any sign which is or has been directly painted or lettered on the windows or doors in a business district as defined in the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Posters placed in the windows or doors of a building located within zoning district B-1 or B-2. 
(3)  Any sign located within a building which is not generally visible from outside the building. 
(4)  Any sign, the use of which augments a legal, nonconforming principal use of private property and which sign is operational on the effective date of the enactment of this article and in compliance with all applicable provisions of this article except as to the location of the sign within a particular zoning district as provided in the Hillside Zoning Code of 1980. 
(5)  Public signs pertaining to legal notices or of an identificational, informational or directional nature, erected or required by governmental bodies, or authorized for a public purpose by any law, statute or ordinance. 
(6)  Any bulletin or notice board, of not more than 20 square feet, for public, charitable or religious institutions, located on the premises to which the sign pertains. 
(7)  Any sign, not more than 20 square feet in area, located on the premises of a business or public institution, which announces only the name and nature of the occupancy and information as to conditions of use or admission. 
(8)  Any sign, which does not exceed two square feet in surface area, located on residential premises, which sign states only the name and/or occupancy of the resident, or warns that a vicious animal is kept on the premises. 
(9)  All signs, including decorations or decorative fixtures, placed on buildings, lampposts, utility poles, signposts, or other structures, and used for public demonstration or for the promotion of charitable, educational, civic, political, patriotic, religious, social, literary, scientific, or athletic not-for-profit organizations and their respective endeavors and functions, which may be authorized by the village administrator for a stated period of time and which shall be removed within 24 hours after expiration of such time and for which the consent of the owners of such structures and of the real estate upon which the structures are erected has been obtained; provided, however, that the village and its officers and employees shall be held harmless for any damage resulting therefrom. 
(10)  Posting of notices of personal property sales in accordance with chapter 66, article V (Garage Sales). 
(Code 1965, § 24.1402) 
Sec. 22-743. - Permit required; nonconforming signs. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, move or convert any sign in the village, or cause the same to be done, without first obtaining a sign permit from the building inspector, and in the case of electrical signs, from the electrical inspector. These directives shall not be construed to require any permit for the repainting, cleaning and other normal maintenance or repair of a sign or sign structure for which a permit has been previously issued, so long as the height or size of the sign or the sign structure is not increased in any way. No new permit is required for any operational sign which is located within the village on the date this article shall become effective, or for any sign for which a permit shall be outstanding on the effective date of any amendment to this article. However, not later than May 1, 1988, such signs must be modified, if necessary, to be in conformance with this article, including any amendment thereto. Furthermore, such signs may not be moved or structurally altered in any way unless the signs shall be made to conform to this article. After May 1, 1988, all signs not in conformance must be removed unless the president and board of trustees shall grant special approval for their continued existence. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1403) 
Sec. 22-744. - Application for permit. 
    Application for sign erection permits under this article shall be made upon forms provided by the building department and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the owner of the premises and sign. 
(2)  Location of building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the sign or other advertising device is to be attached or erected. 
(3)  A plot plan of the property involved showing accurate placement thereon of the proposed sign. 
(4)  Blueprint or ink drawing of the plans and specifications and method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground. 
(5)  For signs over 40 square feet a copy of stress sheets and calculations prepared by or approved by a registered professional engineer licensed by the state showing that the sign is designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction in the amount required by the village building code. 
(6)  Name of the person, firm or corporation erecting the sign. 
(7)  An individual annual $15,000.00 bond for each sign, or insurance providing applicable bodily injury liability coverage of not less than $300,000.00 per accident and property damage limits of not less than $20,000.00 per accident, when such bond or insurance is required to hold the village harmless by section 1406.0 of the BOCA Basic Building Code or by section 86.1-10 of the Chicago Electrical Code, both of which codes have been adopted by reference by the village as part of its building codes. 
(8)  Such other information as the building department shall require to show full compliance with this article and all other laws and ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1404) 
Sec. 22-745. - Permit fee. 
    Every applicant, before being granted a permit hereunder, shall pay the requisite permit fee to the village for each sign for which application for permit is made. The amount of such permit fee shall be determined and set by the president and board of trustees from time to time. Any permit issued hereunder shall be null and void 30 days after the mailing date of a written notice of issuance of the permit by the building inspector to the applicant, if for any reason the applicant shall have failed to pay the permit fee in full within said 30-day period. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1405) 
Sec. 22-746. - License fee for billboards. 
    Each billboard located within the village limits, the size of which is 300 or more square feet, shall be subject to an annual license fee as established by the village board from time to time. The fees shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of section 22-36 (Fees). All fees shall be payable May 1 of each year without benefit of proration for any period less than one year during which billboard is so displayed. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1405.1) 
Sec. 22-747. - Compliance with building and electrical codes and zoning ordinance. 
    In addition to the regulations contained in this article, no sign shall be erected, constructed, enlarged, moved or converted except in compliance with the village building and electrical codes and the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1406) 
Sec. 22-748. - Restrictions. 
(a)  Height of ground signs. No ground signs located in zoning districts B-2, M-1, M-2 and M-3 shall exceed 45 feet in height above grade, measured to the top of the sign. 
(b)  Temporary signs. A temporary sign may only be installed pursuant to a permit issued in accordance with section 22-743, and may only be located within a B-1 or B-2 business district of the village. Only one such sign, to be displayed for a maximum of two weeks during any calendar year, may be permitted for any single business location. 
(c)  Roof signs. No sign shall be erected upon the roof of any building located within the village boundaries. 
(d)  Flashing lights. No sign shall have flashing lights, except for a sign which displays the time and temperature. 
(e)  Obstruction of visibility; traffic hazards. No sign shall be permitted which obscures any visibility for traffic purposes or creates any traffic hazard. 
(f)  Signs in residential districts. See section 22-748.5 for the regulations for signs in residential districts. 
(g)  Maximum area. In zoning districts B-1, B-2, M-1, M-2 and M-3, the total area of all signs displayed on a property shall not exceed two square feet per lineal foot of lot frontage on the street from which the signs are visible and readable. 
(h)  Separation of signs. Signs which exceed 20 square feet in size must be separated by at least 100 feet, measured at their closest points. 
(i)  Size limitations based on distance from residential district . All signs must adhere to the size limitations corresponding to the respective distance of each sign to the closest point of any residential zoning district in the village, set forth as follows: 
Distance to 
R-1, R-2, R-3 or R-4 Zoning District Maximum Allowable Size 0-100 feet 20 square feet 100-500 feet 150 square feet 500-1,000 feet 300 square feet 1,000 feet or more 1,200 square feet  
(j)  Placement on right-of-way. No sign, except temporary posters announcing a charitable or semipublic event the display of which is authorized by the president and board of trustees for a period not to exceed two weeks, shall be placed upon any space within the right-of-way of any street in the village. 
(k)  Signs in B-1 district. In zoning district B-1, all signs must be flush mounted to a building, except ground signs not exceeding 25 feet in height above grade, measured to the top of the sign. 
(l)  Posting on wall or fence; signs facing side or rear yard of lot in residential district. No sign or poster shall be printed, pasted, or similarly posted directly on the exterior surface of any wall or fence, nor shall any sign be placed or permitted to be placed, attached or otherwise fastened on any wall, fence or sign standard or structure facing the side or rear yards of an adjoining lot located in a residential district. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1407; Ord. No. 04-08, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 22-748.5. - Signs in residential districts. 
(a)  Real estate signs. 
(1)  No more than one real estate sign shall be erected on any premises, except one additional "Open House" sign may be used on the day of the "Open House." 
(2)  No real estate sign shall exceed six square feet in area. The top surface at the sign shall not exceed four feet in height from the existing grade at the point of installation. 
(3)  No signs shall contain the word "sold" or "leased." 
(4)  No sign shall be an illuminated sign. 
(5)  No sign shall be on the property for more than three days after the sale has been completed. 
(b)  Political signs. 
(1)  No more than two candidate signs shall be erected on any premises. 
(2)  No sign shall exceed six square feet in area. The top surface at the sign shall not exceed four feet in height from the existing grade at the point of installation. 
(3)  No sign shall be an illuminated sign. 
(4)  No sign shall remain on the property for more than three days after the election. 
(c)  Contractor signs. 
(1)  For a contractor actually doing work on a residential home and only while the work is in progress. 
(2)  No more than one sign shall be erected on any premises. 
(3)  No sign shall exceed six square feet in area. The top surface shall not exceed four feet in height from the existing grade at the point of installation. 
(4)  No sign shall be an illuminated sign. 
(5)  No sign shall be on the property for more than three days from the completion of the work. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 2, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 22-748.6. - Directional retail signs on municipal property. 
    Upon application for permit as set forth in section 22-744 herein, the building department may allow a variance from the size and height limitations set forth in section 22-748 herein for any directional retail sign to be located on municipal property zoned B-1 provided the building department determines that the location and size of the sign is reasonably necessary to direct the flow of vehicular traffic to the shared site of the retail establishments. 
(Ord. No. 07-24, § 2, 8-22-2007; Ord. No. 08-28, § 2, 12-22-2008) 
Sec. 22-749. - Electronic message centers. 
(a)  The electronic message center signs shall only be permitted subject to the granting of a conditional use permit by the village board of trustees. 
(b)  The electronic message center shall serve the public convenience of that location, shall promote only that business located on that property and shall be located no closer than 200 feet to another such device directed to the same street. 
(c)  The sign message shall periodically include public service information such as time, temperature, date, weather, traffic conditions or other messages of interest to the motorists viewing the sign or to the general community. 
(d)  The electronic message center shall be designed and located such that the entire sign message will be legible to motorists viewing the sign. 
(e)  The sign structure shall conform to all applicable regulations as specified in this article. 
(f)  The sign message shall not consist of flashing, scintillating, chasing or animated lights, and shall not change more frequently than once every ten seconds. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1407.1; Ord. No. 11-13, § 1, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 22-750. - Removal of unsafe or unlawful signs. 
    If the building inspector shall determine that any sign or sign structure is unsafe or insecure, or has been erected, constructed, enlarged, moved or converted, or is being maintained, in violation of the provisions of this article or of the provisions of the village building or electrical code or the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980, he shall give written notice, specifying the violation, to the sign permittee thereof, or if no permit was issued, to the owner of the premises as shown on the most recent real estate tax rolls. If, within ten days after receipt of such notice, the sign permittee or premises owner fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards of this article, the building inspector may cause any such sign to be removed summarily without further notice. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1408) 
Sec. 22-751. - Removal of abandoned signs. 
    Any sign now or hereafter existing, which does not advertise a bona fide business being conducted or a product being sold on the property upon which said sign is located, shall be taken down and removed, within ten days after receipt from the building inspector of a written order to do so, by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the sign or building structure on which said sign is placed, attached or otherwise fastened. Upon failure to comply with such order within the time specified therein, the building inspector may cause removal of such sign, and any expense incidental thereto shall be paid by the owner of the property to which such sign is attached. This section shall not apply to "off-premise signs," defined as signs which advertise products or services sold or offered on land other than the property on which the sign is located. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1408.1) 
Sec. 22-752. - Variances or appeals. 
    All requests for variances or appeals from any ruling of the building inspector, electrical inspector or zoning administrator shall be directed to the zoning board of appeals in accordance with the established rules and procedures of that body. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1409) 
Sec. 22-753. - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where the provisions of this article and the provisions of the village building and electrical codes and the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980 may differ as to the standards for erection, construction, alteration, repair, maintenance, use, size, height or location of signs, the more restrictive provisions shall take precedence and shall be applied. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1410) 
Sec. 22-754. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1411) 
Secs. 22-755-22-780. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - AUTOMATIC TELLER MACHINES 

Sec. 22-781. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Access device means a card, code, and/or other means that identifies a customer of the bank or savings and loan association for the purpose of permitting its customer to initiate an electronic fund transfer at an automatic teller machine. 
    Automatic teller machine means an information processing machine established by a bank or savings and loan association which utilizes electronic, sound or mechanical signals or impulses or any combination thereof, and from which electronic fund transfers may be instituted. As used in this article, the term "automatic teller machine" shall include a group of such machines established by a single bank or single savings and loan association at a single location, the radius of which shall not exceed 100 feet. 
    Electronic fund transfer means a transfer of funds through an automatic teller machine which may include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Receive deposits. 
(2)  Permit withdrawals. 
(3)  Accept payments on existing indebtedness in the respective bank or savings and loan association. 
(4)  Respond to account balance inquiries. 
(5)  Transfer funds between different accounts of the same customer within the same bank or savings and loan association. 
(6)  Check verification or guarantee. 
(7)  Pay out cash pursuant to preauthorized lines of credit. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1701) 
Sec. 22-782. - Location. 
    Automatic teller machines may only be located as follows: 
(1)  In a drive-up facility in such a manner that a customer of the operating bank or savings and loan association can conduct, by means of an access device, an electronic fund transfer without leaving the security of the passenger compartment of a motor vehicle; 
(2)  In a locked building or structure, or in a similar secure environment, accessible only to authorized officers, employees and agents of the operating bank or savings and loan association or to its customers by access devices; or 
(3)  In a retail facility environment, accessible only during the facility's normal business hours. The automatic teller machine is to be located in an open well-lit area of the sales floor, and monitored with a security camera. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1702) 
Sec. 22-783. - Construction and installation. 
    The construction of any building, structure or secured environment intended to enclose an automatic teller machine, and the installation thereof, shall comply with all applicable provisions of the zoning and building codes of the village, and proper permits must be issued before any necessary work is commenced and before the automatic teller machine is made available to the public. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1703) 
Sec. 22-784. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1705) 
Secs. 22-785-22-800. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - VISIBILITY INTO VACANT BUILDING AREAS 

Sec. 22-801. - Visual obstruction of interior prohibited. 
    No vacant building or vacant segregated unit within a building designed or intended for business or commercial use shall contain any screen, blind, curtain, partition, window covering, or visual obstruction of any kind which could restrict or prevent clear visibility into the interior of such vacant premises from an adjacent street or sidewalk through the building's exterior doors and windows. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1801) 
Sec. 22-802. - Duty to remove visual obstruction. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or person having custody of such premises to remove any such visual obstruction within ten days after service upon such owner or custodian of written notice to do so by the code enforcement officer of the village, either personally or by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. Failure to comply shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1802) 
Sec. 22-803. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1804) 
Secs. 22-804-22-820. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - PAY TELEPHONES 

Sec. 22-821. - Placement in public way. 
(a)  The village administrator shall have the authority to enter into contracts that grant to one or more persons, subject to the conditions set forth in the contract and this chapter, the privilege of installing and maintaining pay telephones in the public way. The village administrator may also contract for the removal of telephones illegally installed or maintained in the public way. Any such contract may be approved as to form and legality by the village attorney. In the administration of this article, the village administrator shall consult and cooperate with all appropriate village departments. The village administrator may at any time cause to be advertised a request for proposals relating to such contracts. 
(b)  Such contracts and the method of awarding such contracts shall, to the greatest extent possible, be designed to: 
(1)  Discourage illegal drug sales and other criminal activity that are sometimes associated with and facilitated by pay telephones in the public way; 
(2)  Reduce the disturbances that pay telephones may tend to promote in residential areas; 
(3)  Reduce visual clutter in the public way; 
(4)  Reduce the unnecessary obstruction of pedestrian and vehicular traffic; 
(5)  Ensure the availability of pay telephones where they are needed for lawful purposes; 
(6)  Provide adequate access to pay telephones by disabled persons; and 
(7)  Generate revenue for the village. 
In addition to those considerations the contracts may generate revenue for the village. 
(c)  Any contract entered into pursuant to this section shall provide that the privileges granted by the contract are subject to the village board's authority to order the removal of a pay telephone pursuant to subsection (f) of this section. Any such contract shall also permit the village board or the village administrator to require pay telephones in the public way to have special features designed to reduce criminal activity. In addition, the contract must provide that the village administrator must be notified of the location of any pay telephone that is to be situated in the public way in his village pursuant to this section.
