No person shall be awarded a contract under this section unless the person has a valid certificate of service authority to provide pay telephone service granted by the Illinois Commerce Commission where required by law. 
(d)  No person may install a pay telephone in the public way on or after the effective date of this article unless the installation is made pursuant to a contract entered into under this article. Beginning January 1, 1997, no pay telephone may remain in the public way other than pursuant to a contract entered into under this article. Any telephone installed or maintained in violation of this subsection shall be subject to immediate removal at the owner's expense by the village. However, in the case of a telephone deemed to be in the public way as the result of the revisions of this article, no such pay telephone shall be removed until at least seven days after a representative of the village has affixed a notice on the telephone stating that it will be subject to removal within seven days, and in no event shall such telephone be removed before December 15, 1996. A list of the locations at which such pay telephones are scheduled to be removed shall be made available for public inspection at least seven days prior to removal of the telephones on that list. 
(e)  No later than 30 days after the effective date of this article, every person who owns or maintains a pay telephone in the public way must file with the village administrator a list of the locations of all such telephones owned or maintained by that person. No later than December 1, 1996, every person who maintains a pay telephone that is considered to be in the public way as the result of this amendatory ordinance must file with the village administrator a list of the locations of those telephones. Any pay telephone in the public way that does not appear on such a list shall be subject to immediate removal at the owner's expense by the village beginning 30 days after the effective date of this article. 
(f)  The village board may at any time after January 1, 1997, or at any time after the effective date of this article, if pursuant to a contract under this article, by ordinance order the removal of a particular pay telephone that is in the public way. Such an ordinance must identify the location of the telephone to be removed. Any pay telephone that is not removed within 14 days after an ordinance ordering its removal is adopted shall be subject to immediate removal at the owner's expense by the village. 
(g)  Any pay telephone removed by the village pursuant to this section may be reclaimed by its owner within 30 days after its removal. The owner must reimburse the village for its removal and storage costs before any such telephone may be reclaimed. Such costs shall also include the costs of removing any installation ancillary to the pay telephone, and the costs of restoring the public way to its original condition. Any telephone not so reclaimed may be disposed of as unclaimed property. Any contract for the removal of one or more pay telephones may include a provision, in a form subject to the approval of the village attorney, for indemnification of the contractor by the village against claims and liabilities arising out of performance of the contract. 
(h)  Any person who installs or maintains a pay telephone in violation of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. Each day that the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. However, for the period ending six months after the effective date of this amendatory ordinance, no fine shall be imposed with respect to a telephone considered in the public way as the result of the provisions of this article, unless a removal notice has been posted on the telephone pursuant to this article, or unless the location of the telephone appears on a list of locations scheduled for removal made available to the public pursuant to this article. 
(i)  As used in this article: 
    Pay telephone means any publicly accessible self-service or coin or credit card operated telephone. 
    Public way means any road over which every person has a right to pass. For purposes of this section, a pay telephone will be considered in the public way beginning on the effective date of this amendatory ordinance if: 
(1)  Any portion of the telephone or its enclosure is situated on or projects or hangs over the public way; or 
(2)  The telephone is so situated that it can be used by a person standing on the public way. 
(j)  The village administrator shall have the authority to promulgate rules and regulations to implement this article. 
(k)  No provision of this section or any contract issued pursuant to this section may be applied to any transaction in interstate commerce to the extent to which such business may not, under the Constitution and statutes of the United States, be made the subject of regulation by the village. 
(Code 1965, § 24.2101) 
Sec. 22-822. - Outdoor pay telephones. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall install or maintain any telephone booth, mounted telephone, or other form of pay telephone not enclosed within the interior of a building unless it is located on the public way and in accordance with this article. Any outdoor pay telephone located on property other than the public way in violation of this article shall be removed by its owner, any person with control over the pay phone, or the owner of real estate on which the pay phone is locate d, within 30 days after the effective date of this section. 
(b)  If any outdoor pay telephone is installed in violation of this article at substantially the same location where a telephone was previously removed pursuant to this article, any person participating in the violation shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. Each day that a violation of subsection (a) of this section continues shall constitute a separate offense. However, for the period ending six months after the effective date of this amendatory ordinance, no fine shall be imposed with respect to a telephone unless a removal notice has been posted on the telephone pursuant to this section. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the village administrator may issue a revocable certificate of registration jointly authorizing the owner of real property on which a telephone is to be located and a telecommunications company that will operate the telephone, subject to the conditions of this article, the installation or maintenance of a telephone booth, mounted telephone, or other form of pay telephone not enclosed within the interior of a building and not on the public way, but permitted by this subsection (c). The certification of registration shall create no legal rights or entitlements, and shall not be deemed to create any type of vested interest. The application for the certificate of registration shall designate a registered agent for receiving notices under this section. Applications shall be maintained by the village as confidential business records. The certification shall be issued no later than 30 days after a complete application for an eligible location is received. No certificate of registration shall authorize installation of a telephone at a location that the village administrator determines will not be in the public interest or may have a deleterious impact on the surrounding neighborhood. The village administrator may issue a certificate of registration pursuant to this section for no more than two telephones on any zoning lot of property; provided that the number of telephones authorized under this section for any parking lot with 200 or more parking spaces, or for any property on which there are facilities designed for public assembly and having a capacity for more than 10,000 persons, shall not exceed a number determined by the village administrator by rule as necessary for public convenience. No certificate of registration shall authorize a telephone situated: (i) on vacant property; (ii) on property on which there is situated an abandoned building; (iii) on property on which there is situated an establishment that has or requires a tavern license, or that is kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place that primarily sells alcoholic liquor at retail, or (iv) on property on which there is a building that is used primarily for residential purposes. Certificates of registration shall be issued for particular locations identified in the application therefor. The village administrator by rule may establish and impose an application fee or an annual registration fee, or both, for certificates or registration issued under this section. The total amount of the fees may not exceed an amount sufficient for the village to recover its costs in administering this section, exclusive of costs directly related to preliminary or final hearings. 
(d)  Whenever the village administrator determines that it is not in the public interest for the telephone to remain on private property, or that the telephone may have a deleterious impact on the surrounding neighborhood, the village administrator shall initiate procedures to revoke the certificate of registration for that telephone. A certification by the village administrator setting forth facts establishing that it is not in the public interest for the telephone to remain on private property, or that the telephone has a deleterious impact on the surrounding neighborhood, shall be prima facie evidence that the certificate of registration is subject to revocation or should not be issued under this section. Whenever the village administrator makes such a determination with respect to a telephone for which a certificate of registration has been issued, the village administrator shall attempt to notify the registrant of the determination by mailing a notice to the registered agent or the registrant, and a representative of the village may enter upon any private property and may place upon the telephone a notice stating that the certificate of registration is subject to revocation and that the registrant has a right to request a preliminary hearing at which the registrant will be give an opportunity to be heard in opposition to the revocation within seven days of the notice. The preliminary hearing shall be informal and shall provide the registrant with an opportunity to address the reasons for the village administrator's preliminary determination. If no preliminary hearing is requested or if the village administrator determines that there is probable cause for revocation of the certificate of registration after the preliminary hearing, the village administrator shall issue an order requiring the telephone and its appurtenances to be removed within seven days after the order is issued pending a final determination. Telephones that are not timely removed may be removed by a representative of the village. The owner of a telephone for which a determination of probable cause for revocation of a certification of registration has been issued may contest such determination timely removing the telephone and its appurtenances and by filing with the village administrator a request for a final hearing within 14 days after removal in accordance with rules promulgated with the administrator. If, after a final hearing, the administrator determines that it is not in the public interest for the telephone to be located on the private property, or that the telephone has a deleterious impact on the surrounding neighborhood, or if no timely request for a final hearing is made, the village administrator shall revoke the certification of registration for that telephone. No certificate of registration may be issued for a telephone at a zoning lot with respect to which a previous certificate has been revoked for a period of one year after revocation. At the preliminary and the final hearing, the formal or technical rules of evidence shall not apply. Evidence may be admitted if it is a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. The village administrator may establish and impose a fee for preliminary and final hearings conducted under this section. The total amount of the fees may not exceed an amount sufficient for the village to recover its costs directly related to the preliminary or final hearings. 
(e)  Outdoor pay telephones not lawfully installed or maintained pursuant to this Code are hereby declared to be public nuisances subject to summary abatement upon due notice. A representative of the village may enter upon any private property within the village that he has reason to believe contains an outdoor pay telephone in violation of this section, and may place upon the telephone a notice that the telephone must be removed within seven days. Such notice shall also provide that, if the telephone is not removed within seven days, a representative of the village may remove the telephone and charge the costs of removal jointly and severally to its owner, operator, and the person who owns or controls the real property on which the pay telephone is located. If such telephone has not been removed within seven days, a representative of the village may remove the telephone. 
(f)  If the costs to the village of removing telephones and their appurtenances pursuant to this section are not paid within 30 days, the telephone shall be deemed abandoned and may be sold or destroyed. The costs of removing outdoor pay telephones shall be a debt to the village jointly and severally owed by the telephone's owner and operator, and any person who owns or controls the real property on which the telephone was located. 
(Code 1965, § 24.2102) 
Secs. 22-823-22-840. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - SQUARE FOOT BUSINESS TAX 

Sec. 22-841. - Tax levied. 
    An annual tax is hereby established, levied and imposed upon all businesses not specifically listed and licensed in chapters 6, 10, 22, and 42. The tax imposed shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1701) 
Sec. 22-842. - Application for permit. 
    Applications for such permits shall be made to the village clerk and shall comply with the general provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1702) 
Sec. 22-843. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1703) 
Secs. 22-844-22-870. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - LANDFILL GAS MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS 

Sec. 22-871. - Definitions. 
    Defined terms in this article need not be capitalized to have the meaning proscribed to them herein. 
    Applicant , as used herein, shall include any person, group of persons, partnership, firm, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind that files a license application pursuant to this Ordinance, including, but not limited to, any and all persons or entities having any pecuniary interest in the subject matter of the license application, provided, however, that this definition shall not include holders or owners of less than five percent of the stock of any such company or entity whose stock is publicly traded on a national exchange. 
    Landfill gas collection system, as used herein, is the portion of landfill gas management system that collects the landfill gas generated within a sanitary landfill in the process of the decomposition of the material deposited therein and delivers same to (a) a landfill gas disposal system or (b) a landfill gas recovery system. 
    Landfill gas disposal system, as used herein, means a landfill gas collection system that collects and delivers landfill gas to flares for disposal. 
    Landfill gas management system, as used herein, shall have the meaning given that term in Article XII, Section 12.90.1 of the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980, and includes a landfill gas collection system, landfill gas disposal system and landfill gas recovery system. 
    Landfill gas recovery system, means a landfill gas management system that processes landfill gas for beneficial uses by adjuncts to the landfill gas collection or disposal systems such as an electrical generating facility operated by the energy from components of the landfill gas, or a gas recovery facility which recovers for other uses the methane and/or other components of the landfill gas. A landfill gas disposal system is not a landfill gas recovery system. 
    License, as used herein, shall mean a license required by, and issued pursuant to, this article. 
    Licensee default, as used herein, shall include, but not be limited to, the voluntary or involuntary bankruptcy of licensee, whether for the purpose of reorganization or liquidation, dissolution of the licensee, or distribution of assets of licensee for the benefit of creditors, or such other defaults as establish grounds for License revocation pursuant to the provisions of section 22-879. 
    Operate, as used herein, shall include the exercise of any interest or right whatsoever with respect to landfill gas at a sanitary landfill that gives rise to a tax credit. As used herein, operate does not include holding an interest in a tax credit in the absence of holding an interest or right with respect to the landfill gas that gave rise to the tax credit. 
    Operator, as used herein, shall include any person, group of persons, partnership, firm, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind that is designated or identified in a license application pursuant to this Ordinance to operate the proposed facility, provided, however, that this definition shall not include holders or owners of less than five percent of the stock of any such company or entity whose stock is publicly traded on a national exchange. 
    Ownership of a sanitary landfill, as used herein, means to own the real estate within the Village on which the sanitary landfill is located. 
    Person, as used herein, means an individual, trust, firm, joint stock company, corporation, (including a government corporation), limited liability company, partnership, association, State, municipality, commission, political subdivision of a State, or any interstate body and shall include each department, agency and instrumentality of the United States. 
    Tax credits, as used herein, means the transfer of any interest or right whatsoever with respect to landfill gas by the owner of a sanitary landfill that qualifies the transferee of said interest or right with respect to landfill gas, or any other person, to claim a tax credit or credits under the Internal Revenue Code, Title 26, United States Code, or regulations promulgated pursuant thereto by the Internal Revenue Service, including, but not limited to, tax credits claimed under sections 29 or 45 of the Internal Revenue Code, 26 U.S.C. 29 and 45. 
    Transfer of ownership, as used herein with respect to landfill gas or a landfill gas management system, means: 
(1)  The transfer of any property interest in, or contractual right whatsoever to use, sell, pledge, market, dispose, beneficially reuse, control or otherwise derive any financial benefit whatsoever, including tax credits, from landfill gas; 
(2)  The transfer by the owner of the sanitary landfill of any interest in landfill gas, or the landfill gas management system, giving rise to a claim for tax credits by the transferee or another person; and 
(3)  The transfer of a property interest in, or contractual right to operate or exercise any control over any component of the landfill gas management system. An option, right of first refusal or other interest, the exercise of which is subject to the person holding the option, right or other interest first securing a License under this Ordinance, does not constitute a transfer of ownership. The transfer of ownership of landfill gas or a landfill gas management system, or portion thereof, by a person who owns the sanitary landfill within the village at the time of adoption of this Ordinance to a parent, subsidiary or affiliated company does not constitute a transfer of ownership for the purpose of this article. 
    Zoning ordinance , as used herein, refers to the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980 [Appendix A]. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. I, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-872. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate any landfill gas recovery system in the village without having first secured a license under this article. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection 22-872(c), it shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate any landfill gas management system in the village without having first secured a license under this Article. 
(c)  A person who at the time of adoption of the ordinance form which this article derives owns the sanitary landfill that produces landfill gas is not required to secure a license to operate a landfill gas collection system or a landfill gas disposal system. A person who at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this article derives owns the sanitary landfill that produces landfill gas is required to secure a license to operate a landfill gas recovery system. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer ownership of a landfill gas management system, any portion thereof, or landfill gas, to another person who has not first secured a license under this article to own or operate the landfill gas management system or portion thereof. 
(e)  This article shall be the exclusive procedure for securing a license to own or operate a landfill gas management system or transfer ownership in landfill gas and in a landfill gas management system or portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. II, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-873. - Criteria for license application review. 
(a)  The applicant to the village board for a license under this article shall have the burden of demonstrating that the applicant has adequate financial resources, knowledge and experience to install, maintain and operate the landfill gas management system as designed for the entirety of the period the sanitary landfill will generate landfill gas. 
(b)  In evaluating the application the village board shall also consider as evidence the previous operating experience and past record of convictions or admissions of violations of the applicant and the operator (and any subsidiary, parent corporation, or subsidiary of the parent corporation) in owning or operating landfill gas management systems. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. III, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-874. - Filing of application. 
(a)  A minimum of three complete copies of applications for a license shall be filed in the office of the village clerk by the applicant. All exhibits that the applicant wishes to have considered as evidence by the village board must be attached to the license application at the date of filing. 
(b)  All applications shall be in writing on eight and one-half-inch by 11-inch, eight and one-half inch by 14-inch, or eleven-inch by seventeen-inch paper, and shall also be submitted in an electronic P.D.F. format. All exhibits shall likewise be made available both in paper and electronic formats. The pages of the application and all exhibits, including pages intentionally left blank, shall be consecutively numbered. 
(c)  The license application shall contain a certification signed by an officer or partner of the applicant stating "I certify under penalty of law that, based on information and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the statements and information provided in the license application are true, accurate, correct and complete." 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. IV, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-875. - Filing fee. 
(a)  There shall be paid to the village clerk for delivery to the village treasurer, for deposit in a segregated license application fund, at the time of the filing of a license application, a fee of $5,000.00), by certified or cashier's check. 
(b)  The village board may, at its discretion, retain the services of one or more professional consultants to assist the Village and Village staff review the license application. The village board shall use the filing fee to pay any costs and expenses incurred by the Village as a result of the license application and the hearing process set forth herein, including, but not limited to, the fees and costs of: Village employees or staff review time, legal fees, expert witnesses, records or other investigations, data searches, notices, court reporters, transcription costs, consultants, the hearing officer (if appointed), other expenses incurred by the village in conducting the review of the application, the public hearing, and the village's license application decision, or any issue raised at any time during any hearing, to pay any costs incurred in any appeal(s) of any decision of the village board related to the application and to pay any other cost or expenses in any way connected with the application. 
(c)  Records of village-incurred fees and costs, including but not limited to relevant time records of village employees and staff and village consultants, to the extent the village is seeking reimbursement of their time, are to be submitted by the persons creating such records to the village treasurer on a monthly basis. 
(1)  The village treasurer, or his/her designee, shall organize the records and prepare and submit periodic reports to the village board, village clerk and the applicant, of invoices to or expenditures by the village. The actual invoices and bills shall be submitted to the village treasurer and included in the report submitted to the village board, village clerk and applicant, with all privileged and confidential information, if any, redacted. Inadvertent disclosure of confidential or privileged information by the village is not a waiver of confidentiality or privilege. 
(2)  Upon approval of each report, described in subsection (1), above, by the village board, the village treasurer may draw upon the applicant's filing fee deposits in the amount of the reported incurred costs and fees, or as otherwise provided by the village board. 
(3)  In compensating such employee or staff member, such as salary or wage, or benefits. The village treasurer shall include the rate he/she calculates per employee in the report described in (1) above. 
(d)  If the costs incurred by the Village with respect to the license application exceed, or are reasonably estimated to exceed, the amount of the filing fee then remaining on deposit, the village shall present a claim to the applicant for the excess, and for such additional amount as is reasonably estimated to be needed to complete the license application process. Payment of this excess is due within five business days of the date the claim is presented to the applicant. Any unpaid amount shall constitute a debt and the village shall recover its costs and attorneys' fees if it is required to make a claim or commence a suit against the applicant and to recover the unpaid fees. Failure of applicant to pay the excess fee due within five business days of the date the claim is presented to the applicant is deemed a withdraw of the license application by applicant. 
(e)  Upon termination of all proceedings hereunder (including all appeals of a decision by the village board), the village treasurer shall prepare a final accounting and summary of all bills and expenses which shall be presented for approval to the village board. Any portion of the filing fee deposits that remains unexpended at the conclusion of the license application review process (including all appeals), shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. V, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-876. - Contents of license application. 
    Each license application shall contain information sufficient to allow the village board to evaluate whether the proposed site meets the criteria set forth in section 22-873. The determination of the quality and quantity of information to be included in an application is, ultimately, the applicant's to make, as it is the applicant's burden to demonstrate that the criteria in 22-873 are met. However, for purposes of this article, an application shall contain, at a minimum, the following documents and information: 
(1)  Background of applicant, owner and operator. The license application shall contain the following information concerning the applicant and any other owner(s) or operator(s) of the landfill gas management facility. 
a.  Full name, address, and telephone number of applicant, owner or operator. If applicant, owner or operator are a partnership or limited partnership, the names and addresses of each partner and limited partner. 
b.  If applicant, owner or operator are a corporation or are a limited partnership having a corporation as its general partner: 
1.  The names and addresses of all officers, directors, all stockholders owning five percent or more of the capital stock of the corporation and the name, address, and telephone number of the corporation and the registered agent of the corporation; 
2.  Certified copy of the articles of incorporation or organization in the State of Illinois or, if incorporated or organized in a state other than Illinois, a certified copy of its authorization to do business in the State of Illinois; and 
3.  The most recent annual report. 
c.  If applicant, owner or operator are a corporation or are a limited partnership having a corporation as its general partner and more than five percent of such corporation's capital stock is owned by another corporation, either directly or derivatively, then the requirements of this section shall apply to such corporation. 
d.  A list of any and all court actions or administrative proceedings of any kind in which the applicant, owner or operator (including all persons and entities identified in definition of "applicant in section 22-871) are or have been a named party and the subject matter of which was related to landfill gas management. Such list shall identify the court or agency, the number of the case, and a brief summary of the facts and disposition of the case. 
e.  A description of the previous operating history of the applicant, owner and operator in the field of landfill gas management, including but not limited to: 
1.  The name of each landfill gas management facility. 
2.  A description of the nature of each facility generating the landfill gas (i.e., sanitary landfill, hazardous waste landfill, etc.). 
3  A description of the applicant's involvement in each facility (i.e., investor, owner, operator, co-operator, etc.). 
4.  A description of each court action or administrative proceeding initiated against the applicant, owner or operator (including all persons and entities identified in the definition of "applicant" in section 22-871) related to the ownership or operation of a landfill gas management system. 
f.  With respect to each individual named in the license application, said license application shall state the prior employment history for the preceding five (5) years and qualifications of such person as it relates to the management of landfill gas. 
g.  A description of all claims made by the applicant, owner or operator within the five years prior to the date of the application under or against any policy of insurance which covers, or is alleged by the applicant to cover, claims against the applicant related to management of landfill gas. 
(2)  Financial background of applicant, owner and operator. The license application shall include information sufficient to demonstrate the financial ability of the applicant and any other owner(s) or operator(s) of the landfill gas management facility to install, maintain and operate the landfill gas management system as designed for the entirety of the period the sanitary landfill will generate landfill gas. 
(3)  The applicant shall clearly mark "BUSINESS CONFIDENTIAL/PROTECTED FROM PUBLIC DISCLOSURE UNDER FOIA" each page of the application applicant asserts qualifies as a trade secret or commercial information protected from disclosure under § 7(g) the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 40/7(g). 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. VI, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-877. - Public hearing. 
(a)  The Village of Hillside Landfill Gas Management System License Application Hearing Committee (the "committee") shall be appointed by the president of the village board, with the advice and consent of the village board. 
(1)  The village board president, with the advice and consent of the village board, shall appoint five (5) people to serve on the committee. The village board president shall also designate a chairman of the committee. The committee shall include a maximum of two (2) village board members. The remaining members may consist of professional consultants, village staff or any other individuals whom the village board president decides merit appointment. Compensation for the committee shall be fixed by the village board president at the same time that the committee is appointed, and will be funded by the filing fee. 
(2)  Three members of the committee shall constitute a quorum. 
(b)  Conduct of the public hearing shall be substantially as follows: 
(1)  Call to order with determination of a quorum; 
(2)  Introduction of the hearing officer, if one is appointed by the village board president, otherwise by the chairman of the committee as elected by a quorum of the committee; 
(3)  Introduction of the committee and village board members who are present; 
(4)  Recognition of the applicant and identification of the license application; 
(5)  Recognition of fees, notices, and date of filing of the license application; 
(6)  Recognition of the village staff and attorneys present; 
(7)  Recognition of all documents of record as filed pursuant to subsection 22-875(c). 
(8)  Applicant, the village, and the committee may then make an opening statement. 
(9)  The committee shall then hear testimony from the license applicant and/or any witnesses the license applicant may wish to call. 
(10)  After the close of the license applicant's case, the committee and the village may present any witnesses and evidence they wish to present. 
(11)  Rebuttal testimony and evidence will be allowed at the discretion of the committee chairman or hearing officer, if appointed; but if it is allowed, it will be presented in the same order as described in (10), above. 
(12)  Following rebuttal testimony, if any, any other member of the public who wishes to present un-sworn oral comment may then present such comment to the committee. 
(13)  Closing statements, if any, by applicant, the committee and the village, who presented evidence or testimony at or questioned witnesses during the public hearing. 
(14)  Rebuttal statement, if any, by the applicant, subject to limitations as imposed by the committee chairman or hearing officer, if appointed. 
(15)  Hearing closed. 
(c)  All testimony at any public hearing shall be under oath or affirmation. All witnesses who testify under oath shall be subject to reasonable questioning as follows: direct, cross-examination, redirect, re-cross, etc. 
(d)  Upon conclusion of the public hearing the applicant may submit to the committee a post-hearing memorandum addressing the license application criteria set forth in section 22-873, as well as any other issue relevant to the proceeding. The post-hearing memorandum shall be based on the record developed during the license application review process. If the applicant elects to submit a post-hearing memorandum, it shall do so within seven days after the date of the last public hearing, which shall be made part of the record of the public hearings and the village board shall consider any such timely submitted post-hearing memorandum in making its final determination on the license application. The post-hearing memorandum shall be limited to no more than 25 pages in length. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. VII, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-878. - License application decision. 
(a)  After the public hearing(s) or any continuation thereof, the Committee shall provide findings of fact and a recommendation concerning the license application. Any findings of fact and recommendation shall be supported by the record and shall be presented by the committee to a quorum of the village board. 
(b)  The village board shall consider the record of the public hearing, the findings of fact and the recommendations of the committee, outside counsel for the committee and the committee chairman or hearing officer, if appointed, and shall, by written resolution, upon the vote of a majority of its members, make a written decision concerning the license application. 
(c)  The village board shall state in its decision its findings as to whether the applicant has established, and whether the public record supports the establishment of the criteria stated in section 22-873. 
(d)  In making its decision, the village board shall consider the public record of the hearing proceedings. The village board shall give greater evidentiary weight to sworn testimony and evidence presented during the public hearings than to un-sworn oral or written comment. 
(e)  The village board shall grant or deny any license application or shall grant such application with conditions within 60 (sixty) days of conclusion of the public hearing on the license application. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. VIII, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-879. - Revocation. 
(a)  Upon application by the village attorney or special environmental counsel to the village to the village board, with due notice to licensee, providing licensee the right to appear before the village board with legal counsel to confront and cross examine witnesses, introduce evidence and give testimony, and upon the Village Board's finding, based on evidence presented during the hearing, that licensee has (1) repeatedly and materially violated a license issued pursuant to this Article and (2) that such violations continued after three written warnings to licensee by appropriate village staff or legal counsel for the village, the village board shall revoke the license issued under this article. The hearing before the village board and a decision by the board shall be governed by the procedures set forth in section 22-877 of this article. 
(b)  In enacting this article, the village board finds that a licensee default is a material violation of this article, places the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the Village in immediate jeopardy, and as such, the village board may revoke a license issued hereunder in accordance with the procedure set forth in subsection 22-879(b). 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. IX, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-880. - Severability. 
    The sections, subsections, paragraphs, and provisions of this Article shall be deemed severable and the invalidity of any portion of this Article shall not affect the validity of the remainder. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. X, 3-27-2006) 
Sec. 22-881. - Compliance with zoning ordinance. 
    The requirement to secure a license under this article is in addition to, and does not supersede, other applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, Art. XI, 3-27-2006) 
Secs. 22-882-22-900. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - SICK LEAVE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-04, § 2, adopted May 22, 2017, enacted provisions set out as §§ 22-781, 22-782. Inasmuch as sections so numbered already exist, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 22-901, 22-902, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 22-901. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee means an individual permitted to work by an employer regardless of the number of persons the employer employs. For purposes of this article, the term "employee" does not mean an employee of the village. 
    Employer means any individual, partnership, association, corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or any person or group of persons that gainfully employs at least one employee. To qualify as an employer, such individual, group or entity must maintain a business facility within the geographical boundaries of the village and conduct business within the village. For purposes of this article, the term "employer" shall not include: (a) the government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by the government of the United States; (b) an Indian Tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian Tribe; (c) the government of the State of Illinois or any agency or department thereof; or (d) units of local government, including the village. 
    Village means the Village of Hillside, Cook County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 2, 5-22-2017) 
Sec. 22-902. - Earned sick leave. 
(a)  Employers located or conducting business within the territorial boundaries of the village shall not be required to offer or provide earned sick leave to employees who work at least 80 hours within any 120-day period. No additional obligations with regard to earned sick leave adopted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners shall apply to employers located or conducting business within the village. 
(b)  All employers located or conducting business within the village shall comply with all applicable federal and/or state laws and regulations, as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time, with regard to the payment of paid sick leave. 
(c)  Except for incentive agreements directly between employers and the County of Cook, including, but not limited to, 6b Tax Classification status incentives, no additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave, including, without limitation, any additional obligations by ordinance adopted by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners, shall apply to employers located or conducting business within the village. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 2, 5-22-2017) 
Secs. 22-903-22-920. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - MINIMUM WAGE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-04, § 3, adopted May 22, 2017, enacted provisions set out as §§ 22-801, 22-802. Inasmuch as sections so numbered already exist, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 22-921, 22-922, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 22-921. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee shall have the meaning ascribed to such term in section 3(d) of the Illinois Minimum Wage Law (820 ILCS 5/3(d)). For purposes of this article, "employee" shall not include an employee of the village. 
    Employer means any individual, partnership, association, corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or any person or group of persons that gainfully employs at least one employee. To qualify as an employer, such individual, group, or entity must maintain a business facility within the geographic boundaries of the village or conduct business within the village. For purposes of this article, the term "employer" shall not include: (a) the government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by the government of the United States; (b) an Indian Tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian Tribe; (c) the government of the State of Illinois or any agency or department thereof; or (d) units of local government, including the village. 
    Village means the Village of Hillside, Cook County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 3, 5-22-2017) 
Sec. 22-922. - Minimum wage. 
(a)  Employers located in or conducting business within the territorial boundaries of village shall comply with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations with respect to the payment of minimum hourly wages for non-tipped employees, including but, not limited to, the wages established by the Fair Labor Standards Division of the Illinois Department of Labor. No employer located in or conducting business within the village shall be required to pay employees a minimum hourly wage in excess of those wages established by federal and/or state laws and regulations, including, but not limited to, the minimum wage rate established by the Fair Labor Standards Division of the Illinois Department of Labor. 
(b)  Except for incentive agreements directly between employers and the County of Cook, including, but not limited to, 6b Tax Classification status incentives, no additional obligations with regard to minimum hourly wages, including, without limitation, any additional obligations by ordinance adopted by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners, shall apply to employers located in or conducting business within the village, except those required by federal and/or state laws and regulations, as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 17-04, § 3, 5-22-2017) 
Chapter 26 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, adopted Aug. 23, 2010, amended and restated former Ch. 26, Arts. I, II, in its entirety. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Civil emergency means: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting together without authority of law; or 
(2)  Any natural disaster or man-made calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any person or persons walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village, exception officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to said civil emergency. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1201; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-2. - Declaration of emergency. 
    Whenever an emergency as defined in section 26-1 exists, the president shall declare the existence by means of a written declaration setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1202; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-3. - Curfew. 
    After proclamation of a civil emergency by the president, he may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village or to the village as a whole, as he deems advisable, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interests of the public safety and welfare. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1203; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-4. - Orders. 
    After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the village president may also in the interest of public safety and welfare make any or all of the following orders: 
(1)  Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted. 
(2)  Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any wholesaler or retailer. 
(3)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle. 
(4)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(5)  Set curfew hours for all persons within the corporate limits of the village-this curfew to be during such hours of the day or night as deemed necessary; 
(6)  Order the evacuation of all residences, businesses and other buildings as may be deemed necessary; 
(7)  Call on the National Guard through the Office of the Governor in accordance with the Illinois Internal Security Plan as outlined by the Adjutant General of the State of Illinois when the local law enforcement authorities are unable to cope with a dangerous or disastrous situation; and 
(8)  Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1204; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-5. - Duration of proclamation. 
    The proclamation herein authorized shall be effective until the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the corporate authorities after the state of emergency is declared or for a period of 48 hours, whichever is sooner, unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the president indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists. The president shall have the power to re-proclaim the existence of a civil emergency at the end of each period during the time that the said civil emergency exists. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1205; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
State Law reference- Authority to declare state of emergency, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-6. 
Sec. 26-6. - Notice of proclamation. 
    Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the Village Clerk shall notify at least one newspaper having circulation within the village, and shall cause three copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the following places within the village: the village hall, the police station and the post office. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1206; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-7. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article or an executive order issued pursuant thereto shall be guilty of an offense against the village, and shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1207; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-8. - Effect of article on powers of police and fire departments. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to impair the powers contained in this Code giving powers to the police and fire departments, but this article shall be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1208; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Secs. 26-9-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY 

Sec. 26-31. - Established; coordinator. 
(a)  Established. 
(1)  Pursuant to the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1, Et Seq.) (the "IEMA Act") there is hereby created a local emergency management agency (the "EMA") to coordinate the emergency management program within the village and with private organizations, other political subdivisions, and the state and federal governments. 
(2)  The village president shall be the executive in charge of the EMA. 
(3)  The village president shall appoint, subject to the advice and consent of the village board, a coordinator, who shall be the assistant to the village president with the duty of coordinating the emergency management program for the village consistent with the applicable provisions of the IEMA Act. 
(4)  The village president shall be the chairperson of the EMA. The EMA shall meet at the call of the village president who shall be advised on all matters pertaining to emergency services. 
(5)  The EMA shall, from time to time, recommend to the village board action or procedures necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the village as it may deem necessary or advisable in order to carry out the purposes of this ordinance and of the IEMA Act, including, but not limited to: 
a.  The formulation of a plan of action, to be coordinated with the Illinois Emergency Preparedness Plan and program, and to serve particularly the residents of the village and of any surrounding area. 
b.  Any regulations of the EMA shall not become effective until approved by the village board. 
(b)  Coordinator. 
(1)  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the EMA, subject to the direction and control of the village administrator as provided by statute. 
(2)  In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to s2erve as the coordinator, the village administrator, or any person designated by him, shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this article. 
(3)  The coordinator will designate a "director" with the approval of the village board to oversee the administration, training and operation of the EMA. 
(Code 1965, § 7.301; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-32. - Functions. 
    The EMA shall perform such functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state IEMA plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-municipality entered into as provided in the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq. 
(Code 1965, § 7.303; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-33. - Service as mobile support team. 
(a)  Members of the EMA may be designated by the governor or the director of the Illinois Emergency Management Agency (the "IEMA") as members of a mobile support team to aid and to reinforce the IEMA and emergency services and disaster agencies in areas stricken by disaster. 
(b)  Any member of a mobile support team who is a municipal employee or officer while on duty pursuant to a call to duty or while engaged in a regularly scheduled training exercise shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, may receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 7.304; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-34. - Agreements with other municipalities or political subdivisions. 
    The coordinator may negotiate mutual assistance agreements with other municipalities or political subdivisions of the state, but, notwithstanding any provisions thereof to the contrary, no such agreements nor amendments thereto, nor any expansion thereof by the addition of any other such municipalities or subdivisions, shall be binding against the village until approved by the president and board of trustees, and, if required, by IEMA. 
(Code 1965, § 7.305; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-35. - Emergency action. 
    If the governor declares that an emergency exists in the event of a disaster, as defined in the IEMA Act, then it shall be the duty of the EMA to cooperate fully with the IEMA in the provision of emergency services as provided in the IEMA Act. 
(Code 1965, § 7.306; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-36. - Compensation of members. 
(a)  Neither the village president, the coordinator, nor members of the EMA shall receive compensation from the village for their services in the EMA, but this provision shall not affect their compensation authorized by the village for other services to the village or their compensation for activities related to the EMA as otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  Members of the EMA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the state director of IEMA, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the president and board of trustees. 
(c)  Members of the EMA who are neither employees nor officers of the village shall receive for such training time only such compensation as may be provided by law. 
(d)  Members of the EMA who are also members of a village mobile support team, and who, while engaged in a disaster or disaster training exercise, suffer disease, injury or death, shall be deemed to be employees of the state for the purposes of benefits under the Worker's Compensation Act or Worker's Occupational Diseases Act only, if (1) the claimant is a duly qualified and enrolled (sworn in) volunteer of the EMA, and (2) the claimant was participating in an actual disaster as defined in the IEMA Act or engaged in a regularly scheduled training or exercise pursuant to a call for duty by the IEMA. 
(Code 1965, § 7.307; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-37. - Reimbursement by state for expenses incurred by village. 
    The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the EMA as prescribed by the director of the IEMA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or the director of the IEMA and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to EMA's activities, all as provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 7.308; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-38. - Purchases and expenditures. 
(a)  The village board may, on recommendation of the coordinator, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the village and its residents. 
(b)  In the event of any disaster, the coordinator is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for emergency purposes, in light of the exigencies of the disaster and, excepting mandatory constitutional requirements, without regard to the procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase of supplies and materials, and the appropriation, expenditure, and disposition of public funds and property as authorized by the IEMA Act, until the village board is able to act effectively, whereupon the coordinator shall then act in accordance with the direction of the village president, pursuant to law. 
(Code 1965, § 7.309; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-39. - Oath of members. 
    Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village EMA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
I, ________________, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Hillside EMA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence. 
(Code 1965, § 7.310; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-40. - Office space. 
    The village administrator is authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere, for use of the EMA for an office, storage or other functions. 
(Code 1965, § 7.311; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-41. - Succession to office during emergency. 
(a)  In the event that at the time or as a consequence of any disaster or occurrence described in section 26-31, the incumbent of any municipal office, position or place of employment shall be killed or rendered incapable of performing the duties of such office or position and it is necessary to fill such office or position, such office or position shall be filled, until such time as a successor can be selected as prescribed by law, in the following manner: Any such vacancy shall, for the emergency period, be filled by appointment of the village administrator for those positions normally filled by appointment of the village administrator, otherwise by the following order of preference: the village president, the remaining members of the board of trustees, the village administrator, the EMA coordinator, the assistant village administrator, the chief of police, the chief of the fire department-if not designated as EMA coordinator. 
(b)  The person appointed in the manner prescribed herein to fill any such office or position shall exercise all the duties and powers of that position during the emergency and until such time as a successor can be appointed or selected in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 7.312; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Sec. 26-42. - Temporary location of government during emergency. 
(a)  Whenever, due to an emergency resulting from the effects of enemy attack or natural or man-made disaster, it becomes imprudent, inexpedient or impossible to conduct the affairs of local government at the regular or usual place or places thereof, the corporate authorities may meet at any place within or without the village limits on the call of the village president or any two members of the board of trustees, and shall proceed to establish and designate, by ordinance, resolution or other manner, alternate or substitute sites or places as the emergency temporary location, or locations, of government where all, or any part of the public business may be transacted and conducted during the emergency situation. Such sites or places may be within or without the territorial limits of the village. 
(b)  During the period when the public business is being conducted at the emergency temporary location or locations, the governing body and other officers of the village shall have and possess and shall exercise at such location or locations, all of the executive, legislative, and judicial powers and functions conferred upon such body and officers by or under the laws of this state. Such powers and functions may be exercised in the light of the exigencies of the emergency situation without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law and pertaining thereto, and all acts of such body and officers shall be valid and binding as if performed within the territorial limits of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 7.313; Ord. No. 10-18, § 1, 8-23-2010) 
Chapter 30 - EMERGENCY SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUTUAL AID BOX ALARM SYSTEM 

Sec. 30-31. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for a program of mutual aid between the village and other municipalities whereby each such municipality will be obligated to come to the assistance of one another in case of emergency, fire or other disaster therein of such magnitude that the local fire equipment and personnel cannot effectively cope with it. 
(Code 1965, § 6.101) 
Sec. 30-32. - Program adopted. 
    A mutual aid box alarm system program (MABAS), conforming to the provisions of this article, has been agreed upon by the chief of the fire department of the village and by the chiefs of various other fire departments located both within and without the village, and has been submitted in the form of a written agreement to the president and board of trustees of the village for approval. The agreement between the village and all other municipalities which shall have adopted said program and shall have assumed the obligations thereby imposed upon them is hereby approved and the program is hereby adopted by the village. 
(Code 1965, § 6.102) 
Secs. 30-33-30-60. - Reserved.

(a)  Fees for village ambulance services shall be changed as follows:

(b)  Each and every time that an ambulance is used in providing services to such recipient shall be treated as a separate obligation of that recipient. All recipients of such service shall be billed for service after the completion of said services whether the recipient was transported or not and no person shall be denied services for reasons of failure to pay prior amounts or for reasons of residency status.
