Secs. 30-62-30-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY ENERGY PLANS 

Sec. 30-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Control area means as electrical system bounded by interconnection (tie-line) metering and telemetry. It controls generation directly to maintain its interchange schedule with other control areas and contributes to frequency regulation of the interconnection. 
    Control area emergency means that control area is at risk of having to shed firm load, having taken or committed to take all feasible mitigating action short of shedding firm load and firm sales. 
    Controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service means the implementation of a plan to curtail electric service to firm load customers for a short period of time and rotating this curtailment of electric service through different areas within the electric utility's service territory in a situation where the demand has exceeded or is at significant risk of exceeding the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. The action of an electric utility to interrupt or curtail electric service to a customer participating in or taking service under an interruptible or curtailable rate is not included in this definition of a "controlled rotating interruption of electric service." 
    Electric utility company or electric utility means any person or entity engaged in the business of distributing, transmitting, or otherwise delivering electricity, regardless of its source, for use or consumption within the village. This term shall not include any person or entity that delivers electricity to fewer than 50 customers within the village. 
    Emergency energy plan means the portions of the emergency load conservation procedures, which immediately precede and include the controlled rotating interruption of electrical service to firm load customers within the village. The emergency energy plan shall include the following steps: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use; and 
(4)  Implementation of the plan for controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service. 
    Emergency load conservation procedures means a planned course of action developed by an electric utility company to be implemented in emergency situations when the demand for electricity exceeds, or is at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. 
(Code 1965, § 15.2101) 
Sec. 30-92. - Submission required; revisions; contents. 
(a)  Submission required; revisions. Every electric utility company must have adopted an emergency energy plan no later than 30 days after the effective date of this article, or within 30 days after becoming an electric utility company, whichever is later. Every such electric utility company shall submit to the village administrator an emergency energy plan adopted by the company no later than 30 days after the effective date of this article, or within 24 hours of the time the plan is adopted, whichever is later. The electric utility company shall be required to examine and update as needed its emergency energy plan at least annually. The electric utility company shall notify the foregoing public official in writing of any material revisions to its plan and the rationale for said revisions within five business days of the time said revisions are made. 
(b)  Contents. The emergency energy plan shall include, at a minimum, information detailing: 
(1)  Circumstances that would require the implementation of the emergency energy plan; 
(2)  Stages of the emergency energy plan; 
(3)  The approximate geographic limits of each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(4)  The approximate number of customers within each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(5)  The police facilities, fire stations, hospitals, nursing homes, schools, day care centers, senior citizen centers, community health centers, blood banks, dialysis centers, community mental health centers, correctional facilities, stormwater and wastewater treatment or pumping facilities, water-pumping stations, and buildings in excess of 80 feet in height that have been identified by the village and persons on life-support systems that are known to the company, and that could be affected by controlled rotating interruptions of electric service under the emergency energy plan; and 
(6)  The anticipated sequence and duration of intentional interruptions of electric service to each outage area under the emergency energy plan. 
(Code 1965, § 15.2102) 
Sec. 30-93. - Review. 
(a)  Upon submittal of the emergency energy plan to the village, the village shall review the emergency energy plan in order to determine if the emergency energy plan is complete and to assure appropriate coordination with public health and safety agencies. The village may reject the emergency energy plan if it does not contain all the information required under section 30-92(b), in which case the village shall notify the electric utility company in writing of said rejection and the reasons therefor. The electric utility company shall thereafter submit a complete emergency energy plan to the village no later than 30 days after such notice is sent by the village. 
(b)  The village and the electric utility shall work cooperatively to: 
(1)  Identify customers and facilities for which a controlled rotating interruption of electric service would require heightened response by village public health and safety agencies; 
(2)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on public health and safety; and 
(3)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on the duties of the village's public health and safety agencies. 
(Code 1965, § 15.2103) 
Sec. 30-94. - Implementation. 
(a)  Whenever an electric utility company determines that it may be necessary to implement a controlled rotating interruption of electrical service due to the demand for electricity exceeding, or being at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility company, the electric utility company shall do the following: 
(1)  Take appropriate action in preparation for implementing a controlled rotating interruption of electric service and notify the appropriate electric utility company personnel; and 
(2)  Notify the village administrator that the electric utility company will be implementing its emergency energy plan. The notification shall be made pursuant to a notification procedure approved by the village administrator after consultation with the designated public official. The village administrator may waive the notice requirement to accommodate exigent circumstances. 
(b)  Subsequent to providing the notice as required above, an electric utility company shall reasonably and separately advise the designated village officials when it implements each of the steps of the emergency energy plan. Such steps shall include the following: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use. 
(c)  The electric utility company shall give a separate notice to the village administrator, immediately upon the determination that there will be a controlled rotating interruption of electric service pursuant to the emergency energy plan. The notification shall include the areas to be interrupted, the sequence and estimated duration of the service outage for each area, and the affected feeders and number of affected customers in each area. Whenever practical, the notification shall be made at least two hours prior to the time of the outages, and in no case shall the notification be made less than 30 minutes prior to the outages, if the company is aware that controlled rotating interruptions may be required. 
(d)  Notification required by this section shall be in addition to any notification requirements set forth in any applicable franchise agreement or franchise ordinance, or as may be required by applicable federal or state law or regulation. 
(Code 1965, § 15.2104) 
Sec. 30-95. - Penalty; additional remedies. 
(a)  Any electric utility company that knowingly violates this article or any rules promulgated thereunder shall be subject to a fine of not less than $2,500.00 and not more than $10,000.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(b)  The village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or order to compel the other party to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 15.2105) 
Sec. 30-96. - Construction. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude or interfere with the implementation by an electric utility company of measures necessary to assure the provision of adequate, efficient, reliable and environmentally safe service, as required by the Illinois Public Utilities Act, 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq. Nothing set forth in this article shall be deemed to modify the terms of any existing franchise agreement or franchise ordinance otherwise applicable to any electric utility company, or to excuse any performance required by such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any authority that may be exercised pursuant to such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any remedy that may be available under such agreement or ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 15.2106) 
Secs. 30-97-30-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AUTOMATIC AND MANUAL BURGLAR, HOLD-UP AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 30-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm equipment installer means any person, firm or corporation that sells, leases or installs alarm systems or signaling devices which transmit alarms upon receipt of a stimulus from a detection apparatus to a bell or a remote monitoring location. 
    Alarm user means any person, firm or corporation on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the village or whose alarm is registered by indicators at a monitor panel in a receiving terminal of the police and/or fire departments except for alarm systems on motor vehicles or proprietary systems. If, however, an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected with an alarm system at a premises (other than a proprietary system), the person, firm or corporation using such a system is an alarm user. Also, excluded from this definition and from the coverage of this article are persons, firms and corporations who use alarm systems to alert persons within the premises in which the alarm system is located of an attempted unauthorized intrusion or holdup attempt. If such system, however, employs an audible signal emitting sounds or flashing lights, or a beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such system shall be within the definition of alarm system and shall be subject to this article. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or his employees or agents. Such term does not include alarms caused by hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes or other violent conditions. 
    Proprietary system means an alarm system sounding and/or recording alarm and supervisory signals at a control center located within the protected premises, the control center being under the supervision of the proprietor of the protected premises. If a proprietary system includes a signal line connected directly to a monitor panel in a receiving terminal of the police and/or fire departments and/or alarm companies' receiving locations or an answering service, it thereby becomes an "alarm system" as the term is used in this article. 
    Signaling device means an electrically operated instrument which automatically sends visual and audible signals over a signal line to be registered by indicators at a monitor panel in a receiving terminal of the police and/or fire departments' and/or alarm companies' receiving locations to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police and/or fire personnel are expected to respond. Signaling devices shall include the terms "automatic holdup alarm systems," "burglar alarm systems," "holdup alarm systems," "manual holdup alarm systems" and "fire alarm systems." Fire alarm systems shall include alarms received from heat and smoke detectors, automatic extinguishing systems and manual pull-stations and related supervisory systems. Alarm systems shall also mean medical emergency devices. Signaling devices shall also include such systems that provide visual and/or audible systems on the premises. All such alarm systems shall conform to the appropriate building or fire codes of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1301) 
Sec. 30-122. - Signaling devices; permit. 
(a)  Monitoring system. The president and board of trustees may contract for the installation of a uniform monitoring system to receive visual and audible signals over a signal line or lines at a central location. This system shall have a capacity to meet present needs and the ability to expand for future needs, and shall be available to any subscriber who meets the requirements for a permit for connection. 
(b)  Application for permit by alarm installation company. Applications for permits to install, maintain and operate signaling devices shall be filed with the chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, on forms supplied, with an application fee as established by the village board from time to time. Said application shall include the following: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the alarm installer and type of business organization (individual, partnership, corporation); if a partnership, the names and addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names and addresses of the principal officers and the state where incorporated. 
(2)  A description of and operation specifications for the signaling devices offered to the public, together with a statement that the equipment does comply with the standards of Underwriters' Laboratories, Factory Mutual or equal. 
(3)  A list of names and addresses of persons for whom installations have been made by the applicant prior to the effective date hereof. 
(4)  A list of criminal convictions, if any (other than for minor traffic offenses) of the applicant, or a list of criminal convictions, if any (other than for minor traffic offenses) of the partners, directors, and officers if the applicant is other than an individual. 
(5)  A statement of responsibility for service of the signaling device that the applicant proposes for the public. 
(6)  A statement that the applicant is willing to comply with other reasonable rules and regulations about details of installation and operation of such devices, as may be issued by the chief of police or fire chief as appropriate. 
The chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, shall approve such application if he finds that the alarm installer has answered all questions in such application fully and truthfully, and the alarm installer maintains an adequate service organization to repair, maintain and otherwise service the signaling devices sold or leased by him. 
(c)  Permit required. No person shall install, operate or maintain signaling devices to transmit visual or audible signals over a signal line or lines to a central location without first obtaining a permit as required by this article. 
(d)  Application for permit by user. Applications for permits to install, maintain and operate a signaling device shall be filed with the chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, on forms supplied, with an application fee as established by the village board from time to time. Said application shall include the following: name, address, telephone number and emergency telephone numbers of alarm user and type of business organization (individual, partnership, corporation); if a partnership, names and addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names and addresses of the principal officers and the state where incorporated. 
(e)  Inspections. The chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, shall have the right to inspect any signaling device on the premises where it is intended to be used both prior to and subsequent to the issuance of a permit, at reasonable times, to determine whether a permit should be granted and whether it is being used in conformity with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this article. 
(f)  Revocation of permit. The chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, may revoke any permit or renewal thereof issued pursuant to the provisions of this article, after giving notices to the permit holder to bring the signaling device into compliance within ten days from said notice date, if the respective chief shall determine that the signaling device has been installed, maintained or operated in violation of the provisions of this article or of any term or condition of said permit or renewal thereof, including but not limited to the failure to pay renewal permit fees or false alarm fees as required under this article. 
(g)  Subscriber charges; user permit fee. The permit holder shall pay the alarm equipment installer for all equipment at their location and connection fees to the monitoring systems and maintenance charges necessitated by the installation, operation and maintenance of the signaling devices in the monitoring system. The company supplying and maintaining the monitoring system shall have the right to charge subscribers or their alarm equipment installer a reasonable fee for connection to and maintenance of the system. In addition, the user permit holder shall be liable to the village for an annual user permit fee as established by the village board from time to time, payable initially concurrent with the issuance of the permit for connection and annually thereafter on each May 1. No renewal user permit shall be issued to a user who shall be indebted to the village for unpaid renewal user permit fees, or for false alarm charges as established under the provisions of section 30-123. Renewal user permit fees and false alarm charges not paid in full on or before the respective due dates shall be doubled to include a late payment penalty. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1303) 
Sec. 30-123. - False alarms. 
(a)  Generally. Each person, firm or corporation holding a user permit for the operation or maintenance of an automatic voice tape dialer or signaling device shall be responsible for any false alarms transmitted by the device which they operate. The chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, shall maintain a record of all false alarms so transmitted and pursuant to the required notice and opportunity to be heard may revoke or suspend the permit for the operation of an automatic voice tape dialer device or signaling device involved in the transmission of four false alarms in any one year or may make reasonable charges therefor. 
(b)  Charges. The chief of police or fire chief, as appropriate, shall charge such permit holder, for each false alarm in excess of three in any one year transmitted by an automatic voice tape dialer or signaling device, a fee as established by the village board from time to time. Such charges shall be remitted to the police department by the user permit holder upon receipt of a statement for such charge. 
(c)  Exception. No charge shall be imposed for false alarms for 30 days from the date of installation and or date of major alterations and additions, nor shall a charge be made for false alarms activated by weather related conditions, telephone line interruptions, or acts of God. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1304) 
Sec. 30-124. - Identification cards for employees of alarm equipment installers. 
    All employees or agents of the alarm equipment installer shall be supplied with a proper identification card. This ID card shall be in his possession at all times and shall include photo, physical description, and signature by an officer of the employing company. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1305) 
Sec. 30-125. - Liability of village limited. 
    The village shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals received by the village are given appropriate attention and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the village shall not be liable for any defects in operation of signal device systems, for any failure or neglect of any person in connection with the installation and operation of equipment, or for the transmission or relaying of alarm systems' signals. In the event that the village finds it necessary to disconnect a defective signaling device, the village shall incur no liability by such action. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1306) 
Secs. 30-126-30-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - 9-1-1 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-151. - Surcharge imposed. 
    A surcharge is hereby imposed upon the monthly billed subscribers of telecommunication carriers residing within the village for funding of a 9-1-1 emergency telephone system. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1901) 
Sec. 30-152. - Rate of surcharge. 
    A surcharge is hereby imposed on monthly billed subscribers of telecommunication carriers residing within the village at a rate of $0.85 per month per network connection, as hereinafter defined. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1902) 
Sec. 30-153. - Applicability of surcharge. 
    A monthly billed subscriber shall be deemed to reside within the village if the service address, as hereinafter defined, is located within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1903) 
Sec. 30-154. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Network connection means the number of voice grade communication channels directly between a subscriber and a telecommunications carrier's public switched network without the intervention of any other telecommunications carrier's switched network which would be required to carry the subscriber's interpremises traffic. 
    Service address , except for mobile telecommunication services, means the location of the primary use of the network connection or connections, and for mobile telecommunication services, such term means the customer's place of primary use as defined in the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Conformity Act, 35 ILCS 638/1 et seq. 
    Telecommunications carrier means any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1904) 
Sec. 30-155. - Certified list of network connections exempt from surcharge. 
    The village clerk shall provide any telecommunication carrier collecting the surcharge with a certified list of those network connections assigned to the village to be exempt from imposition of the surcharge. The certified list may be revised by the village on 60 days prior written notice provided to the telecommunication carriers. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1905) 
Sec. 30-156. - Date of imposition of surcharge. 
    The surcharge shall be imposed on the first day of the month following the expiration of 90 days from the date the village clerk certifies to any of the telecommunication carriers who are required to collect the surcharge that the provisions of this article are in effect. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1906) 
Sec. 30-157. - Authorized deductions by telecommunication carriers. 
    Each telecommunication carrier is hereby authorized and instructed to deduct three percent from the gross amount of surcharge collected prior to remittance under section 30-158 in reimbursement for the expense of accounting and collecting the surcharge. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1907) 
Sec. 30-158. - Remittance of surcharge. 
    Every telecommunication carrier shall remit to the village treasurer the amount of surcharge collected for each calendar month within 30 days following expiration of each month to which the surcharge applies, net of any network or other 9-1-1 or sophisticated 9-1-1 system charge then due to the particular telecommunication carrier as shown on an itemized bill and the three percent accounting and collection charge described in section 30-157. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1908) 
Sec. 30-159. - Returns. 
    Simultaneously with the remittance described in section 30-158, each telecommunication carrier shall make a return to the village treasurer for the period to which the remittance applies stating as follows: 
(1)  The name of the telecommunication carrier. 
(2)  The telecommunication carrier's principal place of business. 
(3)  The number of network connections to which the surcharge applies. 
(4)  The amount of surcharge collected. 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1909) 
Sec. 30-160. - Excess payment of surcharge to be credited to customer's account. 
    If it shall appear that an amount of surcharge has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this article, whether as the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any surcharge due, or to become due, under this article; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be so credited. Ninety days' prior notice shall be given to the emergency telephone system board established under division 2 of this article on any credit against a surcharge due. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1910) 
Sec. 30-161. - Limitation on time period to recover unpaid surcharge. 
    No action to recover any amount of surcharge due under the provisions of this article shall be commenced more than three years after the due date of such amount. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1911) 
Secs. 30-162-30-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD 

Sec. 30-181. - Established; membership. 
(a)  Board established; composition. There is hereby established an emergency telephone system board (hereinafter "board") for the village, consisting of five persons, four of whom shall be representatives of the public safety agencies using the 9-1-1 service and one of whom shall be a resident of the village, all chosen for ability or experience and all appointed by the president and board of trustees of the village. 
(b)  Term of members. The terms of the members of the board shall be three years. 
(c)  Removal of members. A member of the board may be removed, for cause, by the president and board of trustees. 
(d)  Compensation of members. Members shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1912(a)) 
Sec. 30-182. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the board shall include the following: 
(1)  Planning a 9-1-1 system. 
(2)  Coordinating and supervising the implementation, upgrading or maintenance of the system, including the establishment of equipment specifications and coding systems. 
(3)  Receiving monies from the surcharge imposed under division 1 of this article, and from any other source, for deposit into the emergency telephone system fund. 
(4)  Authorizing all disbursements from the fund. 
(5)  Hiring, on a temporary basis, any staff necessary for the implementation or upgrade of the system. 
(6)  Such other powers and duties as may be imposed from time to time by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1912(b)) 
Sec. 30-183. - Disposition and use of funds. 
    All monies received by the board pursuant to a surcharge imposed under division 1 of this article shall be deposited into an emergency telephone system fund. The treasurer of the village shall be custodian of the fund. All interest accruing on the fund shall remain in the fund. No expenditures may be made from such fund except upon the direction of the board by resolution passed by a majority of all members of the board. Expenditures may be made only to pay for the costs associated with the following: 
(1)  The design of the emergency telephone system. 
(2)  The coding of an initial master street address guide database, and update the maintenance thereof. 
(3)  The repayment of any monies advanced for the implementation of the system. 
(4)  The charges for automatic number identification and automatic location identification equipment, a computer aided dispatch system that records, maintains, and integrates information, mobile data transmitters equipped with automatic vehicle locators, and maintenance, replacement and update thereof to increase operational efficiency and improve the provision of emergency services. 
(5)  The nonrecurring charges related to installation of the emergency telephone system and the ongoing network charges. 
(6)  The acquisition and installation, or the reimbursement of costs therefor to other governmental bodies that have incurred those costs, of road or street signs that are essential to the implementation of the emergency telephone system and that are not duplicative of signs that are the responsibility of the jurisdiction charged with maintaining road and street signs. 
(7)  Other products and services necessary for the implementation, upgrade and maintenance of the system and any other purpose related to the operation of the system, including costs attributable directly to the construction, leasing, or maintenance of any buildings or facilities or costs of personnel attributable directly to the operation of the system. Costs attributable directly to the operation of an emergency telephone system do not include the costs of public safety agency personnel who are and equipment that is dispatched in response to an emergency call. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1912(c)) 
Chapter 34 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Firefighter means a firefighter or a firefighter/paramedic. 
Sec. 34-32. - Department established; composition. 
    There is hereby created and established a fire department consisting of a chief of the department, who shall also have the title of fire marshal, and such other regular and volunteer officers and members as may be hereafter determined by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 6.001) 
Sec. 34-33. - Appointment and promotion of full-time members. 
    Appointments and promotions of all full-time members of the fire department, with the exception of the office of the fire chief, shall be made by the board of fire and police commissioners. All applicants for appointment to a full-time position in the fire department shall be subject to reasonable limitations, to be imposed by the board of fire and police commissioners, as to health, habits and moral character, and shall be subject to an examination which shall be public, competitive and open to all applicants. 
(Code 1965, § 6.002) 
Sec. 34-34. - Discharge of members. 
    No firefighter shall be discharged from the fire department except after a hearing on any charges before the board of fire and police commissioners as provided by law; except that this shall not be construed as affecting the power of the president and board of trustees to appoint and remove the chief. 
(Code 1965, § 6.003; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003) 
Sec. 34-35. - Appointment of volunteers. 
    The president and board of trustees may appoint such number of voluntary members of the fire department as they may from time to time determine. 
(Code 1965, § 6.004) 
Sec. 34-36. - Medical examinations. 
    All persons hereafter appointed to the position of full time or voluntary members of the fire department pursuant to the provisions of sections 34-33 and 34-35, before commencement of the performance of duties as such members and before such appointments shall become effective, shall submit to medical examination, including test of physical qualifications and health. Such examinations shall be practical in their character and shall relate to those physiological matters which will fairly test the appointees as to their relative capacity to discharge the duties of the positions to which they have been appointed. The examinations of appointees to positions of full-time members shall be conducted under the supervision of the board of fire and police commissioners, whereas the examinations of appointees to positions of volunteer members shall be conducted under the supervision of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 6.004.1) 
Sec. 34-37. - Supervision of department and equipment. 
    The fire chief shall have the control, subject to the orders and direction of the president and board of trustees, of the fire department and all fire apparatus belonging to the village; whenever any fire apparatus needs repairing said fire chief shall cause the same to be done without delay. 
(Code 1965, § 6.005) 
Sec. 34-38. - Command at fires. 
    In case of fire, the fire chief and his assistants shall rank in the order named and the officer of the highest rank at the fire shall take command of the fire and direct the management thereof for the suppression of the fire, in the best manner possible; and when it may be necessary for the protection of other property and to prevent the spread of the conflagration, the officer in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or destroyed in the best manner possible. 
(Code 1965, § 6.006) 
Sec. 34-39. - Management of funds. 
(a)  Election of officers. The full-time members of the fire department shall meet annually to elect officers for the purpose of managing monies received from foreign fire insurance companies. The officers shall consist of chairperson, vice-chairperson, secretary and treasurer. 
(b)  Duties of officers; accounts. The chairperson or vice-chairperson shall preside at all meetings, the secretary shall keep a record of all minutes, and the treasurer shall receive all funds transferred to the fire department by the village treasurer as receipts from foreign fire insurance companies. All such funds shall be used for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department. The treasurer shall also give a sufficient bond to the village, approved by the village president, conditioned upon the faithful performance of duties, and shall cause to be prepared a financial statement, fully accounting for all such funds coming into and leaving his possession during the preceding year ending July 1, with a copy of such statement to be signed by the treasurer under oath and filed with the village clerk not later than the following July 15. 
(c)  Adoption of rules and regulations. The officers so elected shall provide for the rules and regulations governing the management and payment of monies so held by the treasurer. 
(d)  Limitations. At no time shall the actions of these elected officers interfere with the powers of the chief, the composition of the fire department, or the board of fire and police commissioners, or in any way impede the ordinary operation of the fire department. 
(Code 1965, § 6.007) 
Sec. 34-40. - Records and reports. 
    The fire chief shall keep or cause to be kept a record of all meetings of the company and the attendance of all members, and a record of all fires, and during the last week in April of each year, file with the village clerk a full report of such records and attendance and fires, which report shall be under oath. 
(Code 1965, § 6.008) 
Sec. 34-41. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the function of the fire department, and every member thereof, to extinguish accidental or destructive hostile fires, to prevent the occurrence or spread thereof, to answer calls for and assist in emergency ambulance service, and to do other related acts, all in accordance with the instructions and directions of, and under the supervision of, the superior officers of said department. 
(Code 1965, § 6.009) 
Sec. 34-42. - Enforcement of ordinances. 
    It shall be the duty of all members of the fire department and all members of the police department of the village to see that provisions of this chapter are enforced and to arrest on view any person who shall be found violating any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall hinder, resist or refuse to obey any such officer in the discharge of his duty, and to that end all such officers are hereby vested with the usual power and authority of police officers. 
(Code 1965, § 6.010) 
Sec. 34-43. - Rules and regulations. 
    The fire chief may prescribe rules and regulations to govern the actions of the members of the fire department, subject to approval by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011) 
Sec. 34-44. - Firefighters' pension fund. 
    The firefighters' pension fund shall operate under the provisions of 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq. Additionally, any person appointed as a firefighter of the village, as a condition of employment with the village fire department, shall make written application to the village firefighters' pension fund board within three months after receiving his appointment and within three months after any reappointment, to become a member of, and actively participate in, the village's firefighters' pension fund. Failure, for any reason, of any firefighter to make such timely application and to become a member of, and actively participate in, said firefighters' pension fund shall be grounds for cause for removal from his position as a village firefighter. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.1) 
Sec. 34-45. - Education pay. 
    An employee of the fire department who has received an associate degree in fire science administration or any other degree in a college approved by the village board of trustees shall receive, in addition to normal base pay, $1,500.00 per year; and if he obtains a bachelor's degree in fire science administration, or any other degree, he shall receive, in addition to normal base pay, an additional $1,500.00 per year for a total of $3,000.00 per year. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.2; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003) 
Sec. 34-46. - Tuition reimbursement. 
    The employer shall reimburse employees the cost of tuition for courses for degrees related to their job duties if the employee has received written permission in advance of the start of the course from the fire chief and the village board of trustees to take the course, which shall not be unreasonably denied or withheld, and the employee has obtained a grade "C" or above, or the equivalent, for classes, courses or degrees. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.2.1) 
Sec. 34-47. - Uniforms. 
    Uniforms will be issued to each regular member of the fire department upon his appointment to service. Thereafter, whenever the fire chief, or the officer designated by the fire chief, shall determine that any part or all of such uniform should be replaced, he shall approve a purchase order therefor. Upon receipt of the replacement uniform or any part thereof, the items being so replaced must be turned in to the approving officer, who shall keep accurate records of all such replacements and file a summary thereof with the president and board of trustees at least semiannually. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.3; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003) 
Sec. 34-48. - Fire chief. 
    There is hereby created the office of fire chief, who shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees. If any officer, first class firefighter or regular firefighter shall be appointed fire chief, he shall retain, while so serving, whatever rank he held in the fire department at the time of his appointment as fire chief and resume such rank when his services as chief terminate. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.4) 
Sec. 34-49. - Captains. 
    There is hereby created the office of captain of the fire department, who shall serve as a shift commander. The particular shift assignment shall be made by the fire chief, who, at all times, shall have complete supervisory authority over such captain. The number shall be specified by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.5; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 09-20, § 1, 8-24-2009) 
Sec. 34-50. - Lieutenants. 
    There is hereby created the office of lieutenants of the fire department, of whom shall serve in that capacity during one of three separate work shifts. The particular shift assignment shall be made by the fire chief who, as all times, shall have final supervisory authority over such lieutenant. The lieutenant, while on duty in the firehouse or while responding to a fire or ambulance call, shall be deemed to be the ranking officer in the temporary absence of the fire chief or the captain. It shall be the responsibility of the fire chief to prepare a job description for the office of lieutenant, a true copy of which shall be provided to the lieutenant at the time of his appointment and thereafter as the description may be amended from time to time. The number of lieutenants shall be specified by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.51; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 09-20, § 1, 8-24-2009) 
Sec. 34-51. - Firefighter/paramedics. 
    There is hereby created the office of regular firefighter/paramedics, all of whom shall be appointed as full-time members of the fire department. The number of firefighter/paramedics shall be specified by the president and board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.6; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 09-20, § 1, 8-24-2009) 
Sec. 34-51.1. - Part-time fire inspector(s). 
    There is hereby created the position of part-time fire inspector(s). Full-time fire department employees shall be allowed to apply for the position after signing a 7(g) salary agreement with the village administrator. Part-time fire inspectors shall receive compensation as may, from time to time, be fixed by the Village Board. 
(Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 1-28-2008) 
Sec. 34-52. - Enforcement powers; inspections; citations; penalty. 
(a)  Definition of fire. For purposes of this section, the term "fire" includes, but is not limited to, the consumption of mass under conditions of high heat and low oxygen. 
(b)  Inspections. The fire chief shall make or cause to be made inspections or investigations, personally or through any such full-time member of the fire department as the fire chief may designate from time to time, for the purpose of determining compliance or noncompliance with the provisions of this Code relating to fire prevention or life safety, including the existence or abatement of a dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance. 
(c)  Notice. If the fire chief or his designee determines a dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance exists on premises in the village, the fire chief and his designee shall each be empowered to serve the current owner or operator of the premises, or any other person who caused the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance, with a written citation specifying the date, time, location, and nature of the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance. 
(d)  Abatement orders. Three days after issuance of the written citation provided for in subsection (c) of this section 34-52, or sooner if the fire chief deems it necessary under the circumstances, the fire chief may order the current owner or operator of the premises, or any other person who caused the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance, to: 
(1)  Abate the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance; 
(2)  Cease or refrain from activities that will exacerbate the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance; 
(3)  Investigate the cause, location, extent and threat to persons and property in the village presented by the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance; 
(4)  Investigate feasible alternatives for abatement of the dangerous condition or fire hazardous nuisance; 
(5)  Prepare a contingency plan acceptable to the fire chief that addresses the reasonably foreseeable consequences of the continued dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance; or 
(6)  Take such other action with respect to the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance as the fire chief deems reasonable and necessary under the circumstances. 
(e)  Abatement. The village may proceed to abate the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance as provided in sections 42-8 and 42-212 of the Code. 
(f)  Lien. Costs and charges incurred by the village in abating the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance shall be a lien upon the premises as provided in section 42-8 of the Code. 
(g)  Foreclosure of lien. Foreclosure of a lien for unpaid costs and charges incurred by the village in abating the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance shall proceed as provided in section 42-8 of the Code. 
(h)  Penalty. The penalty for a violation under this section, including failure to comply with an order issued by the fire chief pursuant to subsection (d) of section 34-52, shall be stricter than the general penalty as provided in section 1-10 of the code. Any person violating any provisions of this section 34-52 shall be subject to penalties as provided in subsection (h) of this section 34-52. Each day on which a violation of this section occurs or continues, and each day which passes without compliance with an order issued by the fire chief pursuant to subsection (d) of this section 34-52, shall constitute a separate offense. A violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not less than $750.00 for the first violation, with fines escalating for subsequent violations as follows: 
Fine Per Violation Number of Violations $1,500.00 2-3 3,000.00 4-5 6,000.00 6-7 10,000.00 8 or more  
provided, however, that a violation that occurs more than 90 days following a prior violation shall be deemed a first violation for purposes of this section of the Code. 
(i)  Punitive damages. In addition to any other penalty provided for herein, if any person fails without sufficient cause to comply with an order issued by the fire chief pursuant to subsection (d) of this section 34-52 of the Code to abate a dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance, such person may be liable to the village for punitive damages in an amount at least equal to, and not more than, three times the amount of any costs incurred by the village in abating the dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance. The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the village in any court having jurisdiction over such matter to enforce an order issued by the fire chief under subsection (d) of this section 34-52, achieve compliance with this ordinance, otherwise seek a judicial order abating a dangerous condition or fire hazard nuisance and recover penalties imposed by subsection (i) of this section 34-52. 
(j)  Aiding or abetting. Consistent with section 1-11 of the Code, every person concerned in the commission of an act prohibited under any provision of this section 34-52, whether he directly commits the act, or prosecutes, counsels, causes, allows, permits aids or abets in its commission, may be prosecuted and on conviction is punishable as if he had directly committed such act. 
(Code 1965, § 6.011.7; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 08-02, § 2, 1-28-2008; Ord. No. 08-09, § I, 3-24-2008) 
Sec. 34-53. - Unauthorized use of apparatus; interfering with apparatus. 
(a)  Whoever shall use any fire engine, hose, cart or other apparatus belonging to the village for any private purpose, other than the extinguishment of fires, or whoever shall remove the same or any part thereof from its place of deposit, or having control thereof, shall permit such engine, hose, cart or other apparatus to be used for any private purpose other than aforesaid, shall upon conviction be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense. 
(b)  Whoever shall wilfully or negligently interfere with any fire engine, hose, equipment or other fire apparatus belonging to the village, when being used by the proper person or authority, or shall remove any screw, bolt, or nut or any part of such engine or other fire apparatus or in any manner interfere with the same when being used by the proper person or authority, shall upon conviction be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 6.012) 
Sec. 34-54. - Entering firehouses. 
    It shall be and hereby is declared unlawful for any person or persons to enter the fire department house or any place where the equipment and apparatus of the fire department is stored, at any time, except on business pertaining to the fire department or other village business. The penalty for the violation of this section shall be as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 6.013; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003) 
Sec. 34-55. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the term "fire lane" shall be deemed to be any street, alley, driveway, roadway, access way, or easement of access, whether paved of unpaved, that is kept, maintained, or intended to provide ingress and egress for firefighting vehicles and equipment to or from any building, structure, or fire hydrant. A fire lane may be publicly dedicated or located wholly or partly on or over private property. 
(b)  Designation. The following described areas in the Village are hereby designated as fire lanes: 
(1)  The vehicular driveway that is immediately adjacent to the sidewalk along the east and north sides of the building complexes situated in the Family Square Shopping Center located south of Washington Boulevard and west of Mannheim Road, except the designated "Customer Parcel Pickup" areas thereupon. 
(2)  The vehicular driveway that is immediately adjacent to the west sides of all buildings located at 1919, 2021 and 2121 South Wolf Road, Hillside, Illinois, also known as the Westbrook Complex. 
(3)  On both sides of May Street between its intersection with Mannheim Road and a point 85 feet west of the west line of Mannheim Road. 
(4)  The vehicular driveway which generally encircles the office building commonly known as High Point Plaza, 4415 West Harrison Street, Hillside, Illinois, including the two north-south ingress and egress driveways between Harrison Street and said building, all as more specifically depicted on the site plan attached to and made a part of the original ordinance establishing this subsection on file in the office of the village clerk. 
(5)  The vehicular driveway which generally encircles the motel building commonly known as Chicago Hillside Best Western, 4400 Frontage Road, Hillside, Illinois, including the two northerly-southerly ingress and egress driveways between Frontage Road and said motel building, all as more specifically depicted on the site plan attached to and made a part of the original ordinance establishing this subsection on file in the office of village clerk. 
(6)  The vehicular driveway which is immediately adjacent to the sidewalk along the south side of the two buildings commonly known as the Butterfield Apartments, 4900-4970 Butterfield Road, Hillside, Illinois. 
(c)  Marking or posting of signs. Fire lanes designated in subsection (b) of this section shall be posted with signs or pavement lettering identifying the location of such fire lanes and the "Customer Parcel Pickup" areas thereupon. 
(d)  Obstruction prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to block or obstruct, wholly or partly, any duly designated and posted fire lane, except for the designated "Customer Parcel Pickup" areas when occupied during any period not to exceed ten minutes by a vehicle whose operator is actually picking up or delivering parcels. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of a violation of this section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 6.014; Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 13-22, § 1, 12-16-2013) 
Sec. 34-56. - Interfering with fire hydrants and valves. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except an employee or official of the public works department or the fire department of the village, to open, close, take water from or in any way interfere with any fire hydrant or valve belonging to the village without having first received written authority from the fire chief or the superintendent of public works to do so. The penalty for the violation of this section shall be as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 6.015) 
Secs. 34-57-34-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND BOARD 

Sec. 34-81. - Established; composition. 
    There shall be a board of trustees of the firefighters pension board consisting of five members. Two members shall be appointed by the mayor or village president of the board of trustees. Two members of the board shall be active participants of the pension fund who are elected by the active participants of the fund. One member of the board who is retired under the Firemen's Pension Fund Act of 1919, or this article who is elected from the person's retired under the Firemen's Pension Fund Act of 1919, or this article. 
    In the event that there are no retired firefighters under the fund, or if there is none willing to serve, then an additional active firefighter shall be elected to the board in lieu of the retired firefighter that would otherwise be elected. 
(Code 1965, § 7.601; Ord. No. 16-11, § 1, 10-24-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/4-121. 
Sec. 34-82. - Powers and duties. 
    The board of trustees of the firefighters' pension fund shall have control of the management of all funds belonging to or designated by law as part of the firefighters' pension fund and of the administration of such funds, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.602) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/4-122-4-129.1. 
Sec. 34-83. - Deposit of funds in pension fund. 
    There shall be deposited in the firefighters' pension fund the sums required by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.603) 
Secs. 34-84-34-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, adopted Jan. 22, 2007, amened fromer art. III, §§ 34-111-34-113, in its entirety. Former art. III pertained to the same subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965. 

Sec. 34-111. - Adoption of the International Fire Code 2018 Edition and NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition. 
(a)  For the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion and to facilitate egress from buildings and structures and avoid panic during times of emergency, those certain codes, known as the International Fire Code 2018 Edition and NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition whole thereof, as hereafter amended from time to time, of which codes not less than three copies of each have been and now are filed in the office of the clerk of the village, are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which the ordinance from which this section derived shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the Village of Hillside. 
(b)  Whenever the term "municipality" is used in the said codes, it shall mean the Village of Hillside, the term "corporation counsel" as used in said codes shall mean the village attorney for the Village of Hillside, and the phrase "Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention" as used in said codes shall mean the Chief of the Hillside Fire Department. 
CHAPTER 1 
SCOPE AND GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Wherever the phrase "(name of jurisdiction)" or the word "jurisdiction" appears, they shall be deemed to refer to the Village of Hillside. 
Wherever the phrase "fire code official" appears, it shall be deemed to refer to the Village of Hillside Fire Chief, or his/her duly designated agent or agents. 
Wherever any reference to "ICC Electrical Code" appears, it shall be replaced with the phrase "Chapter 18-27 of the Chicago Code, titled "Chicago Electrical Code", as adopted by the Village of Hillside, Illinois". 
Wherever any reference to "ICC Plumbing Code" appears, it shall be replaced with the phrase "Title 77: Public Health, Chapter I: Department of Public Health, Subchapter r: Water and Sewage, Part 890 Illinois Plumbing Code". 
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of Village of Hillside, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
103.4 Liability. The fire code official, officer or employee charged with the enforcement of this code, while acting for the jurisdiction, in good faith and without malice in the discharge of the duties required by this code or other pertinent law or ordinance, shall not thereby be rendered civilly or criminally liable personally, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage accruing to persons or property as a result of an act or by reason of an act or omission in the discharge of official duties. 
105.3.1 Expiration. An operational permit shall remain in effect until reissued, renewed or revoked, or for such a period of time as specified in the permit. Construction permits shall automatically become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within 90 days after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of 90 days after the time the work is commenced. Before such work recommences, a new permit shall be first obtained and the fee to recommence work, if any, shall be one-half the amount required for a new permit for such work, provided that changes have not been made and will not be made in the original construction documents for such work, and provided further that such suspension or abandonment has not exceeded one year. Permits are not transferable and any change in occupancy, operation, tenancy or ownership shall require that a new permit be issued 
105.3.2 - Extensions. 
A permittee holding an unexpired permit shall have the right to apply for an extension of the time within which the permittee will commence work under that permit where work is unable to be commenced within the time required by this section for good and satisfactory reasons. The fire code official is authorized to grant, in writing, one or more extensions of the time period of a permit for periods of not more than 90 days each. Such extensions shall be requested by the permit holder in writing and justifiable cause demonstrated. 
109.1 - Application for appeal: 
In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a Board of Elected Officials. The Board of Elected Officials shall be appointed by the governing body and shall hold office at its pleasure. The fire code official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall not have a vote on any matter before the board. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the fire code official. 
109.3 - Qualifications: This section shall not apply to the Village of Hillside. 
110.4 - Violation penalties. 
Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of an offense specified in Sec. 1-10 of the Village of Hillside municipal code, punishable by a fine specified in Sec. 1-10 of the Village of Hillside municipal code or by imprisonment specified in Sec. 1-10 of the Village of Hillside municipal code, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
112.4 - Failure to comply. 
Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine specified in Sec. 1-10 of the Village of Hillside municipal code.

None of the exceptions stated in 311.2.2 shall apply to the Village of Hillside. 
None of the following chapters shall apply to the Village of Hillside:

Chapter 25, Fruit and Crop Ripening 
Chapter 36, Marinas

(Ord. No. 18-12, §§ 2, 6, 8-27-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-12, §§ 2, 6, adopted August 27, 2018, amended section 34-111 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 34-111 pertained to the adoption of BOCA Fire Prevention and Life Safety Codes, and derived from Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, adopted January 22, 2007. 
Sec. 34-112. - Definitions. 
    Authority having jurisdiction (AHJ). The AHJ shall include the following: The Chief of the Hillside Fire Department, his delegates, officers and firefighters. 
    This Code refers to: International Fire Code 2018 Edition and NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition as adopted by the Village of Hillside. 
(Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, 1-22-2007; Ord. No. 18-12, § 3, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 34-113. - Conflicts between codes. 
    Wherever a conflict arises between the International Fire Code 2018 Edition and NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition the more stringent of the two shall be applied. 
(Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, 1-22-2007; Ord. No. 18-12, § 4, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 34-114. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of the Fire Prevention Code adopted by reference under Sec. 21.401 of the Article IV is hereby amended in the following respects: 
Exception 1. 
Fire Protection Systems: 
A.  NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition 9.7 Automatic Sprinklers and IFC 2018 Sec. 903 Automatic Sprinkler Systems. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Apartment buildings having less than 7 dwelling units. 
2.  All one and two-family dwellings. 
B.  As applicable in NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition Chapters 11-43 in regards to automatic Sprinkler Systems. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Apartment buildings having less than 7 dwelling units. 
2.  All one and two-family dwellings. 
Exception 2. 
Fire Detection and Alarm Systems 
All existing buildings, regardless of size shall be equipped throughout with an approved fire alarm system as listed in NFPA 72 when any of the following conditions occur: 
A.  Change of occupancy class 
B.  Change of ownership 
C.  Remodeling of more than 50% of total structural value (EAV) in cost Exceptions: 
1.  Apartment buildings having less than 7 dwelling units. 
2.  All one and two-family dwellings. 
Exception 3. 
All new buildings, additions or alternations to an existing building shall be protected throughout, with an approved fire alarm system regardless of square footage as listed in NFPA 72. 
Exception 4. 
NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition. 9.10.1, 9.10.2: All new occupancies having three or more stories shall have an approved standpipe system installed in each stairwell. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Apartment building having less than 7 dwelling units. 
2.  All one and two-family dwellings. 
Exception 5. 
All Assembly, Educational, Healthcare and Residential Occupancies requiring an approved fire sprinkler system, shall use sprinklers that are rated as Fast or Quick Response (FR or QR). 
Exceptions: 
1.  In Electrical or mechanical equipment rooms, or 
2.  In commercial laundry or cooking areas, or 
3.  In any approved area deemed necessary by the AHJ. 
Exception 6. 
NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition. 9.2.3: All hood and duct extinguishing systems for commercial kitchen areas requiring such a system, shall be of an approved type "K" system for the following: 
1.  New construction. 
2.  Remodeling rehab of existing systems. 
3.  Appliance line changes, including the installation of high efficiency/high recovery fryers. 
4.  Change of ownership. 
Exception 7. 
NFPA 101 Life Safety Code 2018 Edition. 9.2.3 
All existing commercial kitchen systems requiring a hood and duct system shall be required to have at least one, 6-liter, type "K" extinguisher. 
(Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, 1-22-2007; Ord. No. 18-12, § 5, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 34-115. - Permit fees. 
    The following permit fees shall be applied for all plan reviews and are in addition to any other existing fees. 
For fire sprinkler systems, per 100 sprinklers ..... $250.00 
For life safety without sprinklers ..... 100.00 
Exception: If in the opinion of the Code Official, the scope of the review is beyond the ability of the Fire Department to conduct, the review shall be conducted by an agency of AHJ's choosing. Any and all costs associated with this process shall be charged as part of the permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, 1-22-2007) 
Sec. 34-116. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 07-02, § 1, 1-22-2007) 
Secs. 34-117-34-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS 

Sec. 34-141. - Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful to store, discharge or set off any fireworks or give any pyrotechnic displays in the village except as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 24.401(a)) 
Sec. 34-142. - Public displays. 
    No public exhibition of fireworks or pyrotechnics shall be given unless a permit is first obtained from the president and board of trustees. All such public displays shall be under the supervision of a competent person, and shall be supervised by the fire marshal or some member of the fire department assigned to this duty by him. 
(Code 1965, § 24.401(b)) 
Sec. 34-143. - Sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to sell, offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling, any fireworks in the village at any time. 
(Code 1965, § 24.401(c)) 
Sec. 34-144. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occur or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.402) 
Chapter 38 - FLOODS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLOODPLAIN REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-17, adopted July 28, 2008, amended former art. II, §§ 38-31-38-41, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 05-13, adopted May 23, 2005. 

Sec. 38-31. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this village by 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8, and 5/11-31-2 (1994). The purpose of this article is to maintain this village's eligibility in the National Flood Insurance Program; to minimize potential losses due to periodic flooding including loss of life, loss of property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare; and to preserve and enhance the quality of surface waters, conserve economic and natural values and provide for the wise utilization of water and related land resources. This article is adopted in order to accomplish the following specific purposes: 
(1)  To meet the requirements of 615 ILCS 5/18g Rivers, Lakes and Streams Act. 
(2)  To assure that new development does not increase the flood or drainage hazards to others, or creating unstable conditions susceptible to erosion; 
(3)  To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from flood damage; 
(4)  To protect human life and health from the hazards of flooding; 
(5)  To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control projects, repairs to flood-damaged public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations; and 
(6)  To make federally subsidized flood insurance available for property in the village by fulfilling the requirements of the National Flood Insurance Program. 
(7)  To comply with the rules and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program codified as 44 CFR 59-79, as amended. 
(8)  To protect, conserve, and promote the orderly development of land and water resources; 
(9)  To preserve the natural characteristics and functions of watercourses and floodplains in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts, improve water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian habitat, provide recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and enhance community and economic development. 
(Ord. No. 08-17, § 1, 7-28-2008) 
Sec. 38-32. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following definitions are adopted: 
(1)  Accessory structure. A structure which is on the same parcel of property as the principal structure to be insured and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure. 
(2)  Act. "An act in relation to the regulation of the rivers, lakes and streams of the State of Illinois," 615 ILCS 5/5 et seq. 
(3)  Applicant. Any person, firm, corporation or agency which submits an application. 
(4)  Appropriate use. Only uses of the designated floodway that are permissible and will be considered for permit issuance. The only uses that will be allowed are as specified in section 38-37.2. 
(5)  Base flood. The flood having a one-percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year frequency flood event. Application of the base flood elevation at any location is as defined in section 38-35. 
(6)  Base flood elevation (BFE). The elevation in relation to mean sea level of the crest of the base flood. 
(7)  Building. A structure that is principally above ground and is enclosed by walls and a roof. The term includes a gas or liquid storage tank, a manufactured home, mobile home or a prefabricated building. This term also includes recreational vehicles and travel trailers to be installed on a site for more than 180 days, unless fully licensed and ready for highway use. 
(8)  Channel. Any river, stream, creek, brook, branch, natural or artificial depression, ponded area, flowage, slough, ditch, conduit, culvert, gully, ravine, wash, or natural or man-made drainageway, which has a definite bed and banks or shoreline, in or into which surface or groundwater flows, either perennially or intermittently. 
(9)  Channel modification. Alteration of a channel by changing the physical dimensions or materials of its bed or banks. Channel modification includes damming, rip-rapping (or other armoring), widening, deepening, straightening, relocating, lining and significant removal of native vegetation from the bottom or banks. Channel modification does not include the clearing of dead or dying vegetation, debris, or trash from the channel. Channelization is a severe form of channel modification involving a significant change in the channel cross-section and typically involving relocation of the existing channel (e.g. straightening). 
(10)  Compensatory storage. An artificially excavated, hydraulically equivalent volume of storage within the SFHA used to balance the loss of natural flood storage capacity when artificial fill or structures are placed within the floodplain. The uncompensated loss of natural floodplain storage can increase off-site floodwater elevations and flows. 
(11)  Conditional approval of a designated floodway map change. Preconstruction approval by IDNR/OWR and FEMA of a proposed change to the floodway map. This preconstruction approval, pursuant to this part, gives assurances to the property owner that once an appropriate use is constructed according to permitted plans, the floodway map can be changed, as previously agreed, upon review and acceptance of as-built plans. 
(12)  Conditional letter of map revision (CLOMR). A letter which indicates that FEMA will revise base flood elevations, flood insurance rate zones, flood boundaries or floodway as shown on an effective or flood insurance rate map, once the as-built plans are submitted and approved. 
(13)  Control structure. A structure designed to control the rate of flow that passes through the structure, given a specific upstream and downstream water surface elevation. 
(14)  Critical facility. Any public or private facility which, if flooded, would create an added dimension to the disaster or would increase the hazard to life and health. Examples are public buildings, emergency operations and communication centers, etc. 
(15)  Dam. All obstructions, wall embankments or barriers, together with their abutments and appurtenant works, if any, constructed for the purpose of storing or diverting water or creating a pool. Underground water storage tanks are not included. 
(16)  Designated floodway. The channel, including on-stream lakes, and that portion of the floodplain adjacent to a stream or watercourse as designated by IDNR/OWR, which is needed to store and convey the existing 100-year frequency flood discharge with no more than a 0.1 foot increase in stage due to the loss of flood conveyance or storage, and no more than a ten percent increase in velocities. 
a.  The floodways are designated for Addison Creek on the Flood Insurance Rate Map prepared by FEMA and dated August 19, 2008 and Addison Creek. When two floodway maps exist for a waterway, the more restrictive floodway limit shall prevail. 
b.  The floodways for those parts of unincorporated Cook County that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the village that may be annexed into the village are designated for Addison Creek on the Flood Insurance Rate Map prepared by FEMA and dated August 19, 2008 
c.  To locate the designated floodway boundary on any site, the designated floodway boundary should be scaled off the designated floodway map and located on a site plan, using reference marks common to both maps. Where interpretation is needed to determine the exact location of the designated floodway boundary, IDNR/OWR should be contacted for the interpretation. 
(17)  Development. Any manmade change to real estate, including: 
a.  Construction, reconstruction, repair, or placement of a building or any addition to a building. 
b.  Installing a manufactured home on a site, preparing a site for a manufactured home, or installing a travel trailer or recreational vehicle on a site for more than 180 days. If the travel trailer or recreational vehicle is on site for more than 180 days, it must be fully licensed and ready for highway use. 
c.  Drilling, mining, installing utilities, construction of roads, bridges, or similar projects. 
d.  Demolition of a structure or redevelopment of a site. 
e.  Clearing of land as an adjunct of construction. 
f.  Construction or erection of levees, walls, fences, dams, or culverts; channel modification; filling, dredging, grading, excavating, paving, or other non-agricultural alterations of the ground surface; storage of materials; deposit of solid or liquid waste; 
g.  Any other activity of man that might change the direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface water, including extensive vegetation removal; 
Development does not include routine maintenance of existing buildings and facilities such as re-roofing or re-surfacing of roads when there is no increase in elevation, or gardening, plowing, and similar agricultural practices that do not involve filling, grading, or construction of levees. 
(18)  Elevation certificates. A form published by FEMA that is used to certify the elevation to which a building has been elevated. 
(19)  Erosion. The general process whereby soils are moved by flowing water or wave action. 
(20)  Exempt organizations. Organizations which are exempt from this chapter per Illinois Compiled Statutes (ILCS) including state, federal or local units of government. 
(21)  Existing manufactured home park or subdivision. A manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) has been completed before April 1, 1990. 
(22)  Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision. The preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads). 
(23)  FEMA. Federal Emergency Management Agency and its regulations at 44 CFR 59-79 revised as of October 1, 2001. This incorporation does not include any later editions or amendments. 
(24)  Flood. A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from overflow of inland or tidal waves, or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
(25)  Flood frequency. A period of years, based on a statistical analysis, during which a flood of a stated magnitude may be expected to be equaled or exceeded. 
(26)  Flood fringe. That portion of the floodplain outside of the designated floodway. 
(27)  Flood hazard boundary map. An official map of a community where the boundaries of the flood having special hazard areas have been designated as zone A. Flood hazard boundary maps are superseded by flood insurance rate maps. 
(28)  Flood insurance rate maps (FIRM). A map prepared by FEMA that depicts the special flood hazard area (SFHA) within a community. This map includes insurance rate zones and floodplains and may or may not depict floodways. 
(29)  Flood insurance study. An examination, evaluation and determination of flood hazards and if appropriate, corresponding water surface elevations. 
(30)  Floodplain. That land typically adjacent to a body of water with ground surface elevations at or below the base flood or the 100-year frequency flood elevation.
