b.  Any person or persons so notified to fail to respond and meet with the chief of police within the 20-day period without good cause shown. 
(4)  When any party affected by this section responds and meets with the chief of police as required above, no statements made in connection with the furnishing of that response or in a meeting shall constitute or be used in any judicial or quasi-judicial proceeding as an admission that any nuisance activity has or is occurring at or on the property. This subsection (4) does not require the exclusion of any other evidence which is otherwise admissible and offered for any other purpose than an admission by a person affected by this section. 
(e)  Abatement-Administrative hearing. 
(1)  At any hearing before the village administrative hearing officer to determine whether the property in question is a chronic nuisance property, which hearing shall be conducted pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 2, Article VI of the Village Code of Ordinances, the village shall have the initial burden of proof to show, by a preponderance of evidence, that the property in question is a chronic nuisance property. Notice of the hearing shall be provided to all persons or entities that may be adversely affected by a decision declaring the property to be a chronic nuisance property. 
(2)  The village's representative shall present evidence in support of its claim that the property is a chronic nuisance property. The property owner, manager(s) or tenant(s) in possession if a leased property, or person(s) in charge or the person in charge's local representative or attorney on behalf of the responding party shall be permitted to rebut such evidence. No continuances shall be authorized by the administrative hearing officer in proceedings under this section unless for good cause shown or except where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of any party to the proceeding. Lack of preparedness shall not be grounds for a continuance. At any time prior to the hearing date, the administrative hearing officer may, at the request of either party(s), direct witnesses to appear and give testimony at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing and hearsay evidence including police reports shall be admissible only if it is the type commonly relied upon by reasonable, prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. 
(3)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the administrative hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing, whether or not a violation(s) exists or existed and whether or not the property is a chronic nuisance property. The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as the findings, decision, and order. The administrative hearing officer's decision shall be final and binding, except that the provisions of the Illinois Administrative Review Law shall apply with respect to judicial review of the administrative hearing officer's findings, decision and order. The findings, decision, and order shall include the administrative hearing officer's findings of fact, a decision whether or not a violation(s) exists, a determination as to whether the property in question is or is not a chronic nuisance property based upon the findings of fact, and a monetary fine or other appropriate sanction imposed against the person(s) in Charge/manager(s)/owner(s)/ tenant(s) or occupant(s), as specified in subsection (4) below, or dismissing the case in the event a violation is not proved. A copy of the findings, decision, and order shall be served upon the person in charge, owner, or tenant or occupant, within 14 business days of the date of the hearing. 
(4)  If the administrative hearing officer makes a finding that a property was, or is, a chronic nuisance property, the administrative hearing officer may fine the manager(s), person(s) in charge and/or the owner, tenant or occupant of the property if those persons are different from the manager(s) or person(s) in charge of the property, an amount not to exceed $750.00 for each violation of this section. Each day a nuisance activity occurs or continues shall be considered a separate and distinct violation for purposes of determining a property to be a chronic nuisance property. The administrative hearing officer may, in his or her discretion, impose such a fine for each day the nuisance activity goes unabated. No person shall be found in violation of this section unless the village proves the violation by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(f)  Alternative enforcement. 
(1)  Nuisance abatement. The village, as an alternative to administrative adjudication, may commence an action in the circuit court of the county fourth municipal district or chancery division of the circuit court of the county for a determination that the property is a chronic nuisance property and/or to abate a chronic nuisance property. 
Upon being satisfied by affidavits or other sworn evidence that an alleged chronic nuisance property exists, the court may, without notice or bond, enter a temporary restraining order or a preliminary injunction or permanent injunction to enjoin any defendant from maintaining such chronic nuisance property and may enter an order restraining any defendant named from occupying, using or interfering with all property used in connection with the chronic nuisance property. 
(2)  Commencement of action, burden of proof. 
a.  In an action seeking closure of a chronic nuisance property, the village shall have the initial burden of showing by a preponderance of the evidence that the property is a chronic nuisance property. 
b.  It shall be an affirmative defense by the property owner of rental or leased property to an action seeking the closure of a chronic nuisance property that the owner of the property, manager(s) or person(s) in charge, at the time in question, could not, in the exercise of reasonable care or diligence, determine that the property had become a chronic nuisance property, or could not, in spite of the exercise of reasonable care or diligence, determine that the property had become a chronic nuisance property, or could not, in spite of the exercise of reasonable care and diligence, control the conduct of tenants or others in possession leading to the findings that the property is a chronic nuisance property, or that the owner, tenant, or person in control of the property was the victim of a crime, including, but not limited to, an act of domestic or sexual violence, had contacted police or emergency services to prevent or respond to acts of domestic or sexual violence, or contact was made by, on behalf of, or otherwise concerned an individual with a disability, and the purpose of the contact was related to that individual's disability. The terms "domestic violence", "sexual violence", and "disability" shall have the same meaning as set forth in 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.5. 
c.  In establishing the amount of any civil penalty or other relief requested, the court may consider any of the following factors if they are found appropriate, and shall cite those found applicable: 
1.  The actions or lack of action taken by the owner or person(s) in charge to mitigate or correct the nuisance activity at the property. 
2.  Whether the criminal activity or nuisance activity at the property was repeated or continuous. 
3.  The magnitude or gravity of the criminal activity or nuisance activity at the property. 
4.  The cooperation of the owner or person(s) in charge of the property with the village to correct the offending condition or abate the nuisance. 
5.  Whether the property owner, in the event of rental or leased property, has required the tenant(s) to sign a "crime free lease addendum." 
6.  The cost to the village of investigating and correcting or attempting to correct the condition. 
(3)  Remedy. 
a.  In the event a court determines a property to be a chronic nuisance property, the court may order that the property be closed and secured against all use and occupancy for a period of not less than 30 days, but not more than 180 days or until the nuisance activity(s) or violation(s) complained of is abated or the court may employ any other remedy deemed by it appropriate to abate the nuisance. 
b.  In addition to the remedy provided in subparagraph (a) above, the court may impose upon the owner, manager(s), person(s) in charge and/or tenant(s) or occupant(s) of the property in question a civil penalty in an amount not to exceed the sum of $750.00 per day, payable to the village, for each day the owner, person(s) in charge and/or tenant(s) or occupant(s) had actual knowledge that the property was a chronic nuisance property and permitted the property to remain a chronic nuisance property. 
c.  In determining what remedy or remedies to employ, the court may consider evidence of other conduct which has occurred on the property, including, but not limited to: 
1.  The disturbance of neighbors; 
2.  The occurrence of other criminal activity or nuisances at, on or from the property; 
3.  The property's general reputation and/or the reputation of persons in or frequenting the property; 
4.  Physical damage to the property in question or surrounding properties; 
5.  The hazard posed to any occupant of the property or adjoining property owner resulting from the physical condition of the property in question or its structures. 
d.  The court may authorize the village to physically secure the property against use or occupancy in the event the owner fails to do so within the time specified by the court. In the event that the village is authorized to secure the property, all costs reasonably incurred by the village to affect the closure shall be made and assessed as a lien again the property and debt to the village. As used herein, "costs" mean those costs actually incurred by the village for the physical securing of the property. 
e.  The village building department or code enforcement department employee affecting the closure shall prepare a statement of costs, and the village shall thereafter submit said statement to the court for its review. If no objection of the statement is made within the period described by the court, a lien in said amount may be recorded against said property. 
f.  Any person who is assessed the cost of closure and/or civil penalty by the court shall be personally liable for the payment thereof to the village. 
(g)  Chronic nuisance located at multi-unit rental residential property. In the event any chronic nuisance property is a multi-unit rental residential property, any order entered by the court to abate the nuisance or otherwise vacate the property shall, in the discretion of the court, be limited in scope as to apply only to the individual rental unit or person(s) in charge or tenant(s) or occupants of that unit forming the basis for the finding that the property is a chronic nuisance property. 
(h)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance in conflict with the provisions of this section is repealed solely to the extent of such conflict. 
(i)  Severability. Should any provision or portion of this section be declared void or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining portions of this section not so declared shall remain in full force and effect. 
(j)  This section shall be in full force and effect ten days after its passage, approval and publication in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 12-14, § 2, 11-26-2012; Ord. No. 13-03, § 2, 2-25-2013; Ord. No. 16-03, § 1, 2-22-2016) 
Sec. 58-37. - Possession of cannabis and cannabis paraphernalia. 
(a)  [Definitions.] For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Cannabis includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis Sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative mixture, or preparation of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination. 
(2)  Cannabis paraphernalia means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are intended to be used unlawfully in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis in violation of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.). It includes, but is not limited to: 
a.  Kits intended to be used unlawfully in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis; 
b.  Isomerization devices intended to be used unlawfully in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis; 
c.  Testing intended to be used unlawfully for identifying or analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of cannabis; 
d.  Diluents and adulterants intended to be used unlawfully for cutting cannabis by private persons; 
e.  Objects intended to be used unlawfully in inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body, including, where applicable, the following items: 
1.  Water pipes; 
2.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
3.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
4.  Carburetor pipes; 
5.  Electric pipes; 
6.  Air driven pipes; 
7.  Chillums; 
8.  Bongs; 
9.  Ice pipes or chillers; 
f.  Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of this section. 
(b)  Prohibition on cannabis possession. 
(1)  It shall be a violation of this section for any person knowingly to possess any quantity of any substance containing cannabis, except that the effect of this section shall be limited to persons knowingly possessing less than ten grams of any substance containing cannabis. 
(2)  When a police officer finds a person in possession of cannabis, he or she may, in lieu of filing a complaint or arresting the person, issue the person an ordinance violation ticket and seize the cannabis that is the subject of a violation of this section in accordance with Section 12 of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 550/12). This ordinance violation ticket shall allow the person to settle the violation by agreeing to the forfeiture of the cannabis that is the subject of a violation of this section to the village police department and paying to the village the amount set forth below, not more than ten days after the time the violation was committed: 
Amount of Cannabis Fine Under 2.5 grams $100.00 2.5 grams or more, but not more than 5 grams $175.00 More than 5 grams, but not more than 10 grams $275.00  
(3)  If the person to whom an ordinance violation ticket was issued fails to settle and pay the violation claim within ten days after the time the violation was committed, administrative adjudication proceedings shall be initiated against the violator. If a fine is imposed by the administrative hearing officer, the fine shall not be less than the amount set forth above as the settlement amount. 
(4)  No person previously convicted under Sections 4(a) through 4(c) of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 550/4(a), (b), (c)) will be afforded the opportunity to pay a fine in accordance with the terms of subsection (b)(2) of this section and will be charged under Section 4 of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 550/4), and processed accordingly. 
(5)  Any person committing a second offense under this section will not be afforded the opportunity to pay a fine in accordance with the terms of subsection (b)(2) of this section and will be charged under Section 4 of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 550/4), and processed accordingly. 
(c)  Prohibition on cannabis paraphernalia possession. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly possess an item of cannabis paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis into the human body, or in preparing cannabis substance for that use. 
(2)  The provisions of subsection (c) of this section shall not apply to: 
a.  Items marked for the use in preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis as incident to lawful research, teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale; 
b.  Items marked for, or historically and customarily used in connection with the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, or inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance; 
c.  Garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette rolling papers; and 
d.  Items listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section which are marked for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered completely inoperable or incapable of being used for any illicit purpose prohibited by this section. 
(3)  When a police officer finds a person in violation of subsection (c)(1) of this section, he or she may, in lieu of filing a complaint or arresting the person, issue the person an ordinance violation ticket, and seize the cannabis paraphernalia that is the subject of a violation of this section in accordance with Section 5 of the Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 600/5). This ordinance violation ticket shall allow the person to settle the violation by agreeing to the forfeiture of the cannabis paraphernalia that is the subject of a violation of this section to the village police department and paying to the village the amount of $275.00, not more than ten days after the time the violation was committed. 
(4)  If the person to whom an ordinance violation ticket was issued fails to settle and pay the violation claim within ten days after the time the violation was committed, administrative adjudication proceedings shall be initiated against the violator. If a fine is imposed by the administrative hearing officer, the fine shall not be less than the amount set forth in subsection (c)(3) of this section as the settlement amount. 
(5)  In determining intent under this section, the administrative hearing officer or other trier of fact may take into consideration the proximity of cannabis to the drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis on or in the drug paraphernalia. 
(6)  In determining whether or not a particular item is exempt under subsection (c) of this section, the administrative hearing officer or other trier of fact should consider, in addition to all logically relevant factors, the following: 
a.  The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put; 
b.  Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the device upon its functioning; 
c.  Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning the purpose or uses to which the item can or may be put; 
d.  Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and place of sale or commercial delivery; 
e.  Any national or local advertising concerning the design, purpose or use of the item involved and the entire context in which such advertising occurs; 
f.  The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any item or items displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited upon the premises where the sale was made; 
g.  Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products; and 
h.  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
(7)  No person previously convicted under Sections 3 and 3.5 of the Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 600/3, 3.5) will be afforded the opportunity to pay a fine in accordance with the terms of subsection (c)(3) of this section and will be charged under Section 3.5 of the Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 600/3.5), and processed accordingly. 
(8)  Any person committing a second offense under this section will not be afforded the opportunity to pay a fine in accordance with the terms of subsection (c)(3) of this section and will be charged under Section 3.5 of the Illinois Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 600/3.5), and processed accordingly. 
(d)  [Paraphernalia.] All cannabis and cannabis paraphernalia that is subject of a violation of this section shall be subject to forfeiture upon a finding of guilty of any person for a violation of this section. All cannabis shall be maintained and disposed of in accordance with Section 16.2 of the Illinois Cannabis Control Act, as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 550/16.2), except that no evidence shall be disposed of by the court or administrative hearing officer until 45 days after judgment on the ordinance violation is entered, and if a complaint for administrative review is filed, no evidence shall be disposed of until those proceedings and any appeal from those proceedings. All cannabis paraphernalia shall be destroyed upon appropriate order of the court or administrative hearing officer. 
(e)  Record retention policy. 
(1)  The village police department shall keep a record of all violations of this section, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. The department shall initially maintain all records for two years from the effective date of this section and shall maintain such records of violations and dispositions for the most recent two-year period. 
(2)  Periodically, and not less than once per calendar year, the village police department shall expunge from the records of the department and the village all references to tickets issued for violations of this section and any records of resolution of those violations, by way of payment, settlement or disposition of those violations in which the date of the final disposition or resolution is more than two years old. 
(3)  All forms for records of violations and notices of violations shall be serially numbered. For each month and year, a written record shall be kept available to the public showing the disposal of all such forms. 
(4)  All such records and reports shall be public records. 
(f)  The ordinance from which this section derives shall take effect after its passage, approval and publication in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 11-01, § 2, 1-24-2011) 
Secs. 58-38-58-60. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-14, § 2, adopted August 27, 2018, repealed the former section 58-38 in its entirety, which pertained to appropriate dress for persons in certain public places, and derived from Ord. No. 13-07, § 2, adopted April 22, 2013. 
ARTICLE II. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-61. - Contributing to delinquency of minor. 
(a)  No person over the age of 18 years having the care, custody or control of any child under the age of 18 years shall knowingly or willfully permit, cause, aid, abet or encourage such child to commit any act or omission in violation of any law, statute, or ordinance of the Village of Hillside, the County of Cook, the State of Illinois, or the United States, where the violation of such law, statute, or ordinance is punishable by fine or imprisonment. 
(b)  No person over the age of 18 years not having the care, custody, or control of a child under the age of 18 years shall knowingly or willfully permit, cause, aid, abet or encourage such child to commit any act or omission in violation of any law, statute, or ordinance of the Village of Hillside, the County of Cook, the State of Illinois, or the United States, where the violation of such law, statute, or ordinance is punishable by fine or imprisonment. 
(c)  Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(d)  In addition to the penalties set forth under subsection (c), any person who violates subsection (a) or (b) shall also be jointly and severally liable with the child that commits the act or omission for any fine, condition or reparation imposed by a court on the child and for full restitution to any injured or damaged party or parties for the willful or malicious acts of such child; provided, however, that the person in violation of subsection (a) or (b) has been served, at least ten day prior to the scheduled hearing date, with a summons or notice to appear and written notice, setting forth the charges against the child in the original cause as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 17-02, § 2, 3-27-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-02, § 2, adopted March 27, 2017, repealed § 58-61, which pertained to parental responsibility for violations by minors and derived from Code 1965, § 25.032.7. 
Sec. 58-62. - Truancy. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Legal guardian means a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor under the Juvenile Court Act of 1987, 405 ILCS 5/1-122. 
    Minor means any person over five but who shall not have reached 18 years of age. 
    Parent means the lawful father or mother of a minor child, whether by birth or adoption. 
    Unemancipated minor means a minor still under the care and custody of his parents. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any minor enrolled in a public, private or parochial school within the corporate limits of the village to absent himself from attendance at such school without prior written permission of his parent or legal guardian having been filed with the proper school authorities. Emergencies or unforeseen absences due to illness or other causes beyond the control of the absentee minor shall not constitute truancy if permission for such absence has, in substance, been obtained from the parent or legal guardian, and such permission is confirmed in writing and filed with the proper school authorities within 24 hours after such absence. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any juvenile, between the age of seven (7) and sixteen (16) years, who is subject to compulsory school attendance pursuant to the Illinois School Code, whether attending a public, private or parochial school, who has been expelled or suspended from attending such school, and who is not otherwise subject to the truancy laws established by the Illinois School Code, to be upon any public road, street, alley, park or other lands used for public purposes or in any public place of business or amusement within the Village during the day-time hours when such schools are in session. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with said parent or legal guardian to knowingly allow or knowingly permit said minor child to violate or attempt to violate subsection (b) of this section. 
(e)  In addition to or in lieu of the penalties applicable to this section as set forth in section 58-63, a period of community service not to exceed 160 hours may be imposed upon a minor who violates any provision of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 25.032.8; Ord. No. 06-42, § 1, 12-18-2006) 
Sec. 58-63. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 25.033) 
Secs. 58-64-58-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CURFEW[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, adopted March 24, 2004 amended former div. 2, §§ 58-81-58-85 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 24.201-24.205. 
State Law reference- Authority of village to establish curfew, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-5. 

Sec. 58-81. - Children on the streets at night. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, under the age of 17, to be upon any public road, street, alley, park or other lands used for public purposes, on or in any public place of business or amusement in the village: 
(1)  Between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Friday and 6:00 a.m. Saturday; 
(2)  Between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Saturday and 6:00 a.m. Sunday; and 
(3)  Between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any other day of the week. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 58-82. - Permitting a child to violate curfew. 
    It is hereby unlawful for any parent, guardian, custodian, or other person having legal care and custody of any person under the age of 17 years, to allow or permit such child, ward or other person under such age, while having such legal custody, to be in or upon any public road, street, alley, park or other lands used for public purposes or in any public place of business or amusement in the village within the times prohibited in this division. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 58-83. - Encouraging or inducing a child to violate curfew. 
    It is hereby unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally encourage, aid, induce or cause a person under the age of 17 years, to be in or upon any public road, street, alley, park or other lands used for public purposes or in any public place of business or amusement in the village within the times prohibited in this division. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 58-84. - Defenses. 
    It is a defense to a violation under this division that the child engaged in the prohibited conduct while: 
(1)  Accompanied by the child's parent, guardian or custodian; 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult specified by the child's parent, guardian or custodian; 
(3)  Participating in going to or returning from: 
a.  Lawful employment; 
b.  A school-sanctioned activity; 
c.  A religious service or event; 
d.  An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; 
e.  An activity involving the exercise of the child's rights protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or Article 1, Sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Constitution of the State of Illinois, such as freedom of speech, religious freedom and the right of assembly; 
f.  An activity conducted by a non-profit or governmental entity that provides recreation, education, training or other services under the supervision of one or more adults. 
(4)  Engaged in interstate travel from a location outside Illinois to another location outside Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 58-85. - Arrest and detention. 
    Before any police officer may detain or arrest, without warrant, any person under the age of 17 years for violation of this division, the officer must inquire into the person's reasons for being in the public place during curfew hours. A police officer is hereby authorized to arrest, without warrant, any person for violation of the provisions of this division and detain such person until he or she is turned over to the parent, guardian, custodian, or other person having the legal care and custody of the child, only if the officer reasonably believes that the person has violated this division and that none of the defenses to a violation under this division apply. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 58-86. - Delinquent children. 
    It shall be the duty of the juvenile officer of the police force, upon the arrest of any child or minor person, where the parent, guardian or custodian has refused to become responsible for said minor person for violation of the provisions of this division, to inquire into the facts of said arrest and the conditions and circumstances of such child and to cause the proper proceeding to be taken as provided by law in such case. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Sec. 58-87. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any parent, guardian, custodian or person having legal custody of such child, after having received one warning notice that such child was in violation of this division, who permits the child to again violate the provisions of this division, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each occurrence. 
(b)  Any person found to have knowingly or intentionally encouraged, aided, induced or caused a person under the age of 17 years to be in violation of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 1, 3-22-2004) 
Secs. 58-88-58-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TOBACCO POSSESSION AND CONSUMPTION 

Sec. 58-111. - Purchase by or sale to minors prohibited. 
(a)  No minor under 18 years of age shall buy any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms. No person shall sell, buy for, distribute samples of or furnish any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms, to any minor under 18 years of age. For the purpose of this section, "smokeless tobacco" means any tobacco products that are suitable for dipping or chewing. 
(b)  Tobacco products listed above may be sold through a vending machine only in the following locations: 
(1)  Factories, businesses, offices, private clubs, and other places not open to the general public. 
(2)  Places to which minors under 18 years of age are not permitted access. 
(3)  Places where alcoholic beverages are sold and consumed on the premises. 
(4)  Places where the vending machine is under the direct supervision of the owner of the establishment or an employee over 18 years of age. The sale of tobacco products from a vending machine under direct supervision of the owner or an employee of the establishment is considered a sale of tobacco products by that person. As used in this subsection, "direct supervision" means that the owner or employee has an unimpeded line of sight to the vending machine. 
(5)  Places where the vending machine can only be operated by the owner or an employee over age 18 either directly or through a remote control device if the device is inaccessible to all customers. 
(c)  The sale or distribution at no charge of cigarettes from a lunch wagon engaging in any sales activity within 1,000 feet of any public or private elementary or secondary school grounds is prohibited. For the purpose of this section, "lunch wagon" means a mobile vehicle designed and constructed to transport food and from which food is sold to the general public. 
(Code 1965, §§ 20.501-20.503) 
Sec. 58-112. - Possession. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age to posses any tobacco in any of its forms, or any smoking paraphernalia in any manner at any time or place within the Village of Hillside. 
(Ord. No. 06-33, § 1, 12-18-2006 
Sec. 58-113. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 20.504; Ord. No. 06-33, § 1, 12-18-2006) 
Note- Formerly numbered as § 58-112. 
Secs. 58-114-58-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMPLIFIERS 

Sec. 58-141. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any loud speaker or amplifier connected with any radio, phonograph, microphone, or other device by which sounds are magnified and made heard over any public street or public place without first having secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 24.101) 
Sec. 58-142. - License fee. 
    The fee for such permit shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 24.102) 
Sec. 58-143. - Application for license. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring a license for the use or operation of such a device shall file an application therefor with the village clerk, upon a form provided by him, setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the name of the owner of such device, the date upon which it is intended to be used, and such other information as may be prescribed. 
(Code 1965, § 24.103) 
Sec. 58-144. - Issuance of license. 
    Such license shall be issued upon the payment of the license fee as above provided to the village clerk, and shall permit the use of any such device subject to the terms and conditions of this article, only upon the date specified on such license and no other. 
(Code 1965, § 24.104) 
Sec. 58-145. - Restrictions. 
(a)  No licensee shall use, operate, or employ any such device within the village limits on Sunday, or after the hour of 8:00 p.m. prevailing time of any day or before the hour of 8:00 a.m. prevailing time of any day. No licensee shall use or operate or employ any such device within a radius of two blocks from any hospital or within the radius of two blocks of any church while services are being held there. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to radios in homes or in private pleasure vehicles, when the same are operated in such manner as not to be audible at a distance of 50 feet from such vehicle, or to noise devices, bands, or other musical devices used in any public parade or procession which are operated under a permit in accordance with the ordinances of the village. 
(c)  No licensee shall cause or permit to be emanated or emitted from any such device any obscene, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), language or sounds, or any false representation of any matter, produce, or project advertised thereby the sale of which is prohibited by any law, ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1965, § 24.105) 
Sec. 58-146. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.106) 
Secs. 58-147-58-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OWNERS AND OCCUPANTS OF COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL PROPERTY 

Sec. 58-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial property means a parcel of real estate located within an area of the village designated under the provisions of the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980 as a B-1 general business district or as a B-2 planned shopping center district, or if located within the village but outside either of said B-1 or B-2 districts, then a parcel of real estate devoted to a special or a legal nonconforming business use. 
    Industrial property means a parcel of real estate located within an area of the village designated under the provisions of the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980 as an M-1 office and restricted industrial district, an M-2 light industrial district, or as an M-3 limited industrial district, or if located within the village but outside any of said M-1, M-2 or M-3 districts, then a parcel of real estate devoted to a special or a legal nonconforming industrial use. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1601) 
Sec. 58-172. - Information to be filed with village. 
    Every owner of a commercial or industrial property located within the village shall provide the village clerk with the name, address and telephone number of the owner and of each tenant who shall be occupying the property from time to time. If the owner or tenant is a corporation, partnership, trustee or estate the owner shall provide the village clerk with the name, address and telephone number of an individual person designated as agent for the owner or tenant with whom the village may communicate in case of an emergency or other matter of village concern relating to the property, and involving the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1602) 
Sec. 58-173. - Annual update of information. 
    The village clerk shall mail to each owner whose identity and address is known to the clerk, on or before April 1 of each year, a form eliciting such information. It shall be such owner's responsibility to complete and return the form to the clerk not later than May 1 following receipt of the form. Failure to receive the form by such owner shall not relieve such owner from the responsibility to report the information required under section 58-172 on or before each May 1. If there is a change in the tenancy subsequent to the previous report, the owner shall be obligated to promptly update the information in the clerk's file. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1603) 
Sec. 58-174. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 24.1604) 
Secs. 58-175-58-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - POLICY PROHIBITING SEXUAL HARASSMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-16, § 1 (Exh. A, § I), adopted Dec. 11, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion, hence, codification as §§ 58-191-58-196 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Note- This policy was drafted using the Illinois Department of Human Rights Sexual Harassment Model Policy and has been modified to conform to Public Act 100-0554. 

Sec. 58-191. - Prohibition on sexual harassment. 
    It is unlawful to harass a person because of that person's sex. The courts have determined that sexual harassment is a form of discrimination under Title VII of the U.S. Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended in 1991. All persons have a right to work in an environment free from sexual harassment. Sexual harassment is unacceptable misconduct which affects individuals of all genders and sexual orientations. It is a policy of the Village of Hillside to prohibit harassment of any person by any municipal official, municipal agent, municipal employee or municipal agency or office on the basis of sex or gender. All municipal officials, municipal agents, municipal employees and municipal agencies or offices are prohibited from sexually harassing any person, regardless of any employment relationship or lack thereof. 
(Ord. No. 17-16, § 1(Exh. A, § I), 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 58-192. - Definition of sexual harassment. 
    This policy adopts the definition of sexual harassment as stated in the Illinois Human Rights Act, which currently defines sexual harassment as: 
    Any unwelcome sexual advances or requests for sexual favors or any conduct of a sexual nature when: 
(1)  Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individual's employment, 
(2)  Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for employment decisions affecting such individual, or 
(3)  Such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment. 
    Conduct which may constitute sexual harassment includes: 
 Verbal: sexual innuendos, suggestive comments, insults, humor, and jokes about sex, anatomy or gender-specific traits, sexual propositions, threats, repeated requests for dates, or statements about other employees, even outside of their presence, of a sexual nature. 
 Non-verbal: suggestive or insulting sounds (whistling), leering, obscene gestures, sexually suggestive bodily gestures, "catcalls", "smacking" or "kissing" noises. 
 Visual: posters, signs, pin-ups or slogans of a sexual nature, viewing pornographic material or websites. 
 Physical: touching, unwelcome hugging or kissing, pinching, brushing the body, any coerced sexual act or actual assault. 
 Textual/electronic: "sexting" (electronically sending messages with sexual content, including pictures and video), the use of sexually explicit language, harassment, cyber stalking and threats via all forms of electronic communication (e-mail, text/picture/video messages, intranet/on-line postings, blogs, instant messages and social network websites like Facebook and Twitter). 
    The most severe and overt forms of sexual harassment are easier to determine. On the other end of the spectrum, some sexual harassment is more subtle and depends, to some extent, on individual perception and interpretation. The courts will assess sexual harassment by a standard of what would offend a "reasonable person." 
(Ord. No. 17-16, § 1(Exh. A, § II), 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 58-193. - Procedure for reporting an allegation of sexual harassment. 
    An employee who either observes sexual harassment or believes herself/himself to be the object of sexual harassment should deal with the incident(s) as directly and firmly as possible by clearly communicating her/his position to the offending employee, and her/his immediate supervisor. It is not necessary for sexual harassment to be directed at the person making the report. 
    Any employee may report conduct which is believed to be sexual harassment, including the following: 
 Electronic/direct communication . If there is sexual harassing behavior in the workplace, the harassed employee should directly and clearly express her/his objection that the conduct is unwelcome and request that the offending behavior stop. The initial message may be verbal. If subsequent messages are needed, they should be put in writing in a note or a memo. 
 Contact with supervisory personnel . At the same time direct communication is undertaken, or in the event the employee feels threatened or intimidated by the situation, the problem must be promptly reported to the immediate supervisor of the person making the report, a department head, a director of human resources, an ethics officer, the city manager or administrator, or the chief executive officer of the municipality. 
    The employee experiencing what he or she believes to be sexual harassment must not assume that the employer is aware of the conduct. If there are no witnesses and the victim fails to notify a supervisor or other responsible officer, the municipality will not be presumed to have knowledge of the harassment. 
 Resolution outside municipality . The purpose of this policy is to establish prompt, thorough and effective procedures for responding to every report and incident so that problems can be identified and remedied by the municipality. However, all municipal employees have the right to contact the Illinois Department of Human Rights (IDHR) or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) for information regarding filing a formal complaint with those entities. An IDHR complaint must be filed within 180 days of the alleged incident(s) unless it is a continuing offense. A complaint with the EEOC must be filed within 300 days. 
    Documentation of any incident may be submitted with any report (what was said or done, the date, the time and the place), including, but not limited to, written records such as letters, notes, memos and telephone messages. 
    All allegations, including anonymous reports, will be accepted and investigated regardless of how the matter comes to the attention of the municipality. However, because of the serious implications of sexual harassment charges and the difficulties associated with their investigation and the questions of credibility involved, the claimant's willing cooperation is a vital component of an effective inquiry and an appropriate outcome. 
(Ord. No. 17-16, § 1(Exh. A, § III), 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 58-194. - Prohibition on retaliation for reporting sexual harassment allegations. 
    No municipal official, municipal agency, municipal employee or municipal agency or office shall take any retaliatory action against any municipal employee due to a municipal employee's: 
(1)  Disclosure or threatened disclosure of any violation of this policy, 
(2)  The provision of information related to or testimony before any public body conducting an investigation, hearing or inquiry into any violation of this policy, or 
(3)  Assistance or participation in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of this policy. 
    For the purposes of this policy, retaliatory action means the reprimand, discharge, suspension, demotion, denial of promotion or transfer, or change in the terms or conditions of employment of any municipal employee that is taken in retaliation for a municipal employee's involvement in protected activity pursuant to this policy. 
    No individual making a report will be retaliated against even if a report made in good faith is not substantiated. In addition, any witness will be protected from retaliation. 
    Similar to the prohibition against retaliation contained herein, the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act (5 ILCS 430/15-10) provides whistleblower protection from retaliatory action such as reprimand, discharge, suspension, demotion, or denial of promotion or transfer that occurs in retaliation for an employee who does any of the following: 
(1)  Discloses or threatens to disclose to a supervisor or to a public body an activity, policy, or practice of any officer, member, state agency, or other state employee that the state employee reasonably believes is in violation of a law, rule, or regulation; 
(2)  Provides information to or testifies before any public body conducting an investigation, hearing, or inquiry into any violation of a law, rule, or regulation by any officer, member, state agency or other state employee; or 
(3)  Assists or participates in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of the state officials and Employees Ethics Act. 
    Pursuant to the Whistleblower Act (740 ILCS 174/15(a)), an employer may not retaliate against an employee who discloses information in a court, an administrative hearing, or before a legislative commission or committee, or in any other proceeding, where the employee has reasonable cause to believe that the information discloses a violation of a state or federal law, rule, or regulation. In addition, an employer may not retaliate against an employee for disclosing information to a government or law enforcement agency, where the employee has reasonable cause to believe that the information discloses a violation of a state or federal law, rule, or regulation. (740 ILCS 174/15(b)). 
    According to the Illinois Human Rights Act (775 ILCS 5/6-101), it is a civil rights violation for a person, or for two or more people to conspire, to retaliate against a person because he/she has opposed that which he/she reasonably and in good faith believes to be sexual harassment in employment, because he/she has made a charge, filed a complaint, testified, assisted, or participated in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing under the Illinois Human Rights Act. 
    An employee who is suddenly transferred to a lower paying job or passed over for a promotion after filing a complaint with IDHR or EEOC, may file a retaliation charge - due within 180 days (IDHR) or 300 days (EEOC) of the alleged retaliation. 
(Ord. No. 17-16, § 1(Exh. A, § IV), 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 58-195. - Consequences of a violation of the prohibition on sexual harassment. 
    In addition to any and all other discipline that may be applicable pursuant to municipal policies, employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/or collective bargaining agreement, any person who violates this policy or the prohibition on sexual harassment contained in 5 ILCS 430/5-65, may be subject to a fine of up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per offense, applicable discipline or discharge by the municipality and any applicable fines and penalties established pursuant to local ordinance, state law or federal law. Each violation may constitute a separate offense. Any discipline imposed by the municipality shall be separate and distinct from any penalty imposed by an ethics commission and any fines or penalties imposed by a court of law or a state or federal agency. 
(Ord. No. 17-16, § 1(Exh. A, § V), 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 58-196. - Consequences for knowingly making a false report. 
    A false report is a report of sexual harassment made by an accuser using the sexual harassment report to accomplish some end other than stopping sexual harassment or retaliation for reporting sexual harassment. A false report is not a report made in good faith which cannot be proven. Given the seriousness of the consequences for the accused, a false or frivolous report is a severe offense that can itself result in disciplinary action. Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this policy shall be subject to discipline or discharge pursuant to applicable municipal policies, employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/or collective bargaining agreements. 
    In addition, any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of the state officials and Employees Ethics Act to an ethics commission, an inspector general, the state police, a state's attorney, the Attorney General, or any other law enforcement official is guilty of a Class A misdemeanor. An ethics commission may levy an administrative fine of up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) against any person who intentionally makes a false, frivolous or bad faith allegation. 
(Ord. No. 17-16, § 1(Exh. A, § VI), 12-11-2017)

ARTICLE II. - PLAN COMMISSION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal plan commissions, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq. 

Sec. 62-31. - Composition. 
    The seven members appointed by the village president pursuant to article III, section 62-61 to act as the board of appeals for zoning matters shall also serve as the plan commission. The member designated as the chairperson of the board of appeals for zoning shall also serve as the chairperson of the plan commission. A majority of the plan commission shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of all plan commission business. Each member's term on the plan commission shall coincide with the member's term on the board of appeals for zoning. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1001; Ord. No. 17-06, § 2, 7-24-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to create plan commission and appointment members 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4. 
Secs. 62-32, 62-33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-06, §§ 3, 4, adopted July 24, 2017, repealed §§ 63-32, 62-33; § 63-32 pertained to auxiliary plan commission and derived from Code 1965, § 7.1001.1; and § 62-33 pertained to term of members; vacancies and derived from Code 1965, § 7.1002. 
Sec. 62-34. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The plan commission shall have all duties and may exercise all powers which such commissions may exercise by virtue of the applicable provisions of the state statutes, and in addition thereto, and without limiting the foregoing, the commission shall have the duties and may exercise the powers set forth hereinafter as follows: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or re-development of the village. Such plan, after its adoption by the board of trustees, shall become part of the official plan of the village as defined in article IV of this chapter, approved February 19, 1965, as amended. Such commission may thereafter, from time to time, recommend any changes in such official plan. Such plan may include reasonable requirements in reference to streets, alleys and public grounds upon land situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more than 11/2 miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any city, village or incorporated town. 
(2)  To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time plans for specific improvements in pursuance of such plan. 
(3)  To give aid to the officials of the village charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the making of such improvements and generally to promote the realization of such plan. 
(4)  To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by this article, by applicable statutes of the state and by such other ordinances of the village as may be conferred by the board of trustees on the commission. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1005) 
State Law reference- Powers generally, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-5. 
Sec. 62-35. - Compensation of members. 
    The chairperson of the plan commission shall be paid the sum of $20.00 for each hearing session convened or reconvened in accordance with this article, and each of the other members of said commission shall be paid the sum of $15.00 for each such hearing session; provided, however, neither the chairperson nor any of such members shall be so paid unless he is actually in attendance at the particular session, it being the intention of this article that no person shall be compensated for any session during which that person was absent from the entire session, whether or not such absence was excused or unavoidable. Immediately following each such session, the secretary thereof shall verify in writing the names of persons entitled hereunder to be paid, and shall transmit such verification promptly thereafter to the village clerk for processing of payment. 
(Code 1965, § 7.1006) 
State Law reference- Compensation of members of plan commission, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4. 
Secs. 62-36-62-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS 

Sec. 62-61. - Established; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of appeals for zoning matters which shall consist of seven members to be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. One member of this board shall be designated as chairperson. 
(Code 1965, § 7.901) 
Sec. 62-62. - Term of members. 
    Each member of the board of appeals shall serve for five years as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.902) 
Sec. 62-63. - Powers and duties generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the board of appeals to hear and decide any appeal of any decision, order or interpretation by the officer whose duty it is to enforce the zoning ordinance, and it shall have the power to reverse any decision of such officer on a four-fifths vote as provided by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 7.903) 
Sec. 62-64. - Variations. 
    Where, in a specific case, an application for a variation is made in writing to the board of appeals, explaining that because of certain exceptional conditions peculiar to applicant's property or its environment that strict application of the regulations of the zoning ordinance would result in practical difficulties and particular hardship upon the owner, the board of appeals shall consider the case at a public hearing, 15 days' notice of which shall have been given as prescribed by statute, and shall determine and record all the facts that tend to sustain or fail to sustain the granting of a variation from the requirements of the zoning ordinance. If the board of appeals determines, by a concurring vote of not less than four members, that the proposed variation or some modification of it will not: 
(1)  Reduce the minimum area or dimensions, nor increase the maximum dimensions, by more than 50 percent; 
(2)  Impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property; 
(3)  Increase the congestion in public streets unreasonably; 
(4)  Increase the hazard of fire; 
(5)  Endanger the public safety; 
(6)  Diminish or impair the values of property within the surrounding areas; or 
(7)  In any other respect impair the public health, safety, comfort, morals and welfare of the people; 
It shall adopt a motion embodying such findings, and may recommend the issuance of a permit. 
(Code 1965, § 7.904) 
Sec. 62-65. - Compensation of members. 
    The chairperson of the zoning board of appeals shall be paid the sum of $20.00 for each hearing session convened or reconvened in accordance with this article, and each of the other members of said board shall be paid the sum of $15.00 for each such hearing session; provided, however, neither the chairperson nor any of such members shall be so paid unless he is actually in attendance at the particular session, it being the intention of this article that no person shall be compensated for any session during which that person was absent from the entire session, whether or not such absence was excused or unavoidable. Immediately following each such session, the secretary thereof shall verify in writing the names of persons entitled hereunder to be paid, and shall transmit such verification promptly thereafter to the village clerk for processing of payment. 
(Code 1965, § 7.905) 
Secs. 62-66-62-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY PLAN 

Sec. 62-91. - Contents. 
    The official plan of the village shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The village plan hereto approved by the president and board of trustees consisting of a map of the village, charts and diagrams showing proposed additions to and improvements of the village streets, parks, public buildings, sewage disposal system, water system, and street lighting system. 
(2)  The specifications for street construction and paving hitherto established by the president and board of trustees. 
(3)  The zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 8.601) 
Sec. 62-92. - References to official plan. 
    Any reference to the official plan of the village shall be taken to mean and include all of the enactments mentioned in section 62-91. 
(Code 1965, § 8.602) 
Sec. 62-93. - Compliance. 
    No plat of subdivision, plan for the construction or layout of streets, or work involving laying sewer or water mains shall be approved unless the same complies fully with the requirements of the village plan. 
(Code 1965, § 8.603) 
Chapter 66 - SECONDHAND GOODS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND DEALERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of village to license and regulate secondhand stores, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

Sec. 66-31. - License required; license fee. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall operate or conduct a secondhand store in the village without having first obtained a license therefor, or without complying with the provisions of this article. The annual license fee for a secondhand store shall be as established by the village board from time to time, and no license shall be issued except on payment of this fee. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1001) 
Sec. 66-32. - Application for license; persons ineligible for license. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made to the clerk in writing and shall state the location intended to be used. Upon receipt of any such application the clerk or any person authorized by the president and board of trustees to do so shall investigate the character of the applicant and shall report to the village board the result of such investigations. No license shall be issued to a person of bad character nor to any person who shall have been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary or robbery. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1002) 
Sec. 66-33. - Records. 
    Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which records shall be together with the articles themselves open to inspection by any member of the police department at all reasonable hours. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1003) 
Sec. 66-34. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1004) 
Secs. 66-35-66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JUNK DEALERS[2] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Authority of village to license and regulate junk dealers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

Sec. 66-61. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junk dealer or to keep any junk shop, store or place for the purchase of or sale of junk, rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper or empty bottles, without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 15.601)

(Code 1965, § 15.602) 
Sec. 66-63. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for doing business as a junk dealer shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.603) 
Sec. 66-64. - Lost or stolen goods. 
    Every keeper of a junk shop who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall, upon demand, produce such article or thing to any member of the police department for examination. 
(Code 1965, § 15.604) 
Sec. 66-65. - Vehicles. 
    Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon, in legible characters, the name and address of the owner and proprietor thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 15.606) 
Sec. 66-66. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.607)

ARTICLE IV. - OUTDOOR SECONDHAND MOTOR VEHICLE LOTS 

Sec. 66-91. - Definition. 
    The term "outdoor secondhand motor vehicle sales lot," as used in this article, is hereby defined as meaning any outdoor lot or premises within the village where the business of dealing in secondhand motor vehicles is conducted or operated. 
(Code 1965, § 15.901) 
Sec. 66-92. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain an outdoor secondhand motor vehicle sales lot in the village without having first obtained a license therefor as is hereinafter provided in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 15.902) 
Sec. 66-93. - Application for license. 
    All applications for the license required in section 66-92 shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall state the location of the lot and the number of cars which can be accommodated therein. 
(Code 1965, § 15.903) 
Sec. 66-94. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee to operate or maintain a used car lot shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 15.904) 
Sec. 66-95. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.905) 
Secs. 66-96-66-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 66-121. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of these regulations to prohibit the infringement of any businesses in any established residential area and, in so doing, to regulate the term and frequency of a personal property sale (such as a garage sale, porch sale, basement sale, yard sale and other similar types of sales), thereby avoiding disturbance to or disruption of the residential environment of the area. It is not the intent of these regulations to assume municipal control of infrequent sales by individuals selling but one or a few of their household or personal items in a single transaction. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1401) 
Sec. 66-122. - Authorized sales. 
    Any resident may hold a personal property sale or resale of used household, clothing or any other personal property items by means of a garage sale, porch sale, basement sale, yard sale or other similar types of sales. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1402) 
Sec. 66-123. - Frequency, duration and hours; signs; restriction on items offered for sale; inspections. 
    Any such sale, limited to two per calendar year per each dwelling unit, shall be conducted only during the hours between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on each of three consecutive calendar days. Notice of the sale shall not be posted more than 24 hours prior to the intended commencement hour of such sale, and such notice shall be removed not more than four hours after the conclusion of such sale. Only items of personal property which are owned by the residents of the premises shall be sold or offered for sale. The resident extends an invitation to any village inspector or officer to enter upon that portion of the premises whereon such a sale is being or is about to be conducted, for the purpose of inspection for or compliance with these regulations, and such inspector or officer may order the sale closed and/or arrest or cause to be arrested any person who is in violation thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1404; Ord. No. 03-06, § 1, 4-28-2003) 
Sec. 66-124. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 15.1405) 
Secs. 66-125-66-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SCAVENGERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Disposal of garbage and refuse in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq. 

Sec. 66-151. - License required; license fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in the business of scavenger or the collection or disposal of animal, human or vegetable refuse or offal without having first obtained a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1001) 
Sec. 66-152. - Application for license. 
    Applications for such permits shall be made to the village clerk and shall be referred by him to the president and board of trustees, and no such permit shall be issued except on order of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1002) 
Sec. 66-153. - Vehicles; operation on Sunday. 
    Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight, and equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the transportation of refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be driven over or through any street in the village during or on a Sunday. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1003) 
Sec. 66-154. - Storage and disposal of refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose or to store any refuse in any place within the village limits or within one mile thereof, excepting with the permission of the president and board of trustees.

    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 16.1005) 
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE AND REFUSE 

Sec. 70-31. - Receptacles required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of any house, building, flat or apartment located within the village where people reside, board or lodge, or where animal or vegetable matter is prepared or served, to maintain in good order, condition and repair, at all times, one or more refuse containers designed as receptacles in sufficient size and number for discarded garbage, bottles, cans and similar refuse, so as not to allow the container(s) to overflow. 
(b)  Single-family homes may use standard refuse containers, as defined in this section, in addition to the containers provided by the village, if such containers are necessary to prevent the container(s) from overflowing. 
(c)  The owner or his agent of every multi-family structure, as defined in section 70-35, or any commercial unit, as defined in section 70-35, at the owner's or his agent's expense shall provide or contract for sufficient commercial refuse containers, as defined in this section, and servicing by a private scavenger. All refuse which is placed for collection service outside of the building must be kept in commercial refuse containers within a garbage corral as defined in subsection 70-32(c). All refuse containers must have their lids closed at all times. 
(d)  Definitions for purposes of this section: 
(1)  Standard refuse container. The standard refuse container required by this article shall be a receptacle of impervious material and sturdy construction, with a tight fitting cover, and may not exceed 35 gallons. This may include garbage cans or containers designed as receptacles. 
(2)  Commercial refuse container. The commercial refuse container required by this article shall be provided or contracted for by the property owner or his agent or the occupant of an occupational unit, and shall be a leak-resistant, rodent-resistant, and lidded container which is constructed of impervious material and subject to the inspection of the department of health and the department of streets and sanitation. 
(Code 1965, § 20.201; Ord. No. 18-15, § 2, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-32. - Specifications for receptacles. 
(a)  Any standard refuse container, as defined in section 70-31, in which garbage is deposited shall be watertight and shall be fitted with a closed cover, which must remain closed at all times without any obstructions, garbage, or other items that inhibit the ability of the container to be opened and closed appropriately. All standard refuse containers shall have a capacity of not more than 35 gallons and shall be provided with suitable handles. All waste, including waste that is contained in a plastic garbage bags, must be placed into the refuse container, and cannot be placed next to the refuse container or on the ground. 
(b)  The owner or his agent of every multi-family structure as defined in section 70-35, or commercial units, as defined in section 70-35, at the owner's or his agent's expense shall provide or contract for sufficient commercial refuse containers, as defined in section 70-31 and must be in compliance with subsection 15-588(a). 
(c)  The owner, his agent, or the occupant of multi-family structures, as defined in section 70-35, and commercial properties, as defined in section 70-35, must construct a garbage corral to enclose the refuse containers, subject to the following conditions, by February 1, 2019: 
(1)  Trash collection areas shall be screened from view by construction of a garbage corral that will contain and visually obstruct the view of the refuse container by decorative material as approved by the village administrator; 
(2)  The garbage corral must have enclosures that will allow the gates to be in the closed position at all times; and 
(3)  The lids of the refuse containers shall be closed at all times. 
(d)  All refuse or recycling which is placed for collection service outside of the building must be kept in commercial refuse containers as provided in section 70-31, and must be contained within the garbage corral as described in this section. 
(e)  Failure to construct the garbage corral by February 1, 2019 shall result in a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense to which a separate fine shall apply. 
(Code 1965, § 20.202; Ord. No. 18-15, § 3, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-33. - Placing receptacles or waste in right-of-way; title to waste. 
(a)  Use of receptacles required; time for placement and removal. No garbage or refuse of any kind shall be placed for collection on the paved portion of any street right-of-way, nor shall such garbage or refuse be placed for collection on any parkway, except within refuse containers thereof and in such a manner as would reasonably assure that the garbage and refuse would not be blown about nor be scattered by the wind, animals or vandals. No refuse containers of any kind shall be placed on any parkway prior to 4:00 p.m. of the day before the scheduled pick-up day for that particular area, and such containers shall be removed before midnight of the actual pick-up day. 
(b)  Definitions. For purposes of this section: 
    Municipal solid waste means refuse, garbage or other discarded material generated by those persons residing in separate buildings within the village having three or fewer dwelling units. 
    Placed for collection means placed at the curb, alley or back door for collection by the village. 
(c)  Title to waste. Title to municipal solid waste which is placed for collection shall pass to the village when it is collected by the village or by a contractor retained by the village for the purpose of collecting municipal solid waste. 
(Code 1965, § 20.203; Ord. No. 18-15, § 4, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-34. - Unauthorized removal of recyclable refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to collect, pick up or remove any recyclable item of refuse placed or deposited on any village parkway for purpose of being collected at curbside in connection with the village's refuse recycling program, unless said person, firm or corporation is then an employee or agent of a contractor duly authorized under contract with the village to collect recyclable refuse within the village limits. 
(Code 1965, § 20.203.1) 
Sec. 70-35. - Definitions pertaining to article II. 
    Commercial property for purposes of this article means any commercial or industrial property as defined in section 58-171. A commercial property includes a parcel of real estate located within an area of the village designated under the provisions of the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980 as a B-1 general business district or as a B-2 planned shopping center district, or if located within the village but outside either of said B-1 or B-2 districts, then a parcel of real estate devoted to a special or a legal nonconforming business use, as defined in section 58-171 of this Code.
