An industrial property includes a parcel of real estate located within an area of the village designated under the provisions of the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980 as an M-1 office and restricted industrial district, an M-2 light industrial district, or as an M-3 limited industrial district, or if located within the village but outside any of said M-1, M-2 or M-3 districts, then a parcel of real estate devoted to a special or a legal nonconforming industrial use. 
    Multi-family structure means a building with more than three residential living units which is not included in the village curbside refuse, recyclables and landscape waste collection and disposal service. 
    Owner means any person, corporation, partnership, or entity such as a condominium or homeowners' association, jointly or severally having an ownership interest in a multi-family structure or otherwise being responsible for solid waste collection. 
    Private scavenger means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the removal of solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from any location within the village not covered by either an exclusive collection contract between the village and a contracted hauler, or a franchise agreement between the village and a franchised hauler. 
    Recyclable material means a material which would otherwise be abandoned or discarded but which can be utilized in the secondary material market. 
    Recycling means the process by which materials that would otherwise be disposed of or discarded are collected, separated or processed and returned to the economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products. 
    Residential property means a single-family living unit, or a building with three or less living units that is included in the village curbside refuse, recycling and landscape waste collection and disposal service. 
    Source separation means a process that separates recyclable material from other refuse prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. 
(Code 1965, § 20.203.2; Ord. No. 18-15, § 5, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-36. - On-site multi-family structure recycling program. 
(a)  Program required; duties of property owner. 
(1)  All multi-family structures, as defined in section 70-35, shall be required to institute an on-site recycling program, with collection of recyclable materials to be no less than one pickup per week. 
(2)  Said program shall be instituted by a multi-family structure owner on or before January 1, 1996. 
(3)  Multi-family structure owners are required to contract for refuse and recycling services with a private scavenger, duly licensed by the village. Multi-family structure owners shall be billed for recycling and refuse services directly by the private scavenger. 
(4)  An acceptable recycling program shall include, but is not limited to, the following components: 
a.  Siting and design of common area collection areas for recyclable materials; 
b.  Recyclable materials collection; 
c.  Provision of common area recycling containers; 
d.  Data collection and reporting; 
e.  Education campaign and materials; and 
f.  Recycling program administration and maintenance. 
(5)  Any persons required to contract with a private scavenger, must stay in compliance with the provisions of article II in its entirety. Should this require that the owner, agent, or occupant schedule pick-ups multiple times a week to avoid garbage overflow, then it is the owner, agent, or occupant's responsibility to arrange for multiple pick-ups per week to remain in compliance with this article. 
(6)  It shall be the duty of the owner, his agent or occupant of every multi-family structure to annually submit the pick-up frequency, private scavenger service, and private scavenger contact information to the village. The owner of the multi-family structure must also provide his or her contact information and emergency contact information to the village and update the village with any changes within seven days. 
(b)  Specific requirements. 
(1)  Recycling collection areas for residents shall be conveniently located and maintained within common areas in or near the buildings, and consist of separate containers for the purposes of temporary storage of recyclables. Whenever possible, recycling containers should be placed adjacent to common area solid waste collection containers. 
(2)  Indoor common area collection/storage areas shall be established in accordance with appropriate village fire and/or safety codes. 
(3)  Exterior recyclables storage areas shall be established in accordance with village requirements for solid waste enclosures, and shall be included in the garbage corral as required in subsection 70-32(c). 
(4)  The multi-family structure owner shall maintain all waste and recycling areas, including the containers, in a clean, sanitary, and litter-free manner. 
(5)  On-site multi-family structure recycling programs and refuse services are required to offer collection of the same solid waste and recyclable materials collected through the village residential recycling program as contained in the exclusive contract or franchise agreement. 
(6)  Recyclable materials must be source separated from other solid waste prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. Separate collection containers and collection vehicles shall be employed. 
(7)  The licensed private scavenger providing the on-site waste and recycling collection service shall be responsible for furnishing and replacing all common area waste and recycling containers and collection vehicles which are deemed necessary in the waste and recycling program. The private scavenger shall be responsible for the collection, intermediate storage or transfer, transportation, and sale of recyclable materials to a processor, broker, or market desired for reuse of materials. 
(8)  Multi-family structure owners shall notify residents of the availability of recycling services through a formal and ongoing educational campaign, and shall use their best efforts to gain and maintain participation in the program. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized persons to remove or damage any recyclable materials placed in designated containers, or the containers themselves. Title to recyclable material shall pass to the private scavenger when the materials are placed into the collection vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 20.203.3; Ord. No. 18-15, § 6, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-37. - Recyclable materials collection requirements for private scavengers. 
(a)  Conditions for obtaining license. All private scavengers desiring to receive a scavenger license to collect solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from multi-family structures in the village must comply with all applicable federal, state, county and local laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. As a condition of receiving, renewing and maintaining a scavenger license to collect solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from multi-family structures within the village, each licensee or applicant for such license shall: 
(1)  Obtain all permits and licenses required by federal, state and county laws, ordinances, rules and regulations and maintain the same in full force and effect. 
(2)  Submit to the village a list of the multi-family structures it serves within the village's jurisdiction. 
(3)  Provide waste collection and recycling services for any multi-family structure owner that requests such service with the on-site multi-family structure recycling program requirements set forth above. 
(4)  Upon notification and request from the village, the private scavenger agrees to respond to immediate pick-up requests by the village prior to the close of business the same-day of the request, so long as they receive the call requesting the same-day pickup by 10:00 a.m. If the private scavenger receives the pick-up request after 10:00 a.m., they will have 24 hours from the time of the immediate pick-up request to complete the requested pick-up. Should this pick-up not occur within the designated time-frame as set herein, the private scavenger shall be fined $100.00. Each day this violation is not corrected, it will constitute as a separate offense and will be fined $250.00. 
(5)  It shall be the duty of the licensed scavenger to maintain in good condition and repair such commercial refuse containers. Notwithstanding this requirement, and unless otherwise agreed to by the parties via contract, the occupant shall be liable for its usage of the container(s) and for notifying the property owner or his agent of the need for additional containerization or service, including recycling service. 
(b)  Reports. 
(1)  Each licensed private scavenger shall submit a quarterly report to both the multi-family structure owner or his designee and the village and/or its designee that contains the following information: 
a.  Total weight or volume of refuse collected from multi-family structures it serves within the village. 
b.  Total weight or volume of yard waste collected from multi-family structures it serves within the village. 
c.  Total weight or volume of recyclable materials collected from multi-family structures it serves within the village. 
d.  Total number of immediate pick-up requests made during the quarter. 
e.  A summary of the waste and recycling services provided to each multi-family structure owners, to be submitted only on an annual basis with the fourth quarter report. 
(2)  Quarterly reports submitted to the multi-family structure owner by the licensed private scavenger shall only pertain to that property's activity. 
(3)  Quarterly reports submitted to the village shall contain aggregate totals concerning the information listed above for all multi-family structures the licensed private scavenger serves within the village's jurisdiction. 
(4)  Reports shall be due no later than 15 days after the close of each quarter. Quarters are defined as follows: 
First quarter-January 1 through March 31; 
Second quarter-April 1 through June 30; 
Third quarter-July 1 through September 30; and 
Fourth quarter-October 1 through December 31. 
Reports shall follow the format prescribed by the village. 
(5)  The information shall be considered exempt from the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (5 ILCS 140/1-11) disclosure by the village or its designee upon assertion as to its proprietary nature by the licensed private scavenger. The village or its designee shall only report the information in the form of statistics and/or volume totals for all multi-family structures in the village. No specific information on individual licenses shall be divulged. 
(6)  The village and/or its designee shall have the right to inspect and examine the licensed private scavenger's records pertaining to the collection and disposal or processing of refuse and recyclables upon request and with reasonable notice. The village or its designee shall further have the right to require the reporting of other data or information relative to the recycling program from time to time. 
(7)  All such reports, data, and information, once received by the village or its designee, shall become the property of the village to be used as it shall determine without obligation to any person, firm or corporation. 
(8)  Failure to submit any required report to the village or its designee shall be grounds for revocation of the business license and or franchise agreement until such time as the licensed private scavenger or franchised hauler complies with the requirements set forth in this section. 
(c)  Waste and recycling program requirements for multi-family structures. Implementation of on-site multi-family structure waste and recycling programs shall be required as stated in subsection 70-36(a). Such waste and recycling programs shall be maintained in effect regardless of any change of building ownership or private scavenger service. Multi-family structure owners shall be required to notify the village in writing within 30 days after a change in their choice of private scavenger. 
(Code 1965, § 20.203.4; Ord. No. 18-15, § 7, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-38. - Penalty. 
    Where no specific penalty is provided in this section, the violation of any such provision in this section shall be a misdemeanor and punished by a fine not exceeding $750.00, as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. Each day any violation of any provision in this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 20.204; Ord. No. 18-15, § 8, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-39. - Contract with a private scavenger-When required-Exemptions. 
(a)  The following persons must contract with a private scavenger, or cause a contract to be entered into with a private scavenger: 
(1)  The owner or his agent of any multi-family structures, as defined in section 70-35, must contract for their waste and recycling services; and 
(2)  The owner or his agent of any commercial property, as defined in section 70-35, must contract for their waste services. 
(b)  Any persons required to contract with a private scavenger, must stay in compliance with the provisions of article II in its entirety. Should this require that the owner, agent, or occupant schedule pick-ups multiple times a week to avoid garbage overflow, then it is the owner, agent, or occupant's responsibility to arrange for multiple pick-ups per week to remain in compliance with this article. 
(c)  Any person who violates this section or any rule promulgated thereunder shall be given a 30-day notice of noncompliance, and shall come into compliance with this section within 30 days of the date on which such notice is personally served, mailed, sent or otherwise provided. 
(d)  In addition to any other penalty provided by law, any person who violates this section or any rule promulgated thereunder shall be fined not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00 for a first violation; not less than $300.00 nor more than $600.00 for a second violation within any 12-month period; and not less than $500.00 nor more than $750.00 for a third and each subsequent violation occurring within 12 months of the most recent violation. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense to which a separate fine shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 18-15, § 9, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-40. - Duty to provide refuse containers and service for commercial vendors. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, agent or occupant of every commercial property as defined in section 70-35, to provide or contract to maintain in good condition and repair, unless otherwise provided for by lease agreement, sufficient commercial refuse container(s) and must hire a private scavenger service to meet its waste generation needs, so as not to allow the container(s) to overflow and to allow for the lids of the refuse containers to close tightly. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, his agent or occupant of every commercial property to annually submit the pick-up frequency, waste hauler, and waste hauler contact information to the village. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensed scavenger to maintain in good condition and repair such commercial refuse containers. Notwithstanding this requirement, and unless otherwise agreed to by the parties via contract, the occupant shall be liable for its usage of the container(s) and for notifying the property owner or his agent of the need for additional containerization or service. 
    All refuse which is placed for collection service outside of the building must be kept in commercial refuse containers as provided in sections 70-31, 70-32, and must be contained within the garbage corrals as provided in subsection 70-32(c). 
(Ord. No. 18-15, § 10, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-41. - Residential refuse program. 
(a)  All residential properties as defined in section 70-35, are included in the village curbside refuse, recyclables and landscape waste collection and disposal service. This includes pick-up and removal services one-time a week to all residential properties. 
(b)  Village provided carts. The village shall provide the following carts for refuse, recycling, and landscape waste to all residential properties as defined in section 70-35: 
(1)  Refuse. The village shall provide 95-gallon dark gray carts for the disposal of household waste. If the quantity of the owner's refuse exceeds the capacity of the cart supplied, the owner may provide additional standard refuse containers, not to exceed 35 gallons. 
(2)  Recycling. The village shall provide a 65-gallon municipal blue recycling wheeled cart for recyclable materials, which shall be defined as newspaper (including inserts), aluminum, tin/steel cans, glass (clear, brown and green bottles, jars), all #I PETE plastics - soft drink bottles, all #2 HOPE plastics - milk and water jugs, colored laundry bottles, all #3 plastics (PVC), all #4 plastics (LOPE), all #5 plastics (PP), all #7 plastics (other), corrugated cardboard, magazines, chipboard - cereal, shoe, tissue boxes, telephone books, catalogs, brown paper grocery bags, mixed paper- junk mail, stationery, envelopes, aluminum pie tins, aluminum foil, aerosol cans (empty), 6-pack rings, milk cartons and juice boxes. 
If the quantity of the owner's recyclable materials exceeds the capacity of the cart supplied, the owner may provide additional standard refuse containers, not to exceed 35 gallons that are clearly marked "RECYCLING." 
(3)  Yard waste. The village shall provide a teal green yard waste wheeled cart for any yard waste materials such as grass clippings, leaves, plant materials and byproducts, weeds, small branches, com stalks, vines and the like. If the owner's yard waste quantity exceeds the village provided cart capacity, the owners may continue to utilize additional standard refuse containers, not to exceed 35 gallons that are clearly marked "YARD WASTE" or biodegradable Kraft paper bags if they chose not to receive a wheeled cart or if their yard waste quantity exceeds the cart capacity. 
(c)  All residential refuse, recycling and yard waste carts and any additional standard refuse containers shall be kept behind the front building line either in the side or rear yard in a manner so as not to be visible from the street. 
(d)  Any violation of this article shall be subject to the penalties and fines as provided in section 70-42. 
(Ord. No. 18-15, § 11, 8-27-2018) 
Sec. 70-42. - Violations. 
(a)  No person shall deposit refuse in a standard or commercial refuse container, in a manner that prevents complete closure of the container's cover, or deposit refuse on top of a container in a manner that interferes with opening of the container, or pile or stack refuse against a container, or place waste, including waste contained in sealed trash bags, next to or outside of the refuse container. 
    Additionally, large items that do not fit inside of the refuse container must be scheduled for pick-up and removal with the private scavenger the same day it is placed outside for pick-up. These large items cannot be placed inside the refuse container in a matter that prevents the closure of the container's cover, or placed on top of a container, or piled or stacked against the container, or left outside or on the ground. 
(b)  The owner of a residential property shall not allow any person to violate subsection (a) of this section. It is the owner, his agent, or occupant's responsibility to provide additional refuse containers should the refuse, recycling or yard waste exceeds the capacity of the Village provided cart supplied. The presence of refuse preventing complete closure of the container's cover, deposited on or piled or stacked against a standard refuse container or a commercial refuse container shall be prima facie evidence of violation of this subsection. 
(c)  The owner, his agent or occupant of a multi-family structure or commercial property shall not allow any person to violate subsection (a) of this section. If the owner and/or his agent is not an occupant of the dwelling, they must designate a person that will monitor the refuse container to ensure it does not overflow and that no items are placed outside the container. It is the owner, his agent, or occupant of the property's responsibility to schedule with the private scavenger the appropriate frequency of pick-ups per week, the container sizes, and number of containers needed in order to comply with subsection (a). The presence of refuse preventing complete closure of the container's cover, deposited on or piled or stacked against a standard refuse container, a commercial refuse container, or compactor shall be prima facie evidence of violation of this subsection. 
(d)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be fined not less than $200.00 and not more than $500.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(e)  In addition to the fine in subsection (d), additional fines may be acquired if the owner, his agent, or occupant of a multi-family structure or commercial property fails to remedy the violation. Upon notification of overflowing refuse containers or refuse containers in violation of article II, the village may contact the private scavenger directly to schedule an immediate same day pick-up. Any charges for the same-day pickup by the private scavenger will be billed directly to the owner, his agent or occupant of the property. 
(Ord. No. 18-15, § 12, 8-27-2018) 
Secs. 70-43-70-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITIES SITING 

Sec. 70-71. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act and the Act mean the Illinois Environmental Protection Act, as amended from time to time (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.). 
    Applicant means is any person, firm or partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind proposing to obtain site location approval and IEPA permits for a new pollution control facility in the village, and includes the fee owner of such site, the proposed operator, and any other party with an interest in the site, such as a lessee, contract purchaser or land trust beneficiary. 
    Board means the state pollution control board. 
    Hazardous waste means waste as defined in the Act. 
    Hazardous waste disposal site means a site at which hazardous waste is disposed. 
    IEPA means the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    PCF means a pollution control facility as defined in the Act. "PCF" includes a new pollution control facility as defined by the Act. 
    Village means the Village of Hillside, Illinois. 
    Village board means the board of trustees of the Village of Hillside. 
(b)  All other terms used in this article and defined in the Act shall have the same definitions and meanings as found in said Act (including but not limited to those terms defined in section 3 thereof (415 ILCS 5/3)). 
(Code 1965, § 8.801) 
Sec. 70-72. - Approval required. 
    No site location approval for the development or construction of a new PCF in the village may be granted by the village board unless an application is filed for approval of such site and is submitted for consideration to said village board. Any village trustee or staff member who has, or feels he has, any disqualifying interest in the property or affairs of the applicant may be excused from participating in any hearing or decision. 
(Code 1965, § 8.802) 
Sec. 70-73. - Application for approval. 
(a)  Application form . 
(1)  The form application to be filed by all applicants for PCF siting in the village has been or will be adopted by resolution separate from this article. The administrator shall from time to time update the form application and may retain qualified consultants and experts for that purpose. Additional pages shall be attached where the space provided on the form is insufficient. At a minimum, the application shall comply with the requirements of the Act and this article. The form of said application may be obtained from the office of the village administrator. The applicant shall also file with the village clerk, on computer diskette or other electronic medium, in a format compatible with the computer system utilized by the village, a copy of as many of the documents which it files as part of its application as were drafted or otherwise generated by or on behalf of the applicant and, in addition, such other documents as are submitted as a part of the application which are available on diskette or other electronic medium. 
(2)  All sections of the application shall be clearly marked and submitted with dividers. Exhibits and drawings shall be clearly marked as to what sections they pertain. Notwithstanding the specific application requirements detailed herein, applicants must include all information which the applicant believes necessary to demonstrate compliance with the Act, the applicable regulations and the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Filing of application; filing fee deposit. 
(1)  In order to request siting approval for a new PCF in the village, an applicant must file an application with the village clerk, with a minimum of 35 copies of the application and the substance of the applicant's proposal showing sufficient details describing the proposed facility to demonstrate compliance with the Act and board regulations, including all site plans, engineering including calculations, exhibits and maps, and all documents, if any, to be submitted to the IEPA as of the date of filing the application. In the interest of fundamental fairness, the village administrator shall have the authority to reduce the number of copies of the application required to no fewer than 20 provided the applicant agrees in writing to furnish additional copies within 24 hours of a request that the applicant do so. 
(2)  In addition to the foregoing, the applicant shall deposit with the village clerk, at the time of filing the application for site approval of a new PCF, a filing fee deposit of $250,000.00, except that a filing fee deposit of $400,000.00 is required if the PCF is proposed to burn or incinerate waste and a filing fee deposit of $600,000.00 is required if said proposed facility is designed as a hazardous waste disposal site or if the PCF is intended to burn or incinerate hazardous waste. If the applicant elects to file an amended application for site location approval for any PCF in accordance with this article, such filing shall be accompanied by payment of a supplemental fee of $75,000.00. The applicable filing fee is intended to defray the reasonable and necessary costs related to the application, including, but not limited to: costs of site inspection, clerical expenses, copying costs, space rental, hearing officer compensation, court reporter expenses, transcription costs, public notice expenses, staff review time, applicable per diems, if any, village attorneys and village consultants (such as qualified professional engineers, planners, appraisers, environmental counsel, etc., including tests, exhibits, and testimony, if any, provided by said consultants), and other relevant costs incident to the consideration of an application, the costs incident to preparing the record for appeal, and the cost of representing the village on appeal in case of an appeal of a village board decision (the "village costs"). If there are funds remaining in the filing fee deposit after payment of the village costs, such amount shall be refunded to the applicant upon the final resolution of the application process (including appeals to the state pollution control board, appellate court, Illinois Supreme Court, federal courts, and administrative review in the courts, if any, and any related litigation). Should the village incur any additional costs in excess of the applicable filing fee deposit, the applicant shall bear any and all such additional costs and shall promptly pay over such additional amount to the village upon request or demand. 
(3)  The application must be complete, with answers provided for each question on the application form. The application must contain consecutively numbered pages and it must be accompanied by all required site plans, exhibits, maps and documents. The date that the applicant files a complete application in proper form, together with the applicable filing fee deposit, with the village clerk shall be considered the official filing date for all time limit purposes. The application is not effective unless the application is in strict compliance with this article. If upon review of the application within 21 days of its submittal it is determined by the village to be incomplete and not in strict conformance with the aforesaid, the application is deemed not filed and the filing fee (less village costs and expenses) shall be returned to the applicant. At any time prior to completion by the applicant of the presentation of the applicant's factual evidence and an opportunity for cross-questioning by the village trustees, other village representatives and any participants, the applicant may file not more than one amended application upon payment of additional fees pursuant to this article and section 39.2(k) of the Act (415 ILCS 5/39.2(k)). The filing of an amended application shall extend the time limitation for final action set forth in section 39.2(e) of the Act (415 ILCS 5/39.2(e)) and this article for an additional period of 90 days. 
(c)  Processing of application; employment of hearing officer and consultants. 
(1)  Upon receipt of a proper and complete application, and payment of the applicable filing fee deposit, the village clerk shall date stamp all the copies and immediately deliver one copy to the president of the village board, one copy to the village administrator, one copy to the village attorney, and one copy to the West Cook County Solid Waste Agency. 
(2)  In order to develop a record sufficient to form the basis of an appeal of the village board's decision, the village may retain a hearing officer and consultants who will act on behalf of the village. The hearing officer shall conduct all hearings in accordance with law and shall have the discretion to reasonably interpret this article consistent with the principles of fundamental fairness. A secretary may be employed by the village to assist the hearing officer during the hearing process. The consultants an d the village staff shall then commence a study of the application. The applicant shall cooperate fully with the consultants and the village staff in their review of the application, including providing access to the site for study or testing, including but not limited to geophysical testing. 
(d)  Re-application after disapproval. An applicant may not file a request for local siting approval which is substantially the same as a request which was disapproved, pursuant to a finding against the applicant under any criteria of section 70-75(a)(1) through (9), within two years of the date of the denial. 
(e)  Public availability of information. A copy of the application and all related documents or other materials on file with the village shall be made available for public inspection by the village clerk. Members of the public shall be allowed to obtain a copy of said application or any part thereof upon payment of the actual cost of reproduction as outlined in the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
(f)  Notice requirements. It is the applicant's duty to comply with all notice and other requirements set forth in the Act and in this article. The applicant shall have the following duties: 
(1)  No later than 14 days prior to filing an application for site location approval with the village clerk, the applicant shall cause written notice of the filing of such application to be served either in person or by registered mail, return receipt requested, on the owners of all property within the subject area not solely owned by the applicant, and on the owners of all property within 250 feet in each direction of the lot line of the subject property, said owners being such persons or entities which appear from the authentic tax records of the county; provided that the number of all feet occupied by public roads, streets, alleys and other public ways shall be excluded in computing the 250 feet requirement; provided further, that in no event shall this requirement exceed 400 feet, including public streets, alleys and other public ways. 
(2)  The applicant shall serve such notice upon each member of the Illinois General Assembly from the legislative district in which the proposed facility is to be located, and this notice shall also be published in a newspaper of general circulation in village. 
(3)  The applicant shall state in such notice the name and address of the applicant, the location of the proposed site, the nature and size of the development, the nature of the activity proposed, the probable life of the proposed activity, the date when the request for site approval will be submitted to the village clerk, a description of the right of persons to comment on such request as hereafter provided, and any other information as may be reasonably required by the village administrator or the Act. 
(4)  The applicant shall include in the application proof of compliance with all applicable pre-filing notice requirements. 
(Code 1965, § 8.803) 
Sec. 70-74. - Notice and scheduling of public hearing. 
(a)  At least one public hearing shall be held by the village no sooner than 90 days, but no later than 120 days, from and after the receipt of the application for PCF site location approval. 
(b)  The applicant shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the village a notice of such public hearing not later than 14 days prior to said hearing. The applicant shall also serve written notice of such hearing by certified mail, return receipt requested, on all members of the Illinois General Assembly from the district in which the proposed site is located, to the governing authority of every municipality contiguous to the proposed site, to every municipality contiguous to the village and to the IEPA. The applicant shall file with the village clerk copies of each notice with proof of service of such notice prior to the commencement of said public hearing. 
(c)  Providing as much notice as is reasonably practicable, the village administrator or the hearing officer shall notify the applicant in writing of the date when and location where public hearings before the village are to commence. 
(Code 1965, § 8.804) 
Sec. 70-75. - Conduct of public hearing; criteria for approval. 
(a)  Record of hearing; criteria for approval . The public hearing shall develop a record sufficient to form the basis of any appeal. During the course of the public hearing before the village, the village shall receive testimony from the applicant and witnesses whom the applicant may call in support of the application, any village witnesses, any objectors, and any other witnesses having relevant information, and shall recommend approval only if the proposed facility meets the following criteria (or such amended criteria as may be set forth from time to time in the Act): 
(1)  That the facility is necessary to accommodate the waste needs of the area that it is intended to serve; 
(2)  That the facility is so designed, located, and proposed to be operated that the public health, safety and welfare will be protected; 
(3)  That the facility is located so as to minimize incompatibility with the character of the surrounding area and to minimize the effect on the value of the surrounding property; 
(4)  That the facility is located outside the boundary of the 100-year floodplain, or that the site is flood-proofed; 
(5)  That the plan of operations for the facility is designed to minimize the danger to the surrounding area from fire, spills, or other operational accidents; 
(6)  That traffic patterns to or from the facility are so designed as to minimize the impact on existing traffic flows; 
(7)  That if the facility will be treating, storing or disposing of hazardous waste, an emergency response plan exists for the facility which includes notification, containment and evacuation procedures to be used in case of an accidental release; 
(8)  That if the county board has adopted a solid waste management plan consistent with the planning requirements of the Local Solid Waste Disposal Act (415 ILCS 10/1.1 et seq.) or the Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act (415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.), the facility is consistent with that plan; and 
(9)  That if the facility will be located within a regulated recharge area, any applicable requirements specified by the board for such areas have been met. The village board may also consider as evidence the previous operating experience and past record of convictions or admissions of violations of the applicant (and any subsidiary or parent corporation of the applicant) in the field of solid waste management when considering the criteria in subsections (a)(2) and (5) of this section. 
(b)  Burden of proof. The applicant for site location approval shall have the burden of proof and the burden of going forward with evidence. The testimonial evidence introduced by the applicant may not exceed the scope of the application. Such oral testimony may only explain and clarify the application, not expand or amend the application. 
(c)  Call to order; opening statements. The hearing officer shall call the hearing to order and shall allow the applicant and the village, or its counsel or agent, to make an opening statement. The hearing officer may allow objectors or their counsel to make an opening statement. 
(d)  Transcript of hearing. A court reporter shall be employed and shall be present at any and all public hearings on an application for local siting approval and shall provide the village with a certified transcript of the hearing as soon as possible. The court reporter shall prepare a transcript of all proceedings before the village. 
(e)  Presiding officer. The hearing officer shall preside at the public hearing and shall make any decisions concerning the admission of evidence and the manner in which the hearing is conducted subject to this article and the principles of fundamental fairness. The hearing officer may exclude irrelevant, immaterial, incompetent or unduly repetitious testimony or other evidence. The hearing officer shall rule on all questions relating to the admissibility of evidence. The rulings of the hearing officer shall not be appealable to the village board. However, issues of jurisdiction shall be finally determined by the village board. 
(f)  Hearing participants. All persons desiring to be participants in the hearing, including members of the public, must submit written notification of said intent to the village clerk before the first day of the public hearing or register with the hearing officer on the first day of the hearing. Any person so appearing at such public hearing shall have the right to present testimony and witnesses. Any such person shall have the right to be represented by an attorney at said public hearing. Opportunity for any persons appearing at said public hearing to cross-examine any witness may be reasonably limited in scope, time and duration by the hearing officer, to assure completion of the hearings in accordance with the deadlines of the Act. The hearing officer may propound questions to any witness and to the applicant to clarify the record established by the participants at the hearing or to bring out relevant information. The village shall be deemed a participant and a party to all proceedings. 
(g)  Testimony and evidence generally. The hearing officer shall hear testimony from the applicant and/or any witnesses the applicant may wish to call. Upon the close of the applicant's testimony, any other parties may offer any witnesses and evidence they may wish to present. These other parties may or may not be represented by counsel. Upon the close of the applicant's and other parties' testimony and evidence, the village may present any witnesses and evidence it may wish to present, unless the village is the applicant, in which case it shall proceed as any other applicant. The hearing officer shall decide the order of presentation of testimony subject to these rules. 
(h)  Form of testimony. All witnesses shall testify under oath or affirmation. Testimony may include the use of exhibits and prepared statements. If testimony is by prepared statement, copies of such prepared statements shall be made available at the hearings (or, prior to the first hearing date, at the office of the village clerk) at least one day in advance of such testimony being given. All witnesses shall be subject to reasonable examination as follows: direct, cross, redirect, recross, etc. After all parties have presented testimony, reasonable rebuttal, sur-rebuttal, etc., may be allowed at the discretion of the hearing officer. 
(i)  Applicant's employees and consultants to be available for questioning. The applicant shall make available any of its officers, employees, consultants and experts for questioning by the village at the hearing upon 24 hours' notice. 
(j)  Examination of witnesses. The applicant and the village's counsel shall be allowed to cross-examine witnesses by right, subject to such reasonable limitation as may be set by the hearing officer. Cross-examination by the village shall not be limited to matters contained in the application. Parties represented by attorneys may be allowed to cross-examine in the discretion of the hearing officer. Other persons shall be allowed to submit questions to the hearing officer, who shall exercise discretion in the manner in which such questions are to be posed to witnesses. Sufficient examination of witnesses is to be allowed so as to provide for fundamental fairness. 
(k)  Public comment. The hearing officer may exercise discretion to allow public comment at each hearing or may set a time for public comment. 
(l)  Amendment of application. 
(1)  At any time prior to completion by the applicant of the presentation of the applicant's factual evidence and an opportunity for cross-questioning by the village and any participants, the applicant may file not more than one amended application. Before consideration of such amendment, an additional fee must be paid in accordance with this article. Upon the filing of an amendment, the time limitation for final action set forth in this article and in section 39.2(e) of the Act (415 ILCS 5/39.2(e)), as amended, shall be extended for an additional period of 90 days; 
(2)  Within seven days of the filing of the amendment the hearing officer shall notify the applicant of the date of the next public hearing; and 
(3)  The application shall be deemed amended if, at any time after the official filing date, the applicant either changes any of the information contained in the application or submits any additional substantive information, either written or oral, regarding the application. 
(Code 1965, § 8.805) 
Sec. 70-76. - Filing of written comments regarding application. 
(a)  Any person may file written comments with the village clerk concerning the appropriateness of the proposed site for its intended purpose. The village board shall consider any comment received or postmarked from the date of acceptance of the application through and until 30 days after the date of the last public hearing in making its final determination. Said written comments shall be mailed or delivered to the village clerk. Said written comments shall clearly reference the PCF application to which they refer to ensure their consideration by the village board. Upon receipt, the village clerk shall date stamp the comments and refer them to the village board. 
(b)  The above-mentioned written comments shall become part of the record of the proceedings. 
(Code 1965, § 8.806) 
Sec. 70-77. - Decisions. 
(a)  The hearing officer shall submit proposed findings to the village board as soon as practicable. All parties shall have the right to submit proposed findings in accordance with a scheduling order entered by the hearing officer. 
(b)  Once the hearing officer has made proposed findings, the proposed findings shall be submitted to the village board for its decision as to the ultimate approval or disapproval of the proposed site location. A sufficient number of copies of the record of the public hearing shall also be made available to the full village board as soon as reasonably practicable once the transcript becomes available. 
(c)  The village board shall make a decision based on the record from the public hearing and review of the hearing officer's proposed findings as well as the proposed findings of other parties which are timely filed. The decision of the village board shall be by resolution in writing, specifying the reasons for the decision, such reasons to be in conformity with section 39.2(a) of the Act (415 ILCS 5/39.2(a)). In granting site location approval, the village board may impose such conditions as may be reasonable and necessary to accomplish the purposes of the Act to the extent that said conditions are not inconsistent with the Act and the regulations promulgated by the board. Such decisions shall be available for public inspection at the office of the village clerk and may be copied upon payment of the cost of reproduction. If there is no final action by the village board within 180 days after the filing of the application for site location approval, the applicant may deem the application approved. 
(d)  The decision of the village on the application shall be in writing, specifying, in general terms, the reason for the decision. The deliberations of the village are and shall be subject to the Illinois Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.). 
(Code 1965, § 8.807) 
Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Supervision of public ways. 
    All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. He shall have supervision over all work thereon, and the cleaning thereof, and shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to such public places (except traffic ordinances) and is hereby authorized to enforce such ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 9.101) 
Sec. 74-2. - Permit for construction or repair of public ways. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way or to repair the same without having first secured a permit therefor. Application for such permit shall be made to the village clerk and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person or firm who is to do the actual construction work. No such permit shall be issued except on order of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102) 
Sec. 74-3. - Bond for work on public ways. 
    Each applicant shall file a bond in the amount of $50,000.00 with sureties to be approved by the president and board of trustees, conditioned to indemnify the village from any loss or liability or damage resulting from the work undertaken or the manner of doing the same. 
(Code 1965, § 9.103) 
Sec. 74-4. - Specifications for pavement. 
    All street and sidewalk pavement shall be made in conformity with the specifications laid down from time to time by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 9.104) 
Sec. 74-5. - Injuring pavement. 
    It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure any newly laid street or alley pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade or to knowingly injury any street, sidewalk or alley pavement. 
(Code 1965, § 9.105) 
Sec. 74-6. - Repair or replacement of pavement; cash deposit for restoration of sidewalk after building construction. 
    All public streets, alleys and sidewalk pavement shall be kept in good repair or replaced when repair is impractical. Such repair or replacement work, whether done by the village or the abutting owner, shall be done under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. To insure repair or replacement of all contiguous sidewalk pavements which may become damaged during construction periods, and to further insure that each water buffalo box installed before or to be installed during such periods of construction shall be level with the finished grade of the construction site and in vertical alignment with the water shut-off valve, each application for a building permit for the construction of a new building shall be accompanied by a cash deposit of $300.00. The sum so deposited will be refunded promptly following completion of construction and installation of the buffalo box, provided that the public sidewalk has been properly repaired or replaced and that the box and valve have been properly installed and aligned. 
(Code 1965, § 9.106) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to regulate repair of sidewalks, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-13. 
Sec. 74-7. - Report of defects in street, alley or sidewalk. 
    It shall be the duty of every village officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk or any obstruction thereof to report the same to the superintendent of public works as soon as possible. 
(Code 1965, § 9.107) 
Sec. 74-8. - Obstructing public way. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 9.108) 
Sec. 74-9. - Depositing snow on street or sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk or public street any snow which accumulates upon and is removed from any adjacent private property or from the area between the adjacent lot line and the curb line of the street. 
(Code 1965, § 9.108.1) 
Sec. 74-10. - Barricades required for excavation or repair work. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk, or other public place, or making any excavation in any such place, shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work. Such barricades shall be protected by suitable and sufficient electric battery operated flashing lights. Such lights shall be kept burning from twilight in the evening through the night. Flares, lanterns, "bombs" or other devices using a flame shall not be permitted. 
(b)  Defects in pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury; and any person, firm or corporation properly maintaining an opening or excavation in such place shall guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open, by proper barricades and lights described in the preceding paragraph of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 9.109) 
Sec. 74-11. - Disturbing barricades. 
    It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or lights lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 9.110) 
Sec. 74-12. - Display of merchandise; writing advertisements on pavement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use any street, sidewalk or other public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale, or to write or mark any signs or advertisements on any such pavement. 
(Code 1965, § 9.111) 
Sec. 74-13. - Encroachments. 
(a)  No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall install, place, maintain or construct any building, structure or obstruction that encroaches upon any public street right-of-way, including but not limited to the state right-of-way of Mannheim Road, within the limits of the village. 
(b)  In residentially zoned areas, within residential neighborhoods, the village may permit the installation of landscape improvements; including, but not limited to trees, shrubs, flowers, landscape stones, rocks, and brick pavers. 
(c)  Prior to the installation of these improvements, the resident must first obtain approval from the village public works director. Should the village be required to excavate an enhanced parkway for a public improvement or repair, the village will not be required to replace any enhancements that may have been installed. 
(Code 1965, § 9.112; Ord. No. 05-30, § 1, 10-24-2005) 
State Law reference- Authority of village to prevent and remove encroachments or obstructions upon streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-3. 
Sec. 74-14. - Obstructing drains. 
    It shall be unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley. 
(Code 1965, § 9.113) 
Sec. 74-15. - Permission required for installation of poles and wires. 
    It shall be unlawful to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires over any public place, street, alley or other public way without having first secured permission from the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 9.114) 
Sec. 74-16. - Gas pumps prohibited in streets and sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or erect any gasoline pump or tank in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 9.115) 
Sec. 74-17. - Openings and stairways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street or alley or sidewalk or other public place without a permit from the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or railing to the approval of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 9.116) 
Sec. 74-18. - Barbed wire or electrical fences. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to maintain or construct any fence composed in whole or part of barbed wire or with any similar materials designed to cause injury to person anywhere within the village except to protect property located within the following zoning districts as defined in the Hillside Zoning Ordinance of 1980, as amended: 
(1)  B-1 general business district; 
(2)  B-2 planned shopping center district but only to protect areas occupied by public or private utilities or governmental service used under a special permit authorized by the president and board of trustees; 
(3)  M-1 office and restricted industrial district; 
(4)  M-2 light industrial district; and 
(5)  M-3 limited industrial district. 
(b)  In no event, however, shall any barbed wire be affixed to a fence: 
(1)  At any point less than six feet above ground level, measured from the base of the fence; and 
(2)  Unless the barbed wire extends inward of the property to be protected; and 
(3)  If the property to be protected adjoins or is adjacent to any residential district which is not separated from such property by a public street or public alley. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to maintain or construct any fence charged with electrical current anywhere within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 9.117) 
Sec. 74-19. - Deposits on street. 
(a)  Deposit of injurious material prohibited. It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof or any waste material or any glass or other articles which may cause injury to any person, animal or property. 
(b)  Permitted deposits. Coal or other materials may be deposited in streets preparatory to delivery for use, provided that such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the street or roadway at that point to less than 18 feet, and provided that such material or coal other than material used in actual building construction shall not be permitted to remain in such street for more than three hours. 
(c)  Lighting of material remaining at night. Any such material or coal shall be guarded by lights if the same remains upon any street after nighttime. 
(Code 1965, § 9.118) 
Sec. 74-20. - Deposits on sidewalks. 
(a)  Deposit of injurious materials prohibited. It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass or other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or property. 
(b)  Permitted deposits. Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery, providing that the usable width of the sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet, and provided that no such article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half hour. 
(Code 1965, § 9.119) 
Sec. 74-21. - Burning leaves, rubbish or other substances on street or sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to burn any leaves, paper, rubbish or other substances upon any of the public streets, sidewalks or alleys in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 9.120) 
Sec. 74-22. - Gas pipes to be kept free from leaks. 
    Any person, firm or corporation maintaining any gas pipe in the village shall, in the absence of a provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such pipes free from leaks. 
(Code 1965, § 9.121) 
Sec. 74-23. - View at street corners. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct, or maintain or permit to remain, any fence or other structure, or any bushes or other plants, on a corner lot within 50 feet of the street line, which obstructs the view at a height of more than five feet above the level of the adjacent street pavement. 
(Code 1965, § 9.122) 
Sec. 74-24. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each and every day during or on which a violation occurs or continues, except that the minimum fine for the offenses hereinafter described shall be as follows: for each violation of section 74-9, the violator shall be fined not less than $25.00. 
(Code 1965, § 9.701) 
Secs. 74-25-74-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OBSTRUCTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 74-51-74-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OVERHANGING SIGNS AND AWNINGS 

Sec. 74-71. - Permit required; fee. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall erect or maintain any sign, sign board or rigid canopy over any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way in the village without having first obtained a permit therefor as herein provided. Permits for signs, canopies or sign boards shall be issued by the village clerk upon payment of the fee provided, and shall designate the location of the proposed structure. 
(b)  The annual fee for such permit shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 9.401) 
Sec. 74-72. - Bond. 
    Each person, firm or corporation maintaining such a sign shall file with the village clerk a bond or indemnity policy in the sum of $50,000.00, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage or liability that may result from the construction or maintenance of such sign or canopy. Such bond or indemnity policy shall have such sureties as may be approved by the president and board of trustees. Provided that if the village shall have a public liability policy covering all signs in the village then no such bond shall be required. 
(Code 1965, § 9.402) 
Sec. 74-73. - Temporary permits. 
    Temporary permits may be issued for maintenance of a temporary sign for a short time and not to exceed three weeks, upon payment of a fee of as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 9.403) 
Sec. 74-74. - Construction. 
    All signs and canopies extending over any public sidewalk, street, alley or other public place must be securely fastened or constructed so that there will be no danger of the same being dislodged by ordinary winds or falling from other cause. 
(Code 1965, § 9.404) 
Sec. 74-75. - Term of permit. 
    The period for which permits required by this division shall run shall be the same as the general license year. 
(Code 1965, § 9.405) 
Sec. 74-76. - Height above walk. 
    The lowest part of any such canopy, sign or of any non-rigid awning or any support thereof which extends over any public way shall be at least ten feet above the level of the walk or public way over which it extends, but no such sign shall be maintained over any public way used by vehicles if any part of its support or of the sign is less than 15 feet above the level of such public way. 
(Code 1965, § 9.406) 
Sec. 74-77. - Inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector to inspect or cause to be inspected every sign, canopy or awning which extends over any sidewalk, street, alley or other public way. If any such sign or canopy is found to be insecurely fastened, he shall report this fact to the owner of the sign or to the owner or occupant of the premises on which it is fastened. If the sign or canopy is not made secure within ten days after such notice it may be torn down on order of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 9.407) 
Secs. 74-78-74-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 74-101. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall construct, alter or repair any driveway for vehicles in the village without first having obtained a permit therefor. 
(b)  Applications for such permits shall be made to the village public works department. 
(Code 1965, § 9.201; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2-24-2003) 
Sec. 74-102. - Permit fee. 
(a)  The fee for driveway curb cut permits shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(b)  The curb cut permit is over and above any other fees that may be required under section 18-203. 
(Code 1965, § 9.202; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2-24-2003) 
Sec. 74-103. - Grade; surfacing. 
    No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp depression or other obstruction as it adjoins the sidewalk, street, curb and gutter or alley. The grade shall be nearly as possible the same as that of the adjoining structure. It shall be unlawful to have the surface finish of any driveway where the same crosses the sidewalk constructed of such materials as to render it slippery and hazardous to pedestrians, or to have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk or be other than level. 
(Code 1965, § 9.203; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2-24-2003) 
Sec. 74-104. - Specifications. 
(a)  Driveways shall be designed in accordance with all requirements of the village, the state department of transportation's "Handbook for the Policy on Permits for Access Driveways to State Highways, May 1, 1990" and/or constructed in accordance with the Institute of Transportation Engineers "Guidelines for Urban Major Street Design," section 12.0, Driveways. In the event of conflict between these documents, the strictest provisions in the village's interest shall take precedence and govern. All driveways shall be reviewed, at a minimum, upon these standards and for compliance to width, grades and break over angles, sight distance, turning radius and vehicular on-site storage. Driveways servicing properties within R-3, R-4, M-1, M-2, M-3, B-1, and B-2 districts shall be required to provide with a permit submittal an estimate of a.m. and p.m. peak traffic volume based upon occupant load, gross floor area, customer volume and/or shipping/receiving volume. 
(b)  Commercial, industrial and business driveways accessing local roadways shall have a maximum width measured at the property line of 24 feet for one-way operation and 35 feet for two-way operation. The maximum driveway opening measured at the edge of roadway pavement shall be 36 feet. 
(c)  Commercial, industrial and business driveways accessing state or county roadways shall comply with the respective agencies' requirements. 
(d)  Residential driveways shall access state, county or local roadways at one location. 
(e)  Residential driveways shall have a maximum width measured at the property line of 12 feet for an attached/detached one-car garage, 12 feet for a detached two- or three-car garage, and 20 feet for an attached two- or three-car garage. The maximum driveway opening measured at the edge of roadway pavement shall be 24 feet. 
(Code 1965, § 9.204; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2-24-2003) 
Sec. 74-105. - Repair. 
    It shall be the duty of the person maintaining a driveway to keep the same in good repair. Driveways shall be kept free from obstructions and openings where the driveway crosses the sidewalk and or public right-of-ways. 
(Code 1965, § 9.205; Ord. No. 03-03, § 1, 2-24-2003) 
Secs. 74-106-74-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - USE OF SUBSURFACE SPACE 

Sec. 74-131. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to use any vault, space, room or structure under any street or sidewalk in the village, where the village owns the fee or has the power to control the use of such space, without having first secured a permit therefor as is herein required. Such permits shall be issued by the village clerk and shall be signed by the village president. No such permit shall be transferred except in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 9.601) 
Sec. 74-132. - Application for permit. 
    Applications for a permit to use or maintain a vault, space, room or structure under any street or sidewalk in the village shall be made in writing to the village clerk, and shall state thereon specifically the size of the space intended to be used or maintained, and the purpose for which it is to be used. Each application shall contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by the regulations contained in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 9.602) 
Sec. 74-133. - Bond. 
(a)  Each applicant shall file with the application a bond in the sum of $10,000.00, with surety approved by the president and board of trustees, conditioned to save the village harmless from any liability resulting from or caused by such vault, room or structure. 
(b)  Whenever, in the opinion of the president and board of trustees, the sureties on such bond become insolvent or unlawful, different sureties may be required by order of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 9.603) 
Sec. 74-134. - Conveyance of premises. 
    Whenever any premises abutting on any such vault, room or structure for which a permit has been issued shall be conveyed or whenever the interest or lease or right of occupancy of the person holding the permit shall be transferred or conveyed, the grantee or transferee must make application for a transfer of the permit to him or it, and must furnish a bond as is required in section 74-133. A fee as established by the village board from time to time shall be required for such transfer, and upon the payment of the fee and the full compliance with the contents hereof a new permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1965, § 9.604) 
Sec. 74-135. - Openings. 
    All openings through the sidewalk or street into any such vault, space, room or structure shall be kept covered and guarded. If the opening is a manhole or trap door, an adequate, strong metal cover must be provided and must be equipped with a rough surface so that there will be no danger of any pedestrian slipping on it. If a stairway is provided, the stairway must be properly guarded with a railing at least three feet high to protect pedestrians from injury. 
(Code 1965, § 9.605) 
Sec. 74-136. - Permit fee. 
    The annual fee to be paid for such permits shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 9.606) 
Sec. 74-137. - Existing uses. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation using or maintaining any such vault, space, room or structure subject to the provisions of this article shall comply with the provisions of this article within ten days after this article comes into effect as an ordinance. 
(b)  The board of trustees may authorize the superintendent of public works to close up any vault, space, room or structure for which no such permit has been obtained. 
(Code 1965, § 9.607) 
Sec. 74-138. - Prohibited uses. 
    No such vault, room, space or structure shall be used for the storage of explosives or flammable liquids, nor shall a cesspool be located therein. 
(Code 1965, § 9.608) 
Sec. 74-139. - Construction; inspections. 
(a)  Such vaults, rooms, spaces or structures shall be firmly constructed so as to support the sidewalk or street over it or them, with the maximum load which the sidewalk or street will carry, with a margin of safety of 50 percent over its maximum load or weight. 
(b)  The superintendent of public works shall inspect all such rooms, spaces, vaults, or structures to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 9.609) 
Sec. 74-140. - Maintenance of sidewalks. 
    The surface of the sidewalk over any such structure shall be kept free of snow and ice, and free from all dirt and obstruction of any kind, by the person holding the permit, and such person must keep the sidewalk over such structure in good repair. 
(Code 1965, § 9.610) 
Sec. 74-141. - Revocation of permit. 
    Any permit issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by order of the president and board of trustees for a violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 9.611) 
Secs. 74-142-74-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXCAVATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of village to regulate openings in streets, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-7. 

Sec. 74-171. - Permit required; compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to tunnel under or to make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the village without having first obtained a permit as is herein required or without complying with the provisions of this article or in violation of or in variance from the terms of any such permit. 
(Code 1965, § 9.301) 
Sec. 74-172. - Application for permit. 
    Applications for such permits shall be made to the director of public works. The permit application shall describe the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose thereof, and the name and current phone number of the person, firm or corporation doing the actual excavating work. The permit application shall also contain the name and current phone number of the person, firm or corporation for whom or which the work is being done. The signed permit application shall be considered an agreement that the applicant will comply with all ordinances, laws and village specifications relating to the work which is to be done. 
(Code 1965, § 9.302) 
Sec. 74-173. - Records of permits. 
    Properly executed applications will be issued a corresponding permit number and will be documented within the permit issuance file as a record of agreement between the village and the permittee. 
(Code 1965, § 9.303) 
Sec. 74-174. - Fee; deposit. 
(a)  Whenever it is necessary to perform an excavation in, on or about any building, structure or property located within the village there shall be a charge as established by the village board from time to time. 
(b)  Performance of an excavation on, in or through any village parkway, street, alley or other public place, in whole or part, shall require a minimum cash deposit with each permit application to ensure the appropriate restoration of said area to its original or better condition. The minimum cash deposits are dependent upon excavation locations and are detailed as follows: 
(1)  All streets, alleys, sidewalks, curbs and driveways: $2,500.00. 
(2)  All grass parkways or vegetated areas: $1,000.00. 
(c)  The sum of the cash deposit may be increased at the discretion of the director of public works and shall be dependent upon the extent of the proposed work. The sum of the cash deposit will be refunded upon written request of the permittee and following completion of all restoration of excavated areas in accordance with the terms of said permit. 
(Code 1965, § 9.304) 
Sec. 74-175. - Street closures. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation who performs work within or on a public street, alley or any other public place which alters the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic in whole or in part shall be charged a street closure fee as established by the village board from time to time. 
(1)  Notification of any and all street closures must be given at least 24 hours in advance of the closure to the clerk's office. The notification must include the estimated length of time for each closure, the proposed detour of traffic, the planned traffic control and the name and current phone number of the person, firm or corporation who is performing the closure. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of the person, firm or corporation who is closing the street to notify all residents, businesses and commercial properties of the street closure at least 24 hours prior to the start of such activities. 
(3)  The clerk's office will notify the police, fire and public works departments of any and all street closures. 
(b)  It shall be the sole discretion of the village whether a street, alley or other public place is permitted to be closed for any duration. 
(Code 1965, § 9.304.1) 
Sec. 74-176. - Barricades and lights. 
    Any person, firm or corporation making or maintaining any excavation in any street or alley shall keep the same adequately guarded by barricades and lights as provided for in section 74-10. 
(Code 1965, § 9.305) 
Sec. 74-177. - Manner of excavating. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to make any such excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. Proper bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground; and in excavations the excavation shall not have anywhere below the surface any portion which extends beyond the opening at the surface. 
(b)  No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables, or conduits in the making of such excavations or tunnels; and notice shall be given to the persons maintaining any such pipes, cables or conduits or to the village department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed. 
(c)  No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or the roots thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 9.306) 
Sec. 74-178. - Temporary sidewalks. 
    If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(Code 1965, § 9.307) 
Sec. 74-179. - Time limit for completion of work. 
    Each applicant for a permit must state in written form the estimated length of time that will elapse from the commencement of the work until the permanent restoration of the excavation site. It shall be unlawful to fail to comply with this time limitation unless permission for an extension of time is granted by the director of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 9.308) 
Sec. 74-180. - Restoration of surface. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation making an excavation or tunnel in or under any public street, alley or public place in the village shall restore the surface thereof to its original or better condition. All trench backfill shall be compacted in accordance with all governing standards and any bracing and sheeting in such tunnel or excavation shall be left in the ground unless otherwise approved by the director of public works. 
(b)  The surface of any paved or improved portion of a village street or alley shall be temporarily restored with a cold asphalt mix immediately after the completion of all trench backfill operations. It shall be the responsibility of the permittee to maintain the said site in such a manner as to promote safe vehicular and pedestrian travel. If said work is not completed, the village may temporarily restore the surface and charge the cost plus 15 percent to the permittee. 
(c)  Any opening in a paved or improved portion of a village street, alley or public place shall be permanently repaired to its original or better condition by the permittee. All repairs shall be made in compliance with all governing standards and are subject to the supervision of the director of public works. If such work is not completed within ten days of restorative actions becoming possible, the village may restore the paved surface and charge the cost plus 15 percent to the permittee. 
(Code 1965, § 9.309) 
Sec. 74-181. - Supervision. 
    The superintendent of public works shall from time to time inspect all excavations and tunnels being made in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the village to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this article. Notice shall be given to him at least ten hours before the work of refilling any such excavation or tunnel commences. 
(Code 1965, § 9.310) 
Sec. 74-182. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article relative to securing permits shall not apply to officers or employees of the village engaged in doing work for the village, nor to persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the village if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels without securing a permit therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 9.311) 
Secs. 74-183-74-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NEWSRACKS 

Sec. 74-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Distributor means the person responsible for placing and maintaining a newsrack in a public right-of-way. 
    Newsrack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the display and sale of newspapers or other news periodicals. 
    Parkway means that area between the sidewalks and the curb of any street, and where there is no sidewalk, that area between the edge of the roadway and property line adjacent thereto. Parkway shall also include any area within a roadway which is not open to vehicular travel. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed, or ordinarily used for a vehicular travel. 
    Sidewalk means any surface provided for the exclusive use of pedestrians. 
    Street means all that area dedicated to public use for public street purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, parkways, alleys, and sidewalks. 
(Code 1965, § 9.101A) 
Sec. 74-212. - Permit required; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, place, maintain or operate, on any public street or sidewalk or in any other public way or place in the village, any newsrack without obtaining a permit from the village specifying the exact location of such newsrack. One permit may be issued to include any number of newsracks and shall be signed by the distributor. The annual permit fee for each newsrack shall be as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 9.102A) 
Sec. 74-213. - Regulations. 
(a)  Indemnification.
