The requirements of this subsection may be met by reflective materials which shall be at least 3/16 inch wide on each side of each tire or rim to indicate as clearly as possible the continuous circular shape and size of the tires or rims of such bicycle and which reflective materials may be of the same color on both the front and rear tire or rim. Such reflectors shall conform to specifications prescribed by the state department of transportation. 
(f)  Front reflector. No person shall sell or offer for sale a new bicycle that is not equipped with an essentially colorless front-facing reflector. 
(Code 1965, § 18.618) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1507. 
Sec. 90-336. - Motorized scooters. 
(a)  Motor driven scooter defined. For the purpose of this section, a "motor driven scooter" is defined as any electric or gas driven wheeled scooter, motor-driven cycle or other similar motor-driven vehicle for which the state does not issue a title document, and does not issue license plates or registration documents. 
(b)  Operation of motor driven scooters restricted. No person shall operate a motor driven scooter upon any public street, sidewalk, parking lot, bike path, park or on any other public property. 
(c)  Exemptions. The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained in this section. 
(1)  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, special district vehicle, Cook County vehicle or Cook County Forest Preserve District vehicle operated by an employee in the course of his or her duties. 
(2)  Motorized wheelchairs. For purposes of this section, a motorized wheelchair means any motorized vehicle designed for and used by a person with disabilities. 
(3)  Electric personal assistive mobility devices, as defined in section 5/1-117.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et. seq.) 
(d)  Violatons. Any person 18 years of age or older who violates any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be subject to a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense. An offense committed by a minor under the direct control or with the consent of a parent or guardian may subject the parent or guardian to the penalties provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-18, § 1, 10-25-2004) 
Secs. 90-337-90-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 90-361. - Right-of-way generally. 
(a)  Where the traffic control signals are not in place or in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway or street within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a moving vehicle which is so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(c)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the condition stated in section 90-362(b). 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(e)  Whenever stop signs or flashing red signals are in place at an intersection or at a plainly marked crosswalk between intersections, drivers shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians as set forth in 625 ILCS 5/11-904. 
(Code 1965, § 18.401) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1002. 
Sec. 90-362. - Pedestrians crossing roadway at point other than crosswalk. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(d)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally unless authorized by official traffic control devices; and, when authorized to cross diagonally, pedestrians shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic control devices pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(e)  Pedestrians with disabilities may cross a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk where the intersection is physically inaccessible to them but they shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(f)  No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business section. 
(Code 1965, §§ 18.402, 18.405) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1003. 
Sec. 90-363. - Obedience to traffic and pedestrian control signals. 
(a)  A pedestrian shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device specifically applicable to him, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic and pedestrian control signals provided in 625 ILCS 5/11-306 and 5/11-307, but at all other places pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 18.403) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1001. 
Sec. 90-364. - Standing on sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near as reasonably possible to the building line or curb line, if such standing interferes with the use of said sidewalk by other pedestrians. 
(Code 1965, § 18.404) 
Sec. 90-365. - Walking along or standing in roadway. 
(a)  Where a sidewalk is provided and its use is practicable, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where a sidewalk is not available, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall walk only on a shoulder, as far as practicable from the edge of the roadway. 
(c)  Where neither a sidewalk nor a shoulder is available, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall walk as near as practicable to an outside edge of a roadway, and, if on a two-way roadway, shall walk only on the left side of the roadway. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any pedestrian upon a roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(e)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 18.406) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1007. 
Sec. 90-366. - Right-of-way of pedestrians with disabilities. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian with clearly visible disabilities. 
(Code 1965, § 18.407) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1004. 
Chapter 94 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 94-1-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-31. - Water supply and distribution systems provisions of Municipal Code of Chicago adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village for the purpose of prescribing the establishment of a minimum code of standards and procedures for water supply and distribution systems in the village, pursuant to authority of the 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4, the following sections of the Municipal Code of Chicago as published January 1, 1964: 11-8-010-11-8-210, and 11-8-230-11-8-770, as such ordinances exist on the date of adoption of the village Code of Ordinances. Three copies of the chapters of the Municipal Code of Chicago relating to plumbing, which set forth said sections in full, have been and now are filed in the office of the clerk of said village and the said sections are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and, unless in conflict with any other provisions of this article, shall be controlling within the limits of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 22.100) 
Sec. 94-32. - Persons authorized to turn on water. 
    No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person but the superintendent of public works or some person authorized by him to perform this service. 
(Code 1965, § 22.101) 
Sec. 94-33. - Application for service; fee for turning on water. 
(a)  Applications to have water turned on shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this article as conditions governing the use of the village water supply. 
(b)  A fee as established by the village board from time to time shall be charged for turning on the water. Such fee shall be paid to the village collector. 
(c)  Each such application for water service shall include the name, address and telephone number of title holder of record of the premises to which water is to be furnished, in addition to the name, address and telephone number of the applicant, if the applicant is not the title holder of record. The village clerk shall incorporate all such information into the water department records for future collection purposes if the account becomes delinquent. 
(Code 1965, § 22.102) 
Sec. 94-34. - Deposit. 
    An applicant for water service, limited to an individually metered premises having a water connection diameter of less than 11/2 inches, shall deposit with such application the sum of $35.00. All other applicants for water service to an individually metered premises shall deposit with such application the sum of $100.00. Each such deposit shall be retained by the village to insure full and timely payment of all water service so furnished to or on behalf of the applicant or to the party or parties in possession of the metered premises. All such deposits, less any amounts then owing to the village for such water service to said premises, shall be promptly refunded to the depositor without interest when such water service to the depositor shall have been permanently discontinued, provided a written request for refund shall have been filed with the village clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 22.103) 
Sec. 94-35. - Plumbing requirements. 
    No water shall be turned on for service in premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the ordinances of the village; provided that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 22.104) 
Sec. 94-36. - Service connections and water taps. 
(a)  No connections with a domestic water main shall be made unless a permit has been issued and unless at least 24 hours' prior notice has been given to the village superintendent of public works. All such connections shall be made by a person or firm designated from time to time by the village, and the work shall be done under the supervision of the village superintendent of public works who shall give his final approval thereof before the connections may be covered. 
(b)  A charge as established by the village board from time to time shall be made for each such connection and, in addition thereto, a water tap fee as established by the village board from time to time shall be charged for each such water tap. 
(Code 1965, § 22.105) 
Sec. 94-37. - Outdoor water use. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, between noon and 6:00 p.m. during the period May 15 through September 15 of each year, to fill any swimming pool, to sprinkle lawns, gardens, shrubs, flowers, plants, fields or any ground whatsoever, or to engage in any outdoor activity, using water obtained from a village water main. 
(b)  Such use of water at all other times of the day during said period would be lawful if limited to even-numbered days on those premises identified by even-numbered street addresses and to odd-numbered days on those premises identified by odd-numbered street addresses. During any other period of the year, such use of water shall be unrestricted. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, if the village administrator shall determine that an emergency water shortage exists in connection with the operation of the village water distribution system, the village administrator is hereby authorized to invoke an emergency ban on all outdoor water use for the duration of the emergency. The village administrator shall use every reasonable means, including but not limited to telephone communication, radio and television announcements, and use of loudspeaker systems by the police, fire and emergency services and disaster unit vehicles, to notify all village water users and the village president, village clerk and all village trustees that the ban is in effect and later that the ban has been lifted. 
(Code 1965, § 22.106) 
Sec. 94-38. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 22.107) 
Secs. 94-39-94-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE PIPES 

Sec. 94-61. - Installation. 
    All service pipes from the mains to the premises served shall be installed by, and at the cost of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. Such installations shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 22.201) 
Sec. 94-62. - Specifications. 
    No service shall be installed unless it conforms to specifications drawn by the village board and approved thereby, a copy of which specifications shall be kept on file with the clerk and shall be open to inspection by any person interested. 
(Code 1965, § 22.202) 
Sec. 94-63. - Repairs. 
    All repairs of potable water service pipes and plumbing systems of a building or residential home shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the premises served. A building or residential home service pipe supplying potable water or fire protection service shall be defined as a pipe with a sole purpose of housing and conveying drinking water or fire protection into a structure for use by a consumer. The term "service pipe" shall mean and include all appurtenances used in a connection to the village main and will include saddle taps, shut-off valves and buffalo boxes. If a repair is deemed an emergency, the village may repair any service pipe and shall have the associated costs repaid to the village by the owner of the premises serviced. 
(Code 1965, § 22.203) 
Sec. 94-64. - Abandonment. 
    Abandonment of all building or residential home service pipes shall be made by and at the expense of the property owner served. Excavations made for the abandonment of all service pipes shall comply with section 74-177 and such owner shall adhere to the following provisions: 
(1)  Service pipes shall be abandoned at the point of connection to the village water main. 
(2)  Various fittings being utilized as a means of connecting large diameter service pipes to the village water main shall be removed and replaced with a segment of material specified by the superintendent of public works or by his designee. 
(3)  In cases where a corporation stop is used as a means of connection to the village water main, the corporation stop shall be completely removed from the main. The remaining tap hole shall be covered with a gasketed full face stainless steel clamp and secured using stainless steel bolts and nuts. 
(4)  Remaining ends of the service pipes shall be either crimped and folded for copper and lead service lines or bricked and cemented for cast and ductile iron service pipes as means of abandonment. 
(5)  All service pipe abandonments shall be inspected by the superintendent of public works or by his designee prior to backfilling. 
(Code 1965, § 22.203.1) 
Sec. 94-65. - Excavations. 
    Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing the same shall be made in compliance with the ordinance provisions relating to making excavations in streets. Provided that it shall be unlawful to place any service pipe in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drain pipe or sewer pipe. 
(Code 1965, § 22.204) 
Sec. 94-66. - Shut-off boxes. 
    Shut-off boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every service pipe, and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily accessible and shall be protected from frost. 
(Code 1965, § 22.205) 
Sec. 94-67. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 22.206) 
Secs. 94-68-94-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - METERS; RATES 

Sec. 94-91. - Meter required; meter installation charges. 
(a)  All premises using the village water supply must be equipped with an appropriate water meter (manufacturer to be specified by the superintendent of public works), the initial charge for which shall be paid by the consumer. All single-family or individually metered duplex residences shall also be equipped with a compatible outside meter reading device. Business, commercial and industrial properties shall be equipped with a compatible outside meter reading device when it has been determined by the superintendent of public works or his designee that it is feasible that such a device can be installed. The initial charge for the outside meter reading device shall be the obligation of the consumer. The meters and outside meter devices shall be furnished by and remain the sole property of the village. The superintendent of public works may order any such meter or device to be inspected, removed, tested, repaired or replaced at any time by village employees or agents and at village expense. 
(b)  The consumer shall pay, within ten days from date of billing, the actual cost plus ten percent of the initial meter furnished by the village. In addition, the consumer shall pay, when added to the consumer's water bill, a sum of as established by the village board from time to time as the consumer's sole charge by the village for furnishing and installing the initial outside meter reading device. 
(Code 1965, § 22.301) 
Sec. 94-92. - Location of meter. 
    Meters shall be installed in a location that will be easy of access. 
(Code 1965, § 22.302) 
Sec. 94-93. - Tampering with meter. 
    No person, other than one so authorized by the superintendent of public works, shall tamper with, test, repair, remove, relocate or in any manner interfere with any water meter, including the seal attached thereto, or outside meter reading device furnished by the village for the control and measurement of village supplied water. When, in the sole discretion of the superintendent of public works, there is sufficient cause to conclude that such meter, seal or device has been so tampered with, he may order the removal thereof for purpose of testing and repair or replacement. The actual cost of such removal, testing, repair or replacement and the reinstallation thereof shall be billed to the consumer and paid within ten days from the date of billing. 
(Code 1965, § 22.302.1) 
Sec. 94-94. - Reading meters. 
    The superintendent of public works shall read or cause to be read every water meter used in the village at such times as are necessary that the bills may be sent out at the proper time. 
(Code 1965, § 22.303) 
Sec. 94-95. - Rates. 
    The rates for water supplied from the municipal water distribution system and for which the charge therefore shall be initially billed on or after March 1, 2016, shall be as follows: 
    $11.00 per 1,000 gallons with a minimum charge of $11.45 per billing period. In addition thereto, a penalty of five per cent of the total charge shall be added if the bill is not paid within 15 days after the date it is billed. 
(Code 1965, § 22.305; Ord. No. 06-40, § 1, 12-18-2006; Ord. No. 10-09, § 1, 4-26-2010; Ord. No. 11-14, § 1, 8-22-2011; Ord. No. 11-20 § 1, 12-19-2011; Ord. No. 12-17, § 1, 11-26-2012; Ord. No. 13-21, § 1, 12-16-2013; Ord. No. 14-22, § 1, 12-8-2014; Ord. No. 16-02, § 1, 2-22-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-17, § 1, adopted Nov. 26, 2012, changed the title of § 94-95 from rates generally; late payment charge to rates. 
Sec. 94-96. - Billing period. 
    The charge for water furnished to an individually metered premises shall be billed monthly. 
(Code 1965, § 22.306) 
Sec. 94-97. - Rates for premises outside village. 
    The charge for water furnished to premises outside the village limits, where authorized by the board, shall be as provided in section 94-95. 
(Code 1965, § 22.307) 
Sec. 94-98. - Use of water by construction contractors. 
(a)  During the construction of any building and before any water is installed, as is hereafter provided, the contractor so constructing such building may be permitted to use the municipal water supply by making application therefor and paying the fee as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Whenever a building permit is issued for construction in connection with which water drawn from the village water system shall be used before water meters are installed, regardless of the type of building involved, a charge shall be made as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 22.308) 
Sec. 94-99. - Termination of service for nonpayment of charges. 
(a)  The water supply may be shut-off from any premises for which the water bill remains unpaid for a period of 15 days after the water bill is produced and mailed. Prior to termination of service, the village will follow the following procedure: 
(1)  Mailing of the original billing. 
(2)  Mailing of a past due notice, advising of the potential of the termination of service if the bill remains unpaid. 
(3)  Tagging of the premises with a door hanger, advising that the service will be terminated on a specific day if the bill remains unpaid. 
(b)  Once shut off, the water shall not be turned on except upon payment of the outstanding bill and a payment of the usual fee for turning on water. 
(c)  The village administrator, or his designee, is authorized to extend payment terms and/or to waive late fees in the case of extenuating circumstances. The village administrator, or his designee, shall from time to time, report to the board of trustees on any such actions taken. Any water customer who is not satisfied with any explanations of his water account, or actions by the village administrator, or his designee, to resolve any disputes to a water account, may request a hearing with the board of trustees. Such hearing shall be scheduled within ten (10) days of its request. 
(Code 1965, § 22.309; Ord. No. 08-03, § 1, 1-28-2008) 
Sec. 94-100. - Unpaid charges to constitute lien. 
(a)  Charges for water shall be a lien upon the premises as provided by statute. Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid after the due date specified on the bill, the account reflecting such charges shall be deemed delinquent and the clerk may file or cause to be filed, with the county recorder of deeds, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for the delinquent amount as well as for all charges for water served subsequent to the period covered. 
(b)  If the water customer whose bill is delinquent is not the owner of the premises to which water was served, and the clerk has notice of that fact, the clerk shall mail or cause to be mailed to the owner at his last known mailing address a copy of this statement of the lien claim. 
(c)  The failure of the clerk to record such lien claim or to mail such notice, or the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water bills as mentioned in section 94-101. 
(Code 1965, § 22.310) 
Sec. 94-101. - Foreclosure of lien. 
(a)  Property subject to lien for unpaid water charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the village. 
(b)  The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which a water bill has remained unpaid 60 days after is has been rendered. Accounts turned over for collection are subject to a collection charge as established by the village board from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 22.311) 
Sec. 94-102. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 22.312) 
Secs. 94-103-94-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - AIR-CONDITIONING AND REFRIGERATION EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 94-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air-conditioning means the cooling or dehumidification, or both, of space for human occupancy, food preservation and industrial processing. 
    Air-conditioning system or air-conditioning installation means one or more air-conditioning units, the water for which passes through a common meter, whether or not the units are owned by the property owner, the tenant or a combination of both. It is intended that separate sub-metering for any one property owner or tenant occupying different space in the same building could create separate systems; it is not intended that sub-metering of individual units serving the same space or adjacent space under one owner or tenant would create separate systems. 
    Installed capacity means the total number of tons of refrigeration installed on one air-conditioning system. 
    Ton of refrigeration means the heat required to melt ice at the rate of one ton in 24 hours. One compressor horsepower shall be considered equivalent to one ton of refrigeration. 
    Water conserving device means a cooling tower, spray pond, evaporation condenser or other equipment by which water is cooled and re-circulated, thereby limiting the use of water from the mains to that amount lost through evaporation. 
    Water regulating device means a regulating valve or other device, the purpose of which is to limit the maximum use of water to a predetermined rate. 
(Code 1965, § 22.401) 
Sec. 94-122. - Installation and operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation to have installed or to operate air-conditioning equipment without first conforming to the following regulations: 
(1)  Permit for new installations; notification of existing installation. All water customers who desire to install air-conditioning and refrigeration equipment after the effective date of this division are required to make written application therefor and to obtain approval and a permit therefor in advance from the building inspector and are required to give notice of completion of the installation. All customers who have installed air-conditioning equipment prior to the effective date of this division shall, in lieu of a permit, notify the department of buildings of such existing installation. Failure to give notice shall be considered a violation of this division. 
(2)  Use of water from village mains restricted. All air-conditioning units shall be equipped with water conservation devices so that water from the village mains shall be used for make-up and flushing purposes only. Any air-conditioning system is prohibited from using water from the mains in excess of 0.2 gallons per minute per ton. Each air-conditioning system shall be sub-metered using a water meter acceptable to the village. 
(3)  Applicability to existing units. All air-conditioning units installed heretofore must be made to comply with the provisions of this division. 
(4)  Inspections. The superintendent of public works and persons designated by him shall, at all reasonable hours, have free access to premises supplied with water for air-conditioning purposes, to examine the equipment and to ascertain if there is more water being used than allowed by this division. 
(5)  Appeals. Whenever the building inspector shall reject or refuse to approve any plan or specification for or the mode or manner of construction proposed to be used in the installation of any air-conditioning equipment, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this division do not apply or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of this division has been misconstrued or improperly interpreted, the owner or any person or corporation aggrieved may appeal to the fire and water committee of the board of trustees. No public advertising shall be required as a condition precedent to such appeal. The decision of the fire and water committee of the board of trustees shall be final. 
(Code 1965, § 22.402) 
Sec. 94-123. - Location. 
    Whenever it shall be necessary for the proper operation of an air conditioning system having a rated heat removal capacity in excess of 20,000 British thermal units per hour, to install any portion of the air conditioning equipment therefor, including but not limited to condensers or compressors, outside the building whose atmosphere said system is intended to cool, such equipment shall be located, in the case of "A" or "B" residential or apartment districts, to the rear of such building. Nothing herein shall be construed to regulate the installation of air conditioning systems in any use district not specified hereinabove. 
(Code 1965, § 22.402.1) 
Sec. 94-124. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 22.403) 
DIVISION 4.5. - GROUNDWATER USE RESTRICTION ZONES 

Sec. 94-125. - Groundwater use restriction. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section: 
(1)  Current owner(s) is the person identified by the Cook County Treasurer to receive real estate tax bills for the property index number assigned to real property shown in the application, or an amended application, within the restricted groundwater zone; provided that if real estate tax bills are not issued by the Cook County Treasurer, the owner shall be the person identified as the current owner by the Cook County Recorder of Deeds. 
(2)  Person is any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, the Village of Hillside and any other political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or any of its or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
(3)  Potable water is any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, preparing foods, watering lawns, or watering gardens in which produce intended for human consumption is grown. 
(4)  Restricted groundwater zone is that areal extent of "groundwater," within the village limits, and around the "source" of a "release" of "petroleum", "pesticides" or "regulated substance," as those words are defined in the Illinois Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1, et seq., ("the Act"). That area shall extend, at a minimum, to any area within the measured and modeled extent of groundwater contamination above what would otherwise be the applicable Tier 1 groundwater remediation objectives at 35 Ill. Admin. Code 742. 
(b)  Application for zone designation. An owner of property within or outside the village limits may apply to the village for the designation of a restricted groundwater zone around a source of a release on the owner's property. The application shall be in writing, shall be filed with the village clerk with an original and three copies, and must be accompanied by an application fee. The owner shall be considered the applicant. 
(1)  Contents of application. The application shall consist of a letter to the village clerk, requesting the board of trustees to enact an ordinance designating a restricted groundwater zone pursuant to this division in accordance with 35 Ill. Admin. Code 742.1015, including the following: 
a.  A scaled map(s) delineating the area and extent of measured and modeled groundwater contamination above the applicable Tier 1 remediation objectives including any measured data showing concentrations of contaminants of concern in soil or groundwater in which the applicable remediation objectives are exceeded, and any supporting information or reports in accordance with 35 Ill. Admin. Code 742.320 or 742.805; 
b.  A scaled map delineating the boundaries of all properties under which measured and modeled groundwater is located which exceeds the applicable Tier 1 groundwater remediation objectives, and any supporting information or reports in accordance with 35 Ill. Admin. Code 742.320 or 742.805; 
c.  Information identifying the current owner(s) of each property identified in subsection (b)(1)b., herein; 
d.  A description of the particular intended use(s) to which the applicant's property is to be put if Illinois EPA issues a "no further remediation" letter to the owner and a statement whether the "no further remediation" letter will contain a generic use limitation. 
(2)  Notification of application. Not later than seven days after filing the application, the applicant shall serve notice, by certified mail, return receipt requested to the village clerk and the current owners identified in subsection (b)(1)c., herein, as required under 35 Ill. Admin.Code 742.1015, which includes the following information: 
a.  The name and address of the Village of Hillside; 
b.  A statement that: 
1.  The applicant is seeking the designation of a restricted groundwater zone pursuant to the Village of Hillside's procedural groundwater ordinance (including citation); 
2.  The designation of a restricted groundwater zone shall prohibit the use or attempt to use groundwater as a potable water supply within the restricted groundwater zone; 
3.  The restricted groundwater zone area may include property owned by recipients of this notice; and 
4.  More information regarding the application and a copy of related documents may be obtained by contacting the village clerk; 
c.  A description of the property being sent notice by adequate legal description, reference to a plat showing the boundaries of the property, or accurate street address; 
d.  Identification of the party requesting to use the groundwater ordinance as an institutional control, and a statement that the party has requested or will be requesting approval from the Illinois EPA to use the ordinance as an institutional control; 
e.  A statement that use of the ordinance as an institutional control allows contamination above groundwater ingestion remediation objectives to remain in groundwater beneath the affected properties, and that the ordinance strictly prohibits human and domestic consumption of the groundwater; 
f.  A statement as to the nature of the release and response action with the site name, site address, and Illinois EPA site number or Illinois inventory identification number; and 
g.  A statement that more information about the remediation site may be obtained by contacting the party requesting the use of the groundwater ordinance as an institutional control or by submitting a FOIA request to the Illinois EPA. 
(3)  Application fee. The required application fee shall be paid by a certified or cashier's check or money order, in the greatest of the following amounts: 
a.  If applicable remediation objectives have been exceeded (or exceedances have been modeled) at any point in the groundwater 25 or more feet away from the applicant's property line; and: 
1.  Any of the applicable groundwater remediation objectives is 25 parts per billion (0.025 mg/L) or less, $3,500.00; or 
2.  All applicable groundwater remediation objectives are greater than 25 parts per billion, $3,000.00. 
b.  If applicable groundwater remediation objectives have been exceeded (or exceedances have been modeled) at any point in the groundwater 150 feet or more away from the applicant's property line, and: 
1.  Any of the applicable groundwater remediation objectives is 25 parts per billion (0.025 mg/L) or less, $5,000.00; or, 
2.  All applicable groundwater remediation objectives are greater than 25 parts per billion, $4,500.00. 
c.  If applicable groundwater remediation objectives have not been exceeded (or exceedances have been modeled) twenty-five or more feet from the property line, and: 
1.  Any of the applicable groundwater remediation objectives is 25 parts per billion (0.025 mg/L) or less, $2,500.00; or 
2.  All applicable groundwater remediation objectives are greater than 25 parts per billion, $2,000.00. 
(c)  Investigation of application. The village clerk shall stamp the application with the date of its receipt, and immediately provide a complete copy of the application to the village public works director and to the village attorney. The village public works director, or his designee, shall provide a technical review of the application, including the current remedial plan proposed by the applicant. The village attorney shall provide a review of the legal and regulatory implications of the application, including compliance with village ordinances. The village may retain the services of outside technical or legal consultants to investigate the application. The village public works director and the village attorney, or the consultants they retain, shall provide a written statement of their findings, conclusions and recommendations to the mayor and village board of trustees. 
(d)  Decision of village on application. 
(1)  The village shall designate a restricted groundwater zone in the form of an ordinance adopted by the village and in conformity with 35 Ill. Admin. Code 742.1015. The designation shall describe the Zone in writing, and by a scaled map exhibit, in conformity with 35 Ill. Admin. Code 742.1015. 
(2)  In making its decision the village board of trustees shall consider any written comments and recommendations from the public, village departments, the village public works director, the village attorney, and any consultants retained by the village. 
(3)  The village board of trustee's decision whether to designate a restricted groundwater zone, is pursuant to the village's contract and legislative powers and in consideration of, among other things, the community's public health and welfare, the future water supply needs and resources of the village, and the best interests of all affected parties, including the applicant, other affected owners or possessors of land, and the village itself. A designation by the village is not, and shall not be construed to be, a release or waiver of the village's or any other person's rights to enforce local, state or federal ordinances, statutes or regulations or common law or equitable remedies with respect to the release which is the subject of the application or the designation. 
(4)  The village shall make its determination, whether to designate the zone, within seventy days following the date of receipt of the application, provided all proofs of service pursuant to subsection (b)(2) of this section, have been received by the village. Failure to issue a written decision within that time period shall be considered a decision that no restricted groundwater zone shall be designated. An applicant may provide a written waiver to the village board of trustees, extending the time within which it may make its decision. 
(e)  Applicability to Village-Owned Property. The provisions of subsections (b), (c), (d)(4), and (f) of this section shall not apply to a decision whether to designate a restricted groundwater zone for property owned by the village itself. 
(f)  Review process fees and expenses. 
(1)  From the deposit of fees required by subsection (b)(3) of this section, the village shall deduct the cost of reviewing an application for the designation of a restricted groundwater zone under this division. This shall include the actual amounts expended for reasonable legal fees and expenses and outside consultants, including technical consultants, fees and expenses reasonably required as part of the review process. 
(2)  Upon the completion of the review process, or withdrawal of the application for the designation of a restricted groundwater zone, whatever sums are remaining on deposit shall be promptly refunded by the village clerk to the owner/applicant. No interest shall accrue or be payable on the deposit by the village. 
(3)  In the event the deposit is insufficient to cover the city's review process fees and expenses, the city shall notify the owner/applicant of the deficiency and the owner/applicant shall deposit the additional amount within 15 days of such notice. If the additional payment is not made within fifteen 15 days then the review process shall be terminated and the application shall be deemed withdrawn. 
(Ord. No. 08-05, § 1, 3-24-2008) 
Secs. 94-126-94-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES 

Sec. 94-151. - Notice to install; installation standards; inspections. 
    All plumbing installed within the village shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of the state plumbing code adopted by reference in section 18-291. If, in accordance with the state plumbing code or in the judgment of the director of public works, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the director of public works or his designee will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the state plumbing code, the requirements of the state environmental protection agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall permit inspections and tests to be made of such approved devices upon installation and as required by the state plumbing code, the state environmental protection agency and local regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 22.501) 
Sec. 94-152. - Use of private water supply. 
(a)  Generally. No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the village may enter the supply or distribution system of the village, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the director of public works or his designee and the state environmental protection agency. 
(b)  Connection to public water supply required. Each person, firm or corporation constructing a permanent or temporary building structure with appurtenances to carry and convey potable or site specific water shall be required to connect to the village public water distribution system. 
(c)  Prohibited water supplies. No person, firm or corporation within the village corporate limits shall establish or maintain potable or site specific water use from any system other than the village public water distribution system. 
(d)  Exception. The village will reserve the right to approve the use of an underground aquifer for the sole purpose of lawn sprinkling, garden irrigation and other permitted outdoor activities based upon the review of the appropriate permit application and submission of five stamped engineering plans. 
(Code 1965, § 22.502) 
Sec. 94-153. - Surveys and investigations. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his designee to cause surveys and investigations to be made of commercial, industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two years, or as often as the director of public works or his designee shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. 
(Code 1965, § 22.503) 
Sec. 94-154. - Right of entry of enforcement officers; duty to furnish information regarding piping system. 
    The village plumbing inspector or his designee shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the village for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross-connections, and the director of public works or his authorized agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the village for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross-connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the director of public works or his designee any information which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal to supply such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the director of public works, be deemed prima facie evidence of the presence of improper connections as described in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 22.504) 
Sec. 94-155. - Termination of service to property in violation. 
    The director of public works of the village or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this division is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem reasonably necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this division, and until a reconnection fee as established by the village board from time to time is paid to the village. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice may be effected when the director of public works is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification to the water customer of the cause of disconnection and an opportunity to be heard. Immediate disconnection without notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or anticipated contamination or pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the reasonable opinion of the director of public works or the state environmental protection agency, such action is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply. Neither the director of public works or the village plumbing inspector or their respective designees, nor the village or its officers, agents or employees, shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages or lost revenues which may result from termination of said customer's water supply in accordance with the terms of this division, whether or not said termination was with or without notice. 
(Code 1965, § 22.505) 
Sec. 94-156. - Responsibility for costs of cleanup caused by violation. 
    The consumer responsible for backsiphoned or back-pressured material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. 
(Code 1965, § 22.506) 
Sec. 94-157. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each and every day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1965, § 22.507) 
Secs. 94-158-94-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - WATER SUPPLIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-03, § 2, adopted Mar. 26, 2012, enacted provisions intended for codification as Div. 6, §§ 94-201-94-219. To avoid duplicate sections and to facilitate indexing, said sections have been redesignated as Div. 6, §§ 94-171-94-189. 

Sec. 94-171. - Scope. 
    This division shall provide the minimum standards for the location, construction and modification of water wells, monitoring wells and closed-loop wells located and/or constructed in the Village of Hillside, Cook County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-201), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-172. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Aquifer means a water bearing formation that transmits water in sufficient quantity to supply a well; 
    Boring means an excavation that is drilled, cored, driven, dug, or otherwise constructed which penetrates an aquifer or which may degrade the quality of an aquifer; 
    Closed-loop well means a sealed, watertight loop of pipe buried outside of a building foundation which is intended to recirculate a liquid solution through a heat exchanger; 
    Department of public works means the public works department for the Village of Hillside, Cook County, Illinois; 
    Monitoring well means a water well intended for the purpose of determining groundwater quality or quantity; 
    Village means the Village of Hillside, Cook County, Illinois; and 
    Water well means any excavation that is drilled, cored, bored, washed, driven, dug, jetted, or otherwise constructed when the intended use of such excavation is for the location, diversion, artificial re-charge, or acquisition of ground water, except monitoring wells. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-202), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-173. - Adoption by reference. 
    In addition to those provisions set forth herein, this division shall incorporate and adopt by reference, and further be interpreted and enforced in accordance with the provisions set forth under the following statutes, rules, and regulations of the state and the state department of public health, and any subsequent amendments or revisions thereto: 
(a)  Illinois Water Well Construction Code, Ill. Admin. Code Tit. 77, § 920 (the "construction code"); and 
(b)  Illinois Water Well Pump Installation Code, Ill. Admin. Code Tit. 77, § 925 (the "installation code"). 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-203), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-174. - Permit requirements. 
    No water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well shall be constructed, deepened, modified or sealed in the village except in accordance with this division, and no such work shall proceed without first obtaining a permit from the department of public works. 
    All applications for permits under the provisions of this division shall be made in writing and on such forms as prescribed by the department of public works. Sufficient data shall be included to allow the department of public works to review the application and determine whether the proposed well meets the requirements of this division. Each application must include, without limitation, the depth to which the well is to be lowered and the aquifer involved. 
    Upon submission of an application for permit, including the plans and specifications for the proposed well, the department of public works shall review said application prior to the issuance of a permit. The department of public works may require additional information. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to obtain all necessary data and to design a system which shall meet the requirements of this division. If the department of public works, upon review of said application, finds that such application meets the requirements of this division, and upon payment of the required fee by the applicant, a permit shall be issued to the applicant. 
    A permit to construct, deepen or seal a water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well is valid for a period of 12 months from the date of issuance. If construction, deepening, modification, or sealing has not started within this time period, the permit is void. Any person who constructs, deepens, modifies, or seals a well for which a permit has been issued under this section shall notify the department of public works by telephone or in writing at least two days prior to the commencement of the work. 
    The fee to be paid for a permit to construct, deepen, modify, or seal a water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well shall be $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-204), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-175. - Inspections. 
    The department of public works shall have the authority to enter any property at any reasonable time for inspection purposes to determine compliance with the provisions of this division. It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of the property to allow the department of public works free access to the property for inspection purposes to determine compliance with the provisions of this division. 
    A water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well shall not be placed into operation until the installation of the well and its components have been inspected to verify compliance with the applicable provisions of this division and written approval has been issued by the department of public works. To the degree practical and permitted by the department of public works, the complete installation shall remain uncovered and/or accessible for inspection purposes until approved by the department of public works. If the department of public works, upon inspection of the specified installation or component thereof, finds that such work meets the provisions of this division and the permit specifications for a stated property, the department of public works shall approve such work, complete the permit form, an authorize operation of the well. However, compliance with section 94-182 of this division shall be obtained prior to utilizing the water system for drinking and culinary purposes. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-205), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-176. - Licensure and registration requirements. 
    No person shall drill a water well or install a water well pump or water well equipment unless he or she either holds a valid license issued pursuant to the Water Well and Pump Installation Contractor's License Act, 225 ILCS 345/1 et seq. (the "license act"), or is exempt from licensure under the provisions of the license act. 
    No person shall install a closed-loop well unless he or she either holds a valid certificate of registration as a closed-loop well contractor issued pursuant to the license act, or is exempt from licensure under the provisions of the license act. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-206), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-177. - Design requirements. 
    Each water well, monitoring well, and closed-loop well shall comply with the applicable design factors set forth under Section 920.40 of the construction code. 
    Each monitoring well shall further comply with the requirements set forth under paragraphs (a) through (f) of section 920.170 of the construction code, and each closed-loop well shall further comply with the requirements set forth under paragraphs (a) through (d), (f) and (g) of section 920.180 of the construction code. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-207), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-178. - Drilled well construction requirements. 
    When a drilled water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well is constructed in an unconsolidated formation, such well must comply with the requirements set forth under paragraph (b) of section 920.60 of the construction code. 
    When a drilled water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well is constructed in a consolidated formation: 
(a)  If the formation is a creviced or cracked formation, which is the upper bedrock formation and is overlain by a mantel of earth having a thickness of less than 30 feet, such well must comply with the requirements set forth under paragraph (a) of section 920.70 of the construction code; 
(b)  If the formation is overlain by a mantle of earth having a thickness over 30 feet, such well must comply with the requirements set forth under paragraph (b) of section 920.70 of the construction code; and 
(c)  If the formation contains an artesian formation, such well must comply with the requirements set forth under paragraph (c) of section 920.70 of the construction code. 
    When an over-sized drill hole is constructed to permit the placement of a gravel pack around a well screen, the construction must be performed in accordance with the requirements set forth under paragraph (c) of section 920.60 of the construction code. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-208), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-179. - Location requirements. 
    All water wells and closed-loop wells shall be located in accordance with the minimum distances set forth under paragraph (b) of section 920.50 of the construction code. No water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well shall be constructed upon a location subject to flooding, as determined by the public works department, nor shall any such well be constructed in a pit or basement. Any water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well that is constructed adjacent to a building shall be so located so that the center line of the well extended vertically will clear any projection from the building by not less than two feet. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-209), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-180. - Special type wells. 
    For any water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well that is dug, bored, or driven, such well must comply with the requirements as set forth under paragraphs (b) through (d) of section 920.80 of the construction code. No radial collector wells shall be constructed in the village. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-210), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-181. - Construction materials and other requirements. 
    All materials used in the construction, repair, and/or maintenance of any water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well shall comply with paragraphs (a), (b), and (d) through (g) of section 920.90 of the construction code. All joints used in such construction, repair, and/or maintenance shall comply with the standards set forth under paragraph (c) of section 920.90; however, no other joints may be evaluated or approved by the village. All grout used in construction, repair, and/or maintenance shall conform with and be applied pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth under paragraph (h) of section 920.90 of the construction code. Further, all water used in the drilling process shall comply with the standards set forth under paragraph (j) of the construction code. 
    The bore of any hole shall be sufficiently plumb and straight to receive the casing without binding. Any and all casing shall be sufficiently plumb and straight so it will not interfere with installation and operation of the pump. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-211), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-182. - Finishing and testing. 
    The casing or riser pipe for all water wells and closed-loop wells shall be terminated at a height above finished ground surface consistent with proposed plans for a pump house and pump installation but not less than eight inches above finished ground surface or 24 inches above maximum high water level where flooding occurs. The well shall be capped watertight until the pump installation is made. 
    After the water well or closed-loop well is effectively cleaned of all remaining drilling mud and drill cuttings, and the pump installation is completed, the contractor shall properly disinfect the well in accordance with the standards set forth under paragraph (b) of section 920.100 of the construction code. 
    Within 30 days after a water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well has been constructed or deepened, the contractor shall submit a report of construction to the department of public works on such forms as are prescribed and furnished by the department. Upon receipt of such report, the department of public works shall submit a copy of the report to the state department of public health. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-212), 3-26-2012; Ord. No. 12-20, § 2(94-212), 11-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-183. - Well modifications. 
    Although water wells, monitoring wells, and closed-loop wells constructed prior to the enactment of the construction code by the State of Illinois may not meet the criteria established herein, when a well is to undergo modification, reconstruction, or repair, the work shall include the changes necessary to make the well conform to this division. Where existing wells have buried well seals, each seal shall be replaced with a pitless well adapter or the casing shall be extended above the ground surface in accordance with section 920.90(c) of the construction code. 
    No new pit wells shall be allowed in the village. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-213), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-184. - Subsequent lowering. 
    If, after the completion of a water well, monitoring well, or closed-loop well in accordance with a permit issued pursuant to section 94-204 of this division, the owner wishes to subsequently lower the well, the owner must submit a written notice of lowering to the department. The notice must be received by the department of public works not less than 14 days prior to the lowering of the well, and shall set forth the depth of the lowering and the aquifer involved. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-214), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-185. - Abandoned wells. 
    The owner of a water well, boring, or monitoring well shall assure that the well is sealed within 30 days after it is abandoned or becomes in such a state of disrepair that the well or boring has the potential for transmitting contaminants into an aquifer or otherwise threatens the public health or safety. 
    Water wells shall be sealed by a licensed water well driller pursuant to the license act. 
    Sealing of a water well, boring, or monitoring well shall comply with the requirements set forth under paragraphs (b) through (d) of section 920.120 of the construction code. The department of public works shall be notified by telephone or in writing at least 48 hours prior to the commencement of any work to seal a water well, boring or monitoring well. 
    Not more than 30 days after a water well, boring, or monitoring well is sealed, a completed sealing form as provided by the department of public works shall be submitted to the department. The department of public works shall then inspect the well or boring to determine compliance with this division. Once the department of public works has determined compliance with this division, the department of public works shall submit a copy of the sealing form to the state department of public health. If the department of public works determines that the well or boring has not been properly sealed, the department shall issue a written statement indicating the basis for its finding and advising the owner that the well or boring must be brought into compliance with this section within 20 days. 
    All vertical piping in closed-loop wells which is abandoned shall be physically disconnected from the horizontal piping and sealed with neat cement grout or any bentonite product manufactured for water well sealing by pressure grouting. All horizontal piping which is abandoned shall be removed or the coolant must be drained from the piping and disposed of off-site in accordance with state and local laws and ordinances. Closed-loop wells shall be sealed, removed, and/or drained by a person holding a valid certificate of registration as a closed-loop well contractor issued pursuant to the license act. The department of public works shall be notified by telephone or in writing at least 48 hours prior to the commencement of any work to seal, remove, and/or drain a closed-loop well. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-215), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-186. - Enforcement. 
    Whenever the department of public works determines that there is a violation of any provision of this division or permit specifications for a stated property, the department of public works shall give notice of such violation in accordance with this section. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons for the issuance of the notice; 
(3)  Contain an outline of the remedial action required and allow a reasonable time to effect compliance with this division; and 
(4)  Be served upon the owner, operator, or resident, provided that such notice shall be deemed to have been properly served when the notice has been personally delivered or sent and received by registered or certified mail. 
    If the necessary changes specified in the notice are not made within the period of time specified by the department of public works, the permit shall be suspended, and it shall be unlawful to place the well into operation. If, pursuant to the notice, the owner is required to seal, remove, and/or drain a water well, boring, monitoring well, or closed-loop well, and the owner fails to seal, remove, and/or drain the well or boring in accordance with the notice, the department of public works retains the right to enter the property and perform the necessary sealing, removal, and/or drainage. The owner shall be liable to the village for the actual costs incurred by the village in sealing, removing, and/or draining an abandoned boring or well. 
    If the department of public works determines that a person is drilling a water well, installing a water well pump or water well equipment, installing a closed-loop well or a monitoring well without a license or certificate as required under section 94-176 of this division, or without a permit issued by the village, the department shall cause such person to cease all further drilling or installation until such person provides proof of the requisite license or certificate to the department or such person obtains a permit. Further, such person shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00 per day of the violation. 
    If the department of public works determines that a person is sealing an abandoned water well or sealing, removing, and/or draining an abandoned closed-loop well without a license or certificate as required under section 94-215 of this division, the department may cause such person to cease all further sealing, removing, and/or draining until such person provides proof of the requisite license or certificate to the department. Further, such person shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00. 
    A health violation notice may also be publicly posted on the property and indicate: 
(1)  The date and time of inspection; 
(2)  The type of violation noted; 
(3)  The inspector's name and telephone number; and 
(4)  A warning of adverse conditions. 
    It shall be a violation of this division for any person except an agent of the department of public works to remove, deface, or allow the removal of a health violation notice posted on any property. The health violation notice shall be removed by the department of public works when compliance with this division has been achieved. 
    Any person affected by any order or notice issued by the department of public works in connection with the enforcement of this division may file with the department of public works a written request for a hearing before the administrative hearing officer. The department of public works shall hold a hearing at a time and place designated by the village within 30 days from the date on which the written request was received by the department. The petitioner shall be notified of the time and place of the hearing not less than five days prior to the date on which the hearing is to be held. As a result of the hearing, the administrative hearing officer shall render a decision within ten days after the date of the hearing, which shall be reduced to writing and sent to the petitioner and any person aggrieved by the decision. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-216), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-187. - Variances. 
    If conditions exist at a proposed installation site which preclude compliance with the requirements of this division, a variance may be requested through the department of public works in accordance with paragraph (c) of section 920.30 of the construction code. If a variance is necessary to allow for compliance with the requirements of this division, no well construction shall begin prior to written notice by the department of public works indicating the department's decision to grant the variance. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-217), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-188. - Record retention. 
    Within 30 days of the issuance of a permit pursuant to section 94-174 of this division, the village shall submit written notice of the permit to the state department of public health. This notice shall set forth the pertinent information concerning the issuance of the permit, which shall include, but not be limited to, the depth of the well and the aquifer involved. Further, the village shall maintain a list of all applications, permits, and notices of subsequent lowerings. This list shall set forth the information contained in the applications, permits, and notices, and shall be arranged by the location of the well. Copies of the list, as well as all applications, permits, and notices of subsequent lowerings, shall be maintained by the village and shall be available for public inspection at the village hall. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-218), 3-26-2012) 
Sec. 94-189. - Effective date. 
    This division shall take effect upon its passage, approval by the village board of trustees, approval by the state department of public health pursuant to section 5b of the state water well construction code (415 ILCS 30/5b), and publication in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 12-03, § 2(94-219), 3-26-2012) 
Secs. 94-190-94-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 94-201. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  Unsanitary deposits prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said village, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  Discharge of polluted water to natural outlet. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Privies, septic tanks and similar facilities. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  Connection to public sewer. The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the village and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary sewer of the village is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so. 
(Code 1965, § 27.101) 
Sec. 94-202. - Private sewage disposal systems. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 94-201(d), the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the building inspector and superintendent of public works. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the village, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the building inspector and superintendent of public works. A permit and inspection fee as established by the village board from time to time shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the building inspector. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the application for the permit shall notify the building inspector and superintendent of public works, when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 24 hours of the receipt of written notice by the building inspector. 
(d)  The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the state Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act (225 ILCS 225/1 et seq.) and private sewage disposal code and with the requirements of the state environmental protection agency. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 43,560 square feet (4,047 square meters). No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(e)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 94-201(d), a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material as described in the village plumbing code and in accordance with the state department of natural resources Rule XI-A. 
(f)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the village. 
(g)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the building inspector. 
(h)  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to said sewer within 90 days after receipt of an official notice to make the connection and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled as described in the village plumbing code. 
(Code 1965, § 27.102) 
Sec. 94-203. - Wastewater service charge system. 
(a)  Basis for charges; review of charges. 
(1)  The wastewater service charge established by this article for the use of, and for services supplied by, the wastewater facilities of the village shall consist of a basic charge for operations and maintenance plus replacement cost as defined by this article. 
(2)  The user charge shall be based upon the water usage of each contributor to the sewer system. Usage shall be determined by the metered water consumption of each user as a part of the user's water bill. The volume of flow used for computing the basic user charges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of 1,000 gallons. 
(3)  The charge shall consist of normal operation and maintenance costs, plus replacement costs, incurred by the village. The village will maintain records of all such costs to develop the user fee structure. The replacement cost component of the charge rate shall reflect the projected replacement needs of the village over a 20-year planning period. 
(4)  The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be reviewed annually by the village, and a statement provided in the annual audit report regarding the status of the costs. The service charge shall be revised after the review if necessary to reflect changes in operation and maintenance and replacement costs. The village will notify its users annually, in conjunction with a regular billing, of the sewer service charge to be applied in the next period, following each review. 
(b)  Rate. The user rate for the use of and for sewers supplied by the wastewater facility of the village shall be as established by the village board from time to time. Eighty percent of the user fee collected shall be allocated to the operation and maintenance component of the sewer budget and 20 percent shall be allocated to sewer system replacement needs. 
(c)  Payment of charges; delinquency. 
(1)  The user charge for wastewater service established by this article shall be payable on a bimonthly basis, consistent with that required for the water service billing. 
(2)  All bills for the wastewater service charge shall be payable with the regular water service bill at the village office. All such bills not paid within 15 days from its date, shall be deemed delinquent. Discontinuance of water service, after notice of hearing before the village board, or designated agents of each of said board, in which opportunity is given to present evidence and argument to show cause why such service should not be disconnected, shall become effective within ten days after notification to the customer of the decision of the village board to disconnect. No change of tenancy or occupancy after any water bill has become due shall affect the application of this section. 
(3)  Whenever the water supply service has been disconnected on account of the violation of any provision of this article or on account of the failure to pay the wastewater service bill or bills for other charges provided in this article, and water service is again requested, a service charge for restoring said water service shall be paid to the village in the sum established by the village board from time to time. 
(4)  Upon the termination of water service and the payment for all water previously furnished, any amount remaining of the deposit, if any, originally made shall be returned by the village to the applicant upon surrender of the initial deposit receipt.
